maiestie estimacion world otherforein prince exterior potentate ether audacitie able attempte thyng within territory region monarchial prince adourned kyng let kyngdome assiriens example suffise loke percians grekes lastly romaine whiche euer desired coue ed haue littel isle scicile territory numidian mean citie samnite beyng daiely within kennyng smell rather obtein populous gaule plenteous pannony manly macedony liyng farre sight circle compasse desire semeth rise great prudent vigilante policy prince puissaunce countreis ioyne strength power hande men lackyng comforte releued frendes whiche presente kinsfolke dwellyng forein region farre prince haue commonly coue ed euer desired se beholde dominion liyng nere rather reporte countreis farre distant hathe bene pollecy conquerours thappetite purchaser study gouerners doth grace desire fraunce scotlande coue countrey farre sight realme vnder nose remember hole isle britain one entier monarchi time noble auncetor kyng brute first kyng ruler famus empire glorious region whiche deuidyng realme thre sonnes gaue lothryne eldest sonne part britain highnes enioyeth albanact second sonne gaue countrey albany nowe called scotland camber third sonne gaue countrey cambria nowe called wale reseruyng alwaies heires homage lege feaultie loiall countreis dominion deuisio glory monarchie britayne clerely defaced separacion strength britishe kynges sore diminished dispersion intestine war began ciuil rebellion sprange first within region vnder one nacion durste either inuade attempte warre briton land deuided monarchie vndone outward enemitie foreyn hostilitie halfe muche infested greued troubled valiaunt brittons owne neighboures discended one parent come one progeny albanac e otherwise called false fraudulet scottes camber otherwise called vnstable welshemen alonly withdrawe fealtie denie homage refuse allegiance due kynges realme also made continuall warre destroied tounes slewe people neyghboures briton whiche cause diuerse noble progenitoures haue made warre subdewed scottes deniyng homage stirryng rebellion also haue deposed kynges prince erected set vp estate dignity scater kyng scottes rebellion dunwallo moluncius noble predecessor slayn extincted kyng arthure also glory brittons erected angosile scepter scotland receaued hym homage fealtie yf shuld reherse many kynges scotland haue done homage auncient predecessor reherse howe many scottishe kynges haue corrected punished disobedience deniyng homage declare kynges superior lordes high emperoures ouer vnderkinges scotland haue elected made ruler thetent people might manifestly perceiue glorious honourable famous kyng make kyng kyng hy natural discent assure eares woulde wery hearyng tounge would fatigate open truth tellyng noble progenitour kyng edward firste couetyng superior surmount honour least equiuolent fame noble ancestours famous progenitor daily studied hourely compassed howe bryng whole isle briteygne whiche brute deuided thre partes one monarchy one dominion longe studie greate consultacion subdewed wale tamed wylde people broughte vnruly parte olde home aunciente degree whiche thyng done likewyse inuaded scotlande conquered countreye towne perche called saincte ihons towne standyng riuer tay whiche walled diched fortefied rulyng part englishe lawes englyshe customes englishe iudges moste poynte thereof haue made perfighte conqueste complete monarchie oh lorde hasty deathe whiche maketh ende mortall creature sodeynly berefte hym life toke awaie spirite thynges whiche deuised whiche ymagened seriously pretended small momente houre turned vpside doune sodainly subuerted sith whose deathe greate graundfather ye noble father haue attempted bryng runnegate region auncient course former line thyng bothe necessary conueniente mete bee ioyned vnited realme reuiue old empire famous monarchye also vnite cobine vertue stregth whiche tyme brute dispersed seuered one body one hed one corporacion wherfore high wisedome semeth necessary takyng terme neccssary nedefull conquere realme scotlande thyng nedes muste doen yet flie first saiyng proue necessary logicall paraphrasian philosophical interpreter distinccion expounde terme necessary signifie thyng conuenient conquest scotlande inuadyng fraunce moste expedient experience teacheth reason agreeth euery persone entedyng purposed enterprise determinate voyage onely prouide make preparacion thynges requisite nedefull purpose exployte also ought vigilantly forsee withlynt beast like wolfe whose sighte dooeth perce al thynges lincis iyes preuet study serpentyne pollicie aduoyde refell thynges whiche might ether bee impediment progression settyng forward occasion returne losse enterprise least leuyng behynd hym euill neighbour continuall aduersary secrete enemie maie assone lese owne propre realme conquere gayne dominion another wherfore trite common adage saith leaue certain vncertain wherefore necessary enucleate open certain article conteined old league amitie betwene realmes fraunce scotlande wherof wordes warre iniurye moued doen englishemen one thesaied nacions commen wrong bothe englishemen make warre frenche nacion scottes costes charge frenche kyng shall minister theim succour likevvyse scottes molested english warres frenche nacion hauyng costes allowed shall bee theim ayders assisters none bothe nacions shall ether contracte make peacewith realme englande without consente agrement thentent league amitee kept vnuiolate robert le bruse vsurper scotland willed testamet twoo thynges especiall bee obserued one neuer breake treatie concluded fraunce second neuer kepe peace promes englishman lenger kepyng therof theim ether profitable necessary yet ihon mayer scottish writer coloure cause saiyng would haue peace concluded englande aboue thre yeres whatsoeuer writer write talker saie thei bee hym moste faithfull executor haue neuer yet broken testament daily kepe precept commaundement performaunce kepyng league none auncetours euer inuaded fraunce incontinent scottes troubled vexed england none progenitor euer passed sea iust quarell freche nacion scottishe people absence entered realme spoyled house slewe people toke great praies innumerable prouoke auncestors returne fro inuadyng frauce declare comen breakyng league craftie subtill dissimulacio false faire promise often sworne neuer kept doubt would ten tymes abhorre doyng would bee ashamed tellyng therfore saie still affirme necessary conuenient forse leaue enemy behind backe go conquere aduersaries face beside consider daily charge inconstant chance maie happen thinke yea litle doubt scotlande shalbee tamed fraunce shalbe framed wil inuade fraunce accompt number shippes must transport armie recon charge ancors multitude cable innumerable thynges apperteigne nauie men decay sickenes sworde vitaill faile money waxe skante wynde turne contrary hideous tempeste arise shall bee destitute aide prouisio treasure whiche strange region co fusion defacyng armie side inuade scotlande men bee hande vitaill nere aide euer backe voyage shall haue haboundance thynges nothyng shall haue wante see occasion fortune hath offered vnto kyng captiue prisoner realme greate deuision crueltie duke albany rather desiryng haue forain gouernor naturall tyraunt wherfore counsaill firste inuade scotlande god grace conquere ioyne region youre empire restore renoumed monarchy britayne olde estate preheminence beautified realmes furnished people entree fraunce recoueryng righteous title true inheritaunce obseruyng old auncient prouerbe vsed forfathers whiche saieth fraunce wynne muste scotlande firste begyn duke excester vncle kyngan acion duke excester whiche well learned sente italy father entendyng haue prieste scotlande win let hym fraunce first begin call remembraunce comon saiyng wise expert philicions whiche bothe write teache heale malady must firste remoue cause cure lore muste first take awaie humor fedeth place destroy plante plucke awaie sap whiche norisshyng life fraunce nori sher scotlande frenche pencios susteiners scottishe nobilitee educacion scottes fraunce cause practise pollicie scotlande plucke away fraunce courage noble scotland shal sone daunted appalled take awaie fraunce hertes comen people wil sone decaie waxe faint plucke away frauce neuer looke scotlande resist withstande power hed gone body sone falleth sap fayleth tree sone withereth let men reade chronicle peruse englishe chronographiers shall sone finde scottes haue seldo owne ocion inuaded vexed englande onely obseruyng league whiche thei bee bounde fraunce scottes shaft dart frenchemen shote cast pleasure englishe nacion wher thei haue inuaded cannot deny thei haue dooen glory profite succeded entrep ice report peculier history kyng malcolyn inuaded englande kyng willia econd makyng warre normandy dauid le bruse also entered englande greate graundfather kyng edward third liyng siege caleis malcolin slain beside tinmouth kyng dauid taken beside durrham let gouernors scotlande kyng sure ynough entre englande price se shall gayne therby notable acte wer scottes euer able owne countree propre climate wer thei able coueigh armie ouer sea owne costes expences rede owne history shall finde fewe none nature condicion tary home idlenes ready defende countree like brute beastes thinkyng rusticall fassion high honestie beggerly liuyng bee welfare beside auncient writer autentike historiographier ether writ honor nameth theim ex pte sainct iherom whiche saieth yong sawe fraunce certain scottes isle britain eate fleshe men thei came woodes findyng greate heardes beastes flockes shepe lefte beastes cut buttockes heardmen pappes brestes sheperdes wome extemyng meate greatest deinties sabellicus saieth scottes muche delighte reioyse liyng may apparauntly perceiue puissaunce scotland self litle able defende lesse able inuade like noune adiectiue cannot stand without substantiue frauce taken shall thei seke aide denmarke refuse kyng brother inlawe portyngall castel wil regarde bothe kynges beeyng cosyns germain auntes sonnes italy farre germany hungary league necessitee thei conclusion destitute ayde depriued succoure bereued frendship fraunce coquered must without warre dent sworde come vnder subieccion due obeysance yet would conquest frauce bee muche mynded scotlande forgotten entier power sent fraunce defence left inuasions scotlande might ensue mischief whole power wer vanquisshed frauce scottes beyng elated victory frendes might displeasor realme one yere recouer fiue sithe god hath sent people rich municios warre thynges necessary ether inuade bothe defende one penetrate passe sea self armie royall leue lorde westmerlande graue capitaines northe conuenient nombre defende march subtill scottes encouraged frenchman thyng attept duryng voyage absence remebred get scotlande haue countree barayne almoste pleasure goodnes gayne people sauage waueryng constant rich shall haue litle pouertie muche get fraunce shall haue countree fertile pleasant plentifull shall haue people ciuill witty good ordre shall haue riche citees beautiful tounes innumerable castle xxiiij puyssaunt duchy lxxx odde populous countrees hudred thre famous bisshoprickes fat monastaries parishe church frenche writer affirme xc thousande mo conquest honorable gayne proffitable iourney plesaunte therfore nether left forslewed uitaill shall haue sufficient flaunders aide men maie haue daily england el leaue competente crewe march caleis refreshe armie furnishe still numbre although cost transportyng greate yet gayne shalbe greater therfore accordyng trite adage muste liberally spende plentefully gayne lorde westmerlade hath alleged romaine desired dominion suche vnder flight owne egle whose possession mote eye numidian whiche hath wisely rehersed behold condicions counsailers desire mouers persones whiche coueted poore neighbor rather riche foreines men effeminate mete carpet campe men weake stomacke desiryng rather walke pleasant gardein passe see tempesteous storme saie menne woulde haue somewhat yet take litell payne menne coueted thynges nothyng honourable yet greatly profitable remember noble cato censor whiche alledged senate rome affrike farre sea brode iourney perillous caused certain newe figges bee brought senate whiche grewe territory carthage demaunded senator howe liked figges saied newe said swete said pleasant oh qoud cato newe gathered region farof grewe kant thre day sailyng longer distance nere v oure enemy figges swete soile delicious fertile fygges pleasante cou trey profitable gaine scicilians shall riche men corne get samnite shall haue plenty oyle vanquishe numidian shall haue copie beastes subdewe carthage conquere affricke shall haue onely corne oyle beastes gold purple precious stone oliphantes thynges bothe necessary pleasant therfore councell rather seke rich beyng farre distant pouertie liyng hand paine forgotten euer gaine foloweth noble saiyng sage cato encouraged inflamed haut hertes lusty courage manly romains neuer desisted persecute people affricke tyll carthage vtterly destroyed whole countrey subdewed brought vnder romain empire iulius ceasar also desired rather conquere brittons deuided continent ye inhabityng almost thend world rather gayne pannonians adioynyng italy saiyng breke stro ger weaker bowe subdue riche pore wil yeld lord lordes vassalles must nedes subiect vanquish frenchemen scottes tamed counsaill cato saiyng cesar maketh bothe speke thynke get fraunce ye get two get scotland get one duke said sat doune opinion muche noted well digested kyng especiall thre brethre diuerse lordes beyng yong lusty desirous wyn honor profite realme fraunce ensuyng couragious actes noble progenitor whiche gat region bothe honor renoune al men cried warre warre fraunce fraunce bil put parliament desoluyng religious house clerely forgotten buried nothyng thoughte onely recoueryng fraunce accordyng title archbishoppe declared set furth vpon poynct fewe actes publicke wealth realme condiscended agreed parliamet proroged westminster kyng like wise prince pollitique gouernor entendyng obserue auncient ordres famous kynges renoumed potentate vsed aswel emong paynimes christian whiche inuade another mannes territory without open war cause hym published declared dispatched frauce vncle duke excester erle dorcet lorde grey admirall englande archbishop deuelin bishop norwiche v hundred horsse whiche lodged temple hous paris kepyng suche triumphante chere lodgyng suche solempne estate ridyng citee parisian frenche men small meruell honorable fassions lordly behaueors frenche kyng receiued honorably sumpteously banquetted theim shewyng theim goodly iustes marciall pastymes space three day together whiche iustes kyng hymself shewe courage actiuitee englishemen manfully brake speres lustely turneyed vvhen great triumph marciall disport finished englishe ambassador accordyng commission required frenche kyng deliuer kyng englad realme croune fraunce entier duchy aquitain normandy aniowe countrees poytieu mayne diuerse requestes offryng frenche kyng would without warre effusion christen bloud rendre kyng master righte lawfull inheritaunce would content take mariage lady katheryn doughter frenche kyng endewe duchie countrees rehersed entended kyng englande expresse signifie hym ayd god help people would recouer right inheritaunce wrongfully holden mortall warre det sworde frenchemen muche abasshed demaundes thinkyng theim vnresonable farre excessiue yet willyng make determinate aunswer till thei farther brethed weighty cause praied thenglishe ambassador saie kyng master thei hauyng oportunitee coclude hie matter would shortly send ambassador england whiche certefy declare kyng whole mynde purpose aunswer englishe ambassador nothyng content doyng departed englande makyng relacion euery thyng said dooen ouerpasse howe writer saie dolphyn thinkyng kyng henry geuen still suche play light folie exercised vsed tyme exalted croune sent hym tunne tennis balles plaie saied could better skil tennis warre expert light game marcial pollicy whether wer moued vnwise presente espiyng frenchemen dalied vaynely delayed purpose demaund moued pricked forward cannot iudge su e returne ambassador beeyng haute courage bold stomacke liuyng pleasantest tyme age muche desiryng enlarge dilate empire dominion determined fully make warre fraunce coceiuyng good trust perfight hope poyncte whiche experimented whiche victory moste part foloweth wher right leadeth auaunced forward iustice sette furth equitie many frenchemen wer promoted ecclesiastical dignitees benefice abbey priores within realme sent daily innumerable somes money fraunce relefe aide naturall countremen lineall kynsmen therfore publique wealth realme subiectes ordeigned straunger bee promoted spirituall dignitee degree within realme without especiall licence royall concent thei admitted find sufficient suretie disclose ye secretes realme forain strauge person also minister aide succor money meane beside assembled greate puissance gathered greate hoste dominion furniture nauie sent holand zeland frizeland conduct hire shippes transportyng conueighyng ouer men municions warre finally prouided armure vitaile money artillary carraiges tetes thinges necessary hie enterprise whiche prouisions wer sone blowen frauce quickly knowen paris wherefore dolphin taken hym gouernance realme cause father fallen olde infirmitie sent duke berry alaunson counseil fraunce coclude done great matter weightie cause long cosultacion determined assemble people whole realme fraunce resist repulce kyng englande puissaunce whensoeuer would arriue set foote fraunce also fortifie tounes stuffe garrison men warre farther tax subsedies leuy muche money wit pollicie could deuised imagined moreouer staie kyng england home polletiquely deuised sende solempne ambassade make offer accordyng demaundes rehersed charge ambassade comitted earle uandosme maister wylliam bouratier archebishop bourgues maister peter fremel bishoppe lysieux lorde yury braquemont maister gaultier cole kynges secretory diuerse ambassadours accompanied ccc fifty horse passed sea caleys laded douer whose arriual kyng departed wyndsor winchester entendyng haue gone hampton haue viewed nauie hearyng ambassadours approchyng taried stil wynchester sayd frenche lordes shewed selues verye honorably kyng nobilitie bishoppes hal kyng sittyng throne imperial lordes spiritual temporal great multitude comons entent assebled tyme prefixed archebishop bourgesse made eloquent long oracion dissuadyng warre praisyng peace offeryng kyng englad great money diuerse base pore country lady katherin mariage would dissolue armie dismisse souldiors whiche gathered made ready oracion ended kyng caused ambassador highly feasted set owne table daie assigned foresayd hall archebishoppe cauntorbury made oracion notable answere theffecte wherof frenche kyng wold geue daughter mariage duchy acquitain normandy aniowe al seignories dominion somtime apperteinyng noble progenitor kyng englad would wise retire army breake iorney would al diligence entre realme frauce destroy people depopulate coutry subuert tounes sword blud fyre neuer cease til recouered auncient right lawful patrimony kyng auowed archbishop saiyng word prince promised performe vttermost bishop bourgesse beyng flamed anger purpose toke none effect desiryng licence pardo king might speake whiche attained verye rashly vnreueretly sayd thynkest thou put doune destroy wrongfully christen kyng redoubted souerain lord excellentest prince al christianitie blud preheminece oh kyng sauyng thine honour thinkest thou hathe offered caused offred landes goodes possession owne daughter feare thy englishe nacion thy friendes wel willers fautours truthe moued pitie louer peace entent innocent blud bee dispersed abrode christian people shoulde bee afflicted battail destroied mortall warre hathe made reasonable offer godly mocion puttyng hole affiance god puissant accordyng right reason trustyng quarel ayded supported beneuolente subiectes fauourable well willers sith subiectes seruauntes require cause v safely surely without dammage conducted thy realme dominion thou wilt write thyne answere wholy thou hast geuen vnder thy seale signe manuell kyng englande nothyng vexed yet moued presumptuous saiynges proude bragges vnnurtered vnmanerly byshop well remebryng kyng salomon xxiiii prouerbes whiche saithe discrecion warres muste taken hand many geue councell victory coldly sobrely aunswered bishop saiyng lorde littell esteme frenche bragges lesse set powre strength know perfightly right region excepte deny apparant truthe yf neither knowe yet god world knoweth powre mayster see daily puissance haue yet tasted master haue louing rendes faithfull subiectes thanke god disgarnished vnprouided say vnto one yere passe trust make highest croune countrey stoupe proudest miter kneele downe saie vsurper maister within thre monethes wyll enter france land mine owne true lawfull patrimonye entendyng conquere braggyng wordes flatteryng oracions coloured persuasion puissaunce men dent sworde aide god whome whole trust confidence concernyng mine answere written subscribed sealed assure woulde speake sentence wold write subscribe subscribe line whiche would refuse put seale therfore saueconducte shal deliuered mine answere may departe surely safely warrant countrey truste soner visite shall haue cause salute bid welcome answere ambassadours sore dismaied displeased although highly entertained liberally rewarded departed countrye relatyng dolphyn kynges councel done duryng tyme ambassade frenche ambassadours departed kyng sayd hauing great foresight disposyng thynges ordre forgettyng olde pranckes sodeyn trickes variable scottishe nacion appoincted earle westmerlande lorde scrope baron greystocke sir robert umfreuile diuers hardye parsonage valiant capitaynes kepe frontier march adioynyng scotland whiche sir robert umfreuile day mari magdalene entred scottes toune gederyng hauyng company cccc englishemen long conflict doubtful battaile slewe enemy lx odde toke captynes ccclx discomfited put flight thousand moo folowed chace alone xii mile laded praies prisoner reculed agayne vnhurt castle rokesbroughe whiche tyme chief capitayne gouernour kyng ordered thynges tuicion sauegarde realme people leauyng behynd gouernor realme quene mother inlawe departed toune southhampton entending take ship transfrete fraunce thentent would steale frenche kyng ware dispatched antelop pursuiuant armes letter whiche frenche cronographers declare right honorable prince charles cossyn fraunce aduersary henry grace god kyng england fraunce c deliuer euery man owne woorke inspiracion deede sage councel right noble prince cosyn aduersary sometymes noble realmes england fraunce vnited whiche nowe seperated deuided accustomed exalted vniuersal worlde glorious victory notable vertue decore beautifye house god whiche apperteined holynes set concorde christes religion agreable warres brought fortunately publike enemy subiection ala fraternal fayth peruerted fraternal occasion lot persecuted abraha humayne impulsion nowe glory fraternal loue deade discent auncient humaine codicion departed mother malice ire resuscitate death life cal wytnes souereigne iudge coscience whiche wil bow either praier gi e power pure loue haue proceaded meanes peace amite sith haue red writyng cou cel haue learned iust title inheritaunce v deteined preiudice oure auncient linage small courage wyll fight death obteyne right iustice authoritie written boke deuteronomy men taught whiche come besiege assaulte cytie fortresse fyrst offre peace albeit violence rauisher iustice haue take away log tyme noblenes croune oure iuste inheritaunce yet charitie haue done might recouer bryng old inheritaunce first degree auncient estate therefore faute iustice may returne armes wherfore glorye may wytnes conscience nowe also personal request beginnyng iorney whiche toward faute iustice exhort bowelles sauiour iesu christ whose euangelical doctrine willeth ought render al men ought v wyl god oure souereigne lorde creator thentent theffusion christen people shuld exchewed whiche image god haue demaunded right restitucion v wrongfully withholden deteined least suche thinges whiche haue often time ambassador messenger required instantly desyred wherwith haue offered pleased satisfied cotented onely reuerence almightie god vtilitie vniuersall peace whiche thought haue ensued therfore part mariage cocluded betwene v wer determined forsake refuse fiftye thonsand crounes v last promised profered preferryng peace rich chosyng rather rightful patrimony v oure noble progenitor lawfully deuoluted discended oure cossyn daughter fayre lady katherin rather treasure desire money multiplier iniquitie shamefully dishenerite selfe croune oure realme whiche god forbid youen vnder oure priuy seale castel hampton sea side v day august vvhen letter presented frenche kyng councel well ouerloked made answere thofficers armes wel perceiued content letter whereupon would take aduice prouide tyme place conuenient licensyng messenger depart pleasure pthe third yerethe iii yere noble prince hauyng nauy furnished al thinges necessary suche royal voyage perceiuyng freshe capitaines complain thei lost many monethes yere whiche might haue done diuerse haute terprices lades theyr enemy nothyng odius prolongyng lingeryng tyme determined diligence cause souldiors entre shippes depart se chaunce night day departure appoincted credibly informed richarde earle cambridge brother edward duke yorke henry lorde scrope syr thomas gray knight copassed death finall distruction wherfore caused apprehended lamentyng sore chaunce compelled loose suche personage whose valiantnes puissaunce dreadful feareful foe enemy prisoner examined onely confessed co spiracy also declared agreat mony receiued frenche kyng inteded either deliuer kyng liue handes enemy el murther shuld arriue duchy normady kyng henry hard al thinges opened whiche sore desired caused al nobilitie asse ble maiestie royal caused brought thre great offendors sayd haue conspired deth destruction whiche head realme gouernor people without doubt must necessitie thinke likewyse haue compassed confusion al also final destruction natiue countrey natural region although priuate scorpion heartes wild worme heades hath caused conspire death cofusion yet shuld haue spared deuelish enterprice long mine army whiche cannot cotinue without capitaine directed without guide yet destruction owne bloud nacion haue pleased forein enemy auncient aduersary wherfore seyng haue enterprised great mischiefe abhominable fact thentent fautors beyng armye may abhorre detestable offence punishement hast receiue payne demerites haue deserued punishment lawe offence prouided vvhen noble men executed kyng sayd lordes se madde imaginacion men whiche persecute dayely studye hourely labour great trauaile vnquietnes aduauncement publique wealth realme region cause spare payne refuse tyme thentent good men hurt man thus dutie thinke borne pray god ther none among infected much vntruth leuer se destroied brought confusion rather se coutrey florishe encreased honor empyre assure coceiue suche opinion put trust confidence may haue helpe beautify realme recouer againe olde honor myne auncestours subduyng frenche nacion selfe wyll forget al peril paine guide lodesman conductor drawe backe wyll moue forwarde beleueue god wyll dispose hereafter shalbe deceiued sore repent wyst kyng finished saiyng noble men kneled doune promised faythfully serue duely obey rather dye suffre fall handes enemy done kyng thought surely conceipte sedicion drouned vtterly extincte cast eye fyre newly kindled haue surely sene horrible flame ince sed walles owne house family whiche conclusion line stocke cleane destroyed consumed ash whiche fyre verye tyme paraduenture might haue bene quenched put diuerse write richard earle cambridge conspire lorde scrope sir thomas graye murther kyng henry please frenche kyng withal onely thentent exalte croune brotherinlawe edmond earle marche heyre duke lyonel whose death consideryng earle marche diuerse secrete impedimentes hable haue generacion sure croune come wife child therfore thought rather cofessed selfe nede money corrupted freche kyng would declare inwarde mynd open entent surely sawe purpose espied earle march haue dronken cup shuld haue come owne child muche doubted therfore beyng dedestitute comfort dispayre life saue child fayned tale desiryng rather aue succession selfe dede richard duke yorke sonne priuely openly claimed croune edward sonne claimed gained hereafter shal heare thyng time kyng henry foresene doubt whether either euer line haue either claimed garlande gained game vvhen wynde prosperous pleasaunt nauye set forward waied vp ankers hoysed vp sailes set forward cxl shippes vigile assumpcion lady toke land caux comonly called kyd caux riuer seine runneth sea without resistence bludsheddyng kyng lodged shore small priory duke clarece gloucester bretherne duke excetter yorke earles marshal oxforde suffolke warwicke lordes lodged farre fro next day marched toward toune harflewe standyng riuer seyne betwene two hilles besieged euery parte capitaine toune lorde escouteuile lorde blaynuile hacqueuile lordes harmanuile galarde boyes clere de becton adsanches brian gaucort lisleadam many othrr frenche kyng beyng aduertised kynges arriuall sente hast lorde delabreche constable fraunce lorde bonciqualt marshall frauce seneschal henaude lorde ligny diuerse capitaines whiche fortefied tounes men vitaile artillary sea coaste heryng kyng england besieged harflew first landyng came castle cawdebec beyng farre harflewe thentent succor frendes whiche wer besieged thei might pollicy inuencion thei imagined sleye hurte englishemen thei wente countree foragyng beastes vitaill trappe destroye thei costrued themselfes vitaile would sone faile ayre sea smell water thei deceiued notwithstandyng prouision pollicy frenchemen englishman forrayed countree spoyled village brought many riche praie campe fore harflewe thenglishmen daily ceassed assaile toune duke gloucester ordre assaulte comitted made thre mynes vnder ground approched walles ordinaunce engynes would suffre theim within reste tyme kyng liyng hill side battail onely kepe frenchman succoryng toune also toke awaie tounes men hope trust succor aide relief also al gonnepouder sent frenche kyng wer beseged taken thenglishmen capitaines frech men within toune perceiued thei wer able resist continuall inuasions hourely assaultes fierce englishemenne knowyng walles vndermyned shortely like fal feryng might happe chance thei fortune ouercome take force desired kyng england truce thre day promisyng thei reskewed within thesame tyme thei yeld themselfes toune liues saued performe thei deliuered kynges possession xxx beste capitaines marchauntes toune kyng englande accepted offre least entendyng greater exploites might lese tyme suche small matter composicion agreed lorde hacqueuile sent french kyng declare necessite toune shorte tyme truce dolphin aunswered kynges power yet assembled suche nombre conuenient raise greate siege aunswer reported capitaines thei seyng hope similitude aide comfort commyng third daie rendered kyng englad toune beyng xxxvij daie besieged whiche daie sainct mawrice greate abashement normandy soueraigne porte al countree souldiours wer raunsomed toune sacked greate gayne englishemen kyng englande ordeigned capitain toune harflew vncle thomas duke excester whiche established leuetenaunte ihon fastolffe xvc men xxxv kinghtes wherof baron carew sir hugh lutterell two counsaillers diuerse noble liyng harflew sicke flixe many wer ded emongest therle stafford bishop norwich lordes molins burnell wer foure beside kyng licensed duke clarece brother ihon erle marshall ihon erle arundel beyng infected desease returne englande kyng henry litle reioysyng good lucke fortunate successe beginnyng pretensed conquest determined withal diligence set forward performyng intended purpose warrely enterprise wynter approched faster furiously tyme accustomed sore troubled vexed whiche cause called together al cheuetaines men pollicy armie consult vpo procedyng forward sure waie redy passage long debatyng muche reasonyng thyng bothe necessary conueniente fully agreed determined set forwarde withall diligence dedde tyme winter approched toward toune caleis goyng forward called slaunderous tongue runnyng fliyng awaie decreed whole armie passe next waie lande middest enemy yet iouruey adiudged perilous reason numbre muche minished flyxe feuers whiche sore vexed brought deth aboue xvc persones whiche cause returne soner concluded apoincted departyng entered toune harflew went foote churche sainct martynes offered men warr whiche paied raunsome sware holy euangelistes yeld themselfes prisoner caleis fea martyn nouember nexte diuerse burgess highly raunsomed greate part woman child expelled toune geuyng euery poore creature fiue sowse priestes licence depart leuyng behinde substaunce goodes toune wer innumerable whiche wer al praie englishemen whiche sent best englande remembraunce good lucke twoo strong toures standyng hauen side whiche lokyng aid yelde ten day toune rendered vvhen kyng repaired walles fortefied bulwarkes refresshed rampiers furnished toune vitail artillary remoued harflew toward pountoyse entendyng pa riuer armie bridge ether withdrawen broken frenche kyng hearyng toune harfflewe gotten kyng englande marchyng forwarde bowelles realme sente proclamacions assembled people euery quarter comittyng whole charge armie sonne dolphin duke aquitayn whiche incontinent caused bridge broken passage defended beside thei caused corne vitaill destroied place thei coniectured thenglishmen would repaire passe thentent thei might ether kepe place certain without passage departure destroye pleasure el kepe theim straite without vitailes comfort famyne ether cause dye yelde kyng englande afflicted withall incomoditees one tyme nether dismaied discoraged keping furth iorney approched riuer perceiued bridge wer enemy broken vnframed wherfore came passage called blanchetaque kyng edwardes greate graundfather passed riuer battaill cressy passage kepte could passe without greate daunger consideryng enemy wer backe face wherfore passed forward arannes burnyng village takyng greate booty euery daie sente light horseman abrode spye seke perilles ther wer hand embushmentes ther wer laid one side thother find might sauely pa riuer espialles returned declared truth cou tree swarmed men warre wherof beyng aduertised set furth good ordre kepyng still waie forwarde ordred armie placed cariage hauyng enemy side passed terribly enemy wer afraid offre hym battaill yet lorde delabreth constable fraunce marshall bonceqault erle uandosme greate master fraunce lorde dampier admirall fraunce duke alanson erle richemonde withall puyssance dolphin laie abbeuile durste touche battailles euer kepte passage coasted alofe like hauke liketh praie kyng englande still kept iourney till came bridge saincte maxence founde aboue xxxm frenchemen pitched felde lokyng surely set fought withal wherfore encorage capitaines dubbed certain hardy valeant gentleman knightes iho lord ferreis groby reignold greistocke pier tempest christopher morisby thomas pikering willia huddleston ihon hosbalton henry mortimer philip halle willia brother iaques de ormod diuerse saw ye frenchman made semblance fight departed good ordre battail toune amiece toune nere castle called bowes laie twoo day euery houre lookyng battaill thence came nere corby staied night reason come people peysantz countree assembled greate nombre men armes garrison corby skirmished armie mornyng whiche tariyng hym bothe ioyous proffitable discomfited crew horsmen draue rustical people euen gate also found thesame daie shalow forde betwene corby peron whiche neuer espied whiche armie cariages night ensuyng passed greate riuer without let daungier morowe sainct luke daie determined withall diligence passe caleis seke battail except wer therto constrained compelled armie sickenesse sore minished appaired onely two horseman xiijm archer bill men sortes englishemen afflicted iourney hundred discomodities vitaile maner spet newe thei could gette none enemy destroyed corne comyng rest thei could take none enemy wer euer hande daily reined nightly fresed fuell skacenes flux plenty money thei ynough comforte thei none yet great necessitee poore folkes wer spoyled thyng without paiment extorted great offence doen except one whiche foolishe souldier stale pixe churche vnreuerently eate holy hostes within thesame conteigned whiche cause apprehended kyng would remoue till vessel restored offender strangled people countrees aboute hearyng straight iustice godly mynd ministered hym bothe vitailes necessary although open proclamacio thei wer therof prohibited frenche kyng beyng roan hearyng kyng englande passed water litle discontente assembled counsaill numbre xxxv consult doen chief wherof dolphin sonne whose name lewes callyng hymself kyng cicile duke berry britayn therle pontieu kynges yongest sonne diuerse wherof xxx agreed englishman departe vnfoughten fiue wer contrary opinion greater numbre ruled matter mountioye kyng armes sent kyng englande defie hym enemie fraunce tell hym shortly haue battaill kyng henry soberly aunswered sir myne entent desire none pleaseth almighty god becometh surely seke master time seke wil willyngly fight hym nacion attempt stoppe iourney toward caleis ieoperdy yet desire none vnaduised harebrained occasion defence shall coloure make redde tawny grounde deathes selfes theffusion christen bloud aunswered harauld gaue great reward liceced depart vvhen lordes fraunce heard kyng englandes answere incontinent proclaymed men warre resorte constable fraunce fight kyng englande puissaunce wherupon men accustomed beare arinure desirous wyn honor realme fraunce drewe toward feld dolphyn sore desired bee battaile prohibited kyng father likewise philip erle charolous sonne duke burgoyn would gladly haue noble assemble duke father would haue suffred hym many men stale awaie went frenchemen kyng englande informed espialles daie battaill nerer loked dislodged bomyers roade good arraie faire plaine beside toune blangy intent armie bee included streight driuen corner chose place mete conueniente twoo army darrayne battail betwene tounes blangy agincourte pight felde constable fraunce marshall admirall lorde rambures master crossebowes diuerse lordes knightes pitched banner nere banner royall constable countee sainct paule within territory agincourte whiche waie englishemen muste nedes passe towarde caleis frenchemen made greate fire aboute banner thei wer numbre lxm horseman owne historian writer affirme beside footemen page wagoner night made greate chere wer mery englishman night sounded trompettes diuerse instrumentes musicall greate melody yet thei bothe hungery wery sore traueiled muche vexed colde deseases howbeit thei made peace god confessyng synnes requiryng hym help receiuyng holy sacramente euery man encouragyng determinyng clerely rather die ether yelde flie novv approched fortunate faire daie englishemen infest vnlucky daie frenche nobiliteethe battaile agincourt whiche fiue twenty daie october yere lorde iesu christe thousaude foure hundred fiftene beeyng fridaie daie crispin crispinian whiche daie mornyng frenche menne made thre battailes uaward wer eight thousande healmes knightes esquiers foure thousande archer fiftene hundred crosebowes whiche guyded lorde delabret constable fraunce hauyng hym duke orleaunce burbone therles ewe richmond marshall bonciqualt master crosebowes lorde dampier admirall fraunce capitaines erle uandosme kynges officer xvjc men armes wer ordred wyng battail wyug guided sir guyshard dolphyn sir clugnet brabant sir lewes burbon viijc menne armes chosen elect persones breake shot englishemen wer appoincted sir guyllia sauesens hector philip brother ferry maylley alen gaspanes viijc men armes midle ward wer assigned many persones mo wer formoste battaill therof charge comitted duke barr alenson therles neuers uawdemont blamout salynges grautpree roussy rerewarde men armes guyded erles marle dampmartyne fawquenberge lorde lourrey capitayne arde hym men frontier bolonoys vvhen battailes thus ordred glorious sight behold surely thei wer estemed numbre sixe time many whole compaigny englishman wagoner page thus frenchman wer euery man vnder banner waityng blouddy blast terrible trompet ordre thei continued restyng themselfes reconcilyng euery one old rancor hatredes whiche betwene theim till houre betwene ix x daie duryng whiche season constable fraunce saied openly capitaynes effecte foloweth frendes companion armesthe oracion costable frauce canot bothe reioyce lament chance fortune two army whiche openly se behold myne iyes presente reioyce victorie whiche se hand part lamet sorow misery calamitee whiche perceiue approche otherside wee cannot victours triuphant conqueror saw euer florisshyng armie within christian region suche multitude valiaunt persones one compaignie flower frenche nacion barded horsses sharpe speares dedly weapon bold briton fiery handgones sharpe swerdes se present practised pickardes strong weightie crossebowes beside haue fierce brabanders strong almaines long pykes cuttyng slaughmesses otherside smal handfull pore englishman whiche entred region hope gain desire proffite whiche reson vitaill cosumed spent daily famyn sore wekened consumed almost without spirites force clerly abated strength vtterly decaied battailes shall ioyne thei shalbe feblenes vaquished ouercom stede men ye shal fight shadowes must vnderstand kepe englishma one moneth warme bed fat befe stale drynke let season tast colde suffre hunger shal se courage bated bodye waxe leane bare euer desirous returne owne countrey experience declareth true famine pinched colde wether nipped surely would houe made progresse farher fraunce many perilous passage retired towarde calays suche courage englishman fayre wether vitaile folow suche weaknes haue famine cold vexe trouble therfore nowe mastery vanquishe ouerthrowe beyng wery weake reason feblenes faintnes weapones shal fal handes profer strike ye may easelier kyll poore shepe destroye beyng alredy sicke hungerstaruen imagyn thei wer lusty strong couragious ponder wisely cause comyng hither meanyng enterprice fyrst king yong striplyng mete tenice playe warlike campe claimeth croune scepter souereigntie verye substance frenche nacion battaile entende occupy country inhabite land destroy wiues child extinguishe blud put name blacke boke obliuion wherfore remembre wel quarel better fight tuicio natural countrey honor prince surety child sauegard land liues cause encourage fight beholde eye tetes enemy treasure plate iewels wel stuffed richely furnished whiche pray surely euery strike one stroke besyde great raunsomes whiche shalbe paied riche capitaines welthy prisoner whiche surely shalbe possession yet thyng charge withal nowise kyng selfe killed force otherwise appreheded taken entent glorye triumphe may conuey openly noble cytie paris ou e kyng dolphyn testimony victory witnes noble act thyng sure fly cannot yelde fight necessitie shalbe compelled therfore good felowes take courage victory gaine honor without great laboure muche losse kyng henry also like leader like one led like souereigne like souldior ordred men aduantage like expert capitaine couragious warirer fyrst sent priuely cc archer low medowe whiche nere forward enemy seperate great diche commaunded kepe selues close tyl thei token geuen shote aduersaries beside appoincted vawarde made capitayne edward duke yorke whiche haute courage kyng required obteined office lordes beaumond wylloughby fanhope battaile al archer middle ward gouerned kyng self brother duke gloucester erles marshal oxford suffolke whiche wer al strong bilmen duke exceter vncle kyng led rereward whiche mixed archer bilmen horseman like winges went euery side battaile king thus ordred battaile like puissaunt coqueror without feare enemy yet cosidering multitude farre excede smal nombre people doubtyng frenchemen would compasse beset aboute fight euery side thentent vaquish power french horsmen whiche might breake ordre arraye archer whole force battaile consist maner remaine caused stakesbound yron sharpe endes length v vi fote pitched archer euery side fote men like hedge entent barde horse ranne rashely vpo might shortely gored destroied appointed certaine person remoue stake archer moued tyme required fotemen hedged stake horseman stode like bulwerke betwene enemy without stake deuice fortifiyng armye tyme fyrst inuented sence tyme haue imagined caltrappes harowes new trickes defende force horsmen enemy auenture runne engine either sodeinly horse wounded stake feete hurt engine necessitie paine sely pore beastes compelled fal tumble ground ordred thus battailes left smal company kepe campe baggage callyng capitaines soldiours made heartie oracion effect foloweth saiyng vvelbeloved frendes countrymenthe oracion kyng henry fift exhort heartely thinke conceiue selues daye shalbe v day ioy day good lucke day victory truely well note wisely considre thinges almighty god vnder whose protection come hither hath appoincted place mete apt purpose selues could nether haue deuised wished whiche apt conuenient smal nombre litle army vnprofitable vnmete great multitude fight geue batttaile especial suche men neither constant faith securitie promise whiche person god neither fauored regarded accustomed ayde succoure suche people whiche force strength contrary right reason detain kepe iust patrimony lauful inheritance whiche blotte spotte frenche nacion apparantly defyled distained god iustice wyll scourge aflicte manifest iniuries open wronges v oure realme dayly committed done therfore puttyng onely trust let multitude feare youre heartes great nombre abate courage surely old warlike father haue said written people army lesse knowledge multitude hath material feates politique practises whiche rude rustical ignorant person shalbe feld vnto hardy capitaines lusty men warre great let sore impediment though al like pollicy like audacitie one vniforme experience marcial affayres yet ought neither feare shrinke consideryng come right whiche euer god fauored set furth auansed whiche good iust quarel al good person shal rather set bothe theyr feete forwarde turne theyr one heale backward aduenture liues iust battaile good cause whiche way soeuer fortune turne whele shalbe sure fame glory renoune victor ouercome enemy strength vertue shalbe spred dispersed whole world ouerpressed great multitude shal happe slaine taken yet neither reproche ascribed either yet infamy reported consideryng hercules alone equiuolent vnto ii men smal handfull equal great nombre victory gift god consisteth puissaunce men wherfore manfully set enemy theyr fyrst encountre strike hardy courage false hearted frenchemen youre noble auncestours haue often ouercome vanquished surely strong geue onset vpo thei much weaker abide stregth long fight tyred battaile assure al england person shal neuer paye raunsome neuer frencheman shal triumph ouer capitain day famous death glorious victory wyl wynne honor obtaine fame therfore ioyously prepare selues battaile couragiously fight enemy tyme realme englande praieth good lucke prosperous successe vvhile kyng thus speakyng eche armye maligned grudged beyng open fight euident apparence euery man cried furth furth forward forward duke clarece gloucester yorke opinion thinkyng conuenient marche toward theyr enemy al spede celeritie least prolongyng tyme arguyng opinion frenche armye might increace hourly multiply howbeit kyng taried least ieopardy forsene hazard preuented frenchemen meane season litle nothyng regardyng small nombre thenglishe nacion suche haute courage aud proud stomackes toke thought battaile saye victours ouercomers stroke striken laughed englishman prid thought selues lifted heauen iestyng boastyng thenglish men inclosed straight ouercome take without resistence capitaines determined howe deuide spoyle souldiors plaied englishman dice noble men deuised chariot might triumphantly conueigh kyng henrye beyng captiue cytie paris criyng theyr souldiors hast selues obtaine spoile glory honor thentent may study howe geue thankes great giftes rewardes whiche hope receiue great liberalitie folishe folye vaine solace brake farre messenger sent cyties tounes adioynyng willyng make open playes triumphes though victory certaine resistance could appeare also geue god thankes prosperous act notable dede remembryng whirlewynd shortely puffe blew away al folishe ioy phantastical braggyng doyng may gather asmuche madnes make determinate iudgement thinges come wisdome doubt wyl folowe thinges begone may forget frechemen beyng pleasaunt pastyme sent herault kyng henry inquyre raunsome wold offre answered within ii iii houres hoped happen frenchemen comen rather thenglishmen redemed englishman take thought pay rausome money theyr deliuerance asserteinyng selfe dead carion rather pray liuyng body pay raunsome messenger departed frenchman put theyr healmettes set ordre vnder theyr banner richely armed gorgeously trapped caused theyr trumpettes blowe battaile englishemen perceiuyng sette lytle forwarde went old knight called syr thomas herpingham man great experience warre warder hand cast vp warder al army shouted frenchman muche marueiled signe archer medowe knowing token shot wholy altogether vaward frenchman perceiued archer medow saw sawe could come ditche al hast set kyng henry forwarde ioyned archer forfront archer side whiche stode medow wounded fotemen galled horse combred men armes fotemen durst go forward horsmen rane plumpes without ordre ouerthrew felow horse ouerthrew maisters fyrst ioynyng frenchemen wer clearely discouraged thenglishmen muche chered frenche vaward thus discomfited english archer cast away theyr bowes toke theyr handes ax malles swordes billes weapon therwith slewe frenchman tyll came middleward king approched encoraged souldiors shortly second battaile ouerthrowen dispersed without great slaughter men howbeit diuers beyng wounded wer releued theyr varlettes conueighed felde englishman sore labored fightyng slaiyng wer busy takyng prisoner folowed chace would breake battaile frenchman strongly westode fearcenes thenglishmen thei came hady stroke fight doubtful perilous one part frenchhorse men thought haue entred kynges battaile stake ouerturned either slaine taken thvs battaile continued iii long houres strake defeded foyned trauersed kylled toke prisoner noman idle euery man fought either hope victory glad saue selfe kyng day shewed selfe like valiaunt knight whiche notwithstandyng almost felled duke alaunson yet plain strength slew ii duke company felled duke duke would haue yelded kynges garde cotrary kynges minde outragiously slew inconclusion mindyng make ende day iorney caused horsmen fetch compasse ioyne rereward fraunce whiche battaile greatest nombre people frenchman perceiued entent wer sodenly amased ranne away like shepe without aray ordre kyng perceiued banner cast doune aray clerely broken encoraged souldiors folowed quickely frenchman trunyng flight ranne hither thither knowyng whiche way take castyng away theyr armure theyr knes desired haue theyr liues saued meane season battaile thus continued thenglishmen taken great nobre prisoner certain frenchman horsbacke wherof captaines robinet borneuile rifflart clamas isambert agincourt men armes nombre vic horseman whiche fled fyrst felde theyr fyrst commyng hearyng englishe tentes pauilions farre army without great bre kepers person mete couenient defence partly moued styrred coueteous desire spoyle pray partly entendyng notable act reuenge damage displeasure done battail day entred kynges campe beyng voide men fortefied varlettes lackey ther spoyled hale robbed tentes brake vp chestes caried awaye caskettes slewe suche seruantes could fynd tentes pauilions whiche act thei wer long imprisoned sore punished like haue lost liues dolphyn longer liued vvhen kyng fearefu messenger euil acte sodainly aduertiled outcry lackey boyes whiche rane away feare robber heard felde saiyng frenchman robbed al tentes lodgynges englishman fearyng least enemy beyng dispersed scattered abroade gather together againe begynne new felde doubtyng farther prisoner would ether aide enemy enemy suffre liue contrary accustomed gentlenes pitie comaunded sounde trompet euery man vpon paine death incotinently sley prisoner dolorous decre pitiful proclamacio pronounced pitie se lothsome behold frenchman wer sodainly sticked dagger wer brained polaxes slaine malles theyr throtes cut belly paunched effecte hauyng respecte great nombre prisoner none saued vvhen lamentable manslaughter finished thenglishemen forgettyng woundes huries remembring paine thei sustained al day fightyng enemy men wer freshe lusty ranged selues aray prest redy abide newe felde also inuade newly set theyr enemy couragiously thei set earles maile fauconbrige lordes louray thyne whiche vic men armes al day kept together slew hand kyng passed felde saw neither resistence apparaunce frenchman auyng dead corsses caused retrayte blowen brought al army together iiii clocke noone fyrst geue thankes almightie god geuer tri utor glorious victory caused prelate chapelaines fyrst sing psalme exitu israel de egipto c commaundyng euery man knele doune ground verse non nobis domine non nobis sed nomini tuo da gloriam whiche say englishe v lord v thy name let glory geuen whiche done caused te deum certaine anthemes song geuyng laudes praisynges god boastyng braggyng selfe humaine power night toke refreshyng suche found freche campe mornyng moutioy kyng armes iiii heraultes came know nombre prisoner desire buriall whiche slaine could make answere heraultes remembryng honorable bee praised enemy extolled frendes praiseth self lacketh louyng neighbor wherfore demaunded thei made hym request considryng knew certainly whether praise victory wer mete attributed nacion oh lorde mountioy kyng armes thinke v officer armes rude beastial persones affe cion beare naturall countrey would ether fauor mede hide deny glorious victory foules aire wormes ground fedyng multitude ded carions onely puyssaunce destroyed confounded beare witnesse v ye muche captiues whiche liuing possessio wiues litle infauntes saie wee bee open liers vntrue taleteller wherfore accordyng duety office whiche bee alwaies indifferently write truely iudge saie determyne affirme victory honor glory aduisyng haue manfully gotten polletikely vse well saied kyng seeyng determinacion willyngly accepte thesame desiryng know name castle nere adioynyng thei answered called agyncourt said conflict called battaill agyncourt whiche victory hath obteigned v power suffraunce god iniury vntruth haue receiued handes prince nacion daie feasted french officer armes graunted theim request whiche busely sought felde suche slain englishemen suffred go alone thei serched found many hurt ieoperdy life thei toke prisoner brought tetes vvhen kyng englande wel refreshed hymself souldiours taken spoyle suche slain prisoner good ordre returned toune caleis tidynges notable victory blowen englande solempne procession praisynges almightie god bonefiers dance wer ordeined euery toune citee borough maire citezens citee london went morowe daie sainct simon iude churche sainct paule church peter westminster deuou e maner redryng god moste humble hertie thankes haboundant grace fortunate lucke geuen sent kyng souereigne lorde vvhen kyng englande departed sondaie toward caleis diuerse frechmen repaired plain battaill remoued ded body finde lordes master theim conueigh countrees bee buried spoyle take reliques whiche englishemen left behynde thei toke nothyng gold siluer iuelles riche apparell costly armure plowman peysantes spoyled ded carkasses leuyng theim nether sherte cloute thei laie starke naked till wednesdaie whiche daie diuerse noble men wer conueighed countrees remnant philip erle charoloys sore lamentyng chaunce moued pitee cost charge buried square plot xvc yardes whiche caused made thre pittes wherin wer buried accompt vm viiic person beside wer caried awaie fre de seruauntes whiche beyng wounded death died hospitalles place whiche groue made churche yarde feare wolues enclosed high walle dolorus iorney piteous slaughter diuerse clerckes paris made many lamentable uerses complainyng kyng reigned cousaillers wer perciall affirmyng noble men fled nature comons destroyed prodigalite declaring also clergy wer dobe durst saie truth humble comons duely obeyed yet euer suffred ponishement whiche cause persecucion deuine lesse numbre vanquished great ouercome wherfore thei concluded al thynges ordre yet man studied bryng vnruly frame meruel though battaill dolorus lamentable frenche nacion taken slayn flower nobilite fraunce wer taken prisoner charles duke orleaunce nephew frenche kyng ihon duke burbone ihon craon lord dommart lorde fossenx arthure bremyer sir ienet poys sone heire lord ligny sir gylbert de lawney lorde dancobe ternoys diuerse numbre fiftene hudred knightes esquiers besyde commen people wer slain noble gentleman charles lorde delabreth hie constable fraunce iaques chastilon lorde da pier admirall fraunce lorde rambures master crosse bowes sir guyshard dolphyn greate master fraunce ihon duke alaunson anthony duke
