lightes wer set vp church anthemes wer song chapelles ioye shewed euery place long woorke yet necessary cause thei like case would haue dooen beeyng like estate would haue doen thei englishman wer thus retired siege orleaunce seuered themselfes diuerse tounes fortress holdyng part duke alaunson bastard orleaunce ione puzell lorde gancort diuerse frenche men came toune iargeaux erle suffolke twoo brother soiorned xij daie iune gaue toune great terrible assaut whiche englishman beyng handfull manfully defended three partes thesame poyton sentrailes perceiuyng one part toune vndefended scaled walles part without difficulte toke toune slewe sir alexander pole brother therle many nombre two hundred thei muche gayned thei lost iiic good men thenglishmen wer taken xl beside brother iho gain good lucke frenchemen returnyng towarde orleaunce fell contencion debate captiues prisoner slewe sauyng erle brother pthe seuenth yerethe vii yere gaynyng toune iargeaux thesame army cam meum toke toure bridge put garrison fro thence remoued bangency whiche garrison beyng vitailed rendered toune thei might departe bagge baggage frankely frely whiche desire graunted toune bangency met duke alaunson arthur britayne false forsworne gentleman kyng englande newly made constable fraunce haue heard lorde delabret xijc men daily repaired freshe aide euery parte erle uandosme nombre xx xxiijm men men warre determined go meum take toune thei wer informed englishemen lefte toune desolate wer returned lord talbot ieneuile thei concluded passe towarde toune thei marched forwarde vpon saterdaie thei perfite knowledge lorde talbot v thousand men commyng meum wherfore thei intendyng stop hym tyde conueyed company small village called patay whiche way thei knewe englishman must nedes passe first thei appoynted horseman whiche well richely furnished go sodainly set englishemen thei wer either ware set ordre englishman commyng forwarde perceiued horseman unaginyng deceiue enemy commaunded fotemen enuirone enclose theselfes stake french horsmen came fiersly archer leyser set themselfes raie remedy fight aduenture battaill cotinued space thre long houres although thenglishmen wer ouerpressed nombre aduersaries yet thei neuer fledde backe one foote til capitain lorde talbot sore wounded backe taken harte began faint thei fled whiche flight wer slain aboue xiic taken xl wherof lorde talbot lord scale lord hungerford sir thomas rampston chief howbeit diuerse archer whiche shot arrowes hauyng swerdes defended theself help horsmen ca safe meu vvhen fame blowen abrode lorde talbot taken al frenchman alitle reioysed thinkyng surely rule englishman shortly assuage waxe faint feare wherof tounes ieneuile meu fort diuerse returned englishe part became frenche greate displeasure regent fro battaill departed without stroke striken sir ihon fastolffe thesame yere valiauntnes elected ordre garter whiche cause duke bedford great anger toke hym image sainct george garter afterward meane frendes apparant cause good excuse hym alledged restored order mynd lorde talbot charles callyng hymself frenche kyng beyng aduertised victory thought al thynges succeded accordyng opinion good hope whiche euer hie corage haut mynd moste aduersitie neuer dispaired good lucke length erle salisbury beyng dedde lorde talbot liuing captiuitie wer glory enemy thought enterprise great waighty thynges wher medeled smal litle doynges fulfillyng mynd appetite determined first conquere citee reynes intent beyng might accordyng fashion progenitor accustomed ceremony sacred anoynted kyng holy ampulle men might se perceiue lawes decree iust lawfull kyng wherfore assemblyng gether great army hauyng company ione puzel vsed oracle southsaier passed champaigne toune anxer thei within sent messegers praiyng certain day abstinece war whiche thei wer rescued thei promised rendre toune willing recompence ingratitude louyng harte citezens graunted gently peticion leuyng certain person se thei iugle hym departed thence troy beyng chief citie cha paigne whiche besieged xii day sir phillip hal capitain vnprouided bothe vitaill men mistrustyng aide would come tyme vpon coposicion rendered toune moucables might sauetie depart citee whiche demaund agreed troy yelded commonaltie chalons rebelled sir ihon awbemod capitain constrained hym deliuer toune vpon like coposicion whiche wil fain likewise citezens reyns desiryng hym geue saueconduite englishemen safely departe vvhen thus conquered reyns presence nobleman faccion duke lorayne barre sacred kyng frauce name charles vi rite ceremony therto apperteinyng thei anxer wer rescued within tyme appoynted brought kayes hym submitted theimselfes obeysaunce likewise citees tounes adioynyng geuyng thankes almightie god whiche hauyng compassion misery restored libertie fredome duke bedford hearyng tounes soyssons also returned part aduersaries charles late dolphyn taken vpon hym name estate kyng fraunce also seyng daily citees tounes returned thenglishe part became frenche though englishman lost al hardy chieftaines valiaut men warre espied euidently perceiued laste vettermoste poynt recouery driuen ouercome battaill subdue force whiche victory putte confidence god trusted onely scourge plague citees whiche sodainly chaungeable also assuage caulme haute corage newe sacred frenche kyng companion wherfore hauyng together xm good englishemen beside norman departed paris warlike fashio passed brye monstrean faultyow sente bedforde herault letter frenche kyng alledgyng hym contrary lawes god man yea contrary finall conclusion taken concorded agreed betwene noble brother kyng henry fifth kyng charles v father thesaid nowe v urper leuyng humayne reason honest communicacion whiche sometyme appeaseth debate pacifieth strife onely allured intised deuilishe wytche sathanicall enchaunterese onely falsely craftely taken vpon hym name title dignitie kyng frauce also murder stelyng craft deceiptful meanes violently gotten wrongfully kept diuerse citees tounes belongyng kyng englande moste best beloued lorde moste derest nephew pro e wherof come doune paris armye countrey brye dent swerde stroke battaill proue writyng cause trewe willyng enemie chose place thesame would geue hym battayle newe frenche kyng departyng solempne ceremony rein remouyng thence dampmartine studiyng compasse parisian ether money promes somewhat troubled message howbeit made freshe countenauce frenche brag answeryng herault would soner seke master duke pursewe hym duke bedford hearyng aunswer marched toward hym pitched feld strong place sent diuerse raungers prouoke frenchman come forward frenche kyng maner determined abyde bettaill hard saie espialles power nombre englishemen wer army equal power determined profite abstain fro battaill without dauger entre conflicte ieopardy fearyng least rashe corage might ouerthrowe al affaire whiche effecteously proceded well aduised turned army alitle waie duke bedford perceiuyng faint corage folowed hym mountaines dale till came toune barre farre senlys found frech kyng army wherfore ordred battail like man expert marciall science settyng archer hymself nobleman mayne battaill put norman bothe side wynges frenche kyng also ordered battailes accordyng deuise capitaines thus twoo army without greate doyng except fewe skirmish whiche duke light horsmen valiauntly laye eche sight space twoo day twoo nightes frenche kyng sawe perceiued glad diligent coragious englishman wer fight geue battail imagened tariyng one twoo thynges must nedes chauce saie either fight lye still like cowarde greate rebuke infamy wherefore dedde night priuely could brake vp campe fled bray flight perceiued mornyng regent could scace refrain people folowyng frenche army callyng cowardes dastardes loutes therfore perceiuing meanes could allure new frenche kyng abide battaill mistrustyng parisias geuyng great credite faire swete flatteryng woordes returned paris assemble together greater power prosecute enemy season bohemian whiche belike espied vsurped authoritie bishop rome began rebell sea eneas siluius doth report wer falle certain sectes heresie wherefore martyn fifth bishop rome wrote vnto abstain warre reconciled reason damnable opinion thei beyng persuaded contrary neither gaue eare vnto hym yet obeyed voyce wherfore bishop rome wrote prince germany inuade realme beame denne heretikes caue deuilishe doctryne besyde appoynted henry bishop winchester cardinall eusebie wel borne haue hard better borne high stomacked yet higher stomacked abundantly enriched legate greate iorney bryng men realme englande countrey beame warre touched religion licenced thesaid cardinall take tenth part euery spirituall dignitie benefice promocio matter declared open parliament englande dissented gladly assented wherfore bishop gathered money assembled foure thousand men mo without great grudge people whiche daily tallages aide weried sore burdened men municions money wer ready high enterprise people came sea stronde douer ready passe ouer sea flaunders bvt meane season duke bedforde consideryng tounes daily wer gotten country hourely wonne realme fraunce lacke sufficient defence nombre men warre wrote brother duke gloucester releue aide tempestious tyme troubelous season letter brought englande duke gloucester alitle amased army redy sende tyme reason crewe sent beame could sodainly reyse newe armye matter suche importaunce might neither fro day day differred yet long delaied wrote bishop winchester passe army toward duke bedford whiche tyme bothe nede men assistauce consideryng stoode vpon losse gaine whiche thyng doen honor acheued might performe iorney vngracious bohemian although cardinall somewhat moued countermaunde yet least noted ayde regent fraunce greate cause necessary entreprise bowed former iorney passed sea company brought cosyn citee paris charles frenche kyng hauyng knowledge meane season espialls whiche went round countrey intise sollicite tounes citees returne englishe part become frenche inhabitates champeigne beuauoys ought hym greate loue synguler fauor gladly coueted renounce subieccion england vnder proteccion also offred open hym gate thei therby ieoperdy life losse goodes hast diligece remoued towarde champeigne duke bedford beyng aduertised progresse hauyng armie augmented new aide whiche cardinal late conducted marched forward greate spede encountre geue battaill mortall enemy frenche kyng duke come senlys frenchemen wer lodged mountpilioll betwene senlis champiegne euery army knew euery hoste might behold cape wer trenched battailes pitched feldes ordered thus great army lay two day nothyng doyng skirmish whiche norman sore vexed frenchemen wherefore lorde regent gaue many high laudes praisynges determined surely next daie set frenche kyng cape would remoue abide battaill kyng charles politiquely consider variable lady fortune sodain vnthought chauce smal thyng might battaill detrimentes ouerthrowes nacion taken tasted thenglishemen wer lernyng example plaine experiment auoyde open ioynyng mutual coflict force force beside explorators spy plain perfect knowledge many diuerse citees tounes fraunce abhorryng thenglishe libertie aspiryng french bondage natiue seruitude accordyng nature ass whiche thei charged thei desire would whe thei sawe tyme onely rebell returne faccion parte also ready aide assiste hym recouery desired realme auncient dominion expellyng also englishe nacion territory fraunce therefore imagined duke bedforde hasty geue hym battaill thynkyng wer ouercome game englishemen clerely gotten frenchemen perpetuall checkemate wherfore determined neuer except necessitie compelled constrained fight open battaill englishman feld aduenture realme predecessor often tymes vanquished wherfore like carpet capitain night remoued campe fled crespy yet nobre double englishe army duke bedforde seyng frenche kyng thus cowardly retrayted man whiche durste assaie stroke englishe arme shamefully reculed power armie returned agayn paris sore suspectyng deceiptfull faith pollitique parisian bishop winchester frenche kynges flight went beame somewhat author kepe silence shortly without greate praise small gayne returned englande glad retraite aduausyng forwarde sone bishop rome without agrement vnlegated hym set another stede authoritie doyng neither cotent pleased pthe eight yerethe viii yere vi day nouembre day sainct leonard kyng henry eight yere reigne westminster pompe honor crouned kyng realme england whiche coronacion reherse costly faire delicate meate pleasaunt wine nombre course sortes dish labor officer multitude people estate lordes beauty lady rich apparell curious deuises solempne banquette would aske long tyme wery wherfore leauyng pleasaunt pastyme england returne troubleous warres fraunce french kyng fled duke bedford haue harde come crespy ualoys credibly informed citezens champaigne desired greatly vnder gouernaunce subieccion wherfore mindyng lese faire offred prey ceased til came toune reuerence benignitie receiued welcomed rendered hym tounes senlis beauoys lorde longuenall tooke stelth castle aumarle slewe englishemen short space lorde barbasan whiche long prisoner castle gaylard muche faire wordes large promise persuaded kepers deliuered awne persone also caused toune turne thenglishmen part kyng charles master whiche kyng although muche reioysed good successe fortune hym sente yet somwhat desperate recouer countrey possession englishemen except vnknitted knotte league betwene duke burgoyn wherfore sent chauncellor diuerse ambassador duke burgoyn first excusyng death murder duke ihon father declaryng could nothing foule dishonest detestable awne peculiar cause priuate displeasure ioyne auncient enemy perpetual aduersaries natiue countrey naturall nacion onely requiryng hym concord peace amitie also promisyng golden mountaines many benefites tyme either able could performe message secrete doyng closely cloked duke bedford thereof plainly informed whiche beyng sore troubled vnquieted mind sawe power thenglishe nacion daily waxe lesse al thynges first forseyng losse necessitie chaunce tounes countreis whiche noble brother kyng henry fifth conquered countrey fraunce lacke tuicion defence yet ankerhold determined kepe possesse defende duchie normandy olde inheritaunce aunciente patrimony kynges englande fro onely force iustice violence right sithe tyme kyng henry thirde deuilishe deuision reignyng realme wrongfully deteined iniuriously vsurped wherefore diligently prouidyng thynges might chaunce appoynted gouernor citee paris lewes luxenberough bishop turwine ely beyng chauncellor fraunce kyng england man lesse wit birthe leuyng hym conuenient nombre englishemen defende bothe citee territory paris isle frauce beyng englishman possession gouernaunce thynges thus ordered departed paris normandy called roan parliament thre estate duchie whiche declared vnto great liberty manifolde priueleges innumerable benefites whiche thei receiued kynges englande duryng tyme thei wer possessor lordes thesame duchie puttyng obliuion misery bondage calamitie whiche thei sustained intollerable yoke daily tribute continually layed neckes like ass cruell coueteous frenchemen puttyng theim also remembraunce kynges england wer brought furth disceded norman bloud progeny wer true vndoubtfull heires thesame countrey duchie lineally succedyng lawfully discendyng rollo hardy first duke prince dominion requiryng theim farther liue loue amitie emongest theim self true obedient kyng soueraigne lorde kepe othe promes made sworne noble brother kyng henry v promisyng englishe libertie priueleges royall duke bedford thus intertainyng encoragyng norman charles newe frenche kyng beyng departure aduertised longyng thrystyng obtain paris chief citee principall place resort within whole realme fraunce departed toune senlis well accompanied came toune sainct denise whiche found desolate abandoned garrison good gouernauce wherfore force small damage entered voyed toune lodged armie mountmartyr abberuilliers nere adioynyng liyng citee paris thence sent ihon duke alaunson sorceresse ione called mayde sent god whole affiaunce consisted thre thousande light horsmen get citie paris either force faire flatteryng reasonable treatie without delaie defer ryng tyme power came betwene moutmartyr paris sodainly appproched gate sainct honore setting vp ladder walles castyng faggottes diches though would french bragge sodainly haue gotte faire cite thenglishe capitaines euery one kepyng ward place assigned manfully fiersly noble corage defended themselfes walles toures assistence parisian thei rebutted draue awaie frenchman threwe doune ione greate goddesse botome toune ditche laie behynd backe asse sore hurte till tyme filthy mire durte drawen guyschard thienbrone seruaunt duke alaunson frenche kyng seyng greate losse susteined assaut accompted pretensed conquest maner impossible leuyng dedde body behind hym takyng hym wounded capitaines whiche wer small nombre returned berry meane waie citezens laignie became subiectes made hym othe promisyng continewe thence furth hym bothe true obedient duke bedford beyng normandy hearyng sodain attempt lost tyme spared trauaile till came paris thanked capitaines praised citezes assured fidelitie good towarde kyng souereigne lorde also extolled hardines manly doynges aboue starres high elementes promisyng honor fame greate aduauncementes whiche gentle exhortacion incoraged inflamed harte parisian thei sware promised co cluded frendes euer kyng englande frendes enemy alwaies foe aduersaries makyng proclamacion stile frendes kyng henry frendes parisian enemy england enemy paris thei spake harte either feare charles frenche kyng punishe obteined superioritie ouer citee toune thei flattred thenglishmen put themselfes credite chief capitaines shal plainly perceiue sequele actes sone doynges came paris greate company phillip duke burgoyn whiche regent lady wife honorably receiued highly feasted long consultacion recoueryng tounes lately frenche kyng stollen taken agreed duke bedford rayle armie recouery thesaid fortress duke burgoyne deputie tary paris defence greate bu inesse thus concluded appoynted duke bedforde hymself without greate resistaunce recouered toune sainct denise diuerse castle doen sent bastard clarence laye siege castle toursie beyng bothe naturall situacion mannes pollicie strong maner vnable beaten doune siege continued sixe monethes conclusion capitain discomfited al releue succor rendered fortresse life hym souldiers saued whiche offre taken castle raised cast doune grounde duryng siege sir thomas kiriell knight foure hundred englishemen departed gourney normandy rode beauoys spoylyng robbyng wastyng countrey suburbes cleremount wherof hearyng erle thesame toune assembled men warre garrison adioynyng fight thenglishmen frenchemen diligence et forward found enemy straight place nere vnto beauois erle cleremount seyng could hurte theim men armes reason straight came doune fote al company fiersly set englishman fight fierse aduauntage doubtful conclusion archer shot terriblie frenchman able abide smart gaules arrowes fled pace englishman leuyng straight leped horsebacke folowed chase whiche wer taken twoo hundred prisoner thrise many slain erle swiftnesse horsse escaped enemy came toune beauoys sir thomas kiriell plentie spoyle prisoner returned goruay renderyng god hartie thankes good chaunce happie victory yet fortune sent good lucke alone therle suffolk thesame season besiegyng toune aumarle wherof capitain lord rambures xxiiii great assautes geuen fortresse toune castle hym symply rendered wherefore caused xxx tounes men vntruthe hanged walles al rest raunsomed sent capitain englande remained sixe yeres continually excaunge deliuered erle fortified toune men municions vitaile litle litle englishman recouered many tounes whiche thei loste without greate losse people whiche thyng frenchemen well consideryng imagined meanes get toune laual whiche lorde talbot haue hard gat scalyng night wherfore possesse desired prey thei money gay promise first corrupted miller kept mil adioynyng wal miller suffered lorde homet thre hundred passe mill toune darke night thei entered thei slewe kepers gate let lorde bertrand la ferrier fiue hundred men armes whiche either slewe toke prisoner thenglishemen within toune shortly sir stephin de uignoles called heire toke scalyng th toune lonuiers normady muche damage tounes adioynyng pthe nynth yerethe ix yere chaunces happened betwene englishman frenchemen phillip duke burgoyne maried lady isabell daughter ihon kyng portyngall greate aunte kyng englande honor whiche mariage instituted began ordre xxxvi knightes without reproche called ordre golden flece deuised statute mantel collers ceremony thesame muche like ordinaunces noble ordre garter begonne englande almoste hundred yeres inuencion fraternitie fredship whiche wife begat hardy duke charles father marie maried maximilia kyng roman place requireth shalbe hereafter declared season englishemen colde moneth decembre besieged toune laigny whiche puzel diuerse good capitaines weither cold raine greate continuall thei force copelled enemy intemperate season reised siege returne puzell garrison within toune issued fought thenglishmen log fightyng bothe party departed without either greate gain losse enterprise doen duke burgoyne accompanied erles arundell suffolke lorde ihon luxenbrough great puissaunce besieged toune champeigne whiche toune well walled manned vitailed besieger must either assaut long tariyng wery famishe theim within toune thei caste trench made moynes studied al way thei could deuise compasse coquest enterprise happened night assencion lorde pothon xentraxles ione puzell fiue sixe hundred men armes issued chapeigne gate bridge towarde mowntdedier intendyng set fire tentes lodgynges lord baudo whiche gone marigny duke burgoyns affaire whiche tyme sir ihon luxenborough eight gentleman whiche riden aboute toune serche vieue place toune might moste aptly conueniently assauted scaled come nere lodge lorde baudo thei espied frenchman whiche began cut doune tentes ouerthrowe pauilions kil men beddes wherefore shortely thei assembled greate nombre men well englishe burgonions coragiously set frenchman sore fight greate slaughter muche frenchemen able lenger indure fled toune faste one letted entre whiche chace taken ione puzell diuerse whiche ione sent duke bedford roan wher log examinacio brent ash wytch manly woman called maide god frenchemen greatly glorified highly extolled alledgyng orleauce vitailed kyng charles sacred reynes englishemen wer often tymes put backe ouerthrowen lorde dispraise nobilitie fraunce blotte frenche nacion rebuke imputed renoumed region affirme write confesse notable victory honorable conquestes neither kyng power nobilitie valiauntnesse counsaill wit comonaltie strenght could compasse obtain gotten achiued shepherdes daughter chamberlein hostrie beggers brat whiche blindyng wittes french nacion reuelacions dreames phantasticall vision made beleue thynges supposed geue faithe thynges impossible surely credite maie geuen actes clergie openly doen comonly shewed woman inspired holy ghoste sent god frenchemen beleue encha teresse orgayne deuill sent sathan blind people bryng vnbelife letter sent fro kyng englande duke burgoyn euidently shall appere moste dere welbeloued vncle feruent loue great affeccion whiche like catholique prince beare mother holy churche aduauncement faithe doth bothe resonably admonishe frendly exhort v signifie write vnto suche thynges whiche honor mother holy churche strengthenyng faith pluckyng vp rote moste pestilent error haue solemply doen within citee roan commonly renoumed euery place published woman commonly called puzell hath space twoo yeres contrary goddes lawe estate womanhed clothed mannes apparell thyng sight god abhominable estate caried ouer conueyed presence chief enemy prelate noble common parte declared sent god presumptuously makyng vaunt communicacion personally visibly sainct michaell greate multitude angel sainctes heauen sainct katheryn sainct margarete whiche falshode subtilitie made diuerse beleue trust faithe promisyng greate notable victory whiche meane turne harte many men woman truthe veritie conuerted theim lie error beside vsurped cote armes displaid standard whiche thynges apperteinyng knightes esquiers greate outrage pride presumpcio demaunded beare noble excellent armes fraunce whiche part obteined whiche bare many skirmish assautes brethre also men report say feld azure swerd poynt vpward pale siluer set betwene two flower deluces firmed croune gold estate cam feld guided men war gathred copanies assebled hostes excercise vnnatural cruelty sheding christen bloud stirryng sedicions commocions emongest people inducyng periurie rebellion supersticio false error disturbyng peace quietnes renewyng mortal warre beside causyng self honored worshipped many woman sanctified dampnably openyng diuerse imagined case long reherse diuerse place well knowen apparantly proued wherby almoste al christendom slaundered diuine puissaunce hauyng compassion vpon true people willyng lenger leaue peril suffre abyde still way daungerous newe cruelty hath lightly permitted greate mercie clemency thesaied puzell taken host siege whiche kept v champeigne youre good meane deliuered obeysaunce dominion required bishoppe dioces wher take noted suspected defamed traitor almightie god deliuer hym ordinary ecclesiasticall iudge reuerence oure mother holy churche whose ordinaunces wee preferre oure awne dedes willes reason also aduauncement christen faithe bayled thesaied ione hym intent make processe willyng vengeaunce punishmete shewed officer secular iustices whiche thei might haue lawfully resonablie doen consideryng greate hurtes damage incoueniences horrible murder detestable cruelty innumerable mischiefes whiche hath committed territory people obediet subiectes whiche bishop takyng company hym uicar inquisitor error herisies callyng great notable nombre solempne doctor master diuinitie lawe canon began great solempnitie grauitie accordyngly procede cause saied ione thesaid bishop inquisitor iudges cause diuerse day ministered certain interrogatory said ione caused confession assercions truly examined thesaid doctor master conclusio generally faculty dere welbeloued daughter uniuersity paris confession assercios maturely deliberatly considered iudges doctor party aforesaied adiudged thesame ione supersticious sorceresse diabolical blasphemeresse god sainctes persone scismatike erronious lawe iesu christe reduce bryng communion company oure mother holy churche purge horrible pernicious crime offence saue preserue soule perpetuall payne dampnacion moste charitably fauorably admonished aduised put away abhor error erronious doynges returne humbly right way come veritie christen creature el put soule body great perell ieoperdie notwithstandyng perelous inflamed spirit pride outragious presumpcio whiche continually enforceth hymself breke dissolue vnitye christen obedience clasped clawes harte woman ione neither ghostly exhortacion holy admonicion wholsome doctrine whiche might bee shewed would mollifie harde harte bryng humilitie aduaunced auowed thynges doen wer well doen yea doen commaundementes god sainctes rehersed plainly apperyng referryng iudgement cause onely god iudge counsaill churche militant wherefore iudges ecclesiasticall perceiuyng hard harte long continue caused brought furth common auditorie clergie people great multitude purpose assembled presence wer opened manifested declared solemply openly truly master diuinitie notable learnyng vertuous life aduauncement catholike faithe extirpyng error false opinion confession assercions charitably admonishyng persuadyng returne vnion feloship christes churche correct amend fautes offence whiche obstinate blinde accordyng lawe iudges aforesaid begainne procede pronounce iudgement entence case right apparteining yet iudge fully declared sentence began somewhat abate corage saied would reconcile self mother holy churche bothe gladly wyllyngly iudges ecclesiasticall persones gentely receiued offer hopyng meane bothe body soule wer gotte eternall losse perdicion submitted self ordinaunce holy churche mouthe openly reuoked errores detestable crime thesame abiured openly signyng hande thesaied abiuracion reuocacion vpon oure mother holy churche beeyng pitifull mercifull glad reioysyng synner conuerte willyng strayed shepe returne folde flocke condepned thesaid ione onely doo open penaunce fire pride whiche harte sodainly brast hurtfull flame blowen belowes enuie incontinent tooke error false opinion adiuered reuoked whiche cause accordyng iudgementes institucions holy churche intent herea ter defile membre flocke lorde iesus christe exhorted preached openly still obstinate trespaces villanous offence deliuered secular power whiche co dempned brent cosumed fire saw fatall daie obstinacie come opely confessed spirites whiche often appere euill false apparant liers promes thei made deliuer captiuitie false vnt rue affirmyng self spirites bee often beguiled blynded mocked beyng good mynde iustices carried olde market within citee roan fire consumed asshes sight people letter kyng englande sente onely duke burgoyne prince declare veritie matter administracion iustice admonishe rude ignorant persones country refraine credite belefe saiynges suche prophane prophesies craftie imageners peuishe painted puzel yet notwithstandyng lawful processe due examinacion publike sentence tho buchet diuerse frenche writer affirme saincte heauen poynt faith man bound beleue iudgement although archedeken paulus emilius famous writer rehersyng citezens orleaunce buylded honor image idole saith pius bishop rome anthony bishop florence muche merueiled greately wondered actes doynges whiche saiyng well agree marueiled false prophetisse seducer people honored worshipped sainct sent god realme fraunce sure auncient writer aswell deuine prophane alledge three thynges beside diuerse apparteine good woman first shamefastnessethre property appertayne good woma whiche romain lady kept seldome neuer thei wer seen openly talkyng man whiche vertue day emongest turkes highly estemed seconde pitie whiche woman harte abhorteth spillyng bloud poore beast sely birde third womanly behauor aduoydyng occasion euill iudgement cause slaundre quality necessitie incident good woman shamefastnes daily nightly conuersant comen souldiors men warre amongest small honestie lesse vertue shamefastnesse least excercised vsed womanly pitie whe takyng harte cruell beaste flewe man woman childe might haue vpper hand womanly behauor cladde self mannes clothyng co uersaunt euery losell geuyng occasion men iudge speake euill doynges thynges beyng thus plainly true men must nedes confesse cause ceasyng effect also ceaseth morall vertues lackyng good woma must nedes consequently folowe sainct novv leuyng woman consumed asshes lette v returne agayne siege compeigne whiche still continewed duryng whiche tyme regent sente duke burgoyne liyng siege erle huntyngdon sir ihon robsert thousande archer whiche daily skirmished theim toune made suche bastiles fortress toune must nedes rendered el thei within famished se chaunce victory tidynges wer brought duke burgoyn phillip duke brabante departed worlde leuyng behynde hym heire bodie thesaied duke pretended next heire wherfore takyng hym best capitaines recouery greate duchy departed siege leuyng poore people behynd hym ordeined place leuetenaunt sir ihon luxenborough whiche beyng small strength lesse corage duke departyng aduised englishman depart tyme till next sommer whiche therto first would nowise agree remedy capitain generall ordynaunce vnder rule without thei could nothyng doo wherfore greate displeasure thei returned normandy whose departure capitain set fire bastiles secretly departed leuyng behynde hym diuerse peces ordynaunce lacke cariage returne duke bedford burgoyn wer sore displeased continued siege eight day lenger toune rendered without dent swerd pestilence famyne almoste consumed souldiors left toune sauegard defence siege broken vp ihon duke norffolke toke tounes dapmartyn chasse mongay diuerse tounes therle stafford toke toune brie countie robert thense forraged al countrey sen toke quesnoy brie grand puys rampellon many prisoner sir iaques de milly sir ihon de la hay duryng whiche tyme frenchemen toke louiers uilluense toune melune rebelled suche ayde tounes adioynyng englishe souldiors wer fayne leaue melune morret gorbell thus accordyng chaunce war one part gat lost thus englishe affaire haue hard within realme began wauer waxe variable whiche caused englishe capitaines diuerse opinion one part beyng sory pensiue adiudged thynges present light moment comparison whiche thei sawe likely folowe another sort adiudged present time moste ieoperdus moste repleted perilles thei sawe power enemy increased awne stregth rather decaied coserued euery man studiyng businesse aduised secretly hymself counsaill best taken waie best folowed remedy thynges thus waueryng doubtful balance concluded tha moste apte mete tyme presente kyng henry royall person new army come doune fraunce partly comfort visite awne subiectes ther partly either feare fauor childe age beautie dooth commonly allure hym harte elder persones cause frenchemen continue due obeysaunce towarde hym wherfore gret hoste conuenient purpose assembled money maintenauce warre redy gathered realme sette ordre duke gloucester appoynted gouernor whiche duryng kynges absence appeased diuerse riottes punished many offender kyng greate power tooke shippyng douer landed calice taried good space thence remoued roan al triumphe receiued soiorned till middest august noble daily consultyng greate busines waightie affaire pthe tenth yerethe x yere moneth nouembre remoued roan ponthoise saincte denice intent make entrie citee paris sacred kyng fraunce receiue sceptre croune realme countrey wer company awne nacio vncle cardinall winchesterthe coronaci n kyng henry vi paris cardinall archebishoppe yorke duke bedforde yorke norffolke erles warwicke salis ury oxford huntyngdon ormond mortayn suffolke gascoynes erle longuile marche beside many noble men england guyan normandy chief frenche nacion wer duke burgoyn lewes luxenbrogh cardinall chauncellor fraunce kyng henry bishop beauoys neyon bothe peres fraunce beside bishopp paris diuerse bishoppes therle uaudemount noble men whose name tedious rehersed gard aboute person thre thousand strong archer horsebacke parte fote commyng betwene sainct denice paris met chapell meane waie sir simon moruer prouost paris greate company clothed redde satin blewe whoddes whiche hym due reuerence lowe obeysaunce came diuerse riche notable burgess toune paris appareled crimosyne clothe thei doen reuerence approched kyng ix worthy ittyng richely horsebacke armed armes apperteinyng next came knight watche prouost marchauntes officer courte appareled blewe hattes redde long space came master phillip de noruillier chief president parliament appareled robe estate presidentes parliament clothed robe scarlet like robe folowed lordes chamber accomptes finaunce master requestes secretary regesters euery copany course came saluted kyng eloquent oracions heroicall verse conueyed hym gate saincte denice prouoste marchauntes shrefes toune receiued hym canapie blewe veluet richely embraudred flower delices gold bare thesame ouer hym toune whiche euery side hanged riche clothes arras tapissrie euery porte bridge passed set pageaunt greate shewe small coste whiche thei trifle ouer passe speke one deuise made gate chastelet wherevpon stage stode goodly childe clothed habite royall set full flower delices hauyng two crounes hed representyng yong kyng right hande stoode twoo noble personage armes burgoyne flaunders lefte side hym stoode three personage clothed armes bedforde salisbury warwicke whiche hym deliuerd swerde englande pagiaunt well regarded highly praised thence departed palace offered chapell thence departed hous tournelles toke repast din isabell late wife kyng charles grandfather long disceased next daie conueyed boy de uyncennes reposed hymself till xv day decebre whiche daie returned palaice paris xvij thesaied moneth departed place greate triumphe honorably accompanied lady churche paris al solempnitie anoynted crouned kyng fraunce cardinal winchester bishop paris beyng content cardinal suche high ceremony churche iurisdiccion offeryng offred breade wine custome frauce deuine seruise finished ceremony due high estate accoplished kyng departed toward palaice hauyng one croune hed another borne hym one scepter hand second borne hym speake honorable seruice daintie dish pleasant conceiptes costly wine swete armony musical instrumentes whiche wer sene shewed feast sithe men maie coniecture nothyng omitted might bought golde nothyng forgotten mannes witte could inuented yet high ioyous feast without spotte displeasure cardinall wynchester whiche tyme would haue man hym egall commaunded duke bedforde leaue name regent duryng tyme kyng fraunce affirmyng chief ruler beyng presece authoritie substitute clerely derogate accordyng comon saiyng presence high power smal authoritie geueth place duke bedford toke suche secret dispeasure dooyng neuer fauored cardinall repugned disdained thynges deuised cardinall would haue temporall lorde either hym superior hym egall set furth proude arrogant conclusion thorowe whiche vnhappie deuision glory thenglshemen within realme fraunce began first decaye vade awaie fraunce next daie solempne feast wer kept triumphant iustes turneis whiche erle arundell bastard sent polle iudgement lady wan price gat honor kepte open hous comer space xx day ayre paris somwhat contrariaunt pure complexion aduised counsaill returne roan departure caused al nobilitie presidetz parliament prouostes citee marchauntes chief burgess toune citee al doctor vniuersitie assembled presence duke bedford said maner vnknowen lordesan oracion duke bedforde made parisian aswell spirituall temporall noble region famous countrey antiquitie called gaule fraunce sithe tyme charles surnamed greate beyng bothe emperor rome kyng realme hath accompted reputed renoumed moste christen region famous seigniory within circle al christendo yea within whole part europe vndeseruyngly iij cause first sincere faithe obedient loue toward sauior redemer iesu christ second obseruyng fidelitie due obeysauce kynges soueraigne lordes thirdly kepyng performyng promise agrementes aswell woorde wrytyng whiche pagane honest christian disagree famous renoume immaculate honor long continewyng without reproche blotte thinke yea doubt wil death kepe defend obserue noble parentes auncient progenitor ineffable praise haue vsed accustomed wherfore sith vnknowen noble vertuous prince kyng henry fifth moste dearest welbeloued brother true inheritor vndoubt full successor croune realme frauce cosin heire lady isabell daughter sole inheritrice kyng phillippe faire recouery whiche right title pain tooke charge well knowe haue felte greate scourge nacion onely prouided god afflicte punishe theim whiche withhold vsurpe mennes rightes possession inheritaunce god oure sauior redemer whiche wil suffre people intendyng conuert dampned euer gently calleth mercy saluacion greate goodnes gentlenes willed holy ghost shed poure hart noble prince kyng charles late welbeloued drad soueraigne lord knowledge lawfull line true pathe inheritaunce croune scepter realme whiche vertuous man hauyng neither harte hardened awne opinion mynd ambicious empire many tyrauntes couetouse prince daie haue vsed accustomed aduoydyng farther effusion christen bloud saluacion soule without battaill stroke weapon content vpon honorable coposicion restore lawful inheritauce true heire rendre title right lignage vndoubted lyne whiche treatie final composicion nether wantonly ouerloked vnwisely ouersene al noble peres realme bothe spiritual temporall yea moste part nobilitie except certain wilde wilfull persones whole comunaltie base burden realme doth consist onely worde auncient writyng signed handes strengthened seales armes redy shewed haue frankly frely scruple contradiccion agreed affirmed thesame whiche composicion mirror plain shewe token kyng henry right three estate assigned allowed heire apparant thesaid kyng charles lately deceassed cruell deathe seperatyng body soule long expectacion people suffered hym possede enioye title regalitie due inheritaunce succession royall yet god willyng stocke noble famous vertuous prince remayne bareyn without budde flower hath sent hym fro florishing child godly prince bothe noble house england fraunce indifferently discended would saie nature neither perfect englishe perfect frenche man indifferent called englishe frencheman frenche englishman whiche noble prince soueraigne lorde maie glad harte louyng countenaunces se heare behold honorable behauor princely maiestie fewe prince full ripe age hym comparable equipollent beautie giftes nature scace absalon hym assembled hauyng respect vertuous disposicion godly mynd sincere conscience noble child princely infant surely thinke perfectly beleue aboue blasyng starre vnmatched paragon precious stone noble iuell onely come naturall countrey nourishyng region receiue croune possession realme dominion also like good shepeherde vieue se knowe welbeloued flocke moste desired subiectes likewise louyng obediet vassal behold knowe soueraigne lorde prince intent aboue nacions aswel christen ethenicke haue serued loued obeyed ruler kynges day doubteth find louyng turtle make sure hym adamant stele permanent obedience hard mountayne olympe whiche neither craft engyne either consume remoue al mistrust ingratitude clerely banished harte consideryng knoweth daily heare preched feare god honor kyng whiche stubburnesse obstinacie toward prince disobedient towarde god prince yearth uicar god hedde shepherde christes flocke bothe spirituall persones temporal subiectes inferior al cause rule gouernaunce although persones within realme seduced phantastical error obstinate arrogancy haue take part entered amitie charles de ualoys vntruly callyng frenche kyng yet verie true vndoubtfull prince souereigne lorde beyng present resolued content remit pardon offence crime thei within twelfe day returne true folde forsake infected flocke sedious company wherefore request tyme fidelitie whiche haue euer borne hym loue hath styll intendeth beare vouchesafe hereafter without lettyng tyme diligetly study busely take pain bothe kepe louyng subiectes good ordre due obeysaunce towarde hym also se theim liue mutuall amitic brotherly concord betwene theim selfes forgettyng olde prouerbe whiche saieth inward discord bryngeth realmes ruyne whiche honorable requestes accoplishe performe bounden duety bound deede shall deserue muche fauor kyng soueraigne lorde al honest requestes eares shalbe open al reasonable desire mouthe shall stopped thus wissheth healthe body increase substaunce soules oye felicitie without ende perpetually vvhen duke finished ended oracion people beyng glad reioysyng saiynges cried liue kyng henry liue kyng henry whiche crie passed noble men aswell fraunce normandy hym homage common people sware hym feaultie although wer child gaue pleasaunt faire wordes hartie thankes many gratificacions greate admiracion frenche people feasted noble common fraunce within citee paris greate company departed thence small iorneis came roan celebrated great solempnitie high feast christmas noble ceremony wer thus doyng citee paris sondery chauces diuersly hapned seueral place displeasure one part gain sir france surrien arragnoys noble capitain normandy toke force pollicie toune mountarges greate prey treasure prisoner therein put garrison vitailed toune greate displeasure frenche kyng aboute thesame season erle arundell beyng truely informed lorde bousac marshall fraunce come beauoys intendyng feate normady assembled nombre thre twentie hundred men laied hymself priuelie close place farre thesaied toune sent great nombre light horssemen ronne barrier citee frenchman like valiaut men warre issued manfully fought englishemen whiche sodainly fled toward stale frenchman coragiously folowed thinkyng game gotten side thei wer entered straight therle set freshely long fightyng wer slain taken maner al frenchman saue whiche fled toune marshall emogest capitaines founde prisoner valiaunt capitain called poynton sanctrailes whiche without delay exchaunged lorde talbot taken prisoner battaill patay also taken one called shepherd simple sely soule frechmen reputed suche holinesse touched walle toune enemy incontinent would fall grounde ouerturne suche false phantasticall fainers tyme muche regarded lesse beleued fraunce chaunce succeded fortunatly alone richard beauchampe erle warwicke greate skirmishe toune gourney discofited repulsed enemy beside carions whiche wer left dedde ground tooke prisoner three score horssemen gentleman name armes like chaunce infortune happened thesame tyme renate reyne duke barr greate frend charles french kyng bothe lendyng hym money also ministeryng hym aide succor duke bearyng displeasure anthony erle uaudemont cosyn kynsman gathered together greate armie besieged toune uaudemont therle duke approchyng thentent would enclosed compassed enemy within wal leauyng behynde hym conuenient crue men warre defende toune tyme al diligece rode duke bedford burgoyne beyng greate triumphe paris whose part euertaken long consultacion agreed sir ihon fastolffe go hym hauyng company sixe hundred archer duke burgoyne sent hym marshall called sir anthony doulongon xv hundred men elre uaudemont thus beyng accompanied marched toward enemy duke reine hearyng commyng towarde hym somewhat dismayed fearyng least enemy approche walles espied garrison within toune one tyme assailed would issue toune behind therle armie wherfore like hardy capitain brake vp siege met face face therle company betwene cruell mortall battaill horseman indured long conclusion englishe archer galled horse wounded men barroys frendes wer copelled flie whiche chace taken thesaied duke barr bishop myes lorde rodemaque sir euerard saseabery uicout darcy two hundred beside thre thousande men whiche slaine lucky tyme also lesse occasion victory offred englishman beyng another parte wh n pigge profered thei opened poke robert lorde willoughby mathew gough valiaunt welsheman xv hundred englishemen laied siege toune aniow beyng bothe situacion pollicie verie strong defensible called sainct seueryne englishman assailed coragiously thei within egall audacitie boldely made defence fortune semed waie bothe party egall balauce charles french kyng beyng thereof aduertised sent spede lorde ambrose de lore many noble valiaut personage aide releue frendes inclosed toune enemy lorde de lore beyng capitain toune made muche haste comfort deputie capitain within thesame marched forward greate spied fearyng sodainly compassed aboute taried still beaumont lokyng armie capitaines folow altogether set enemy reyse siege while made abode toke leysure englishemen espialles assertened aduertised progresse enemy made thei intended wherfore thei pollitiquely prouided fight one parte whole puyssaunce wer ioyned greate parte theim departed secretly night toward enemy found watch ordre ouersene thousande men wer entered camp thei espied slaiyng men cuttyng doune tentes awaked capitaines sodain feare vnlooked chaunce greately abashed man maner either could h felow hymself could make signe expulse driue enemy campe day beganne appere sonne setfurth bright beames thyng might sene perceiued englishman geuen couetuousnes spoyle desire rauyne neither chaced folowed enemy beyng content prey gayne began retraite toward siege se chaunce frenchman whiche wer commyng heard noyce people fraie hand put spurres horse et enemy beyng laded bagges wallettes prey spoiles part whiche fled returned assailed enemy frenchman egerly assailed englishemen manfully defended whiche beyng ordre wer compelled flie matthew gough diuerse wer taken prisoner yet parte many slain great nombre taken emongest lord lore whiche battaile kept deliuered lorde willoughby hearyng chaunce reysed siege departed verie sore displeased therefore let euery capitain take good hede victorie whiche harde obtain quicke flie awaie daily sene whiche thynketh suerly hath handes catche deceiued ronneth great losse dauger otherside gotten except good watche hourely kept steale awaie muche hurte detriment first gainer thus englishman gredy appetite gain lost triumphaunt victorie whiche thei handes englishe frenche nacions thus stroue contended preeminence principalitie yea superior power life vnreasonable rage warre fraunce rich men spoyled goodes spirituall persones taxed brought low comon people wer slain murdred trode vnder foote woman wer defiled virgyns wer rauished tounes wer destroied wasted toune dweller citezens wer robbed exiled beautiful buyldynges wer cruelly brent nothyng spared crueltie mar whiche fire bloud famyne might catched destroied beside hudred calamity daily vexed troubled miserable french nacion although frauce wer tyme thus miserablie aflicted yet englande without doloure trouble daily englishman aswel noble meane personage wer slain taken wounded hurte substaunce cotinually exacted cosumed maintenaunce warres mischief calamitie indifferent bothe nacions quietnes gayne expulsed banished muche lamentacion dolor bothe coutries wer heard whole west part worlde continual discencion al europe affrike eares mouthes ful men onely marueiled frauce could muche trouble long time sustain wo dered realme englande beyng isle able scourge plague trouble large french region whiche cause euginye fourth beyng bishopp rome intendyng bryng cruel warre frendly peace sent legate called nicolas cardinall holy crosse fraunce thentent make amitie concord betwene two prince realmes wise cardinall came first frenche kyng duke bedford beyng paris exhortyng concord persuadyng vnitie shewyng declaryng arguyng peace moste honorable profitable christian prince mortall warre vncharitable discencion gouernors christes people ought haue iye profite people se iustice duly ministred rule theselfes reason wil abstain fro malice abhorre al wrong iniury whiche thynges warre euer enemie cleane contrary vvhen legate thus persuaded prince euery part bothe gently aunswered thei wer content come reasonable ende first communicacion moued comissioners treated dooynges wer farre disagreable wordes onely reasonable honest condicions peace could neither heard accepted frowardnes pertinacie malice kindeled sprong stomackes time sene cardinal beyng vtter dispaire cocludyng peace betwene twoo realmes least seme departe empty thynges whiche taken muche trauaill desired truce sixe yeres come request bothe party hardly graunted frenchman sone lightly broken returne bastarde orleaunce newly made erle dumoys tooke treason toune charter englishemen affirmyng lawe armes stealyng biyng toune without inuasio assaute breach league amitie truce whiche toune slewe bishop burgonyo whiche occasion newe malice increased mortal warre began rise spryng vvhile thynges wer doyng fraunce henry beaufforde cardinall winchester sailed englande appea e represse certain diuisions commocions sprong vp mischeuous pernicious persones within realme whiche vnder colour newe sect religion coniured together disquiet vexe whole quietnes realme willia maundeuile iho sharpe wer taken executed gouernor kynges iustices remnaunt yelded cofessed offence wherof two article wer men write priestes haue possession thynges ordre charitie emongest christen people incommon sedicious coniuracion diligent enquirie thus queched cardinall began commen duke gloucester concernyng affaire busines fraunce suspecting truce would long continue betwene bothe realmes dede diuised send aide men duke bedforde gathered vp money treasure maintenauce warres resistence enemy wherupon duke gloucester called parliament whiche money assigned men wer appointed duryng whiche parliament iames kyng scottes sent ambassador conclude peace duke gloucester whiche kyng ab nte referred matter iij estate long consultacion without greate argumentes peace graunted concluded whiche men iudged long continue kyng iames vexed ciuil warre intestine discencion also frenchemen taken truce haue hard vi yeres vvhen parliament finished cardinall wel garnished men money departed englande came roan kyng also resorted paris iohn duke bedford debate consult thynges vnlikely happen chaunce wherfore greate counsail celebrate within castle roan many doubtes wer moued fewe waighty thynges hand concluded imagined enemy would long kepe promise yet obserue truce solemply graunted consideryng frenche harte brente iyes sore se riche duchie normandy faire citee paris pleasaunt isle fraunce brought reduced vnder obeysauce subieccion thenglish nacion wherfore thei would omit ouerse one thyng souded defence least frenchman sodainly keping promes brekyng truce might cause thenglishmen greate perilous ieoperdy knowyng cousaill take sodainly prouide remedy mischief bothe lacke men substaunce wer opinion nombres men could long maintained kepte together without breache truce violatyng peace knowyng handes men properly geuen spoyle euer redy gain moste especially thei daily redy harneis prone quicke set enemy therfore thei would walled tounes wel manned defeded rest army sent england remain tary til tyme truce wer expired ouer passed disputacion many argumetes ended duke bedford yorke edmond late erle mortayn death ihon duke somerset whiche died without heire male leauing behind hym sole doughter called margaret countesse richemod erected name title duke somerset liked approued first argument first moued reason affirmyng best warre must prouided money disburssed aduoyde doubtes greater army necessary gathered together assembled al thynges wer agreed kyng henry departed calice thence douer easye torneis came xxi daie february citee london receiued onely greate pompe triumphe also highly presented giftes money chronicle robert fabian maie rede large whiche thyng ouer passe kyng departed englande duke bedford regent fraunce capitain calice taried behynde march picardy informed certain souldiors calice grudgyng restraint wolles beganne mutter murmure kyng counsaill toune calice like stand ieoperdy wherfore duke forseyng mischief might insue thinkyng wisedom withstand first mocion caused chieftaynes faccion apprehended due examinacion diuerse put death many banished exiled march euer purged toune vngracious sedicious company furnished new souldiors discrete men war determined first repaire paris harte would serue hym sith departure lady anne wife duchy departed god honorably enterred celestyns paris whose death cause partely haue hard sure loue approued fidelitie betwene duke burgoyn brother lawe hym began waxe fainte colde whiche cause beyng persuaded lorde lewes luxenborough bishoppe tyrwine ely chauncellor fraunce kyng henry agreed marye lady iaquet doughter peter erle sainct paule nicce saied bishop lorde ihon luxenborough intent newe affinitie olde acquaintaunce familiaritie whiche noble familie luxeborough reneued inforced surer knot knit confirmed wherupon departed calice tirwyne highly receiued erle sainct paule brother maried faire freashe lady iaquet age xvii yeres triumphe nup iall solempnitie whiche ceremony ended returned newe spouse calice englande wife remained vntil august next returned paris duke burgoyne whose mynde began incline litle litle toward kyng charles sore greued angry duke bedforde ioyned affinitie noble famous hous luxeborough whiche sawe power englishman greatly aduaunced mariage fully ended could finde remedy pthe eleuenth yerethe xi yere thynges doyng thus place french souldiors lackyng wage emogest theim greate nombre whiche hope prey desire spoile cast vp plough left labor began priuely tyme serued occasion gaue place take bothe englishman burgonyons raunsomed spoyled theim pleasure although thei prohibited thus duryng time truce peace yet inconclusion thei spared openly robbe spoyle burne yea steale tounes whiche thei affirmed breache truce englishemen pricked vexed open wronges manifest iniuries prepared warre sixe moneth truce taken concluded meanes war reneued begonne vntrue frenchemen breaker peace kepers truce reysed crewe men sodainly tooke toune sainct ualerie standyng normandy riuer soame another army vnder coduict sir ambrose lorde lore wasted destroyed countrey aboute caen duke bedford myndyng lie still ydlenesse sent erle arundell erle warwickes sonne lorde lisle adane marshall fraunce kyng henry xiic men ordinaunce municions besiege toune laigny vpon riuer marne wh che erle shot canon brake arche bridge gat frenchman bulwarke set fire diuerse assautes attempted toune well defended within wer shut vp eight hudred men armes beside meane souldiors duke bedford beyng therof aduertised gathered armie sixe thousande men warre whereof wer capitaines robert lorde willoughby sir andrewe ogard chamberlein duke sir ihon saluaine baylife roan sir ihon montgomerie bailife caux sir phillip halle baylife uernoyle sir richard ratclife deputie calice sir raufe neuell sir raufe standishe sir ihon hanforde sir richard euthin sir richard harryngton bailife eurenx sir william fulthorpe sir thomas griffyne irelande dauy halle thomas stranguish leonard ornesto esquiers thomas gerard whiche solde toune mounstrean faultyon frenchemen thynges necessarye came siege laigny made bridge boates brought ordinaunce nere toune people semed long able resist erle dumoys bastard orleaunce diuer e hardy capitaines valiauntly repulsed englishemen assauted siege contyneued fire flame sometyme flame fire although englishemen slewe nombre yet thei gat neither prey boty although frenchemen kepte valeauntly walles defended loupe yet thei loste bothe men capitaines wer long secluded aide succor til charles frenche kyng perceiuyng toune thre corner key betwene territory englishemen burgonyons awne losse therof turne hym innumerable damage incredible hurtes sent lorde rieux poyton heire lorde gancort sixe thousand men great plentie vitailes thentent either reise siege vitaile toune french capitaines made bragge though thei would fight thenglishemen within felde campe englishemen would issue kept themselfes good ordre euer lokyng entrie inuasio regent perceiuyng thei approched sente theim herault armes declaryng intent corage company whiche nothyng desired battaill shewe hymself capitain meanyng offred dissimulyng whiche spake incontinent diuided men three battailes wisely ordered pollitiquely gouerned would saie come frencheman thy harte serue aduersaries craftie hardy pollitique coragious framed themselfes suche ordre battaile thei wer able thyng yet inconclusion concernyng marciall feates thei nothyng thei made proude bragge stoute skirmishe englishemen thei appoynted diuerse rude rusticall persones conueye toune xxx oxe small vitaill swete gain sowerly paied losse gain pondered one balaunce hauyng regard xxx leane ox conflict slain lorde sentrayles brother pothon valeaunt capitain ihon brother lord gawcort fiftie noble valeaunt personage besid common people whiche bought bargayne price common markette frenchemen perceiuyng infortunate chaunce consyderyng vnspekeable heate whiche weried people beyng beginnyng hote moneth august also perceiuyng englishman planted settled place vnable wonne grounde bothe daugerous inuade hard assaile like men desperate gain without hope victory departed fort vnder yerre bridge tunnes thei passed isle fraunce duke bedforde like wise prince myndyng lease lesse accident substaunce fearyng paris tounes necessary thenglishemen estimacion would returne aduersaries thynkyng greater power holden lesse sone obtained reysed siege returned paris nothyng lesse myndyng trie querell dent sweard enemy sent bedford herault lorde gamcort chieftaines army offeryng hym battail pitched feld within conuenient grounde euer would within isle fraunce assigne appoynt whiche officer armes capitaines aunswered battaill thei feared englishe puyssaunce thei muche regarded thei saied tyme gain tyme lose whiche twoo thei doubted espie one either greate gain apparaunt losse wherupon thei sent lorde ambrose de lore viic horseman robbe spoyle poore people commyng faier day sai ct michaell archangell kepte suburbes toune cae whe dauy halle esquier capitain toune duke yorke issued fight hym departed flight without either botie gain faier frenchman perceiuyng neither power force pollicie could auaile englishe nacion determined trippe deceiue accustomed seruaunt called master treason money corrupted pier audebeuffe constable castle roan marshall fraunce lord fountaynes twoo hundred persones disguised entered castle thei wer sone espied driuen dongeon thei wer taken yelded wherof wer hanged hedded raunsomed pleasure regent suche ende traytors whiche would treason rather battaill obtained prey desired purpose pageaunt plaied regent sent peter luxenborough erle sainct paule robert lorde willoughby competet crue men besige toune sainct ualerie whiche frenche men alitle taken valeaunt capitaines myndyng slepe busines enuironed toune strong siege within toune wer sir lewes de uancort sir phillippe de la toure sir reignold de uerseilles capitaines three hundred good fightyng men space iii wekes manfully defended thesame xxi daie thei perceiuyng fiersenes thenglishemen weakenes themself hauyng hope relief confidence aide rendered toune horsse harneis onely saued erle put garrison toune freashe valeaunt souldiors appoynted capitain sir ihon awbemorid whiche toune sodainly whether wer infeccio ayre corrupt vitail long liyng whiche tounes men eate great pestilence sprang infortunate coutrey whiche many calamity euill chaunces beyng twoo tymes besieged frenchemen thryse recouered thenglishe nacion infected corrupted pestilent plague whereby twoo partes people within shorte space wer destroyed consumed toune gotten erle sainct paule lorde willoughby returned regent thei wer well welcomed thesaid erle departed paris laie siege castle monchas beyng encamped nere toune blangy sodain maladie finished day departed worlde leauyng seigniory lewes sonne heire whiche dedde erle wer solempne obsequies kepte bothe paris london father lawe regent meane season frenchemen entered costes high burgoyne brent toke destroyed tounes whiche cause burgonyons beyng sore displeased assembled greate army bothe reuenge querels also recouer tounes theim iniustely taken frendes duke bedforde sent robert lorde willoughby sir thomas kiriel conuenient company souldiors whiche enteryng laundes la noys wer encoutred great nobre enemy whose force long fight french men wer slain dispersed wherof wer left dedde feld hundred sixtie horseman beside prisoner whiche fury wer al killed put destruccion pthe xii yerethe xii yere chaunces thus happened fraunce iho lord talbot gathered together crue chosen men war england nombre viiic sailed normandy passed roan toward paris way toke strong castle ioing betwene beauoys gisors caused frenchman within hanged walles raised defaced castle came duke bedford paris presence renoumed capitain maruelous thyng se incoraged harte english nacion thei thought nothyng able resist puyssaunce discoraged harte frenchemen thei wer doubt whether wer better fight flie without cause surely chosen capitain marcial feates man fully instructed corage practise warre fearfull frenche nacion awne coutremen especial hope sure defence hardy baron commoned regent agreed waie take without long delay prolongyng tyme departed paris army desieged castle beaumont vpon oise wherof capitain sir amadour de uignolles brother heire whiche castle sone rendered vpon condicio regained without long siege tounes creile bridge sainct maxens new toune esinoy crespy ualoys cleremout beauoys greate rich fatte prisoner returned paris thus prosperous successe happened lorde talbot alone also thesame season therle arundell toke castle bomelyne raised ground tooke force castle dorle thence came sainct seleryne lorde ambrose lore capitain whiche issued fought englishemen egerly firste droue theim backe arowe shot fine force erle incoraged men thei toke newe corages set fiersly frenchemen thei slewe greate nombre droue remnaunt toune victory besieged louiers wherof capitain heire brother whiche rendered toune without stroke assaute good lucke therle forgat returne toune seleryne assembled great army enuironed toune strong siege whe lien almoste iij monethes euery daie attemptyng dooyng somewhat performaunce enterprise conclusion thre monethes ende gaue fierce assault force entred toune slewe ihon allemagne gulliam sent aubyne chief capitaines viijc men warre child lorde lore wer taken captiues replenished fortified toune newe men municios made capitain sir ihon cornwale whiche act thus accomplished departed came strong toune sillye pitched campe inhabitauntes thesame somewhat dismaied chaunce late happened toune seleryne deliuered pledge vpon condicion thei wer rescued within xxx day nexte insuyng thei life saued rendre toune possession whiche offre taken capitaines within toune sent post french kyng aduertise hym hard chaunce whiche incontinent sent arthur erle richemond writer ihon duke alaun son greate company men therle sawe frenche succor appere restored pledge gouernors toune issued campe takyng place moste mete conuenient abide battaill whiche sore thirsted longed duke erle take whiche list liying brooke side whiche man might stride ouer seyng englishemen warlike strongly embattailed thought profite geue battaill sette forward dedde time night cowardly fled shame returned although freche writer affirme loked erle arundell haue geuen hym battaill profered forward therfore frenchman departed appereth apparaunt lye frenche bragge thei came rescewe toune thei geue battaill driue away thenglishmen toune thei came fight departed thei without stroke striken semeth thei came make french face nothyng thei without skirmishe succoryng toune departed night secretly haue hearde thei within toune knew succor failed thei rendred themselfes mercy therle arundel gently receiued leauyng garrison toune departed mauns meane waie toke castle mellay sainct laurece tyme lord willoughby sir thomas kiriell returnyng great victory party burgoyne tooke waie toune louiers furnished bothe men municions emongest many good chaunces euill accustomed fall happen el gayners knowe themselfes happened greate nobre rude rustical persones normady dwellyng sea coast either prouoked intised therunto frenche kyng desirous alteracion chauge whiche thyng commen people muche couete desire made insurreccion put harneis force expulsed certain garrisos houldes toke certain tounes publishyng proclaimyng opely onely purpose intent expel banish whole englishe nacion coutreys coastes wherfore maie euidently appere blacke ethyopian blacke coloured raue wil soner turne colour vniuersal people bred frauce hartely loue inwardly fauor englishe borne child yet norman long tyme louyngly gentely haue obeyed subieccion englande haue englishe nacion wel accepted regarded thei forgettyng duetie reme bryng hurtes doubt rebell prince soueraigne lorde mischeuous copany thus frantiquely gathred together spede marched toward caen intent bothe assemble greater nombre people also consult way thei folow newe begon atteptate duke yorke somerset whiche wer liyng normandy hearyng vngracious faccion troubelous comocion hauyng knowledge espial iorney thei intended take incotinent without delay sent therle arundell lorde willoughby vjm archer xiij hundred light horsses staie kepe either settyng furthe makyng farther progresse therle arundell goyng one waie appoynted lorde willoughby twoo thousande archer certain nombre horseman go afore hym lye watche stale secretly waie stop iorney passage rebelles whe thei approch lorde willoughby couertly couered hymself company sendyng worde erle place lay thentent might make signe token tyme luckey fortunate inuade set enemy whiche thyng doen therle folowed backe ragged route mischeuous multitude man draue deare buckestalle sely coneis secrete hay ignoraunt multitude approched nere place stale erle made token shot gonne signe lorde willoughby set erle behynde shotyng fiersly dastarde people partly amased sodain chaunce partly galled wounded shot arrowes threwe awaie harneis desiryng nothing death therle arundel moued compassio caused souldiors leaue staye farther murther bloud sheding apprehendyng thought ledars chief stirrer people let returne home frankly frely yet slain souldiors could brought vnder standerdes commocion appeaced sodain rage beginnyng staied brideled diliget inquirie made malefactor suche wer found gilty diuerse terrible execucions accordyng desertes miserably ended traiterous life duryng whiche rebellion peter rokefort copany gat treason toune deape diuerse houldes therunto adioynyng erle arundell obtained many conquestes notable victory haue heard attempted another last worke extreme labor liuyng day duke bed ford beyng informed aduersaries sodainly surprised take toune rue therin put garrison sore vexed coutreis ponthiew arthoys bolenoys sent word therle without delaye besiege thesaid toune therle obeyed comaundement incontinent sente people vnder gouernaunce marchyng forward came gourney heard tel certain castle nere beauoys called gerborye whiche either force rasyng violence weather sore decaied defaced place opportune necessarie prohibite let stop thenglishmen make sodain runnynges rodes countrey beauoys charles freche kyng commaunded sir stephen de ueignolles commonly called heire se castle reedefied fortified thesaid sir stephen greate company came grounde lackyng neither stuffe necessary artificer sufficient small tyme erected castle began defend fortresse erle arundell beyng crediblie informed dooynges perceiuyng newe edificacion preiudicial englishe part determined first take castle supposyng litle resistence therein shutte vp deceiued heire many good valeaunte capitaines erle fiue hundred horsmen encamped hymself litle close farre castle frenchemen whiche wer thre thousande men perceiuyng erle horse wer wery archars wer yet come determined aduauntage set comyng footemen whiche thei knewe litle mile behynd erle wherfore pollicie thei set furthe fiftie horssemen though mo castle erle perceiuyng sent furth sir randolfe standishe encountre hauyng company hundred horsses frenchemen fought coragiously sodainly came remnaunte slewe sir randolfe standishe company boldly set erle bande whiche manfully defended frenchman gat litle aduauntage al great nombre heire perceiuyng harte corage defence englishe people caused thre culuerynes shot emongest theim whereof one strake erle ancle brake legge pain fell horsse frenche men entered emongest englishe army tooke erle beyng grounde prisoner sir richard wooduile sixe score wer slain almoste twoo c remnaunt saued selfes aswell thei might erle caried beauoys wher hurte shortly died buried frier minor man singuler vertue constancie grauitie whose death troubelous worlde sore appall harte nacion infortune rue besieged gerborie taken suche chaunce warre thus lady fortune daily turneth whiele mightie mar often varied countenaunce one tyme englishemen gat assaut yeildyng diuerse strong tounes castle pile another season frenche people somtyme bargain somtyme assaut obteined thesaid citees fortificacions sted whiche daily attemptes iomit ouer passe notable acte greate warlike feate doen committed small thynges require litle writyng actes require lesse speakyng assure write negligent loss pollitique gaines euery citee fortresse turrett whiche gotten loste day fatigate wery reader volume queares hearer triflyng woordes notable matter wherfore sithe myne author finde matter either greatly necessarie muche conuenient spoken concernyng high enterprise therfore leauyng bothe nacions daily studiyng greue gain turne thynges accidentall whiche chaunced xii yere abovt moneth iune ihon duke burbon auerne taken prisoner battaill agyncourte xviii yeres paste haue heard paiyng raunsome whiche xviiiml sterlyng hauyng ready prepared thynges necessary triumphaunt returne countrey taken moste sore greuous euer whiche sh rtely vnbodied soule citee london daie appoynted departure frauce who corp enterred grey frier thesaied citee euery creature maie se man purposeth god disposeth maie forget chaunce whiche happened yere thexample prince spectacle gouernors deuill hymself set farther diuision betwene englishe frenche nacion apparell certain catchepoules parasite comonly called titiuils tale teller sowe discord dissencion betwene duke bedford burgoyne fainyng trifle phatasies thynges reproche repugnaut bothe honor estate dignity whiche eache well pricked hastely spurred loue betwene theim ceased affinitie forgotten olde familiaritie cast disdain caue obliuio suche pestilent breath hath flattery suche mischief ensueth prince light credence grudge perceiued mutuall frendes whiche charitable exhortacion godly aduertisement exhorted theim renewe old loue familiaritie mete enteruieu place decent conuenient duke bedforde gladly condiscended come sent oners beyng duke burgoyns toune thither accordyng appoyntment honorable estate came resorted likewise duke burgoyne duke bedford beyng regent fraunce sonne brother vncle kynges though duke burgoyne first haue visited saluted duke phillip part beyng lord souereigne toune iudged mete stande honor go hym lodged content entreatie frendes mete place indifferent betwene bothe harberowes whiche offer accepted bothe party departed discontent neuer sawe commoned speake corage twoo proude prince duke bedford myndyng haue pere duke burgoyne willyng haue superior whose proude disdain enuious discord shortly englande lost burgoyne gayned long shall perceiue history ensuyng pthe xiii yerethe xiii yere bastard orleaunce called erle duinoys lorde rocheford marshal fraunce beginnyng xiii yere tooke toune saincte denise treason skirmished theim paris leauyng behynd hym greate garrison tooke toune howdone bridge saincte maxence composicion time taken toune pount meulane sodain scalyng twoo fisshermen whiche entered vp common priuie standyng walle thus tounes vnwalled wer prey rauenous men war poore inhabitauntes within theim beyng able kepe fidelitie allegeaunce sheilde defence lacked constrayned compelled yeilde rendre theimselfes power vpper hande least thei beyng nedy innocente people vexed turmented vnreasonable men warre christendome region vnquiete vexed poore pitied coutrey frauce although rude poore people suffered many plague aduersities yet souldiors prospered thynges although prey spoyle sometyme refreshed mindes comfort stomackes yet sometyme thei wer slain taken licked vp thei ware euery prince studied circumspectly compassed kepe defende releue citees tounes seuerall faccion priuate fidelitie wherfore sacietie slaughter aboundaunce murthers replenished stomackes bothe nacions bothe generall perceiued hurtes pondered loss considered ruynes daily affliccions although stomackes wer haute harte stony yet thei waxed softe priuely inclinyng peace wisshyng concord without vrgente cause thynges necessary mannes liuyng penurie shewed self furth aboundauce hidden caue corne feldes laie vntilled meddowes ouer troden woodes spoyled men went harneis man plough church seldome vsed deuocion many tyemes spoyled desire gayne suche innumerable mischiefes caused bothe people beyng enemy desire peace yet one part disdained ope ly offre priuatly receiue crie noyes perillous insaciable warre blasted europe detested christendom especially counsaill basill themperor alberte al prince potestates christendome deputy assembled vnio vngracious scisme vsurped sea rome vntruly scripture called sainct peter sea wherfore emperor temporall princeis supposyng exhortacion spirituall father profite emongest twoo high stomacked proude encoraged nacions englande fraunce desirered eugeny bishop rome author arbitrer great strife contencion meanes counsail exhortacion weapon might taken handes twoo inuincible nacions neuer would yeild bowe one neither yet heare abstinence fightyng refusyng warre muche harte hardened princely stomackes one thyng muche put hope good conclusio duke burgoyn willyng wer awne suite returne reconcile charles mortal enemie auncient aduersary wherfore authoritie generall counsaill two discreite persones called cardinalles sainct crosse cypre came toune arras arthoys whither sente kyng englande henry beaufford cardinall wynchester henry archebishop yorke willia de la pole erle suffolke ihon hollande erle huntyngdon diuerse knightes esquiers frenche kyng present charles duke burbon lewes erle uandosme arthur brytayne constable fraunce archebishop reyns sir phillip harcort duke burgoyne proper persone accompanied duke gelders erles estampes lygnye sainct paule uaudemont neuers daniel sonne prince orange great gard gallaunt company vpon daie first session cardinal sainct crosse declared thre party innumerable mischiefes multitude incoueniencies whiche succeded al christendom daily discord continuall discencion exhortyng requiryng honor god loue thei bare settyng furthe christes religion aduaucement publique wealth christendo thei would laye rancor apart represse wrath anger conforme themselfes reason godly concorde whiche thei receiue honor profite continuall quietnesse worlde god reward euerlastyng whiche admonicion thus geuen diuerse day communicacion euery part brought demaund whiche wer moste contrary harde come good conclusion englishemen required kyng charles haue nothyng hande kyng englande duetie benefite hym mere liberalitie geuen distributed whiche frenchman aunswered kyng charles would haue kyngdom frakely frely without begging another man requiryng kyng england leaue name armes title kyng fraunce content dukedom aquitain normady forsake paris tounes whiche thei possessed fraunce betwene riuers loyre soame beyng percell du hie normandy englishemen loth lease good boty paris esteme allowe demaundes french ambassador thei otherside couetyng desiryng obtein renoume glory region whiche paris would wise condiscend part englishe requestes thus pride one part ambicion letted concord peace quietnes cardinal seyng frostie harte hardened myndes bothe party determined despute title offered honest reasonable condicions truce peace season whiche article bothe party either frowardnes disdain openly refused muche englishman greate displeasure departed calice englande one writer affirmeth thei beyng warned secrete conspiracie moued theim sodainly remoued arras sailed countrey vvhiles treatie peace thus comunicacion arras lorde talbot lorde willoughby lorde scale lorde lisle adame fiue thousande men besieged toune denise strong bande erle dumoys hearyng therof accompanied lorde lohac lorde bueill great company horseman haisted thitherward rayse siege meane waie thei encountered sir thomas ki iell matthew gouthe ridyng also toward denise betwene great conflict many slain bothe party sodainly came aide frenchman garrison pout melance whiche caused thenglishemen returne without great arme damage sauyng matthew gouth founderyng horsse taken caried pount melance duryng whiche fight toune sainct denise rendered lorde talbot lordes whiche caused al walles raised abated doune ground sauyng walles abbay toure called uenyn toune gotten lorde willoughby left sir ihon ruppelley pounthoyse departed gouerne paris whiche began smoke sone brast flame shall shortly apparautly perceiue whose departure thenhabitaines pounthoyse rebelled droue thenglishmen force rendered themselfes subiectes king charles toune small losse great conuenient kaye betwene paris normandy gate betwene bothe set open passage large let v returne counsail arras englishe ambassador wer departed
