frenchemen burgonyons began familiarly common peace talke amitie whiche mocion phillip duke burgoyne neither deiffe straunge beginnyng rule beyng muche desirous reuenge punishe shamefull murder doen father kepe hymself high estate preeminence began associate reigne thenglishe power serue kyng englad thinking amity ioynyng neither harme hurte common wealth countrey whereof tyme bare whole rule yet lose one iote poynt authoritie gouernaunce happened contrary expectacion kyng englande right course inheritaunce tooke vpon hym whole rule gouernaunce within realme fraunce ordered aduise cousaill al cause iudgementes warres cocordes duke iudged great confidence perfite truste thought duke bedforde would suffre toune orleaunce rendered hym haue heard therfore imagined determined hymself returne pathe whiche straied erred take part ioyne awne bloud nacion honest meane might sought hymself least paraduenture awne sekyng might bind self condicions hurtfull sore inconueniences frenche kyng also noted vntruth traiterous behauor toward king englande nacion doen homage leage sworne fealtie counsaill hym cloke rayne say sought amitie freche kyng whiche thyng harte moste coueted desired therunto persuaded generall counsaill bishop rome reason honest requestes submitte hymself humbly obey shadowed counsaill without long argument prolongyng tyme tooke determinate peace finall conclusion vpon condicios haue hym deliuered counteis arthoys ponthiew bullonoys tounes amience corby mondidier peron sainct quintyne abbeuile many seigniory superiority whiche purpose reherse prouided alwaie french kyng paiyng redy money duke heires iiijcm crounes haue thesaied tounes countres redeliuered many thynges frenche kyng graunted duke burgoyn whiche able performe accomplishe power make deniall duke demaund request whiche duke either phantasied moued would saie thought suche aduersary whiche desired honest reasonable condicions consideryng state tyme occasion concorde moste apparauntly offered hym ought neither refused cast awaie whiche chaunce hym luckey fortunate surely thyng foresene loked succeded toke place shall perceiue concorde pleasaunt frenche kyng set hym swane swimmeth make met hym proper persone citee reynes long comunicacio standing vp vpo fete said wordes dvke phillipp cosin pere frauncethe oracion french kyng du e burgoyne harte welcome comming harte fulfilled ioy spirites refreshed solace doubte recouery lande seigniory clerely banished fully abandoned consideryng haue ioyned vnited principall yere moste noble prince nexte croune moste valeaunt capitain hath day sene knowen nobilitie honor chiualrie fauor poore common loue daily desire beholde men loue embrace aboue creature worship reuerence aboue lordes beyng straiyng shepe returned olde flocke like man wanderyng pathe brought right waie true limite surely text euer beaten much hedde euery realme deuided emongest theimselfe turne desolacio discord bryng pouertie al discencion succeade misery intollerable calamity euer iudged ensue discorde contrauersie betwene v twoo sore cured ship brought sure hauen trustyng perfectly nothyng mistrustyng healp aide shall expell cleane pull vp rootes put englishe nacion realmes territory dominion helpe v maie aide v able promise worde prince yea al shalbe commaundement desire doo spende pleasure whiche duke burgoyn aunswered would let scape nothing appertayned duetie forget poynt whiche might turne dishonor vvhen league sworne knot knit duke burgoyne lette vayle kyng englandes iyes sent thoison dor kyng armes kyng henry letter beyng waxed faint wetled continual warre daily conflictes also chafed daily complaintes lamentacion people whiche frenchemen suffered losse detriment embraydyng rebukyng hym openly affirmyng onely supporter mainteyner englishe people meanes power mortall warre continued sette forward diligetly studied intentiuely toke pain bothe kepe maintein thenglishmen fraunce also aduauce promote desire intentes rather restore kyng charles cosyn rightful inheritaunce paternal possession reason thynges many maner compelled const ained take peace conclude amitie kyng charles exhortyng kyng henry many flatteryng wordes honest reasonable condicions wer offered take make ende war whiche long continued decay bothe realmes effusion christen bloud beside great displeasure almightie god whiche author peace vnitie promisyng hym aide furtheraunce behalfe many glosyng flatteryng wordes whiche passe ouer noted duke burgoyne whiche thought hymself concord maner dishonored spotted infamy sente letter kyng englande rather purge excuse hymselfe vntruth infidelitie yea periury poore man maie vse terme greate prince thentent appere copulsion voluntarie affeccion turned french part malice displeasure whiche bare kyng henry englishe nacion letter alitle loked ally regarded kyng england sage cou saill onely waightines matter also sodain chaunge man strauge superscripcion letter high mightie prince henry grace god kyng englande vvelbeloued cosyn neither namyng hym kyng fraunce souereigne lorde accordyng euer tyme accustomed wherfore al thei whiche wer present beyng sore moued craftie deede vntrue demeanor duke thei muche trusted could neither temper passion moderate yre yet bridle toungues openly called hym traytor deceiuer moste inconstant prince rumor duke returnyng published emongest common people thei lefte woordes went stripe thei beyng moued pricked vnhappie tidynges ran fiersly vpon flemynges hollander burgonyons whiche inhabited within citee london suburbes thesame slewe hurte agreate nombre thei kynges proclamacion could prohibited leaue abstain suche violence iniurious doyng kyng nothyng mynded saue innocent bloud defende whiche offended letter twise redde wisely brooked willed officer armes tell master conuenient honorable hym enemie englishe nacion without cause occasion geuen duetie thynges consydered haue kept auncient truthe oulde allegeauce rather occasion newe warre freashe discencion aduertisyng hym farther poynt wisema leaue let passe certain vncertain admonishyng hym also myngle mixte safetie surenesse vnstablenesse vnsuretie newe alye cosyn kyng charles messenger departed kyng england counsaill thought determined worke displeasure duke set conspiracie hym awne coutrey wherfore rewardes thei su e corrupt certain gouernors ruler tounes city within duke countreis dominios nacions surely euer proc ue ready commocion rebellion gantoys whiche feate euer bare bell wer common rysers souereigne lordes imagenyng power englishman long like continue within realme frauce feare loue duke sat still moued let tounes alone whiche sore troubled duke wittes greate disquiet vexe sens yere xiiij daie september died ihon duke bedford regent fraunce man pollitique peace hardy war yet hardy warre mercifull victory whose bodye greate funerall solempnitie buried cathedrall churche lady roan northside high aulter vnder sumptuous costly monument whiche tombe sepulture kyng lewes xj sonne kyng charles recouered normandy well aduise behoulde certayne noble men company hauyng youthe discrecion enuie harte consideracions parentes counsailed hym deface plucke doune tombe cast deede carcasse feldes affirmyng greate dishonor bothe kyng realme se enemie father haue solempne riche memorial kyng lewes aunswered saiyng honor shall v breake monumet pull ground take vp deed bone hym life neither father progenitor power puyssauce fredes wer able make flie one foote backeward strength witte pollicie kepte theim principall dominion realme fraunce noble famous duchie normandy wherfore saie first god haue soule let body lye reste whiche liue would haue disquieted proudest v tombe assure decent conuenient hym honor actes deserued although wer muche richer beautifull pthe xiiii yerethe xiiii yere page duplicate page duplicate death noble prince valeaunt capitain bright sunne commonly shone frauce faire beautifully vpon englishman began c oudie daily waxe darker frechmen seyng chief capitain taken awaie began onely refuse obedience loyaltie whiche thei sworne promised kyng englande takyng swearde hande rebelled persecuted openly defied englishman yet mischaunces one poynt abated valeaut corages englishe people thei nothyng mistrustyng god good fortune set vp newe saile began warre new appoynted regent fraunce richard duke yorke sonne richard erle cambridge although duke yorke bothe birthe corage worthy honor preferment yet disdained edmond duke somerset beyng cosin kyng promoted high office whiche verie deede gaped loked al way meanes possible bothe hindered detracted hym glad losse sory well dooryng causyng hym linger englande without dispatche till paris floure fraunce gotten frenche kyng duke yorke perceiuyng euill openly dissimuled whiche inwardly thought priuely eche workyng thynges others displesure cancard malice pestiferous diuision long continued harte twoo prince till mortall warre consumed theim bothe almoste lynes ofsprynges within yeres shall perceiue se norman countrey caux beyng somewhat hartened death duke bedforde began newe rebellion slewe diuerse englishman robbed many praty tounes whiche wer kyng heries faccion part toke toune harflew assaute diuerse tounes lorde talbot beyng aduertised rebellion sent lorde scale sir thomas kiriell lorde hoo whiche afflicted plagued people caux thei slew aboue fiue thousand persones brent tounes village countrey beyng walled parte neither habitacion tillage people fled britayne beastes countrey wer brought cawdebe wher good shepe sould englishe peny kowe xii penny daily skirmishyng fightyng euery part muche lorde scale foure hundred englishemen discomfited rye beside roan heire fiftene hundred valeaunt frenchemen sir richarde reignold de fountaynes sir aleyne gerond alayne de monsay geffrey grame capitain scottes thre hundred mo wer taken prisoner beside seuen faire pleasaut courser victorie staied harte frenche nacion myndes full treason malice greate englishemen many tounes turned parte kyng charles without conquest desire diuerse sould couetousnes many deliuered treason depe boy de uyncennes one especiall poynte noted either disdayne emongest chief peres realme englande haue hearde negligence kynges counsaill whiche quicke sight forese preuent thynges come losse whole dominion fraunce betwene riuers soame marne especiall noble citee paris tymes sent ouer aide tuicion tounes citees brought vnder obeysaunce english nacion thousandes men apte mete warre defence sent fraunce hundredes yea score rascall able drawe bowe cary bill lorde willoughby bishop tyrwyne whiche gouernaunce greate large citie paris company two thousande englishman whiche weakenes kyng charles well perceiued wherefore appoynted arthur britayne erle dumoys bastarde orleaunce lordes de la roche lisle adame valeaunt capitaines aswell burgonyons frenche go paris trustyng fauor certain citezens greate intelligence knewe thenglishemennes power doynges shortly lorde citee toune without greate losse battaill capitaynes came citee paris perceiuyng thynges succeded accordyng expectacio returned mount marter next daie sodainly set toune sainct denise englishemen manfully defended theim selfes beyng oppressed greate multitude thei wer compelled flie abbaye toure uenyn succor refuge whiche conflicte twoo hundred englishemen wer slain rest vpon reasonable composicion rendered toune departed paris thomas lorde beaumond whiche late come paris eight hundred men issued paris sixe hundred souldiors onely intendyng se vieue doynges nombre frenche armye sodainly espied compassed aboute within small space discomfited taken hym foure score prisoner beside twoo hundred whiche wer slain feld remnaunt chased gate citee parisian especiall master halle uniuersitie michael laillier many notable burgess toune whiche euer englishe countenaunce couered frenche harte perceiuyng weakenes englishemen force strengthe frenchemen signifiyng frenche capitaines mindes intentes willed come diligence receiue riche prey without difficultie offred geuen constable delaiyng tyme cam power lodged charterhous lorde lisle adame approchyng walles shewed citezens charter sealed greate seale kyng charles whiche pardoned offence graunted old liberty auncient priuileges thei would hereafter hym obedient true seruiceable whiche thyng theim declared thei ranne aboute toune criyng sainct denise liue kyng charles englishemen perceiuyng determined kepe gate denise thei deceiued cheynes drawen euery streate woman child cast doune stone scaldyng water englishemennes heddes citezens persecuted streate streate lane lane slewe hurt diuerse many theim bishop tyrwyne chauncellor kyng henry lord willoughby sir simon moruier toke great pain appeace people represse furie thei saw auailed thei withdrue theimselfes bastell sainct anthony whiche fortresse thei well vitailed furnished men municions vvhiles rumor toune therle dumoys scaled walles passed riuer boates opened gate sainct iames whiche constable banner displaied entered whose entrie parisian wer glad made greate ioye bishop lorde willoughby small copany defended fortresse tenne day lokyng aide thei sawe comforte appered thei yeilded fortresse thei certain baggage might peaceably returne roan whiche desire graunted thei departed parisian rayled mocked taunted englishman moste spitefull wordes shameful termes could inuented deuised men maie apparauntly perceiue harte neuer thought toungues vttered notwithstandyng obeysaunce fidelitie sworne kyng henry nothyng regardyng finall composicion whiche thei sette common seale thei sawe thenglishmen weakest thei turned leafe sang another song declaryng men inconstaunt harte waueryng mindes vntrue demeanor thus cite paris brought possession french kyng ther altered officer ordained lawes pleasure surety safegarde hym realme people glorious gain frenche kyng besieged toune crayle vpon oyse wherof sir william chaberlayn capitain whiche fiue hundred englishman issued toune long fight discomfited enemy slewe twoo hundred toke greate nombre prisoner remnaunt likyng market departed champeigne tounes adioynyng duryng whiche season xii burgess toune gysors solde money poyton xantrayles castle deliuered wherfore power besieged thesame wherof lorde talbot beyng aduertised sent lorde scale thei bothe xviii hundred men rescued castle toke toune discomfited enemy slewe theim aboue foure hundred persones old prouerbes verefied commeth daie faire commeth late ede stollen bote shutte stable dore paris sainct denise sainct germayns lay many tounes fraunce taken betrayed lacke succor sufficient garrison duke yorke appoynted parliament regent fraunce disdaine enuie duke somerset till dispatched sente normandy eight thousande men company erles salisbury suffolke lorde fawconbridge diuerse valeaunt capitaines landed har lewe erle salisbury besieged castle chamboys whiche shortly hym rendered duke remoued roan set good order greate iustice countrey wherfore norman chronicle highly extoll muche magnifie hym poynte howbeit thei saie gat long siege toune abbay fecape none notable act duryng tyme rule gouernaunce phillip duke burgoyne whiche haue heard brake bothe othe promise kyng england imagened hymself englishemen like shortely expulsed al tounes side sea thei certain refuge place resorte ieoperdy onely toune calice wherfore assembled counsaill heddes citees tounes flaunders brabant hollande zelande toune gaunt wher declared right title interest toune calice countie guysnes patrimony belongyng inheritaunce wyng farther thesaid toune golffe swallower vp golde siluer countreis dominion asmuche ther staple woolles tynne leade marchaundise whiche englishemen would take common currant money onely gold siluer greate impouerishment seigniory region saiyng farther calice onely common stop betwene countreis britayne spayne southward westwarde subiectes could passe without daungier toune wherefore detrimentes considered determined thei would assent shortly recouer conquer toune countie guisnes purpose counsaill comon people onely agreed also promised aide bothe men money lorde flemines bragged hollander craked calice wonne englishemen slain swearyng staryng thei would haue within thre day moste thynkyng verely toune calice could resist puyssaunce potte double beere thei fall quaffyng tel ordenauce new cast pouder bought engynes deuised harneis prouided vitale purueyed greate enterprise comber rehersyng euery thyng perticularly flemynges write prouision toung could speake harte could thinke yet maie beleue list doynges priuie sir ihon radcliffe deputie toune calice therof enformed shortly thesame aduertised kyng henry counsaill whiche incontinent sent thither erle mortayne sonne duke somersette lorde cammeys xvc men greate foyson vitaille whiche tissued calice came grauelyne thei wer encountered greate nombre flemynges whiche shortly discomfited foure hundred theim slain sixe score taken prisoner caried calice within twoo day englishman draue fine force lordes waurayn bado barrier arde discomfited company nober xvc slewe vij valeaunt capitaines toke many gentleman prisoner phillip duke burgoyne abidyng still high warlike enterprise assebled together flemynges pycardes holladers henowiers great army nombre xlm well armed wel vitailed wel furnished ordenaunce wel garnished al thynges thei thought harte blasted emongest theim selfes calicians would leaue toune desolate flie sauegard hearyng onely approchyng gauntoys thei reckened host paied shotte came gallant army passed water grauelyn duke intendyng begin greate conquest besieged assauted litle poore castle oye whiche hauyng l souldiors whiche xii sold liues derely remnaunt compelled necessity yeilded themselfes symplie duke please gauntoys beyng moste puissaunt copany army liberally gaue bothe castle prisoner signe token good lucke fortunate victory whiche rude beastly person nothyng expert warre lawes armes rased abated castle also hanged xxix captiues doen remnaunt duke disdainyng crueltie intreated rest victory litle honorable lesse profitable pycardes besieged castle marke three tymes assauted losse gayne englishemen within whereof sir ihon geddyng capitain set banner sainct george rang belle intent haue succor toune calice capitaines myndyng lese lesse substaunce accident wisshed good lucke good fortune without aide sedyng doubt duke great army power souldiors within marke beyng twoo hundred sixe seyng hope succor desperate comfort rendered theimselfes duke vpon condicion life lymmes saued thei wer conueyed suer custody toune gaunt castle marke rased defaced act dooen duke burgoyne accompanied duke cleues erle estampes lordes dantoyng croy cresquy humyers many valeaunt baron knightes greate army came toune calice placed siege thesame moste aduauntage displeasure enemy gaue thre great assautes toune people wer fierce assaut thenglishemen wer quicke defend gainyng litle iii enterprise contet abstain fro farther approching toward walles first assaut heire whiche come se duke burgoyn sore wounded hurte beside duke daily one great iye sore cause euery tyde shippes arriued hauen england openly face laden vitail municios men also calicians would nonce putte cattaill marish vnder toune walles thentent prouoke flemynges come within catchyng daungier whiche beyng couetous prey gayne often aduentured seldome returned many meanes wer taken prisoner many mo slain ordenaunce duke one day rode vieue behold situacion walles toune thentent take moste aduau tage either assaute shot ordenaunce quickely espied stroke canon tropeter whiche rode next thre horse company wer slain hande sawe thynges succeded purpose firste set lorde croy conuenient nombre besiege castle guysnes wher thesaied capitain gat litle profite lesse harme deuised stoppe hauen succor entre also prohibite within toune make egresse rode outward meanes famishe compell yeild rendre toune deuise set forward nothyng slepte iiii great hulkes wer laden great square stone semented ioyned together lead thentent thei lye still like mout seuer sunder shippes renaunt duke nauie wer coueyed mouth calice hauen full sea craft pollicie sounke doune ground whether god would hauen destroyed either conueyers huikes knewe channell foure greate shippes lowe water laie openly vpon sandes without hurte doyng rode chanel whe souldiors perceiued thei issued toune brake shippes caried stone tymbre toune whiche serued well fortificacions seconde deuise also accomplished whiche strong bastell set litle mountayne furnished iiiic men muche artilarie whiche fortresse let thenglishemen issue thei would greate displeasure disturbaunce vvhiles thynges wer doyng ariued duke army herault england called pembroke belongyng duke gloucester whiche declared duke burgoyne protector england master god would send hym wynde wether would geue battail hym whole puyssauce either place within awne countrey would appoynt daie could assigne inconstancie wind mutabilitie aire duke like noble man aunswered herault sir saie master request bothe honorable reasonable howbeit shall nede take pain seke myne awne countrey god willyng shal finde till haue toune ready abide hym power make aunswere made heraulte highly feasted cup hundred golden gyldens hym deliuered reward returned calice whose departure duke called greate counsaill chief pauilion gauntoys declared bothe heraultes message aunswere desiryng regard honor estimacion countreis honesty themselfes like men receiue enemy valeauntly defende aduersaries promisyng theim victory gain perpetual glory lorde flemynges threatened pycardes craked hollander sware thenglishme killed slain promisyng duke rather dye flie recreaunt while great matter consultacion calicians well contented bastell whiche duke newly builded issued toune great nombre part foote part horsebacke footemen ran assaut bastile horssemen went betwene army assailautes stop ayde succor whiche might come alarmy sounded somuch duke proper persone commyng foote releue people meanes horsmen staied kept backe space whiche delaye tyme englishman fine force gat place slewe clx persones remnaunt wer taken prisoner defaced fortresse set fire cariyng al ordinauce artilerie toune calice great displeasure duke counsaill nexte daie sprang rumor army man could tell duke gloucester greate puyssaunce ready embarked shipped would arriue next tyde come doune calice raise siege cause cannot truly write surely thesame night duke fled awaie sent hast lorde croye reise siege guysnes whiche tidynges hym ioyous neither got saued twoo capitaines departed leauyng behynde bothe ordinaunce vitaill greate rich frenche writer saue honor duke burgoyne saie certain discord commocion emongest fleminges duche nacion affirmyng great lordes pycardes frenchemen greatly extoll would betraye sell fleminges frendes thesame cause greate fury thei cried home home would tary request duke could make exhortacio could giuen misgouernaunce duke enforced raise siege departe flemishe author affirme contrary saiyng thei ready abide comyng duke gloucester duke burgoyn fearyng trapped betwene duke gloucester army garrison calice behynde could escape waie fled awaie night geuyng theim warnyng lacke tyme couenient space lade cary stuffe beyng com aunded retire spede diligence thei compelled lose leaue behynde theim vitaill tentes great losse detriment liberty gentle reders whether geue credite frenchman whiche wer absent er acte flemynges partaker losse dishonor infallible veritie fled xxvj daie iuly night next daie mornyng duke gloucester landed calice hauen straight went campe enemy night lodged founde many goodly peace ordenauce inespecially one called dygeon named chief toune burgony beside pauilios wine beere meale innumerable vitaill duke gl cester seyng enemy reculed hauyng company xxvm men entered flaunders burnyng house killyng suche would resist destroiyng countrey euery parte settyng tounes poporniche baillens wasted suburbes many faire citees al waie thei lost man sawe creature appete defende countrey thei passed newe castle destroyed ryme ure uallo chappell entered arthoys arques blandesques settyng fire euery thei came thus thei passed sainct omers guysnes sixe weekes ende thei well refreasshed iorney thei litle plentie good bread whiche caused muche faintnesse diuerse disease army duke gloucester sufficiently plagued wasted countreys duke burgoyn brought great preyes beastes spoyle toune calice settyng thynges good ordre returned englande aduertised iames kyng scottes contrary othe league promise besieged castle rokesborough thirtie thousande men whereof sir raufe graye capitain whiche manfully defended xx day scottish kyng beyng aduertised erle northumberlande commyng fight hym fledde lesse losse dishonor toune edenbrough pthe xv yerethe xv yere daugerous businesse finished time ended meane frendes desire princies truce abstinence warre certaine tyme moued betwene kyng englande duke burgoyne whiche cause wer sent grauelyne kyng englande cardinall wynchester henry beaufford ihon lorde moubrey duke norffolke humffrey erle stafford diuerse well learned honorable personage duke appe ed duches wife bishop arras lorde croy diuerse whiche treatie taken small tyme lesse space obserued whiche abstinence war concluded betwene kyng englande duchesse burgoyne enterlessyng duke name thinke kyng englande would neuer entre league hym broken promise writyng fidelitie written sealed sworne hym father imagened doen cautell cast myst frenche kynges iyes intent beleue feate wrought duchesse without assent knowledge duke counsaill bounde accomplishe acte thyng doen wife treatie thus maie se princies sometyme suche vain gloses scornefull exposicions wil hide doynges cloke purpose thentent thei would either espied plucke hedde coller pleasure common prouerbe saieth whiche promise breaker escapeth alwaie free well sene daily chaunceth bothe prince meane persones breakyng faithe kepyng promise many displeasure arise innumerable inconueniences ensue abovt season katheryne quene mother kyng england departed transitory life buried husband mynster westmynster woman death kyng henry fifth husbande beyng young lusty folowyng awne appetite frendely counsaill regardyng priuate affeccion open honour toke husband priuily goodly gentilman beautyful person garnished many godly gyftes nature grace called owen teuther brought furth come noble lignage aucient lyne cadwaleder laste kyng brytons whome conceyued broughte forthe iii goodly sonnes edmond iasper another whiche monke westmynster lyued smal tyme doughter youth departed transitorie lyfe whose deathe kynge henry bretherne one wombe desceded created edmonde erle rychemonde iasper erle pembroke whiche edmond engendered margaret doughter sole heyre ihon duke somerset hery kyng realme called king henry seuenth shal heare hereafter thys owen death quene wife apprehended comitted ward contrary statute made vi yere kyng presumptuously maried quene without kynges especiall assent agrement pryson escaped let hym agayne apprehendyd escaped agayne duchesse bedford sister lewes erle sainct paule myndyng also marye rather pleasure honour without cou sayl frendes maryed lusty knyght called sir richarde wooduile great displeasure vncle bisshop tyrwyne erle brother coulde remedie chauce cast passed sir richard made baro riuers erle lady many noble sonnes faire daughter whereof one lady elizabeth quene englande maried kyng edward fourth shal perceiue vvhiles mariage celebratyng iane late quene englande duchesse britayne doughter kyng nauer wife kyng henry iiij died mannor haueryng buried husbande canterbury whiche tyme disceased countesse warwicke henry archebishop yorke thought omit ouerpasse regainyng conquest strong toune harflew englishe craft turned frenche part except frenche writer english auth r made mencion remembraunce reduccion thei saie affirme duke somerset accompanied lordes fauconbridge talbot sir franceis surrien arragonoys mathew gough thomas paulet thomas haringto walter limbrike ihon geddyng william watton esquieres thomas hylton bailife roan great puissaunce english partie compassed besieged toune harflew bothe water land capitaine within toune called sir ihon desto teuile sir robert brother nombre sixe hundred good fightyng men assailauntes lost tyme made trench cast diches bothe assaute toune also let frenche succor thei neither approche ayde citezens shut besieged diuerse assautes wer geuen wer manfully resisted losse defender assauters beside englishemen laied greate ordinaunce gate toune whiche continually vexed inhabitautes ouer threwe buyldynges destroyed mancions neither hous high waie sure refuge tounes men siege endured long greate discomfiture people whereof thei aduertised frenche kyng counsaill whiche sent thither erle ewe therle dumoys called bastard orleaunre valeaunt bastard burbon lorde gaucort sir giles sent symon chief capitaines realme foure thousand men bothe pollitique proued valeaunt armie passed riuer soame betwene amyas corby mistrustyng gette whiche thei lost left behynd theim thei came toune diuided theselfes seuerall partes moste aduauntage daily skirmishyng thenglishmen nothyng preuailyng feare losyng honor desperacion gain florishyng frenchemen returned muche labor litle profit capitaines toune seyng theire pillers borken chief ayders discomfited rendered toune duke somerset whiche made capitaines thomas paulet william lymbrike cristopher barker george sent george whiche many yeres till deuision beganne englande manfully valeauntly defended toune hauen afterward saied duke regent gouernor norma dy onely loste toune also citee roan empeire chief iuell thesaied duchie many citees fortress whiche entreatyng threatenyng might still haue holden vnder subieccio men haue wit alike ruler one condicion pollicie duke edmond gatte toune great glory deputie vnder regent beyng gouernor lost thesame al whole duchie greate slaunder infamy hereafter shall perceiue preuent fortune chaunce haue spectacle se thynges come chaunces present seyng god disp seth man purposeth worldely deuises mannes cogitacions vncertain euer vnperfite althovgh haue long talked fraunce yet may forget double dealyng craftie demeanor iames kyng scottes whiche beyng haue heard late prisoner englande onely garnished learnyng ciuilitie whiche thynges wer rare straunge time within realme scotlad also set libertie honorably sent home intent amitie might perpetuall loue might continually succeade betwene bothe realmes meane accord firste greate raunsome abbridged diminished ioyned mariage one bloud royal thentent heires vnited knit progeny england indissoluble knot like twisted tree whiche cannot seuer like hard flinte whiche waxe soft yet vngentle prince forgetfull frend puttyng obliuion bothe dutie obeysauce toward souereigne liege lorde oth promise made kyng henry hym homage liege castle wyndesore haue heard turned backe frend kynsman loked french part whiche neuer hym honor profite onely sendyng fraunce daily aide succor englishe nacion also newe alliaunce sought practised way meanes ioyne forein prince greue hurte neighbor adioynauntes realme england although awne power wer small great damage yet thought linked suche noble house lesse feare malice enemy vpon whiche fe le foundacion concluded ii mariages one lewes dolphin sonne charles frenche kyng fraunces duke britayn whiche mariages desired loue rich onely ayde resist driue englishman fraunce lady margeret maried dolphyn suche nasty co plexion euill sauored breathe abhorred company cleane creature dooth carion whereupon conceiued suche inward grief within fewe day ended day although lady suche impedimentes haue heard yet sister isabell maried fraunces duke britayne lacked neither excedyng beautie pleasaunt breathe wit womanhod ciuile behauor neuer excercised wherfore duke mariage counsaill admonished refuse forsake innocent creature moued faire face woma ly wisedome aunswered ynough woman iudge difference betwene shurte dublet husbande knowe hym darke another man mariages kyng iames demaunded common greate subsidye tallage whiche sore grudged maner denied maried theim faire promise ayde succor thenglishemen rather bagges money chestes plate forein alliaunce litle profited auayled realme scotland new amitie defended kyng iames walter steward erle athole whiche pretended title croune reason begotten kyng robert seconde firste wife whose occasion robert duke albany murdered dauid duke rothesay elder brother kyng iames story kyng henry fourth haue heard declared coronacio kyng iames first scotlande earnestly sollicited hym putt death duke murdo ofspryng robert first duke albany trustyng destroyed line stop waie inuent meane destroy kyng child obtain croune preeminence realme wherfore perswaded robert steward nephiew robert grame cosyn diuerse murther sley kyng souereigne lorde whiche therto deuilishe instigacion incensed procured came toune pertho commonly called ihos toune entred kynges priuy chambre slewe first diuerse seruauntes whiche made resistance killed kyng many mortall stroke hurte quene whiche defence husband felled one traytors vngracious deede blowen toune people rose greate plumpes found princequellers theim brought straight prisone whiche afterward accordyng desertes wer terrible tormentes put death executed iames first succeded iames seconde eldest sonne whiche fearyng sedicion ciuile discord vexed awne nacion englishe people novv leauyng scotland let v returne busines frauce while scottes wer compassyng destroy kyng lorde talbot greate company laied siege castle tankeruile whiche foure monethes hym simplie rendred gyuen vp toune greate gain englishemen meane season frenche kyng awne persone besieged strong toune monstreaue faultyou whereof thomas gerard capitain whiche desire rewarde feare enemy sold toune frenche kyng hym greate giftes good chere whiche afterwarde well knowen shame reproche toune rescued frenche kyng foughten one chaunce happened duke yorke discharged office regent erle warwicke preferred thesame duke yorke liyng roan would haue gladly rescued toune authoritie surceased erle warwicke could wind cleane cotray hym army taried winde aboue tenne wekes betwene discharge one charge toune mo streau deliuered solde presente yere parliament kepte westminster whiche wer diuerse notable conclusion ordained taken aswell preseruacion peace concord home maintenauce warre hostilitie outward region whiche parliament loke actes shall perceiue one act made byyng sellyng straugers profitable publique wealth realme wer wel kept good actes none either negligece gouernors insolencie pride people novv must speake somewhat charles frenche kyng whiche gained citee paris diuerse tounes puffed vp pride thought trifle conquere normandy expulse englishe nacion countreys seigniory wherfore sent arthur britayn constable fraunce iho duke alason normandy great army whiche besieged toune aurauches standyng vpo knop hill nere britishe sea bothe well walled well manned thei laie long litle gettyng muche spendyng lorde talbot valeaunt company men approched nere frenche men encamped themselfes face enemy prouoke entise battail fight frenchman refusyng offre kept theimselfes within trench daily fortifiyng repairyng campe englishemen perceiuyng doynges remoued army halfe mile farther geuyng enemy come issue fight litle auailed frenchemen laye still stirred lorde talbot seyng faint harte reysed feld open sight entred toune next daie issued founde frenchemen ridyng abrode destroye plain countrey enuironed bet discomfited slayng many takyng diuerse prisoner although frechemen gat neither honor profite iorney yet thei enterprised greater matter ponthon sentrayles heire diuerse capitaines great nombre frenchman hauyng promise certain burgess roan let secretly toune came forward village called ryse lodged lorde talbot lorde scale sir thomas kiriell hearyng approche set roan midnight greate pain came rise mornyng couertly frenchemen beyng sodainly surprised set like men madd amased ran away fled chase wer taken lord fontaynes sir alleyne geron sir lewes de balle lx knightes esquire beside ther wer flain two hundred mo heire beyng sore wounded swiftnes horsse escaped narowly englishman returned toune rise found greate nombre horsses baggage whiche thei ioyously brought roan pthe xvi yere sixt daie nouembrethe xvi yere present yere erle warwicke regent fraunce passed sea seuen tymes shipped vnshipped landed humflewe freashe souldiors came roan duke yorke returned englande neither wholy pleased halfe content secretly smelled men priuely disdained aduauncement enuied promocio yet like wise man kept toung close whatsoeuer harte thought betwene chaunge twoo capitaines duke burgoyne whiche sore enuied glory thenglishmen besieged castle croytoy tenne thousande men mo hauyng hym greate plentie gonne goodly ordenaunce erle warwicke hearyng feate sent lorde talbot lorde fawconbridge sir thomas kiriell sir ihon mountgomery thomas limbricke thomas cha do dauy halle diuerse knightes esquiers many tall yeoman nombre fiue thousand men whiche passed riuer soame beside toune ualery passage blach taque daugerous go duke burgoyne laied ordinaunce engyns let trouble stoppe englishemen go ouer foorde yet lord talbot passed men went water vp chinne glad wer men rescew felowes duke burgoyn enformed approchyng lorde talbot power sauyng foure hundred whiche wer left bastile hym newly buylded fled abbeuile whiche bastile sone gained men within either slain taken toune receiued lorde talbot sente woorde duke burgoyn would vtterly wast destroy coutrey pycardy except like valeaunt prince would geue battail accordyng promise brent tounes spoyled slewe many people pycardy doynges duke would appere stale awaie abbeuile fled amyas lorde talbot xx day full countreis pycardy arthoyse destroiyng burnyng thei could se come departed meane season sir thomas kiriell gotten duke cariages ordenaunce left asmuche vitaile toune croytoy would serue sixe hundred men whole yere conueyed remnaunt safetie erle warwicke whiche onely receiued capitaines good semblaunce louing cheare also highly magnified actes muche praised hardinesse enterprise achiued henry erle mortaine sonne edmond duke somerset arriued chierbuege foure hundred archer thre hundred speres passed normandy till came countie mayne besieged castle called anyan whiche wer three c scottes beside frenchemen castle toke strong assaut slewe scottes hanged frenchman thei wer sworne english brake othe gatte also another castle twoo mile sainct iulians called alegerche shortly recouered lorde cameuys whiche came rescue thesame meane waie trapped taken thus victory flowed tyme one parte sometyme treason frenchman far surmounted gettyng bothe pollicy strength englishe capitaines vntruth perfidy burgess inhabitautes tounes meaux brie susanne thesame wer sold deliuered frenche parte ende sixtene yere pthe xvii yerethe xvii yere reherse great tempestes sharpe blastes sodain piries vnmesurable wyndes continuall raynes whiche fell chaunced yere england sithe suche tormentes bothe naturall god pleasure diuersly ordered altred vntemperate stormes rose suche scacety wheat sold iiisiiiid busshell wine xiid gallon bay salt xiiijd busshel malt xiijsiiijd quarter graynes wer sold excessiue price aboue olde custome moneth iune erle huntyngdone stewarde guyen twoo archer foure hundred speres sente gascoyne suppliment countrey common thesame kyng england cousaill wer enformed therle dumoys lay fronters tholose secretly rewardes faire promise entisyng prouoking diuerse tounes guyen become french leaue thenglishe nacio wherfore erle like pollitique warrior altered onely capitaines euery toune cite also remoued magistrate chaunged officer toune toune rowme rowme meanes tyme erle dumoys lost bothe trauaile cost thesame moneth also sir richard wooduile six william chaberlain sir william peyto sir william story men wer lent stuffe tounes normandy whiche surely tyme therof greate nede thenglish capitaines smal confidence norma much awne nacion harlot bribery felowe couetuousnes ran fast abrode french crounes vnneth creature without especial grace could hold either close pursse shut suche strong percer money suche gredie glotton auarice haue heard howe kyng charles harte gettyng paris set vpon merie pynne thought daily thynges would bothe applie purpose folowe appetite whiche inuented imaginacion sodainly bothe deceiued hym also appalled haut corage abate hym somewhat proude stomacke odainly rose straunge storme quicke pirie mischeuous pernicious nothyng execrable abhorred could happen christian region whiche sedicious tempest wise counsail al spede repressed doubt kyng charles whole publique wealthe fraunce turned vp cleane ouerthrowen lewes dolphyn uyen heire apparaunt kyng charles yong prince froward stomacke euil condicions desiryng libertie ward rule suche wer nature condicions began conspire father souereigne lorde chief vngracious faccion hym wer iho duke alaunson ihon duke burbon confederate gathered together greate power dolphyn tooke vpon hym rule gouernaunce realme orderyng cause father name authoritie awne wil affeccion phantasie kyng charles father knowledge vnnaturall disobedience insolent proude doynges maruel greatly moued sodain commocio thinkyng hymself borne predestinate trouble remebryng smal thyng awne countrey many yeres straungers awne nacio fight striue rule dignitie co strained contend make war awne sonne welbeloued child croune regiment realme dominion yet thynges bryng hym beyng man greate wit counsaill daily troubled vnquieted calamity displeasure vtter despaire extreme wanhope like pollitique prince determinyng withstand resist smoke beginnyng fire flame rast abrode called together suche either greate confidence especiall fauor communicatyng al inward thoughtes priuie cogitacions long consultacion agreed moste parte sore mete cured pollitique wittie handelyng rather force ent sweard wherfore letter wer written postes wer sent euery citee borough straightly prohibityng synguler persones either heare obey precept commaundement set furthe published dolphyn hymself name al offence doen confederacie wer open proclamacion frely geuen remitted beside diuerse graue sage persones wer sent dolphyn alies common coclude peace reconciliacion betwene frenche kyng theim declaryng ciuile war inward discencion meane cause enemy vtterly plague destroy natiue countrey whiche almoste desolate brought subieccion continual warre practised whiche meanes perswasions knot sedicious faccio losed dissolued kyng sonne confederate openly agreed apparautly pacified spryng mischiuous secte stopped repulsed flodde thyng encreased flowen farther englishman whiche euer sought aduauntage hearyng domesticall diuision realme fraunce raised armye recouered diuerse tounes whiche wer stollen theim french nacion made great prouision recouer citee paris thei heard dolphyn returned father mate wer ioyned french kyng thei left enterprise reuoked purpose pthe xviii yerethe xviii yere moneth nouembre presente yere suche great frost depe snowe ground couered white al diches hardened frosen whiche weather put englishemen comfort recouer toune ponthoise frenche kyng gotten corruptyng money diuerse burgess toune wherfore englishemen beyng clothed white ihon lorde clifforde capitain came night diches passed theim without daungier reason froste sodainly scaled walles slewe watche tooke toune many profitable prisoner toune thus gotten lorde richard beauchampe erle warwicke regent frauce died castle roan conueyed england solempne ceremony buried college warwicke verie solempne sumptuous sepulture duke yorke made regent fraunce whiche accompanied therle oxford lorde bourchier called erle ewe sir iames ormond lorde clinton diuerse noble men sailed normandy whose arriuall frenche kyng beyng sore greued takyng toune pounthoyse assembled great army besieged thesaid toune hymself made round bastiles trench diches daily shot ordenaunce gaue therunto diuerse greate fierce assautes ihon lorde clifford like valeaunt capit defended toune suche valeauntnes frenchemen rather lost gayned duke yorke landyng hauing true knowledge siege sent lorde talbot great nombre souldiors came nere toune pounthoyse encamped hymself sent woorde frenche kyng ready geue hym battaill would come campe bastiles kyng charles ruled counsaill whiche wise would suffre hym aduenture persone men lowe base degree biddyng hym remembre loss auncesters susteined geuyng englishemen battaill whiche thyng thei principally desire willyng hym kepe ground still bid th im entre perell meane season stoppe passage riuer oy e vitaile could brought englishe army way whiche meanes onely obtein purpose also cause englishemen recule backe lacke vitaile succor duke yorke perceiuyng frenche kyng nothyng mynded ight determined passe ouer riuer oyse fight hym lodgyng wherupon remoued campe appoynted lord talbot make countenaunce thei would passe riuer force gate beaumont appoynted another copany boates tymbre ledder bridge made cordes rope whereof greate plentie caried hym chariottes passe ouer riuer neth abbay lord talbot made crye though would assaile gate certain englishman passed water ouer boates drew bridge ouer greate nombre wer comen ouer frenchemen espied thei sawe chaunce thei ran like mad men stoppe passage labor loste pain purpose moste parte thenglishe people wer sodainly transported muche thei chased enemy fine force toune toke sir guylliam de chastell nephieue lorde canehy diuerse gentleman prisoner frenchman seyng damage irrecuperable returned frenche kyng accomptyng hym euil chauce vnluckey fortune therwith litle displeasaut wel perceiuyng taried comyng thenglishmen like either greate ieoperdy sure sustein muche dishonor greate damage wherefore remouid ordinaunce bastile martyn whiche newly made leauyng behynd hym lorde cotigny dmirall fraunce thre men kepe bastiles dislodged night maubuisson came poissye taried still place lorde talbot certain trustie souldiors whiche passed riuer oyse ii smal lether boates either slain taken hym lodgyng night englishemen next daie good ordre battaill came toune pounthoise thinkyng haue founde frenche kyng gone lodgyng thei founde greate rich muche stuffe whiche could haue space conuey feare sodain inuasion duke yorke company entered toune sent newe vitaill repaired toures bulwerkes toune diuerse tymes assailed bastile frenchemen whiche passed greatly thei power either assaut stoppe vitailes succor toune duke liyng thus toune ponthoise aduertised frenche kyng dolphyn nobilitie fraunce wer lodged poissye wherfore intendyng offre hym battaill left behynd hym capitain sir geruays clifton thousande souldiors remoued army came poysye set hymself men good ordre battaill redy fight issued diuerse gentleman skirmish englishemen thei sone discomfited foure valeaunt horssemen wer taken prisoner diuerse slain englishemen perceiuyng faynte harte colde corage enemy whiche nothyng lesse desired encountre englishnacion open felde dislodged poysye came mante sone roan vvhen regent lorde talbot wer returned normandy frenche kyng euill lucke forgat toune ponthoise firste considered charge susteined bothe duryng tyme siege also makyng bastyles trench deuises remembred people especially parisian toune euil neighbor would rayle saie able lacked corage gette small toune discomfite halfe hadfull amased people wherfore thynges set ordre assembled puyssaunce returned sodainly ponthoise firste assaute gat churche whole toune toke capitain prisoner diuerse englishemen slewe nombre foure hundred whiche derely sold life one frenche writer affirmeth frenche kyng lost thre men mo whole garrison englishemen onely thei gayned toune thei gat gr ate boty men fame victory blowen abrode harte tounes men began appall somuche melune corbuell eureux diuerse tounes yelded turned proude crake frenche bragge without stroke striken blowe gyuen hote rage wether began waxe temperate kyng hery kyng charles wer agreed send ambassador common treate good peace conclusio betwene realmes kyng england sent cardinall wynchester diuers noble personage counsaill calice also sent charles duke orleaunce yet prisoner england thentent might author peace procurer deliueraunce frenche kyng sent archebishop reyns erle dumoys duke burgoyne sent lorde cre ecuer diuerse duke orleaunce passed sea englishe ambassador thei would mete none place commen calice frenche ambassador perceiuyng mynde came calice duke orleaunce gently receiued therle dumoys bastard brother thankyng hartely pain taken gouernyng coutrey duryng tyme captiuitie absence diuerse communicacions wer aswel deliueraunce duke finall peace somuche muche consultyng litle doyng another tyme appoynted newe assembly euery parte declare souereigne request desire ambassador toke leaue departed thenglishe commissioner conueyed duke orleaunce england whiche nothyng paie rau yet could deliuered without paiment cause comissioners agre frenche writer saie englishemen demaunded onely haue possesse peaceably ii duchy aquitayn normandy kynges prince discharged resort superioritie souereigntie frakly frely realme frauce kynges gouernors thesame euer also required restored al tounes citees possession whiche thei within xxx yeres next gone past conquered realme fraunce englishemen thought thei demaunded right reason frenchemen thought request hurtfull realme aucient glory party rather myndyng gain saue lose departed tyme haue heard diet proroged tyme phillip duke burgoyn partly moued coscience make amendes recompence charles duke oleaunce prisoner englande death duke lewes father duke ihon father duke phillip shamefully slewe cruelly murdered citee paris tyme kyng henry fourth plainly mencioned partly entendyng aduauncement niece lady marie doughter adolphe duke cleue whiche aliaunce trusted surely knit firme knot frendly amitie duke orleaunce olde rancor cease discorde forgotten place concorde stablished perpetuall loue embraced sente messenger englande saied duke declaryng hym good deuise entent thinke message ioyous captiue beyng natiue countrey naturall seigniorie space xxv yeres suppose nothyng coueted desired libertie discharge wold refuse honorable offre imagin prince bloud royal brought thraldome restrained fro liberty liuyng farre kyn father farther fredes would geue diligent eare mocion whiche might restored bothe auncient preheminence possession seigniory yes yes maie sure neither cosulted matter deferred au swere therunto gently agreed saie writer affirme foure hundred thousande crounes paied deliueraunce although saie thre hundred thousande deliuered englande fraunce tyme bothe speakyng better englishe frenche also swearyng neuer beare armure kyng englande arriuall fraunce came duke burgoyne especiall frend gratifiyng thankyng hym libertie deliueraunce accordyng promes couencion maried faire lady toune sainct omers begat sonne whiche frenche kyng called lewes xii deliueraunce captiuitie forgat vncle ihon erle angolesme whiche pledge england debt duke lewes orleaunce father sithe laste yere kyng henry fourth story declared made frendes borowed money morgaged land set hym libertie brought hym countrey ihon engendered charles father fraunces firste name whiche death lewes xij obteined croune fraunce noted olde rauncor newly appeaced commonly spryng although vnhappie deuision betwene two noble family orleaunce burgoyn wer great benefite mariage tyme geuen ouer put obliuion continued space xx yeres yet child cosyns within many yeres fell far square hous burgoyne spoyled fairest flower garland shall afterwarde large declared especiall tyme kyng fraunces firste verie heire hous orleaunce whiche onely continually vexed mortall warre charles fift emperor name lineall successor phillip duke burgoyne also asmuche hym laye depriue thesaid charles honor possession men writyng life wil hereafter declare frenche writer affirme duke orleaunce deteined thus long captiuitie reason englishemen gayned yerely hym greate somes money reason greate liberall expense whiche made daily realme england true report indifferent reasonable persones spende goodes frely lande enemie whiche maie pinchyng bearyng lowe saile waxe riche set libertie proude wast consume substauce liuyng prodigally maie sparyng thesame deliuered captiuitie bodage surely apparaunt reuenewes seigniory wer neither able raunsome hym mainteyne hym popeous estate partly thenglishmen possessed diuerse tounes belongyng duchy partly reason rente wer scace able defende possession inuasions englishe nacion burgonions cause long deteinyng wer two one lacke money second principall cause haue heard ihon duke burgoyne father phillippe shamefully cruelly caused lewes duke orleaunce father duke charles nowe speake murthered citee paris whiche murder al alies frendes duke orleaunce enuie hous familie burgoyne somuche thesaied duke ihon b yng measured thesame measure met likewise tyrannou ly murdered bridge mounstreau faultyou haue also heard declared whiche cause reuenged heynous act duke phillip sonne thesaid ihon onely ioyned hymself league amitie englishe nacion also homage sweare fealtie kyng henry fifth kyng souereigne lorde whiche cause englishemen entendyng kepe duke burgoyn trusty treasure sure iuell perceiued thei deliuered duke orleaunce set hym libertie would cease vexe trouble duke burgoyne reuengyng detestable murder committed father parent wherfore bothe surety sauegard duke burgoyne also hym pleasure thei kepte still duke orleaunce englande demaundyng suche raunsome neither able could finde meanes way paie duke burgoyn like vntrue prince vnhonest gentleman broken promes kept faith turned frenche part counsaill kyng englande studied deuised deliuer duke orleaunce displeasure duke burgoyn duke phillip perceiuyng mischief like rise wer redemed set libertie without knowledge preuete matter greate coste charge practised deliueraunce paied rausome ioyned amitie alliance mariage niece rehersed meanes duke charles orleaunce restored libertie whiche prisoner england daie sainctes crispin crispinian yere lorde mccccxv monethe nouembre yere thousand foure hundred fourtie pthe xix yerethe xix yere beginnyng xix yere richard duke yorke regent fraunce gouernor normandy remembryng greate charge weightie office hym deliuered committed determined long consultacion inuade territory enemy bothe sondery army diuerse place thentent frenche people vexed within awne coutrey peculiar dominion make rodes enterynges duchie normandy returnyng whereof somewhat suspicious deuise season semed bothe profitable necessary wherefore without long delaiyng tyme sente robert lorde willoughby greate crue souldiors inuade destroye countrey aboute amia ihon lord talbot appoynted besiege toune deape hymself accompanied edmond duke somerset set forward duchie aniow lorde willoughby accordyng commission entered countrey hym appoynted thentent commission espied knowen straightly forbad inhibited al maner fire burnyng tounes whiche moste open plain token war inuasion reason wherof pore paysautes rustical people goyng abrode without feare suspicion euill wer ouer ronne taken horssemen thei could attain toune forcelet innumerable people wer slain taken thei heard tydynges enemy approchyng frenchman garrisos adioynyng astonnied clamor cry poore people issued good ordre manfully set enemy fight sore victory long doubtfull inconclusio frenchman seyng people forefront battaill killed without mercie like men desperate turned ba kes fearfully fled englishman folowed slewe many chace suche escaped sweard wer robbed spoyled lewes erle sainct paule whiche commyng ayde englishe nacion conflicte slain aboue sixe c men armes greater nombre taken lorde willoughby like victorious capitain riche spoyle good prisoner returned citee roan duke yorke somerset likewise entered duchie aniow countie mayne destroiyng tounes spoylyng people great prey profite repaired normandy duke somerset filled gain entered march britayne tooke fierce assaute toune gerche apperteinyng duke alaunson spoyled brent thesame departed ponzay wher soiourned two monethes fro whence sent daily men war whiche destroyed wasted countreys aniow traonnoys chatragonnoys frenche kyng haste sent marshall loyache iiiim men resist inuasions duke somerset whiche capitain determined set duke people dedde tyme night enterprise secret reueled duke whiche marched forward mette frenchemen halfe waie long fight fine force manfully discomfited slew hundred persones mo tooke captiues lxii whereof chief wer lorde dausigny sir lewes de buell almoste knightes esquire encountre duke tooke toune beaumot le uicount manned fortress frontier enemy riche boties wealthy captiues came duke yorke dvryng fortunate chaunces victory lord talbot also vnweried chieftain maly warrior enuironed toune deape depe trench terrible mountaynes set vp vpon mount de poulet strong defensible bastile whiche tyme capitain thesame toune charles de maretz man force battaill pollitique defence siege englishemen beyng small nobre deliuered faire wordes fainte stroke castle charlemesnyll diuerse fortress adioynyng toune duryng siege many encounter many great assautes geuen thenglishemen sometyme saued somtyme gained moste losse lighted frenchemen awhile iii captaines sent furth one tyme haue heard cannot returne egall honor euen botie lorde talbot perceiuyng toune deape strongly defended men vitaile ordenaunce lacked thesaid furniture accomplisshyng stoute enterprise deliuered custody bastile gouernaunce iege bastarde sonne valeaunt young man departed roan ayde money municions frenche kyng quickely aduertised lord talbot absence estate englishemen wherefore without delaye meanyng lose great prey sent eldest sonne lewes dolphyn uyen accompan ed bastarde orleaunce called erle dumoys diuerse noble fraunce nombre xv thousande persones well armed lesse garnished thynges necessary purpose three day thei assayled bastile many tymes thei put backe poulder failed fortresse weapon wherwith defend scant conclusion englishman wer vanqueshed bastile taken bastard talbot sir william peytow sir ihon repeley whiche shortely redemed englishe souldiors seyng bastile gayned stoode daie good ordre battaill night pollitiquely returned roan without losse damage assaute frenchemen say thei slewe two hundred englishemen deny thei lost fiue hundred persones meanes one nacion loste bastile saued toune greate displeasure lorde talbot whose presence would asmuche auailed attempte absence losse detrement frendes felowes war chiualrie gain alwaies perdurable losse alwaies continuall vvhile thynges wer doyng phillip duke burgoyn hauyng enuious hart glory fortunate successe englishe people intending bereue one assured frendes called lewes luxenborough erle sainct poule made sharpe war vpon countreis toke diuerse tounes fortress hym conclusion feare loue vtterly refused faithe promise made duke bedford brother law turned frenche parte became luke warme enemie realme england losse frend necessary neighbor alitle greued kyng henry counsaill howbeit thei made suche purueiaunce prouision descrete counsail euil would theim litle good yet malice doo theim greate hurte damage englishe capitaines beyng guyen hauyng knowledge valeaut doynges countreymen realme frauce determined notable noble enterprise french costes adioynyng aquitayn thei besieged strong toune tartas belongyng lorde delabreth old auncient enemie capitaines gouernors toune consideryng weakenesse force englishemen toke appoyntment englishe capitaines toune remain neuter assuraunce therof thei deliuered cadet sonne lorde delabreth pledge vpon condicion lorde delabrethe would assent agrement signifie refusall englishe capitaines within three monethes next ensuyng haue pledge thei beste frenche kyng request lordes guyen whiche wer able defende themselfes toke matter hand caused lord delabreth certifie disagrement erle huntyngdon lieuetenaunt kyng englande duchie aquitayne please great lordes guyen assembled lxm men came tholose tartas chieftaines toune seyng succor commyng rendered toune cadet delabrethe whiche lefte pledge deliuered french kyng yeldyng tartas remoued sainct seuere strong toune gascoyn smally peopled men warre whiche toke force slewe thre hundred persones toke sir thomas rampstone prisoner toune gained power besieged citie arques toke bulwarke thesame whiche smally defended sone gotten inhabitauntes toune began sore afraied came lorde mountferrant capitain kyng england requiryng hym haue mercie vpon rendre toune frenche kyng vpon honest couenaunt coposicion capitain perceiuyng faint harte gascoyns knowyng without ayde able resist puyssaunce frenche kyng toke agrement departed englishe crue burdeaux found erle longuile capdaw bueffe sir thomas rampstone whiche alitle deliuered fortress ryoll mermandie yelded frenche kyng although tounes thus submitted theim hym yet long made muche tariyng duchie guyen englishemen onely prohibited gascoynes minister armie viandre sustenaunce also gat handes toke suche vitailes wer conueyed tholo e poytiers maner constrained famyn lacke prouision retired army fraunce whose departure englishe capitaines recouered citee acques tounes french kyng gained toke prisoner lieuetenaunt called reignault guillam burgonyo many gentleman meane souldiors wer either slain hanged vvhile frenche kyng guyen lorde talbot toke toune couchete marched toward gayllardon whiche besieged bastarde orleaunce erle dumoys whiche erle hearyng englishmennes approchyng reysed siege saued hymself alitle enterprise frenchemen taken toune eureux treason fisher sir fraunces arragonoys hearyng chaunce apparreled sixe strong men like rustical people sackes baskettes carrier corne vitaile sent castle cornyll whiche diuerse englishemen kept prisoner imbusshement englishemen laye valey nye fortresse sixe companion entered castle vnsuspected mistrusted straight came chambre capitain laied handes vpo hym geuyng knowledge therof imbushement whiche sodainly entered castle slew toke frenchemen prisoner set libertie englishemen whiche thyng doen thei set castle fire departed great spoyle cit e roan thus lady victory somtyme smiled englishe part sometyme frenche side thus one gayned daie loste nexte thus fortune chaunged thus chaunce happened accordyng old prouerbe saiyng war nothyng certain victory euer doubtfull pthe xx yerethe xx yere let v leaue marciall feactes mortal stroke daily skirmish practised betwene english frenche nacion region fraunce speake alitle smoke rose england whiche grewe greate fire terrible flame destruccion many noble man haue heard duke gloucester sore grudged proude doynges cardinall wynchester howe cardinall likewise sore enuied disdayned rule duke gloucester meanes duke bedforde malice appeaced eche reconciled perfite loue amitie men outward iudgementes whiche concord made cardinall archebishop yorke many thynges without consent kyng duke beyng duryng minoritie prince gouernor protector realme wherwith duke like true harted prince neither contente pleased declared writyng kyng certain article wherin cardinal archebishop offended bothe kyng lawes true tenor ensueth pa complaint made kyng henry vj duke gloucester vpon cardinall winchester bee parte poyntes article whiche humfrey duke gloucester trouthe acquitall saied late would geue writyng right doubted lorde vnto highnes aduertisyng excellece suche thinges partie haue doen tendre age derogacion noble estate hurt realmes yet doen vsed daily first cardinall beyng bishop winchester toke vpo hym state cardinall whiche nayed denayed hym kyng moste noble memory lorde father god assoyle saiyng yt lefe set croune beside hym se hym weare cardinal hat beyng cardinal knewe full wel pride ambicion person beyng bishop haue greatly extolled hym intollerable pride cardinall also though fredome chiefe churche realme whiche worshipped duely euer prince blessed soule howbeit saied lorde father god assoyle would haue agreed hym haue certain clerkes land cardinal haue bishoprikes englande yet intent neuer great derogacion churche caterbury make wer suffraganes set aboue ordinary metropolitan cause ingenerall matter whiche might concerne weale hym realme haue proctor nacion kynges christen courte rome abide lande parte counsailes spirituall temporall parliamentes great counsailes list cal therfore though please hym worship set hym priuie counsaill pleasure yet parliament wher euery lorde bothe spirituall temporall hath place ought occupie place bishoppe item thesaied bishoppe beyng cardinall assoyled bishopricke wynchester wherupon sued vnto holy father haue bulle declaratory notwithstandyng assupt state cardinal sea voyde deede stode voyde certain tyme thesaied bulle graunted exempte ordinary takyng hym state cardinal churche bishopricke winchester standyng voyde tooke pope learned therof ne knowyng wherby fallen cace prouision al good lawfully clearly forfeited right doubted lorde statute declareth plainly aduauntage item vnknowen doubted lord landes noysed thesaied cardinal tharchebishop yorke haue gouernaunce lande whiche none true liege men ought vsurpe take vpon haue also estranged sole vncle cosyn yorke cosyn huntyngdon many lordes kin haue knowledge greate matter might touche high estate either realmes lordes spirituall right archebishoppe cantorbury chief counsailer whiche also estranged set side many right sad lordes well aduised aswell spirituall temporall great hurt right doubted lorde realmes like experience workes shewen clerely euidently harme item tendre age right doubted lorde necessitie armie thesaied cardinal lent iiiiml vpon certain iuels preised xxiim marke letter sale thei wer quited certain daie lese saied cardinall seyng money redy haue quited iuels caused treasorer englande daie beyng paie thesame money parte another armie defraudyng right doubted lord said iuels kepyng theim yet alwaie awne vse right greate losse synguler profite auaile item thesaid cardinal beyng bishop winchester chau cellor englad deliuered kyng scottes vpo certein appoyntmentes maie shewed presumpteously awne authoritie contrary acte parliament haue heard notable men lawe say thei neuer heard like thyng doen emong whiche great defamacio highnes also wedde niece thesaid kyng lord notable memory father god assoile would neuer haue deliuered haue paied costes xlml thesaied cardinall chauncellor englande caused pardon hym therof xm marke wherof greater paied right alitle report highnes item thesaid cardinal lent redoubted lord great notable somes hath assignes rule profite porte hapton wher customer seruautes wher likelihode supposed standyng chief marchaunt wolles lande bee greately defrauded vnder rule wolles marchaundise haue shipped maie tyme tyme hard esteme great hurte preiudice right doubted lorde people item howbeit thesaid cardinall hath diuerse tymes lent greate somme money sithe tyme reigne yet loene hath differred delaied moste part conuenable season themployng good lente passed litle frute none come thereof experience bothe realmes haue sufficiently knowledge item ieuelles plate preised ximl weight thesaied cardinall forfeited right doubted lorde gat hym restorment therof loene litle percell thesame defrauded wholy theim greate hurte auaile whiche good might greately eased highnes sparyng asmuche poore common item cardinall beyng feoft said lorde father god assoyle entent gaue elizabeth beauchampe thre c markes liuelod wer wedded within yere haue el deede twoo iii yeres great hurt diminishyng inheritaunce item notwithstandyng yt thesaid cardinall hath maner authoritie interest croune none may haue possibilitie yet presumeth taketh vpon hym partie estate royal callyng hym greate abusion al lande derogacion highnes whiche hath sene vsed day heretofore greater estate without expresse ordenaunce commaundement item thesaid cardinal nothyng consideryng necessitie right doubted lorde hath sued pardon dismes paie churche wynchester terme life geuyng therby occasion lordes spirituall drawe good necessitie graunt disme laie charge vpon temporaltie poore people item gouernaunce labor thesaied cardinal archebishop yorke hath loste dispended muche notable greate good diuerse ambassador sent realme first arras feined colourable peace likelinesse thought supposed neuer turne theffectual auaile right doubted lorde saied realmes vnder colour thereof made peace aduersary duke burgoyn el partie aduerse thesaid duke might well haue foud meanes way haue comoned together haue concluded cofederacios conspiracios made wrought ther tyme highnes whereby might haue right doubted lorde greater partie obeysaunce aswell realme fraunce duchie normandy muche thyng gone greatly thesaid colourable treatie otherwise sithe death brother bedford god assoyle item late set another ambassador calice labor counsaill thesaied cardinall archebishop yorke cause beginnyng sole vncle lordes kyn counsaill vnknowen greate charge publique good realme openly appeareth whiche good bee imployed defence landes marchaundises thesame might haue course said lades haue stande greate mischief thei item greate charge hurte bothe realmes thesaid cardinall archbishop yorke went saied toune calice diuerse lordes kyn counsaill felowship naturall warre betwene duke orleauce duke burgoyn murder father capitall nemnitie like haue endured euer thesaid cardinall archbishop yorke licenced suffered thesaid duke orleaunce entreate common part counsaiell said aduersaries aswell duchy burgoyne whiche meane peace alliaunce made betwene two duke greatest fortifiyng said capital aduersaries could thought cosequently deare redoubted lorde greatest charge hurt realmes colour whiche treatie said aduersaries meane time wan citee meulx coutrey therabout many diuerse rodes made youre duchie normandy great noysaunce destruccion people sheweth openly item thesaid archebishop yorke sent realme thesaied cardinall communicacion aduerse partie saied toune calice made commyng notable presence wyndsore swasions colour mocions apparaut wise could induce highnes agrement desire capitall aduersaries saw noble presence writyng whiche tyme vnderstode singuler opinion say leaue right title honor croune nominacio kyng frauce duryng certain yeres vtterly abstain content onely writyng rex anglie c greate note infamie euer fell noble progenitor since takyng first thesaid title right realme croune fraunce matter presence ther liked said highnes aske myne aduise therupon bloud cousaill aunswered said would neuer agree therto die therfore thesame disposicion yet liue conseruacion honor othe made vnto saied croune tyme coronacion item thesaied cardinall archebishop yorke haue labored vnto highnes entende newe daie conuencion marche aprill next commyng noysed worship euident world rupture breakyng thesaid peace haue fallen heretofore aduerse partie great vntrouthes meane like peraduenture laied vnto verie greate slaundre doubted lorde like come none purpose effecte conuencions haue doen afore tyme subtilities counsaill saied enemy lande thei hope trust thesaid treatie mightely puyssauntly purueyed shalbe like vnder coloure thesame treatie brent vp destroyed lost vtterly turned obeysaunce item saied deliueraunce thesaied duke orleaunce vtterly appointed mediacion counsaill steryng thesaied cardinall archebishoppe yorke cause diuerse person come aduersaries realme thesaied duke also brought citee london lord father god assoile peisyng greatly inconueniences harme might fal onely deliueraunce concluded ordened determined last wil vtterly wisedome co quest realme frauce yet doen great deliberacion solempnitie suretie maie deuised thought seyng disposicion realme fraunce puissauce might enemy ayde thei haue gotten aswel vnder colour thesaid treatie otherwise maie ought thought said laboryng thesaid duke al thynges considered suche perticular persones lordes bloud called therunto report vnto noble grace excellencie vnto thesaied wise trewe men realme item euery true counsailor specially vnto kyng prince ought trouth dutie counsail promote encrease prefer aduaunce weale prosperitie lorde thesaid cardinall beyng counsaill right doubted lorde hath late purchased highnes certain great landes liuelode castle lordship chirke wale lades realme vnto whiche called sodainly escheuyng breakyng losse army seyng none remedy gaue thervnto myne asset thinkyng euer labored moued stered matter firste vnto lordeship counsailed neither worship profite thesaied cardinall hath bounde parte make hym sure estate saied landes easter nexte commyng coulde bee deuised anye learned counsaill elles suretie made thesaied cardinall haue reioye heires euermore landes duchie lacastre norffolke value vii viiic markes yere whiche thyng semeth right straunge vnsene vnhard way liege man seke vpon souereigne lorde bothe enheritaunce iuelles good thought right extreme necessitie caused ought thynges doen fro necessitie god mercy euer preserue noble person wherfore redoubted lord seyng ye cousailed stired leaue croune enheritaunce england also fraude subtile meanes afore reher ed lose iuelles trouthe myne acquitall seameth maie ought counsaill greate hurte lande item vnknowen right doubted lorde often tymes haue offered seruice defence realme fraunce duchie normady haue put therfro labor thesaid cardinall preferryng singuler affeccion whiche hath caused greate parte thesaied duchie normandy aswell realme fraunce lost wel knowen good right doubted lord lost army last sent thether whiche therle mortayn counsaill fraunce hath well clerely declared highnes beforne item right doubted lorde vnknowen possible thesaied cardinall haue comen greate rich suche meanes churche might rise enheritaunce none wherefore right doubted lorde sithe great good behouefull tyme weale safegard realmes pouertie necessitie indigence liege people highnes vnderstande like vnto noble grace considre thesaid lucar thesaid cardinall greate deceiptes deceiued labor hym archebishop aswell realme realme fraunce duchy normandy neither office liuelode capitain maie without greate good geuen vnto hym wherby great part al losse lost thei haue causers would geue moste price consideryng merites seruice sufficiaunce persones furthermore greatly considered thesaied cardinal forfeited al good prouision statute thervpo plainly declareth hauyng rule right doubted lorde purchased hymself greate defraudacion highnes charter pardo whiche good wel gouerned might many yeres haue susteined warres without talage poore people item redoubted lorde write moche thyng weale realmes peraduenture say vnderstande woulde haue writen waye accusement al counsail whiche god knoweth highnes may well se name theim causers sayed inordinate rule wherfore considering sayd cardinal archebisshop yorke thei pretende gouernaunce realmes lordshippes please vnto highnes rightwisenesse estraunge counsail entent men maye fredome say thinke trueth truth dare speake truth poore dare cardinal archbisshop yorke may afterward declare selfes shalbe sayed right doubted lorde may restore agayn counsaill noble pleasure vvhen kyng heard accusacios comitted hearinge therof counsail wherof moste parte spiritual person feare fauour mater wynked dalyed nothing sayde fayre contenaunce made duke though displeasure ben taken malice borne either hart remembrauce agaynst hym venyme breake oute inwarde grudge sone appeare whiche yere men apparaunt diuers secrete attemptes aduauced forward season noble duke hufrey glocester farre whiche conclusio came nere thei bereft lyfe lande shall hereafter manifestly perceyue first yere dame elyanour cobha wyfe sayd duke accused treason sorcery enchautmet entended destroy kyng thentent aduauce promote husbande croune vpon thys examined sainct stephen chappel bisshop canterbury examinacion conuict iudged open penaunce iij open place within citie lo adiudged perpetuall prisone isle man vnder kepyng sir ihon staley knyght season wer arrested ayders counsailers sayde duchesse thomas southwel prieste chanon saincte stephen westmynster ihon hum priest roger bolyngbroke conyng nycromancier margerie iourdayne surnamed witche eye whose charge laied thei request duchesse deuised image waxe representyng kynge whiche sorcery litle litle co sumed entendyng therby coclusion waist destroy kynges person bryng hym death treison thei wer adiudged dye margery iordayne brent smithfelde roger bolyngbroke drawen quartered tiborne takyng vpo death neuer suche thyng theim ymagened ihon hum pardon southwel died toure execucion duke gloucester toke thynges paciently saied litle pthe yere counsaill englande forgat late enterprise freche kyng doen duchie guyen wherefore ifie countrey least peraduenture would attempt alike orney thei sent thether sir william wooduile viii hundred men fortifie frontier till greater armie might assembled farther made publique proclamacion men whiche would transporte cary corne chese vitaile party acquitayn pay maner custome tallage whiche louse ce caused countrey well furnished thynges necessarie conuenient season kyng remembryng valeaunt seruice noble actes ihon lorde talbot created hym erle shrewesburie company three men sente hym normandy better tuicion whiche neither forgat dutie forslowed businesse daily labored hourely studied molest damage enemy yere died guyen countesse comyng frenche kyng also erle arminacke pretended heire insomuche erle entered al landes thesaied lady inheritor right tooke homage people countrey haue rowland resist oliuer sent solempne ambassador kyng englande offeryng hym doughter mariage onely promisyng hym siluer hilles golden mountaines also would bound deliuer kyng englandes handes suche castle tounes auncestors deteined hym within whole duchie acquitayn guyen either conquest progenitor gyfte deliuery freche kyng offryng farther aide thesame kyng money recouery citees within thesaied duchy auncestors frenche kynges progenitor lorde de albrethe lordes gascoyn iniustely kept wrongfully withhoulden offre semed bothe profitable honorable kyng henry realme ambassador wer bothe well heard louyngly enterteined conclusion gentle aunswere without great rewardes thei departed countrey wer sent conclusion thesaied mariage guyen sir edward hulle sir robert roos doctor ihon grafton deane sainct seuerines honorable company whiche englishe cronographiers affirme bothe concluded mariage proxie aff ed young lady frenche kyng ignoraunt conclusion wherfore disdainyng erle arminacke bothe vsurpe hym countie comyng also ioyne hymself mortall enemie kyng englande recouer right punishe rebell sent lewes eldest sonne dolphyn uyen rouergne puissaunt army whiche sodainly toke erle arminacke isle iordayne yongest sonne bothe doughters force obteined countreis arminacke lonuergne rouergne moullesson beside citees seuerac cadenac chased bastarde arminacke countrey costituted gouernor seigniory sir theobald de walpergne bailif lyon reason infortunate chauce mariage concluded differred yea long differred neuer toke effect shall heare plainly declared pthe xxii yerethe xxii yere thus englande vnquieted fraunce sore vexed spoyle slaughter burnyng christendom lamented continuall destruccion noble realme effusion muche christen bloud wherfore appeace mortall warre long contineuyng betwene twoo puyssaunt kynges prince christendom muche labored trauailed orator ambassador frostie harte bothe party wer somewhat mollified indurate stomackes greatly asswaged greate diete appoynted kepte citee tour tourayne kyng englande appered william de la pole erle suffolke doctor adame molyns keper kynges priuie seale robert lorde roos diuerse frenche kyng appoynted charles duke orleauce lewes de burbon erle uandos e greate master frenche kynges housholde sir pier de bresell stewarde poytou bartram beauriau lorde precignye also sente thither ambassador empire spayne denmarke fro hungary mediator betwene twoo prince assemble greate coste muche greater somuche euery parte honor prince praise countrey set furth themselfes aswell fare apparel vttermoste poynt highest prike many metynges wer many thynges moued come finall peace mutuall concord inconclusion many
