doubtes greate ambiguity whiche rose bothe party finall concord could agreed hope come peace certain truce aswell sea land concluded comissioners xviij monethes whiche afterward againe prolonged yere lorde miiiicxlix meane season violated broken shalbe declared treatyng truce erle suffolke extendyng comission vttermoste without assent associate imagened phantasie nexte waie come perfite peace moue mariage betwene frenche kynges kynsewoman kyng henry souereigne frenche kyng doughter ripe age coupled matrimony kyng master desired haue lady margaret cosyn frenche kyng doughter reyner duke aniow callyng hymself kyng scicile naples hierusalem hauyng onely name stile without peny profite fote possessio mariage made straunge therle good space somuche repented hym first mocio yet like bold man entendyng take afoile greate matter desisted still daily sollicite aduaunce forward cause wily frenchemen perceiuyng ardent affeccion erle toward conclusion mariage declared hym mariage like come conclusion desired kyng master occupied greate parte duchie aniow citee mauns whole countey mayne apperteynyng thei saied kyng reyner father damosell erle suffolke cannot saie either corrupted bribe muche affeccionate vnprofitable mariage condiscended agreed mocion duchie aniow countie mayne released deliuered kyng father demaundyng mariage neither peny farthyng would saie newe affinitie excelled rich surmounted gold precious stone thentent truce might ensue finall concorde daie enteruie e metyng appoynted betwene two kynges place couenient betwene charter roan thynges wer concluded erle suffolke company thinkyng haue brought ioyfull tidynges whole realme englande departed toures long iorneis arriued douer came kyng westminster openly kyng counsail declared taken honorable truce sauegard normandy wealth realme whiche truce thought yea doubted perpetual peace finall concorde shortely proceade growe muche soner honorable mariage inuincible alliaunce godly affinitie whiche concluded omittyng nothyng whiche might extoll setfurth personage ladie forgettyng thyng nobilitie kinne father high stile would saie suche excellent beautie high parentage almoste king emperor worthy make although mariage pleased well kyng diuerse counsaill especially suche wer adherentes fautors erle suffolke yet humfrey duke gloucester protector realme repugned resisted muche hym laie new alliaunce contriued matrimonie alledgyng neither consonaunt lawe god man honorable prince infrynge breake promise contracte hym made concluded vtilitie profite realme people declaryng kyng ambassador sufficiently instructed authorised cocluded cotracted mariage betwene highnes doughter therle arminacke vpon condicions bothe hym realme asmuche profitable honorable whiche offer codicions thesaid erle sith commyng captiuitie thraldome redy yelde performe saiyng conueniente prince marie wife rich frendes take make nothyng disherite hymself realme olde rightes auncient seigniory duke heard erles doynges condiscended vnto allowed whiche facte engendered suche flame neuer wente till bothe party many wer consumed slain great vnquietnes kyng realme performaunce conclusion frenche kyng sent erle uandos e greate master hous archebishop reyns first pere fraunce diuerse england whiche wer ioyously receiued frendly entertayned ambassador instrumentes bothe party sealed deliuered vnteward returned countrey thynges thus doen kyng bothe honor realme assure hymself speciall frendes created lorde ihon holand erle huntyngdon duke excester father humfrey erle stafford made duke buckyngham henry erle warwicke erected title duke warwicke erle suffolke made marque suffolke whiche marque wife many honorable personage men woman richely adorned bothe apparell iuels hauyng many costly chariottes gorgious horselitters sailed fraunce conueyaunce nominated quene realme england kyng reyner father al long stile short purse send doughter honorably kyng spouse pthe xxiii yerethe xxiii yere noble company came citee toures tourayne thei honorably receiued bothe frech kyng kyng scicile wher marque suffolke procurator kyng henry espoused thesaid ladie churche sainct martyns whiche mariage present father mother bride frenche kyng hymself whiche vncle husbande frenche quene also whiche awnte wife wer also duke orleaunce calaber alaunson britayn vii erles xii baron xx bishoppes beside kinghtes gentleman wer triumphaunt iustes costly feastes delicate banquette pleasure hath ende euery ioye continuall high solempnities finished honorable ceremony ended marque ladie margaret hym deliuered whiche greate estate coueyed normandy deape transported englande landed portesmouthe mone aprill woman excelled aswell beautie fauor wit pollicie stomack corage like man woman sone arriuall conueyed toune southwike hamshire nupciall ceremony coupled matrimony kyng henry vi name whiche mariage greate triumphe conueyed london westminster vpo xxx daie may al solempnitie thervnto apperteinyng crouned quene noble realme englande would knowe costly receipt pleasaunt companie gorgeous apparell diuersitie instrumentes strauge pagiauntes behauior lordes beautie lady sumptuous feast delicate viander marcial iustes fierce turnais lustie daunces minio soges wer shewed setfurth practised coronacion let hym loke chronicle london robert fabian shal finde set furth ful mariage semed many bothe infortunate vnprofitable realme england many cause first kyng one peny fetchyng marque suffolke demaunded whole fiftene open parliament also mariage duchie aniow citee mauns whole cou tie mayne deliuered released kyng reyner father whiche countreis wer stayes backestandes duchy normandy furthermore mariage erle arminacke toke suche great displeasure became vtter enemy realme englande chief cause englishman wer expulsed whole duchie acquitayne lost bothe countreis gascoyn guyen moste seme god matrimony content spousage kynges frendes fell hym bothe englande fraunce lordes realme fell diuision emongest themselfes common rebelled souereigne lorde naturall prince feldes foughten many thousandes slain finally kyng deposed sonne slain quene sent home asmuche misery sorowe receiued pompe triumphe suche worldly vnstablenes waueryng false flatteryng fortune dvryng tyme truce richard duke yorke diuerse capitaines repaired england bothe visite wife child frendes also consulte doen truce ended pthe xxiiii yere whiche causethe xxiiii yere kyng called high court parliament whiche aboue thynges concluded diligently forsee normandy well furnished strongly defended terme truce expired openly knowen french kyng ready thynges make open warre peace abstinence warre wer agreed concluded whiche consideracion money graunted men wer appoynted great armie gathered together duke somerset appoynted regent normandy duke yorke thereof discharged whiche parliament please people al enacted yt whe whete sold visviii quartr rye iiiis barly iii lawfull euery cary thesaid kyndes corne party beyond sea without licence wer kynges enemy rebelles whiche act kyng edward iiii vtilitie people approued confirmed marque suffolke beyng high fauor kyng lesse grace quene margaret cocludyng mariage betwene theim twoo somewhat infected sede vainglory thinkyng procedynges dooynges fraunce duryng tyme legacion aswell pleased men thei pleased hymself second daie iune first session parliament lordes spirituall temporall higher house assembled ope ly loquently boldely declared pain trauaile diligece whiche taken susteined late tyme realme fraunce aswel takyng concludyng truce abstinence warre betwene realmes englande fraunce makyng mariage betwene kyng souereigne lorde noble prince lady margarete daughter kyng scicile hierusalem openyng also thesaid truce expire first daie april next commyng except finall peace farther truce wer concluded meane season aduisyng prouide fors e thynges necessarie warre though concorde succede agrement could take place least frenchemen perceiuyng theim vnprouided would take aduauntage agree neither reason amitie saiyng vnto theim sithe admonished kyng accordyng duetie allegeaunce thyng quailed daunger ensued thereof innocent gilteles acquited hymself like louyng subiecte faithfull counsailor praiyng lordes haue remembraunce likewise morowe certain lordes discended comon house declared thesaied matter knightes citezens burgess omittyng nothyng might sounde glory openyng thing whiche might redound dispraise praiyng co mon discharge aswell doynges procedynges kynges affaire beyond sea also aduertisement counsaill opened lordes common together assembled might kyng theim enacted enrolled recordes parliament wherupon morowe william burley speaker common company nether house repaired kinges presence sittyng trone emongest lordes parliament chamber thesaied william burley counsaill common whether thei feare loue wer therevnto entised marque frendes men doubted moste hu blie commended kynges highnes foresaid marque suf olke actes notable woorkes whiche doen pleasure almightie god honor kyng vtilitie realme takyng truce concludyng mariage good admonicion geuen hym open parliament prouision warre made duryng tyme truce least muche trustyng peace might encorage frenchemen soner begyn warre inuasio besechyng kynges highnes name common imprint harte remebraunce thesaid marque labor actes honor renoume whiche exaple al whiche kyng call like seruice employ themselfes like endeuor faithfully honorably serue kyng souereigne lorde praiyng also lordes spirituall temporall thei consideracions rehersed would vouchesaue make like peticio kynges e rie actes demeanor thesaied marque might aucthoritie parliamet honor perpetuall fame rolles thesame parliament recorded substancially regestered whiche humble intercession lordes aswell spirituall temporal rose seates knee made kyng like request peticion thei common wer desired wherupon kyng mouthe archebishop canterbury chancellor made answere requestes wer reasonable honorable wise could louyngly accept gently alowe thesame saiyng also desire wer singuler pleasure especiall comforte would thencefurthe accepte take thesaied marque benigne grace especiall fauoure persone whiche dooen bothe true faithefull notable seruice hym realme intent al men put like trust enforce theim selfes doo like better seruice souereigne lorde master agreyng also accordyng requestes peticions labor demeanor diligence declaracions thesaied marque suffolke thesaied commendacions desire lordes also common aswel honor hym posteritie acquital discharge enacted enrolled recordes thesame parliament whiche doen marque thus gotten vp fortune trone content degree meanes quene shortely erected estate degree duke ruled kyng pleasure muche obteined wardshippes bothe body landes coutesse warwicke lady margarete sole heire ihon duke somerset whiche lady mother kyng henry seuenth beside caused kyng create ihon de foys sonne gaston de foys erle longuile capdaw bueffez erle kendale whiche iho maried niece procurement kyng elected order garter thesaid gaston ihon sonne geuyng sonne towardes maintenaunce degree estate landes castle duchie guyen amountyng one thousand poundes yere whiche landes name stile issue line thesaied erle endall daie haue enioye man maie beholde securitie worldly glory constancie fortune smilyng duke suffolke open parliament lordes praised common thanked kynges fauor entierly receiued within foure yeres thesame place common realme accused many treason mispricions offence doen committed kyng common wealthe realme conclusion beyng exiled realme taken vpon sea made shorter hedde whiche chaunce happened hym remembred counsail popyngay saiyng thou thynkest thy self courte moste surest high tyme get thee home rest thynges beyng doyng frenche kyng seyng toune mauns diuerse fortress mayne hym deliuered accordyng appoyntment made gathered together great numbre people recouer thesame wherof kyng england beyng aduertised least breache truce begynne hym caused toune deliuered without force yere armerars suruaunt london appeled master treason whiche offered bee tried battaill daie assigned frendes master brought hym malmesey aqua vite comforte hym cause discomforte poured muche came place smithfelde fight bothe witte strength failed hym beyng tall hardye personage ouerladed hote drynkes vanqueshed seruaunte beyng cowarde wretche whose body drawen tiborne hanged behedded whiche yere greate insurreccion norwiche prior place muche citezens kepte gate duke norffolke whiche came thither appea e matter conclusion thei opened gate submitted theimselfes chief offender wer accordyng desertes straightly punished executed maire discharged office sir ihon clifton made gouernoure till kyng restored citezens auncient liberty francheses commocion certain newe exaccions whiche prior claimed toke citezens contrary auncient fredomes vsages dewe meane come right purpose therefore thei erred wente pathe thei punishemente brought straight trade right waie pthe xxv yerethe xxv yere duryng tyme truce abstinence warre nothyng vexe trouble myndes men within realme sodain mischief long discorde sprang sodainly meanes woman kyng henry whiche reigned tyme man meke spirite symple witte preferryng peace warre reste businesse honestie profite quietnesse laboure intent men might perceiue could none chaste meke holy better creature hym reigned shamefastnesse modestie integritie pacience bee marueiled takyng sufferyng loss chaunces displeasure suche worldely tormentes good parte acient maner though thei chaunced awne fault negligent ouersight yet gouerned haue ruled brideled suche sharpely haue spurred gaped honor thristed rich studied onely health soule sauyng wherof estemed bee greate wisedome losse thereof extremest folie could parte quene wife woman greate witte yet greater witte haute stomacke desirous glory couetous honor reason pollicye counsaill giftes talentes nature belongyng man full flowyng witte wilinesse lacked nothyng diligence studie businesse vnexperte yet one poynt woman often tyme vehemet fully bente matter sodainly like wethercocke mutable turnyng woman perceiuyng husbande frankely rule would thyng thaduise counsaill hu frey duke gloucester passed muche aucthority gouernaunce realme determined self take vpon rule regiment bothe kyng kyngdome depriue euict al rule aucthoritie thesaid duke called lord protector realme least men shoud saie report yt neither wit stomacke whiche would permit suffre husband beyng perfect age ma estate like yong scholer innocent pupille gouerned disposicion another man manly woman coragious quene ceased prosecute furthwith inuented imaginacion prepesed purpose practised daily furtheraunce thesame although inuecio came first awne high mynd ambicious corage yet furthered set forward suche long tyme borne malice duke declaryng vntruth haue heard whiche venemous serpentes malicious tygers perswaded incensed exhorted quene loke well vpon expense reuenues realme thereof call accompt affirmyng plainly euidently perceiue duke gloucester muche aduaunced preferred commo wealth publique vtilitie awne priuate thinges peculiar estate beside reyner kyng scicile wrote doughter husband take vpon rule gouernaunce realme kept vnder like yong wardes desolate orphanes quene perswaded encoraged meanes toke vpo husbande ye high power aucthoritie ouer people subiectes although ioyned husbande hir name countenaunce yet saied bare whole swynge strong oxe doth whe yoked plough pore silly asse firste excluded duke gloucester rule gouernaunce prohibityng suche knewe mortal enemy inuent imagyne cause griefes hym permissio fauor diuerse noble men conspired hym whiche diuerse writer affirme marque suffolke duke buckyngham bee chiefe vnprocured cardinall winchester archebishop yorke diuerse article bothe heynous odious laied charge open counsaill especiall one caused men adiudged dye put execucion law land ordered assigned surely duke beyng well learned lawe iuill detestyng malefactor punishyng offence gat great malice hatred suche feared haue condigne reward vngracious actes mischeuous doynges although duke without great laude praise sufficiently answered thynges hym obiected yet death determined wisedom litle helped truth smally auailed vnquietnes mynde deliuered hymself thought neither death condempnacion dye suche affiaunce strong truthe suche confidence indifferent iustice capitall enemy mortal foe fearyng tumulte commocion might arise prince well beloued people bee openly executed put death determined trappe vndoo hym thereof haue knowledge warnyng furtherauce purpose parliament somoned kept bery whether resorted peres realme mongest duke gloucester whiche second daie session lorde beamond high constable englande accompanied duke buckyngha arrested apprehended put warde seruauntes sequestered hym xxxii chief retinue sent diuerse prison greate admiracion common people duke night emprisonement found dedde bed body shewed lordes common though died palsey empostome indifferent person well knewe died natural death violet force iudged hym strangled affirme hote spitte put foundement write stiffeled smoldered betwene twoo fetherbeddes whose deathe none seruauntes although thei wer arraigned attainted wer put death marque suffolk thei haue executed shewed openly pardon doyng appeased grudge people whiche saied pardone seruauntes amendes murderyng master dedde corse duke caried sainct albons honorably buried thus noble prince sonne brother vncle kynges whiche valeauntly pollitiquely space xxv yeres gouerned realme demerites called good duke gloucester bone caste enemy choked brought fatall fine last ende al men maie openly se men aucthorit e place courte cheif refuge dwellyng house yet mannes priuate castle bed ordeined quietnes daunger deathes dart semeth many men name title gloucester hath vnfortunate vnluckie diuerse whiche honor haue erected creacion prince si le dignitie hugh spenser thomas woodstocke sonne kyng edward third duke humfrey whiche thre person miserable death inished day kyng richard iij also duke gloucester ciuill warre slain confounded name gloucester take vnhappie vnfortunate stile prouerbe speaketh seianes horse whose rider euer vnhorsed whose possessor euer brought miserie rumor duke death blowen realme many wer sodainly appalled amased feare many abhorred detested faict men reputed abhominable crueltie shameful tiranny publique wealth realme englande vnworthy death pollitique prince susteined greate losse ran ruyne surely whole waight burden realme rested depeded vpo experience afterward declare death good sage men fearyng selfes fled flatteryng court whose place entered suche desiryng awne promocion set open gate new faccions whiche could neuer extinct til seignories beyod sea except caleice march lost kyng hery conclusion spoyled hys realme lyfe olde sayd saw man enteding auoide smoke falleth fyre quene mynding preserue husbad honor selfe aucthoritie procured consentid death noble man whose onely death brought passe thynge woulde fayne haue eschewed toke iewel whiche moste desired duke lyued duke yorke durst haue made title crowne duke liuyd noble conspired king yet comos rebelled duke lyued house lacaster defaced destroyed thynges hapned contrary destruccio good man worldly iudgemet god knoweth predestinate ordeined againste whose ordinaunce preuayleth counsaill whose auayleth stryuinge pthe xxvi yerethe xxvi yere xxvi yere reign kynge first yere rule quene fynde thyng done worthye rehersed within realme englande marque suffolke greate fauor kynge desire quene erected title name duke suffolke whiche dignitie shorte tyme enioied degre briefe seaso possessed deposicion rather destruccion good duke gloucester exaltacion aduauncement glorious man rychard duke yorke beyng greatly alied wyfe chefe peres potentate realme ouer besyde hys awne progenye greate consanguinitie perceyuing kyng ruler ruling whole burden realme depend ordinauces quene duke suffolke began secretly allure hys frendes nobilitie priuatly declared hys title right crowne lykewyse dyd certain wyse saige gouernors ruler dyuers city townes priuie attept politiquely handeled secretly kept hys prouisio ready purpose openly published hys frendes opened theim selfes contrary parte coulde espye conclusion tyme reueled truth olde hyd hatred openly sprange shall hereafter bothe lament heare dvring doynges henry beaufford bishop winchester called ryche cardinall departed world buryed wynchester man sonne ihon gaunte duke lancaster disceded honorable lignage borne baste noble blodd notable learning haut stomacke hygh coutenaunce ryche aboue measure men fewe liberal disdaynfull hys kynne dreadfull louers preferrynge money frendshippe many thinges beginning nothing perfourmyng hys couetous insaciable hope long lyfe made hym forget god hys prynce hym selfe hys latter day doctor ihon baker hys pryuie counsailler chappelleyn wrote lyeng death bed sayd wordes dye hauig muche ryches whole realme wolde saue lyfe able either pollicie get ryches bye fye death hyered money nothyng nephew bedford died thought selfe halfe vp whele sawe myne nephew gloucester disceased thought self able equale kinges thought encrease treasure hoope haue worne tryple croune se worlde faileth deceyued praiyng pray gettyng mannes goodes power legantye spiritual bryberie wil speake kepinge ambycious purpose aspiryng ascend papisticall sea bothe great losse naturall prince natyue countrey hidde ryches might haue wel holpen king secrete treasure migth haue releued comonaltie whe money scante importunate charge dayly imminent death prelate great stay kyng realme affayres fraunce neither well loked gouernours countrey well aduised englishe capitayn called syr franceys surrien arragonoys man witt actiuitie admitted ordre gartier toke scalynge sodaynly night towne frontier normandie belonging duke britayn called fongiers spoyling kyllinge inhabitautes great distruccion people displeasure duke britayn souereigne lorde duke beynge thereof aduertysed sent woorde frenche kynge declaringe time truce allye vassal coprehendyd spoyled bereuyd towne fongiers besechyng frenche kynge cause se recompense amendemente whereupon sent ihon hauart caruar ihon cosynet one master requestes kyng england duke somerset dispatched peter de fountaynes esquyer one cheife stable whome prince aunswered facte enterprise bothe done contrary mynde knowledge truce kept onely restitucion also amendes made duke britayn daye dyet assemble appoynted kept town louiers time appointed bothe party assembled frenche parte demaunded amendes litle recompense englishe orator aunswered without offece thing iustice ought satisfied affirming doynge syr francyes surrien onely acte withoute consent counsail either kynge england duke somerset lieuetenat regent duringe dayly communicacio longe delaye certain frenchemen frendes duke britayn desyring reuenged iniurie done fongiers also imagening new displeasure englishme aduertised wagoner louiers yt town poutelarche meanly manned slenderly furnished watche negligently loked whiche saiynges frenchemen beynge somwhat encouraged deuised waye howe pollicie take towne wagoner laded wagon passed forward hauinge company stronge varlettes clad lyke carpenter greate ax neckes furtherace purpose lord bressy chosen company men armes lodged selfe busshement nere gate sainct andrewe capitayn floquet accompanied syr iames cleremout another great company priuilie lurked vnder wood toward louiers al thinges appoynted early morning beginning moneth october wagoner came gate called porter name praiyng open gate mighte passe roen returne agayne night porter whiche wel knew voice customer toke litle hede ij copaignions opened gate sent another felow ope ormost gate whe ye chariotte draw bridge betwene ye gate chariottemaster gaue porter money none let one pece fal grounde whyle porter stoped take vp wagoner dagger stroke throte cried healpe ij greate lubber slewe porter ax cutte aexletre wagone drawe bridge could shortlye drawen vp thinges done made signe capitayne floquet whiche without delay tract time entered town lew toke englishman neither heard thought suche enterprise emongest lord fauconbridge capitaine saide towne apprehended prisoner praty cautele lyghte imposture towne poutelarche take surprised towne kay passage ouer ryuer soame fro frauce normandy beyng distant fro roen onely iiii leages thus wrong added wrong iniurie heped iniurie wherby terme truce violated mortal warre reuiued taking fortresse certain colour brekig truce duke somerset ambassador force armes deuised recouer pratye town set ye restitucio thesame diuerse ambassador ye frech kyng cousail made auswere agayn yt englishman restored duke brytayn town fogiers codigne amedes damage done comitted within town poutlarche agayne rendered deliuered frenche kynge counsaill beganne perceyue smel affayres englande death duke gloucester sore minished decayed good counsaill began waxe faynte decay sedicion freshely beganne sprynge ryse reason whereof thoughte normandye might sone e conquered recouered englishe nacion region might easely expulsed driue wherfore determined take good occasion openly offered lose tyme good bargayne wherupo kyng charles diuided armye iij partes doubting victory reason fame coquest pountelarche blowen spread abrode ouer al coutrey diuers assautes without losse diuers men rendered coposicion townes louiers gerborie whereof willia harper capitayn thus prosperous victorie dayly succedinge frenche kynges armye augmenting hooste determined get town uernoyle perche gyrd round strog seage inhabitautes wherof although sodayne chaunce somwhat abashed yet hauinge succour hopinge relefe toke good courage manfully defended towne ayde taried lenger either thought desired compelled compound pact enemyes vpon condicion seage reysed within xx dayes shoulde departe bagge baggage whiche condicio accepted rescous came town castel great towre deliuered frenche historian affirme towne taken assaute castell composicion writer agre frenchemen obteyned thus warre reuiued full terme truce expyred whiche moste detestable vnprofitable chaunce either could might haue happened come realme england sodayn damage losse without thought arrising englishe capitaynes busyed vnquieted appeasing dayly rumor within townes studye recouer castels lost taken scace wyste waye take studied kepe defede one citie iiij v folowing fortune chaunce turned frenche parte became enemy chefe cause reuolting turnig blowen throughout fraunce realme englande death duke gloucester seueral faccios prince diuided two partes william de la pole late created duke suffolke diuers occasion death said duke gloucester father countrye sheild defence poore comonaltie forenamed duke suffolke onely lucre money vexed oppressed molested poore people men myndes intentiue geuen outward affayres foren conquestes theire studie driue backe defend domesticall iniuries dayly wronges done home reason whereof men warre vnpayed armye resistece either gathered assebled together mischiefes kyng thinges worlde great moment neglect omit preferred extolled godly thinges aboue worldly affaire mortal cure thought pha tasied labored quene margarete wyfe whole rule realme consisted beyng woman muche credece geuyng euil flattering cosallors litle regarded dayly much encreased meanes coulde either ouercome resisted meanes frenche nacion knew case state realme englande stode whiche elated encouraged harte dauted appalled courage normains gascoyns muche lacke ayde relefe turned frenche parte forsoke souereigne lord king englande shorte space shall heare pthe xxvii yerethe xxvii yere e ough realme englad season thus vexed vnquieted busines normady also new rebellion beganne irelande great displeasure kynge counsaill repressinge whereof richard duke yorke conuenient nuber men sent thither lieuetenant kyng onely appeased fury wylde sauage people also gat suche loue fauour countrey inhabitautes syncere loue fredly affeccion coulde neuer seperated fro lygnage sequele story shall plainly perceyue frenchemen hauing perfyte vnderstading infirmitie vnreadinesse realme englande displaied banner set furthe armyes shorte space gat yeildynge constance gisors castell gayllard pontean du mere sainct lo fescampe newchastel alanson toncque manleo arge ton lisiaux argenton diuers townes normandy lykewise guyen town maulissone redered erle foys townes yelded voluntarilye englishe souldiors thereunto compelled cytizens inhabitauntes townes whiche apparantly perceyuing greate flame englishe force extinct consumid rose capitaines opened gate enemy constrained render vpon composicion enforcement rych citie roan deliuered surely duke somerset lorde talbot erle shrowesburye well kept defended citie bene vexed citizen enemyes frenche king herault somoned citie inhabitautes onely sought way inuented fraudes betray also put harnes rebelled capitaynes manacinge death destruccion al english people capitaines perceyuing vntrought trayterous demeanour retrayted selfes castell palaice certaine space arrowes handgonnes sore molested vexed vntrew citizen co idered great puyssauce frech kyng dispayre ayde relefe victayle artillarye began sore minishe thoughte better compounde agree enemy rather wilfully destroyed dye amy vpon condicion safely departe caen al goodes armure certain townes deliuered daye permitted departe leauing behynd hostage till sayd townes whiche agreed rendered deliuered erle shreuesbury lorde butler sonne erle ormonde sent castell eureux sore feared malice citizen roen frenchemen folowyng still steppe victorie elated brute fame gettinge roen determined either force offer get towne harfflew shortely assauted thesame wherof capitayn syr thomas coneson man great witt lesse force hauing knowledge heauy tidinges brougth roen therewith nothinge abashed coragiously set vpon enemy great hurt manfully repulsed draue walles frenchemen learning wit great perill left scalynge deuised dayly howe batter breake walles fortificacios seage long continued great losse party syr thomas sawe smal lykelihod ayde gayne muche apparaunce losse ieopardy toke conuencion enemyes departed goodes pthe xxviii yerethe xxviii yere whiche towne rendered fortresse hunflew vpon composicion yeilded thus may perceyue fortune euer without measure either muche fauoreth muche hateth beside townes surrendered normandy duke britayne recouered agayne fongiers sent ihon de buerne diuers townes meane season king england sent normandy crew ccccc men valiaunt capitayn called syr thomas kyriel man great stomacke hadde great armye power small either recouer whiche lost either saue whiche yet remayned vngotten surely lacked neither good courage small numbre recouered agayn townes lyseaux ualongnes whiche feate ioyned hymself sir hery norbery sir robert ueere matthew gough capitaines thei aboue fiue thousande men valiaunt harte haute courage long consultacion thei determined fight frenchemen whiche wer gooyng siege caen iourney thei encountered place called formigny betwene carentyne bayeux erle cleremont lieuetenaunt frenche kyng stewarde poytou lorde ray admirall fraunce sixe hundred men armes sixe thousand whiche skirmished englishemen greate season duryng whiche irmishe arriued arthur erle richemond high constable fraunce iames luxenborough erle lauall greate numbre horseman freshe fotemen commyng frenchman set thenglishmen beyng faint wery long skirmishe battaill sore fought conclusio englishemen wer discomfited put flight theim slain aboue iiijm viiic taken prisoner sir thomas kiriell sir henry norbery sir thomas dreue wer chief sir robert uere matthewe gough saued themselfes first foughten feld frenchemen gatte englishemen many yeres wherfore blame theim though thei litle make muche set furthe hide nothyng maie sounde glory thei declare nubre thei slew thei write many wer slain destroyed victory obteined frenche kyng hearyng duke somerset toune caen thought nothyng doen permitted duke still tary normandy whiche newe aide freshe succor might turne whele fortune contrary parte peraduenture recouer hath loste put realme fraunce ieoperdy wherefore like wise prince entendyng preuent thynges imminent hande assembled armie royall awne persone hauyng campe reyner called kyng scicile father quene englande duke calaber alaunson erles cleremont richemond mayne dumoys sent polle dampemartyne beside many noble baron valiaunte knightes thynges ready opportunitie tyme serued caused toune bee enuironed euery side assignyng capitaines seuerall place toune bee assauted proue manhod erle dumoys losse gain entered bulwerke beaten backe thenglishemen within toune kept silence though thei knewe enemy approchyng euery man kept loupe euery capitain well ouerloked ward frenchemen quarrelles morispikes slynges engynes began assaut walles englishemen within shot fiercely withlong bowes cast dartes rolled doune greate stone barres iron cast doune iauelyns firebrades hote leade blockes pitche brymstone like burnyng ire flamyng cast doune ouerthrewe scalyng ladder slewe suche clymed vp walles neither courage lacked assault manhode pollecie def nce embatelme te walles wer set greate rolles tymbre mouyng vnstedfaste neither scalyng ladder could catche holde persone clyme vp could set sure fotyng french kyng perceiuyng assaye litle nought preuailed hym sent greate ordinaunce paris determinyng neuer departe till conquered toune either sworde famyn ordinauce brought daily shot walles hurte castle whiche stode rocke dongeon vnhable beaten doune harme toune duke somerset wife child capitain duke yorke owner toune kynges gifte appoynted capitain generall sir dauy halle castle sir rober ueer dongeon sir henry radford daily shot greate terrible hurtfull sauyng one daie stone shot toune fel betwene duches somerset child whiche beyng amased chaunce praied knee husbande haue mercy compassion small enfantes thei might bee deliuered ye toune sauegard duke piteous hardy moued dolor wife loue child assembled capitaines magistrate toune declaryng theim power puyssaunce frenche kyng debilitie weakenes perswadyng theim rather yeld rendre vpon honest condicions obstinatly resist foolishly perishe sir dauy halle capitain toune aunswered hym saiyng lorde although bee kynges lieuetenaunt generall within countrey dominion maie force aucthoritie deliuer sell geue kynges tounes suche persones either frendes enemy shall please yet sure cut lether large intreate speake renderyng toune apperteinyng lord master richard duke yorke whiche thereof hath geuen bothe charge custody trusty frendes felowes whiche helpe almightie god shall well defende bothe frenche kyng puyssaunce till duke master come succor men money municions trust haue sufficient saied duke kynges deputie representyng persone maie commaunde thynges accordyng discrecion yea said capitain geue away mane right whose aucthoritie haue thesame toune assure without lordes assent shall neither render yelde consent agrement duke sore moued saiyng departed sent ruler toune poorest people thesame declaryng life goodes wer frenche kynges handes thei looked shortely sauegard death thei sure mercie farre vncertain exhortyng theim folowe louyng monicion rather hardened harte hardie capitain people toune thus perswaded whose harte wer rather frenche englishe began rise sir dauy boldely affirmyng tooke composicion within three day thei would open gate let frenche kyng opinion wer common souldiours poore hare saie enuironed hundred houndes silly larke crye middell hundred hawkes take pacience seke awaie escape capitain perceiuyng neither woordes serued truthe toward master preuailed bad duke somerset list would wise named composicio duke partely pleace tounes men desirous pleace duches wife made agrement frenche kyng would rendre toune might depart sauegard goodes substaunce whiche offre frenche kyng gladly accepted allowed knowyng force might lenger haue longed strong toune haue possessed thesame sone conclusion taken sir dauie halle diuerse trustie fredes departed chierburge thense sailed irelande duke yorke makyng relacion hym dooynges whiche thyng kyndeled greate rancore harte stomacke neuer lefte persecutyng duke somersette till brought hym fatall poynt extreme confusion obteinyng strong toune aen therle cleremont besieged citie lyseux whereof capitain matthewe gough thre hundren englishman capitain perceiuyng caen rescewed poore liseux dispaire succor agreed abandon deliuer citee people might departe chierburge hauyng yron weapon armure onely goodes white stafes handes deliueraunce toune frenchemen stil like good begeles folowyng preye besieged toune fallayse apperteinyng lord talbot erle shrewesbury whereof wer capitaines thesaied erle andrewe trollop thomas cotton esquire whiche beyng desperate succor consideryng puissaunce enemy agreed deliuer toune vpon twoo condicions one erle master whiche remained pledge certain condicions agreed bee perfourmed deliueraunce roen haue heard dismissed set libertie thei wer rescued within twelfe day thei depart armure godes moueable whether pleaced agrement daie prefixed rescue came toune dered incontinent fortresse dampforde deliuered vpon like agrement frenchemen bragged thei regarded neither golde siluer desired rule glory fame whiche lightne e tounes normandy beyng perswaded voluntarily rendered themselfes vassalles subiectes frenche nacion novv rested english onely toune chierburge wherof capitain thomas gonuile surely valiautly defended toune long vitail municion serued two handes wer spent consumed destitute comforte aide vpon reasonable composicio yelded toune went caleis duke somerset many englishemen soiorned lamentyng losse desperate recouery thus riche duchie normandy lost yt whiche continued thenglishmennes possession xxx yeres coquest kyng henry fifth whiche duchie wer hundred strong tounes fortress hable kept holden beside theim whiche wer destroyed warres thesame one archebishopricke sixe bishoprickes saie englishemen wer puyssaunce either man tounes thei beeor inhabite countrey whiche cause thei could kepe accordyng frenchemennes adage whiche saieth man cannot long hold whiche cannot gripe say duke somerset awne peculier profite kept halfe nombre ouldiors put wage purse mennes imaginacions coniectures surely losse domesticall diuision within realme euery greate man desiryng rather reuenged foo home outward enemie shall manifestly se perceiue pthe xxviii yerethe xxviii yere conquestes wer obteined partes beyond sea sworde speare target aduersaries englishman thre mischeuous capitaines set people realme aswell nobilitie meane sorte ciuill warre intestine diuision emong high prince peeres reigned inward grudge emong cleargie adulacion emong commonaltie disdain lasciuious souereigntie whiche quene minion vnprofitable counsailers daily toke vsurped vpo wherfore thei myndyng charged backes would beare perceiuyng negligent prouision improuident pollicie wit wantyng gouernors within realme affaire businesse partes beyonde sea daily decaied wer like pollitique ruler put aucthoritie negligent officer sequestered deposed began make exclamacion duke suffolke affirming onely cause deliuery angeow mayne chief procurer death good duke gloucester verie occasion losse normandy moste swallower vp consumer kynges treasure reason whereof warres fraunce wer mainteined expeller fro kyng al good verteous counsailors brynger auauncer vicious persones common enemy apparaunt aduersaries publique wealthe duke called euery mannes mouth traitor murderer robber kynges treasure worthy bee put moste cruell punishement reason exclamacio quene somewhat fearyng destruccion duke confusion self caused parliament begon blacke frier london adiorned leicester thinkyng force rigor ye law subdue represse malice euill conceiued againste duke whiche place fewe nobilitie would appere wherefore adiorned westminster whole company ful apparaunce whiche session common neither house put vp kyng lordes many article treason misprision misdemeanoure duke suffolke theffect wherof aunsweres hereafter ensueth first thei alleged traiterously excited prouoked counsailed ihon erle dumoys bastard orleauce bertrame lorde presigny willyam cosynet enemy kyng frendes ambassador charles callyng imself frenche kyng entre realme leuy warre kyng realme intent destroye kyng frendes make ihon sonne kyng realme mariyng hym margaret sole heire iho duke somerset pretendyng declaryng next heire inheritable croune lacke issue kynges body lawefully begotten item thesaied duke beyng kynges priuie nere cou saill allured greate rewardes faire promise made foresaied erle dumoys caused kyng deliuer ette libertie charles duke orleaunce enemy kyng kynges noble father whiche deliueraunce prohibited expresse woordes last kynges moste victorious father item departure thesaied duke orleaunce forenamed duke suffolke traytorously faste cleauyng charles called french kyng counsailed prouoked entised thesaid duke orleaunce moue thesame kyng make warre england bothe fraunce normandy accordyng whiche procurement counsaill thesaied frenche kyng hath recouered whole realme fraunce duchie normandy taken prisoner erle shrewesbury lorde fauconbridge many valeaunt capitaines three article hedenied either fact thought farther alledged beyng ambassador kyng englande charles callyng hymself frenche kyng promise reyner kyng scicile charles dangiers brother enemy kyng relese angeow deliueraunce countie mayne citie maunt mauns without knowledge ambassador whiche accompanied whiche promise returne caused bee performed kynges disenheritance losse irrecuperable rength enemy feblishement duchy normandie article answered commission conclude doo thynges accordyng discresion obteinyng peace without deliuery coutreys perceiued truce could obteined agreed relese deliueraunce theim also thei surmised thesaied duke beyng fraunce kynges seruice one priuiest counsaill traiterously declared opened capitaines conduyters warre apperteinyng kynges enemy kynges counsaill purueiaunce army furniture tounes ordinaunces wherby kynges enemy enformed trayterous informacion haue gotten tounes fortress kyng meane depriued inheritaunce item thesaid duke declared erle dumoys lorde presigny willyam cosynet ambassador freche kyng liyng london priuities kynges counsaill bothe prouision farther warre also defence duchy normandy disclosyng wherof frenchman knowyng kinges secretes preuented tyme obteined purpose item sayde duke suche time kyng sent ambassadours frenche kyng entreatyng peace trayterously commyng frenche courte certified kyng charles commission aucthoritie instruction reason wherof neither peace amitie succeded kynges enheritauce lost hys enemyes possessed item thesame duke sayde openly starre chamber lordes counsail highe place cousail house frenche kynge aswell trusted coulde remoue frenche kynge priuiest man hys counsayl would item armyes haue prepared souldyers redy waged passe ouer sea resist kynges enemyes thesayd duke corrupted rewardes frenche kynge hath restreyned stayed sayde armyes passe farther item sayde duke beynge ambassadour kyng comprised leage kynges alies neither kyng arragon neither duke brytayne suffered comprised contrary partye reason wherof olde amitie kyng arragon estraunged realme duke britayne become enemy thesame giles brother kynges suer frende cast strong prison lyke ende finishe dayes al obiections vtterly denyed fayntely auoyded fully excused diuers crymes layde charge enrychyng hymselfe kynges goodes landes gatheryng together makyng money polde office fee wardes fermes reason wherof kynges estate greatly mynished decayed kyn highly exalted enriched many pointes whiche cause notable great force stregth omitte ouerpasse quene whiche entierly loued duke fearyng comocion trouble myght ryse let goo vnpunished caused committed towre kepte muche pleasure large oute captiuitie moneth expired ymagenynge people pacified open emprysonement caused bothe deliuered also restored kinges fauour grace muche euer tyme doynge incensed furye mutable comons muche openly demouncyng saiyng shame al realme se persone infected many misdedes either rule prince honor wordes sprang dedes talkyng rose displeasure whiche growen greate mischiefe pollitique prouision celeritie resisted fyrst fury common sundry place realme assembled together gathered great companyes elected capitayn whome called blew berd attempted enterpryse headdes apprehended membres sodainly dispersed without hurte comitted perpetrated litle rage asswaged parliament adiornied leycester whither came kyng quene great estate duke suffolke chefe counsailor comos lower house forgettyng olde grudge beseched king person assented relese angeow deliueraunce mayne might extremely punished tormented priuye facte accused principal duke suffolke ihon bishop salisbury syr iames fynies lord say diuers kyng henry perceiued comons wer thus stomacked bent quenes dearlynge william duke suffolke playnly sawe neither glosyng wolde serue dissimulacion coulde appeace continual clamor importunate comons wherefore begyn shorte pacificacion long broyle firste sequestred lord say beynge threasorer englande duke adherentes office authoritie banished put exile duke suffolke abhorred tode comon noysaunce realme englande terme v yeres meaning exile appeace furious rage ye outragious people pacified reuocate olde estate quenes chefe frede counsailer fortune wold flagitious person shoulde escape shipped suffolke entendynge transported frauce encotered shippe warre apperteynyng duke excesterwilliam de la poole duke suffolke behedded constable towre london called nicholas towre capitayne thesame barke small fight entered duke shyppe perceyuyng person present brought douer rode one syde cocke bote caused head stryken left hys body heade vpon sandes douer corse founde chapelayne conueyed wyngfelde college suffolke buried ende willia de la pole first duke suffolke men iudge god punyshmet aboue thinges noted organ engine diuiser destruccion hu frey good duke gloucester bloudde innocente dolorous death recompensed punished death froward person vngracious patron brought realme quyete deliuered inward grudge intestine diuision realmes pestiferous noysome outward warre dayly famyne extreme pestilece allthough rychard duke yorke pryson kynges deputie ye realm irelande continually resyaunt yet breath puffed hys wynde blew dayly many partes realme many nobilitie meane estate wisely ponderynge estate condicion realme perceyuynge losse encrease ruyne auancement dayly ensue remembryng also frauce conquered normandy gayned frenche people shorte space thought selfes imagened faulte miserable chaunces happened either kynge true enheritor crowne counsaill able wit pollicie circumspeccion rule gouerne noble realme famous region upon coniecture frendes kinsman alyes duke yorke small nuber began practise gouernauce title infusyng puttyng men heades secretely right ye crown pollitique gouernauce gentle behauior iryshe nacion affirming whiche brought rude sauage nacion ciuile fashion englishe vrbanitie wolde ruled realme england depose euil counsaillers correct euil iudges reforme al matter amisse vnameded set ope fludde gate deuises thought necessary cause great com ocio rysyng people made king preuayled duke yorke complices appetite desire kentishmen impacient wronges disdayning much oppression euer desirous new chaung new fangelnes ouerture matter put furthe fyrste kent thentent knowen duke yorke fredes cause sodayne rising certayn yongma goodely stature pregnaunt wit entised take vpon name ihon mortymer though name ihon cade small policie thinking surname lyne lynage assistente house erle marche small number hym adherent fauorable capitayn onely suborned techers also enforced pryuye scholemasters assembled together great company talle personage assuring attept honorable god king also profitable common wealth promisyng either force pollicie might take kyng quene counsaillers handes gouernauce woulde honorabl e entreate kyng sharply handle counsaillers neither fiftenes hereafter demauded imposicions tax spoken perswasions many fayre promise libertie whiche common people affect desire rather reasonable obedience due conformitte animated kentishe people capitayne aboue named good order battell great number came playne blackehethe betwene eldham grenewyche entent cause glorious capitaines comyng thither might shadowed kyng counsaill sent hym humble supplicacion louyng woordes malicious entent affirmyng comyng agaynst agaynst diuers co nsail louers selfes oppressers pore commonaltie flatterer kyng enemyes honor sucker purse robber subiectes perciall frendes extreme enemy rewardes corrupted indifferencie nothing doyng proude byll kyng counsaill disdainfully taken thereupon great consultacion long debating concluded suche proude rebelles rather suppressed tamed violence force fayre woordes amycable aunswer wherupon king assembled great army marched toward whiche lyen blackeheath space vij dayes subtill capitayn named iack cade entendyng bryng kyng farther within compasse net brake vp campe retyred backwarde towne seuenocke kent exspectynge hys pray encamped selfe made abode quene bare rule beyng retrayte well aduertised sent syr humfrey stafford knyght william brother many gentelmen folow chace kentishmen thinkynge fledde verely desceyued fyrst skyrmish staffordes slayne companye shamfully discomfited kynges armye beyng tyme come blackeheathe hearynge discomfiture began grudge murmure emongest selfe wisshing duke yorke home ayde capitayne cosyne desiryng ouerthrow kyng counsaill openly cryeng quene complices rumor opely spoken comoly published caused kyng certayn counsaill ledde fauor corrupted rewardes entent appeace furious rage inconstant multitude commit lord say threasorer england towre london whome lyke displeasure borne presente thei likewise ben serued necessary one suffer rather nobilitie perish kentish capitayn ye couetous cade thus obteyned victory slayne two valeaunt staffordes apparreled hym selfe rych armure soo pompe glory returned agayn toward london whiche retrayte diuers idle vacabonde person resorted sussex surrey partes great nuber thus glorious capitayn compassed enuironed multitude euil rude rusticall persones came agayn playn blackeheath strogly encamped selfe whome sent kynge archebishop canterbury humfrey duke buckyngham comon hys greues requestes lordes found sober communicacion wyse disputyng arrogant hart styfe opinion way possible perswaded dissolue armye except kynge person wolde come assent thinges requyre lordes perceyuyng wilful pertinacy manifest contumacie rebellious iauelyn departed kyng declaring hym temerarious rasshe wordes presumptuous requestes kyng somwhat hearyng markyng saiynges thys outragious losel hauyng dayly reporte concurse accesse people cotinually resorted doubtyng asmuch familiar seruauntes vnknowe subiectes spared speake capitaynes cause profitable common wealth departed haste castell kylyngworthe warwyckeshyre leauing behynd ye lord scale kepe towre london capitayn beynge aduertised kynges absence came first southwarke lodged white hart prohibity g men murder rape robbery whiche colour allured harte common people entered londo cut rope draw bridge strykyng sworde london stone saiyng mortymer lorde citie rode euery strete lyke lordly capitayn flatteryng declaracion made mayre citie thither commyng departed agayn southwarke vpon thyrde daye iulij caused syr iames fynes lord say threasorer englande brought gylde halle london arrayned whiche beyng kynges iustices put aunswere desired tryed peeres lenger delay lifethe lorde say threasorer englande behedded sta dard h ape capitayne perceiuyng dilatorie ple force toke officer brought standard cheape confession ended caused head cut pitched highe poole opely borne hym stretes cruell tyraunt content murder lorde say wente myle ende apprehended syr iames cromer shreue kent sonne law sayd lord say hym without confession excuse heard caused likewyse hedded head fixed poole two heddes blody butcher entered citie agayn despyte caused euery strete kysse gether great detestacion beholder shamefull murder succeded open rapyn manifest robbery diuers house within citie especiall house philip malpas alderman london diuers ouer besyde raunsonyng fynyng diuers notable marchauntes tuycio securitie lyfes goodes robert horne alderman payed vc markes yet neither person either lyfe substance suertie sauegard also put execucion southwarke diuers person infryngyng rule preceptes bycause wolde sene indifferent torme ted olde acquayntance lest shoulde blase declare base byrthe lowsy lynage disparagyng vsurped surname mortymer thought doubted haue frendes fautors londo kent essex wise mayre sage magistrate citie london perceyuyng selfes neither sure goodes lyfe well warranted determined feare repel expulse mischeuous head hys vngracious copany lord scale ordeyned keper ye towre london mathew gough often named capitayne normandy haue harde purposed make pryuye entent enterprise lord scale promised hys ayde shoting ordinaunce mathew goughe hym appoynted assist mayre londoner bycause manhode experience greatly renoumed noysed capitaynes citie appointed toke vpon night kepe bridge london prohibiting kentishme either passe approche rebelles neuer soundly slepte feare sodayne chaunces hearing brydge kept manned ran greate haste open passage betwene bothe partes ferce cruell encounter mathew gough experte marcial feates cheuetaynes citie perceiuyng kentishmen better stande taclyng imaginacion expected aduised co pany procede toward southwarke till day appered entent citezens hearing place ieopardye rested might occurre enemy releue frendes companion counsail came small effect multitude ye rebelles draue citezens stoulpes bridge foote drawe bridge began set fyre diuers house ala sorow beholde miserable chaunce desyringe eschew fyre lept enemy weapon died fearfull woman chyldren armes amased appalled lept riuer doubtinge saue self betwene fyre water swourd house suffocat smoldered yet capitayns nothing regarding chaunces fought draw bridge nighte valeauntly conclusion rebelles gate draw bridge drowned many ew ihon sutton alderman robert heysande hardy citizen many beside mathew gough man great wit much experience feates chiualrie continual warres valeauntly serued kyng father partes beyod sea ye haue hearde often sene whiche many tymes hath vanqueshed enemy straug countreys returned agayn conqueror hath awne nacion afterward shamfully murdered brought confusion hard sore co flict endured bridge til ix clocke morninge doutfull chaunce fortune balaunce tyme lodoners bet back stulpes sainct magnes corner sodaynly agayne rebelles repulsed driuen backe stulpes southwarke partes beyng faynte wery fatigate agreed desist fight leue battail til next day vpon condicion neither londoner passe southwarke kentishme london abstinence warre agreed lusty kentishe capitayne hopyng frendes brake vp gayles kinges benche marshalsea set libertie swarme gallates mete seruice apte enterprise archebishop canterbury beyng chauncelor england suerty lyenge towre london called bishop winchester whiche also feare lurked halywell two prelate seyng fury kentish people reason betyng backe mitigate minished passed ryuer thamyse towre souhtwarke bringing vnder kynges great seale general pardon vnto offendors caused openly proclamed published lorde glad poore people pardone ye great iubile rome thei accepted thesame muche whole multitude without biddyng farewel capitain retired thesame night euery man awne home men amased strike feare ihon cade desperate succor whiche frendes duke yorke wer hym promised seyng copany thus without knowledge sodainly depart mistrustyng sequele ye matter departed secretly habite disguysed sussex metamorphosis transfiguracion litle preuailed proclamacion made whosoeuer could apprehende thesaied iac cade haue pain markes many sought espied hym til one alexander iden esquire kent found hym garden defence manfully slewe cai ife cade miserable ende iac e cade brought ded body london whose hed set londo bridge successe rebelles fortune chaunceth euer traytors men striue streame bote neuer co meth pretensed porte commocion kyng hymself came kent sat iudgement vpo offendors mitigated iustice mercie compassion fiue c rigor lawe iustely put execucion cosidered bothe fragilitie innocencie thei peruerse people seduced deceiued punished stubburne heddes deliuered ignorat miserable people greate reioysyng subiectes dvryng commocion aboute london raufe bishop salisbury awne tenantes seruautes murdered edyngton thensefurth daily succeded murder slaughter discencion pthe xxix yere variable chaunces englandethe xxix yere vnknowen frenche kyng wherfore makyng foundacion vpon english discord determined get possession duchie acquitayne prince englande wer co trouersie title superioritie therfore like spedy puruior whiche slacketh tyme sent therles ponthieure perigot many valiant capitaines ley siege toune bergerac set vpo riuer dordone whiche toune capitain iho geddyng whiche hearyng yeldyng roen conquest normandy consideryng puyssaunce frenche army vpon reasonable condicios rendered toune yet notwithstandyng lord cameyse sir george seymour sir ihon arundell valiaunt capitaines whiche gouernance countrey manned tounes gathered people animated cold stomackes fearefull gascons requiryng constant fidelitie true natural prince vndoubted souereigne lorde sendyng daily letter kyng englande counsaill declaryng weakenes subiectes strength enemy assertenyng hym suertie without spedy aide redy succor whole countrey like gotten fro possessio many letter wer sent many faire aunswers wer brought relief neither appered one man warre thether shipped reason wherof gascoyns perceiuyng enemy hand intendyng aswell destroy countrey subdue people began euery man hymself regard nothyng sauyng tounes goodes corne neglectyng defence fearful assaultes least small resistence thei might receiue detriment thei could recouer either great force muche labor thenglishmen whose nature faint harted euen ieoperdy death al wittes studied bothe repulse conuince enemy turne awaie euil chance whiche thei sawe likely pollicie helpe sodainly fal shortly insue al pollex litle preuailed coclusion succor failed force wanted afther frenchemen toune bergerac rendered fortress io sac bonefoy diuerse place willyngly frely yelded themselfes frenche subieccion duryng whiche tyme lorde doruall third sonne lorde delabreth greate numbre men aswel horssebacke foote departed basas conquere destroy isle madoce wherof hearyng maire burdeaux conuenient crewe men issued citie encontered enemy betwene hard fight dedly battaill frenchemen multitude force vanquished thenglishemen killed toke prisoner aboue vjc englishman gascoynes frenchemen whiche wer double numbre aboue aduersaries writer affirme wer slain viiic persones whiche cause capitaines folowed farther chace lest englishe people would returne slaughter englishe parte frenche writer set furthe moste awne losse thei speake one worde suche indifferency chronographiers discomfiture amased wittes appalled harte meane gascons thei offered many tounes french part thesame wer demaunded bastard orleaunce erle dumoys lo guile lieuetenant generall frenche kyng accompanied brother ihon erle angulesme whiche long prisoner england many valiant capitaines expert men warre besieged castle montguyon whiche rendered saied army besieged fortresse blay standyng riuer gyrond whiche toune keye porte burdeaux toune besieged bothe water lande fiersly assaulted manfully defended conclusion force lacke resistence conquered gayned bastard kendall capitain castle seyng toune lost vpon certain condicions deliuered ortresse possession lord lieuetenant toune gained fortress bourge liburne yelded without fiue wekes besiegyng wittie capitaines perc iuyng fortune fauor towardes thought necessary take tyme good planet reigned wherfore preuent aide englishman thei daily expected come succor people thei appoynted foure army make war foure seuerall partes lorde charles dellebreth accompainied ihon lorde tartas aymon lorde doruall sonnes therle foys uiscount lawtrec brother many noble men guyen laied siege toune acques whiche diuerse ho e bathe therle arminack extreme enemy realme englande breakyng mariage concluded betwene kyng henry daughter haue heard esiged greate puyssaunce strong toune ryon therle po thyeure many noble baron besieged toune chastis perigot erle dumoys enuironed great puyssance toune fronsacke thenglishemen within toune perceiuyng greate ordinaunce frenche part small prouision side couenanted thesaid erle toune wer succored frenchemen foughten feast natiuitie iho baptist next ensuyng toune fronsacke yelded whiche strogest fortresse countrey key guyen chief chamber burdeaux per ormans hereof pledge wer deliuered writynges autentique sealed agrement blowen countrey citie burdeaux al tounes except bayon made like agrement deliuered pledge al noble men getlemen whiche wer subiectes vassal croune englande alacke alacke euery daie lokyng relief euery houre gapyng cofort wisshyng serued hopyng nothyng helped pestiferous diuision whiche reigned englande ueglid braines noble men honor realme clerely forgotten nothing yearthly priuate phantasy looked remembred conclude daie appoynted came succor loked came tounes acquitayne except bayon deliuered keyes became vassal frenche nacion yet citezens burdeaux hopyng rescous offered themselfes fight frenchman desired daie battaill appoynted whiche request theim graunted daie assigned thei beyng dispa refuge succor rendered themselfes toune aduersaries life goodes reserued licence saf conduyte person whiche would depart saile englade city tounes gascoyne wer set good ordre erle dumoys foys greate preparacion vitaill municion men came cite bayon mynes battery thei dismaied fearful inhabitantes neither capitain souldiors could kepe yeldyng force thei deliuered toune capitain prisoner offred great money safegard life goodes beside agrementes taken tounes diuerse noble men made seuerall composicions gaston de foys capdaw buessz kyng henry fifth made erle longuile knight garter whose auncestors wer euer true englad whiche agreed ihon de foys sonne kyng henry sixt created erle kendale made also knight ye garter enioy landes acquitayne geuen kynges englande duke acquitayn intent still serue kyng englande souereigne lorde thei agreed deliuer custody therle foys cosyn sonne heire thesaied erle kendale beyng age three yeres intent full age denied become subiect vassaill frenche kyng tyme disceased death father graundfather thesaid landes wholy remain next heire bloud either male female beyng vnder obeysance frenche kyng heires many noble men whose harte good englishe made like composicions came englande went caleis wer great officer lorde dura whiche marshall monsire uanclere whiche deputie vnder therle warwick shalbe shewed haue declared losse fraunce normandy acquitayn wherfore hauyng cause yet speake theim returne greate trouble discencion diuision whiche long cloked openly set abrode burst realme englande pthe xxx yere haue heard beforethe xxx yer duke yorke heire lionell duke clarence pretended priuily title croune frendes commoned secretly diuerse persones matter excited theim set forward auaunce parte vttermoste howe thesaied duke sent ireland daily aduertised assured frendes thynges doen englande knewe estate stode bothe nobilitie comonaltie wherfore mindyng leger dreame waightie matter kepe secrete right title returned irelande came londo parliamet tyme deliberately consulted especial frendes ihon duke norffolke richard erle salisbury lorde richard sonne whiche erle warwicke thomas courtney erle deuonshire edward broke lord cobham man greate witte muche experience requiryng bothe aduise counsaill might without spot treason colour vsurpacion set furth title obtein right long consultacion thought expedient first seke occasion picke querell duke somerset whiche ruled kyng ordered realme moste might quene common losse normandy worse tode scorpion hated disdained execrated muche diuerse euill ruled persones brake house spoyled goodes within blacke frier citie londo whiche malefactor accordyng desertes wer iustly executed punished wel knewe duke yorke adherentes duke somerset sawe smelled poynt purposed enterprise would speare sheld might main withstand repell thesame thextreme point death vtter confusion wherfore abbridge power minishe aucthoritie thei determined bryng hym hatred people disdain nobilitie stronger settyng furth feate thei rewardes faire promise declaracion great enormity committed kinges counsailors gainst common wealth allected allured lu ty bachelars actiue person great numbre protestyng declaring thei neither meant euil thought harme either kinges person dignitie intent reuenging great iniuries doen publique wealth persecute reforme diuerse ruler kyng daily cotrary right equitie vexed pilled thenglish people without reason measure ye man suretie either awne goodes suer proper lades possessios great enormity thei caused published thintent ye chief purpose espied perceiued vvhen duke yorke thus framed thentery log intended iorney helpe frendes assembled great army march wale publishyng openly cause mocio publique wealth realme greate profite co mon whiche faire told tale allured hym muche people aswell chiualry meane sort kyng muche astonnied sodain commocion aduise counsail raised great hoste marched forward toward duke beyng approche credibly aduertised espial diuerted kynges way toke iorney toward london hauyng knowledge might suffered army passe london crossed ouer thamese kyngston bridge set furth toward kent knewe bothe frendes good willers brente heath mile dertford x mile londo embattailed encamped army strongly bothe trench artilery king therof aduertised great diligece brought army blacke heath pight tetes tharmies lay thus embattailed kyng thaduise counsaill sent bishoppes winchester e ie duke bothe knowe cause greate tumult commocion also make concord requestes duke company semed consonant reason profitable people duke hearyng ye message two bishop either doubtyng variable chaunce mortal battaill lokyng better occasio luckey daie aunswered prelate commyng neither dampnifie kyng neither honor persone yet good man intent remoue fro hym certain euil disposed person counsaill whiche wer bludsuckers nobilitie pollers cleargie oppressor poore people emongest chiefly named edmond duke somerset kyng would commit warde aunswere suche article hym open parliament bothe proponed proued promised onely dissolue army dispatche people also offered hymself like obedient subiecte come kynges presence hym true faithful seruice accordyng truth bouden duetie messenger wer returned reasonable aunswere kyng perceiuyng without great bludshed could bridle duke yorke without war could appeace furious rage comon people beyng set fire except folowed mindes grauted requestes caused duke somerset committed ward saie kepe hymself priuye awne house write till fury people somewhat asswaged pacified whiche thyng doen duke yorke firste daie marche dissolued army brake vp campe came kynges tent beside expectacio cotrary promise made kyng found duke somerset set large libertie duke yorke boldly accused treason bribery oppression many crime duke somerset onely made aunswere duke obieccions also accused hym high treaso toward kyng souereigne lorde affirming fautors complices consulted together obtein croune scepter realme meane whiche wordes kyng remoued straight lodon duke yorke prisoner rode hym kept kyng assembled together greate counsail westminster accusacios ij duke one obiectyng facinorous actes detestable crime duke somerset whiche conceiued mynd thyng shortely folowed incessantly exhorted counsaill duke yorke compulsion otherwise might bee compelled confesse offence beyng attainted treason put execucion child bee taken enemy aduersaries natiue countrey intent losse onely prince sequele ciuill warre inward diuision might cease repressed besechyng almightie god greate enemy kyng bloud might neuer escape punishment continewe long life duke somerset set rth matter vehemently knew perfitely duke yorke dayly studyed howe get crowne obteyn gouernaunce depose destroy kyng hym necessitie destineye man deuise either letted interrupted many thynges common iudgementes declared duke yorkes trought innocecye case first free voluntary coming kyng power able encouter kynges puyssance open token manifest argument neither meate treason yet fraude secondarily humble submission reasonable requestes profitable peticions pore common iudged pointes man desired souereignetie rule aboue thinges onely cautele afterward openly appeared cousail treated sauing losing dolorous duke yorke rumour sprange throughout london edward erle marche sonne heyre apparaunt sayd duke yong prince great much stomacke accompanied stronge armye marchemen comyng toward london tidinges sore appalled quene whole counsail beside thesame daye came ambassadours heades magistrate citie burdeaux whereof chefe erle kendal lord lesparre signified counsaill thei woulde sende armye gascoyne gascoyns wolde reuerte turne agayne english part aduertising partes puissaunce garrison frenche men withstand therefore doubte regay ing recoquest requyring wt diliget celeritie take fayre prey opely offered mynd nothing regayning fruictful countrey ij thinges sore troubled heades kinges counsaill whiche leste discencion betwene two persones might let outward conquest set duke yorke libertie permitted returne fayre castel wignore march wale studied displease enemy obteyn purpose meanes ye absece ye duke yorke maner banished ye court kinges presece ye duke somerset rose vp high fauor wt king ye quene worde ruled voyce hearde pthe xxxi yere counsaill englande forgettinge offer gasconsthe xxxi yere thei might haue citie burdeaux coutrey round offer request whiche great charge longe warre coulde scant agayn recouer repossesse appointed veterane souldiour valiaunt capitayn ihon lord talbot erle shrewsburye chefetayn armye haste transported conucyed acquitayn lordes gascoyn well pleased glad aunswere returned countrey secret maner thense departed declaringe nacion capitaines powre coming exhorting euery man firme stable kyng england heyrs vnder whose libertie fredom thei prospered reioysed aboue iiic yeres rather fal french captiuitie whose tax vnreasonable whose dayly exaccions importable valiant talbot hardy erle shrewsbury appointed assemble army men couey duchie acquitayn lord busy mustering howe diliget setting forward ientelly entertayned men warre though went first warre neuer take payne either serue price gayn honor speake thought euery houre thre till armie ready write payne toke se shipped vitayled verely men iudge labor ende extreme point worldly busynes shew self fearce coragious feareful enemy extreme point death naturall departing thys english hector marcial flower elected hardy coragious person could espye preparing also horse municions vitayles thinges necessarie army great enterprise whe thinges shipped wynd wether serued toke chaunce sayled gascoyn without resistece peaceabl arriued ye isle madre reposed army beyng scant iijm men destroyed countrey betwene burdeaux blay toke strog towne castel fronsac diuers townes fortress inhabitautes burdeaux hearing erles arriual sent messenger darke night tha king congratulating thither comming also requiryng accelerate spede iorney towarde citie enformyng time propice purpose tyme taken labor mispent aunciet fox pollitique capitayne lost one houre spared one mynet till came citie burdeaux citezens glad commynge made french capitayns gouernaunce towne either party priuies entent yet wolde frenchman securitie life goodes departe town wil multitude abhorryng french seruitude embracing english libertie aucestors many yeres tasted opened one gate let great parte englishman army french capitaynes entending escape secretely posterne slayne taken lorde lespar english army regaynyng burdeaux arriued blay bastard somerset syr ihon talbot lord lisle hys wyfe sonne sayd erle shrewesbury lord molyns lordes haryngton cameus syr ihon haward syr ihon montgomerye syr ihon uernon xxiic vitailes municios whe erle shrewesbury thus accordyng entent thinges furnished adorned firste fortified burdeaux englishman victayle rode countrey abrode obteined city gat townes without stroke det swourde poore nedy people beyng fatigate wery oppressio new landlordes rendered townes thei requyred beside townes city farre distauncte fro burdeaux sent messenger erle promisyng seruice obeysaunce emonge towne castell chastillon perigotte deliuered frenchman vpon coposicion might life sauely departe town erle strogly fortified men ordinaunce french kynge lyeng tower towrayne beyng erles actes gascoyn credible enformed litle exasperate quickned wherefore mynding resist first storme repulse first surge assembled great army number xxiim men enteringe acquitayne came lusigneum thence accompanyed erle ponthyure lordes sainct seuere boucat marched toward caleys gascoyn fayre promise obteyned town towne gayned frenche kynge diuided army two party wherof one gouerned erle cleremont sonne law kyng charles heyre duke burdon xvm men whome consisted wayght peyse whole enterprise army appointed take next way toward burdeaux army wherof capitayn leadar self accompaned peres noble men realme kept reteyned still beside caleys sent two marshal frauce xviiic men armes beside archer besege towne chastylon perigot goyng thither thei gat fortresse whiche manned departed chastilone enuyroned strong seage cast highe trench made depe dytches euery syde place enemyes must come thei layde ordinaunce great small wherof great number neuer sene france erle shrewesbury hearing newes perceiuing must necessitie encouter fight two army determined wt selfe first assay least power weeker puyssaunce wherfore without longer procrastinacion assembled togither viiic horseme wherof lord li e sonne lord molyns lord cameus syr edward hull syr ihon haward syr ihon uerno chefe marched forward toward chastylon appoyntyng vm fote men vnder conduyte erle kendalle lord lespar folowe hym spede hys way assauted towre frechmen taken force entered slew founde within way met vc frenchman goyng forragyng slew greatest parte chaced campe frech men knowyng good runers away ye erles approchyng al diligece left seage retired good order place treched dytched fortefied ordenaunce thei within towne seyng seage remoued sent woorde englishman frenchman fledde coragious erle hearyng newes feryng leste long taryeng byrdes might flowen awaye tarieng till fo eme come set forward toward enemy mynd surely haue fledde confessed afterward feare french kynges rebuke whiche farre caused tarye yet army present marshal great master france erle pothyeure senescal poythiew lord bessire many valeant baron knightes englishman come place frenchme encamped eneas siluius testifieth iiic peces brasse beside diuers small peces subtill engynes englishman vnknowen nothing suspected lyghted al fote erle shrewesbury except age rode litle hakeney fought fiercely frechme gat thentre campe fyne force entered thesame coflicte continued doutfull iudgement victory ii longe houres durynge fight lordes montamban humadayre great companye frenchman entered battayle began new felde sodaynly gonners perceiuynge englishman approche nere discharged ordinaunce slew iiic person nere erle perceiuynge imminent ieopardy subtile labirynth hys people enclosed illaqueate despicynge awne sauegarde desiryng life entierly welbeloued sonne lord lisle willed aduertised counsailled hym departe felde saue hym selfe whe sonne auswered neither honest natural leue father extreme ieopardye life woulde taste draught father parent assay begyn noble erle comfortable capitayn sayd oh sonne sonne thy father onely hath bene terror scourge frech people many yeres hath subuerted many townes profligate discomfited many open battayle marcial conflict neither ca dye honor countrey without great laude perpetuall fame flye departe without perpetuall shame cotinualle infamy thy first iourney enterprise neither thy flyeng shall redounde thy shame thy death thy glory hardy man wisely flieth temerarious person folishely abidethe therfore fleyng shalbe ye dishonor progenie also discomfiture company thy departure shall saue thy lyfe make able another tyme slayn reuenge death honor thy prince profyt realme nature wrought sonne neither desire lyfe thought securitie could withdraw pluck fro natural father cosideryng constancy chyld great daunger stode comforted souldiours cheared capitayns valeautly set enemy slew number co pany enemy hauing greater company men abu daunce ordinaunce bene sene battayle fyrst shot thyghe hadgone slew horse cowardly killed lyenge grounde whome thei neuer durste loke face whyle stode fete dyed manfully hys sonne lord li e bastard sonne henry talbot syr edward hull elect noble order gartier xxx valeant personage english nacion lord molyns taken prysoner lx residew englishe people fled burdeaux place wherof flight slayne aboue person battayl chastillon fought xiij day iulij yere ended lyfe ihon lord talbot progenie ye fyrst erle shrewesbury muche fame glory moste victorie prince coutrey space xxiiij yeres valeantly made warre serued kyng partes beyond sea whose corp left ground found hys frendes coueyed whitchurch shropshyre intumulate man french people scorge daily terror much person fearfull terrible aduersaries present name fame spitefull dreadfull common people absent muche woman fraunce feare yong childre would crye talbot commeth talbot commeth discomfiture diuers lordes fled burdeaux erle kendall lordes montferrant rosayne dangladas entered castel chastillon space x dayes manfully defended conclusion beyng desperate succor redered fortresse came safe burdeaux town yelded townes sainct million bybourne erle shrewesbury conquered rendered selfes fre che obeysaunce burdeaux onely except citie beyng last refuge onely consolacion englishe people gascoyne french kyng person puissaunce strogly beseged dayly assauted lost gayned beside english men issued coragiously fought enemy likewise citizen lokyng fauor french kynges hand late coniuracion againste manfully defended selfes sore noyed hurt enemy conclusion bothe garrison inhabitates oppressed much penurye extreme tamyne coacted render citie vpon reasonable condicions french kyng sent oblated effect whereof offence tyme committed done citezes hereafter imputed leyd charge also englishman gascons myght safely departe englande caleys al substance lordes lespar dura xxx neuer vpon payn death founde within french kinges dominion lord lesparre beyng taken disguysed gascoyn made shorter hedde composicion agreed sealed englishman shippes al thinges necessarie iorney deliuered wynd whether propice conuenient shortly transported englad moneth october present yere thus duchye acquytayn cotynued english possession yere lord mlv iiic od yeres ye mariage alienor doughter heyr william duke aequitayn wyfe kyng henry second finally reduced brought agayne french obedience seruitude kepyng duchye neither costly troblesome realme englande pleasant profitable soueraingtie countrey yonge gentelmen learned experiece warre expert promoted many riche office great liuinges within thesame within onely duchye iiija declaration digni y chye acquitay archebishoppes xxxiiij bishoppes xv erledos iic ii baron e aboue capitaynshippes baylywyckes though great losse chaunced yere englishe nacion yet greater detryment hapned thesame season whole flocke christen people machumet called great turk beseaged citie constatynople grece innumerable nuber turkes fiftye dayes togither gaue continuall assaut iiii day iunethe w nnig constantinople great turke toke perforce sleyng man woman chyldren except emperour palialogus diuers blode royal whome toke prisoner caused behedded write detestable murder men abhominable cruel slaughter chyldren shameful rauishmet woman
