inwarde conceipte vndubitatly resolued especiall confidence inwarde fidelitie whiche long hath continued betwene v beyng gether liuyng shall totally death bee extincte vanished like smoke auaileth frendshippe life trust deceiueth death profiteth amitie apparaunt presence confidence fraudulently beguiled absence loue groweth coniunccion matrimonie ofspryng dooe agree concorde profiteth prince auaunce promote subiectes death bountifulnes theim shewed receiuers thesame sequele neither regarded yet remembered paretes make mariage indissoluble amitie prince promote sometyme fauoure sometyme deserte sometyme pleasure yet consider verie pricke whiche giftes promocions finally tend haue loue fauor faithful cou saill diligent seruice suche promoted exalted onely awne life beyng brief transitorie also thei progeny callyng remembraunce fauor estimacion auauncement thei liberal munificent prince receiued obteined spere shelde toungue wit hande penne continually studie defende counsaill prefer onely hym duryng life also serue assist maintein sequ le lineall succession verie image carnall portratures stirpe line stemne naturally disceded case knowe without ineffable trouble moste daungerous wart haue obteined scepter diademe realme empire duryng whiche reigne haue either litle peace small tranquilitie thought self sure quiet life worldly rest death hath blowen terrible trompet callyng somonyng truste perpetuall tranquilitie eternall quietnes therefore perfecte vnmoueable confidence haue euer vnfained loue haue euer shewed vnto commende deliuer gouernauce bothe noble realme naturall child kynsmen child diligent ouersight pollitique prouision bee taught enformed instructed onely scieces liberall verteous morall good literature also practised trickes marciall actiuitie diligent exercise prudent pollicie haue hard clarkes saie although vnlettered fortunate realme philosophiers reigne kynges bee philosophiers louers wisedome tendre age maie writhe turne theim euery forme fashio bryng vp vertue shall haue verteous prince set learnyng gouernors shalbee men knowlege teache actiuitie shall haue valiaunte capitaines thei practice pollicie shall haue bothe pollitique prudent ruler side negligence thei fall vice youth euill prone teady onely honor also honestie shalbe spotted appalled thei bee slogardes geuen slothe publique wealth realme must shortly decaye thei vnlearned thei maie flattery sone bee blinded adulacion often deceiued thei lacke actiuitie euery creature neuer base birthe shall foyle ouerthrowe theim like domme beastes beastly dastardes therfore desire goddes name adiure rather studie make theim riche godly knowlege verteous quality take pain glorifie theim abundance worldely treasure mundain superfluitie certainly whe thei come maturitie age shall peraduenture considre omission negligent educacio thei haue suche grace endued suche notable quality thei might haue performed truste committed thei shall onely deplore lament vngarnished estate naked condicion also maie fortune thei shall conceiue inwardly suche negligent vntruthe sequele thereof maie rather turne displeasure thanke soner vngratitude rewarde kyngdom also leue gouernaunce duryng minoritie child chargyng honor othes fidelitie made sworne indifferently ordre gouerne subiectes thesame bothe iustice mercie willes malefactor haue large scope harte good people muche extremitie bee neither sorofully daunted vnkyndly kept vnder oh slepie muste make ende al commende soule almightie god sauior redemer body wormes yearth kyngdom prince sonne louyng frendes harte trust whole confidence euen fell slepe diuerse suche charitable monicions exhortacions pangues fittes sickenes would permit hym sometyme nobilitie sometyme familier frendes made declared maladie sodainly encreased grewe painfull extremitie short death soner required longer life desired wishyng rather departyng worlde abide painfull smarte dolorous pangues wherfore attrapos hauyng compassion continuall languishyng daily agony dirupted brake threde naturall life ix daie aprill yere lorde mcccclxxxiii fiftie yere bodily age reigned ouer realme trouble perfecte quietnes xxii yeres one monethe eight day whose corp funerall pompe accordyng royall estate kyng conueighed colege winsore greate benefactor right hand high aulter princely enterred intumilate whose death asmuchelamented subiectes life desired begat quene elizabeth wife tenne child whereof left liuyng twoo soonnes edward prince wale richard duke yorke bastard sonne called arthur whiche uicount lisle came good profe beside left fiue daughter elizabeth cicilie anne katherine briget wer maried except lady briget whiche nonne professed kyng edward manne goodly personage stature high excedyng countenaunce welfauored comly iye quicke pleasaunt brode brested well set member doune fete kept iust proporcion bulke body wit quicke pregnant stomacke st e bold courage haute high memorie moste perfecte especially suche thynges trauailed greate affaire weightie cause quicke diligent perelles aduentures bolde hardie enemy fierce terrible frendes straungers bountifull liberal hauyng warres moste prosperous lucke happie successe pleasure body whiche prone much geuen muche abstein forbere whiche cause also greate humanitie lowlines hym nature moste abundauntly engendered vsed emong meane persones familier degree dignitie maiestie required whiche cause suspected hym haue died poyson said day life muche vsed liberalitie towarde latter ende geuen auarice loue money although founde kyngdome greatly impouerished almoste emptie bothe men warre money yet pacified finished ciuill discencion left realme thynges riche abundaunt spirituall promocions gaue euer moste famous excellent clerkes men best liuing meane quality muche fauored preferre greate dignitie high promocios money rewarded theim whiche thyng many prince regardyng honor consider obserue whiche notable vertues ioyned hym surely harte people death life daily wisshed effecteously emong subiectes desired wisshyng serued yet desire tooke none effecte pthe ende prosperous reigne kyng edward fourthe pitifull life kyng edward v eternall god callynge merci noble prince kynge edward ye iiij namethis kynges tyme wt parte kyng richard ye iii shall b anote made place writte syr thomas edward eldeste sonne prince wale beganne reygne ninthe daye april yere oure lord thousande foure hundred fourscore thre xxiij yere lewes leuenthe frenche kynge whiche younge prince reigned smal space litle season ouer realme either pleasure libertie vncle richard duke gloucester within thre monethes depriued hym onely croune regalitee also vnnaturally bereft hym naturall life declaracion craftie engine firste attempted vngraciouse purpose false coulourable vntrue allegacions set furth openly pretensed enterprise finally shamefull cruell detestable act perfourmed ye muste first considre brother dessended nature condicions inclinacions shall easely perceiue coulde bee crueller tiraunt apoincted acheue abhominable entreprise father richard plantagenet duke yorkerichard plantagenet duke yorke whiche began warre lawe calenge crowne englande puttyng claime parliament holden thirty yere kyng henry sixt either righte fauoure cause set furthe auaunced bloude saied kynge henry althoughe goodly sonne clerely abiected crowne ye realme auctoritee parliamente entayled duke yorke heires decease sayed kynge henry syxte duke entendynge long tary mindyng vnder pretexte discencion growen arisen within realme couenauntes made parliamente kepte broken preuent tyme take vpon hym gouernaunce kynge henry life muche hardinesse slaine battaill wakefelde leuynge behinde hym three sonnes edwarde george richarde three thei greate estate birthe thei greate stately stomacke gredy promocionsthe iii sone richard duke yorke described impaciente parteuers rule autoritee edward reuenged father death deposed kyng henry sixt attained crowne scepter realme george duke clarence goodly well feautered prince thynges fortunate either owne ambicion set hym brother thenuy enemy set brother againste hym quene noble blud whiche highly maligned kynges kyn ed woman commely malice nature hate suche husbandes loue wer proud appetitie duke hym selfe entendynge bee kynge leaste wi e heinous treason laied charge finally faulte wer fautelesse attainted parliamente iudged death vpon hastely drowned butte malmesey within towre londongeorge duke clarence drowned malmesay whose death kynge edwarde although commaunded wiste dooen piteously bewayled sorowfully repented richard duke gloucester third sonne whiche must moste entreate witte courage egall beautee liniametes nature far vnderneth bothethe discrip ion richard iii litle stature eiuill featured limnes croke backed left shulder muche higher righte harde fauoured visage estate called warlike visage emonge commen persones crabbed face malicious wrothfull enuious reported mother duches muche dooe trauaill coulde bee deliuered hym vncut came worlde fete forwarde menne bee borne outwarde fame ranne vntothed whether menne hatred reported aboue truthe nature chaunged course beginnynge whiche life many thynges vnnaturally committed leue god iudgemente none euill capitain warre ye whyche disposicion enclined peace sondry victory ouerthrowes neuer defaute owne persone either lacke hardinesse politique order free dispences somwhat aboue power liberall large giftes gatte hym vnstedfaste frendship whiche cause fain borowe pill extort place whiche gat hym stedfaste hatred close secrete depe dissimuler lowlye countenaunce arrogante herte outwardely familier inwardely hated lettynge kisse thought kill dispiteous cruell alwaie eiuill ofter ambicion serue purpose frende fooe indifferent auauntage grewe spared mannes deathe whose life withstode purpose slewe towre kynge henry sixtekynge henry tow r richard iii saiynge heire male kynge edwarde thirde wee house yorke whiche murder doen without kyng edward assente whiche woulde haue appointed bocherly office rather owne brother wise menne also wene drif e lacked helpynge furth owne brother clarence death whiche thyng apparaunce resisted although inwardly mynded cause therof menne notyng doynges proce ynges marke longe kynge edwarde tyme thought obtaine crowne case kynge brother whose life loked eiuil diet woulde sone shorten shoulde happen diseace dede chyldren beynge younge duke clarence liued pretensed purpose far hyndered yf duke clarence kepte hym selfe trewe nephewe younge kynge woulde haue taken vpon hym bee kynge euery one caste troumpe duke gloucester waye sure brother clarence ded knewe might worke without ieoperdy poinctes certentie whosoeuer diuineth coniectureth may wel shote fer shorte coniecture afterwarde toke place fewe dooe shall perceiue hereafter afore declare howe richarde duke gloucester began mischeuous imagined pretenced enterprice apparatly shalbee opened muste litle put remembraunce louyng charitable acte lesse profitable amicable whole comminaltie inwardely thoughte ontwardly dissimuled whiche kynge edwarde liyng deathe bedde longe died life although diuision emongest frendes somewhat greued irked hym yet helthe lesse regarded tooke hede reason thoughte hable al thynges rule bothe party wer thei neuer obstinate last sickenes whiche continued longer false fantasticall tale haue vntruely falsely surmised selfe wrote pamphlet truly knewe perceiued naturall strength gone hoped litle recouery artes phicisians whiche perceiued onely prolonge life began consider youthe child howe bee nothynge lesse mistrusted happened yet wisely forseyng consideryng many harmes might ensue debate noble youth child lacke discrecion good counsaill frendes knewe well euery parte woulde woorke owne commodite rather plesaunte aduise wynne theim selues fauour profitable adnertismente dooe chyldren good wherefore liynge deathe bed westminster called hym suche lordes aboute hym whome knewe bee variaunce especiall lorde marque dorset sonne quene lorde hastynges againste quene especially grudged fauoure kyng bare hym also thoughte hym familier kynge wanton compaignie kynne bare hym sore aswel kyng made hym capitain caleis whiche office lord riuers brother quene claimed kyng former promise diuerse giftes whiche receiued loked lordes diuerse bothe party come vnto kynge presence caused hym self bee raised vp pillowes gesse saied thus muche like sentence theim lordesan exhortacio kynge edward iiii deathe hedde dere kynsmen alies plight lye se perfightly fele whiche loke lesse liue therefore depely moued care case leaue suche leaue suche chyldren like finde whiche yf find variaunce god forbid thei theim selfes mighte hap fall warre discrecion woulde serue set peace se youthe whiche reken onely surety reste concorde suffiseth loue theim yf eche hate yf menne faithfulnesse might hap suffice childhod muste bee maintained mennes autoritie slipper youthe vnder prompted elder counsaill whiche thei neuer haue excepte geue geue excepte agree eche laboureth breake maketh hatered eche impugneth others counsaill muste nedes bee longe tracte good conclusion canne forewarde farther eache partie laboureth bee chiefe flatterer adulacion shall haue place plaine faithefull aduise wiche muste nedes ensue eiuill bryngynge vp prince whose mynde tender youth infecte shall ely fall mischiefe riote drawe downe noble realme ruine yf grace turne hym wisedome whiche god send hym whiche eiuill meanes pleased hym beste shall fall fardest fauoure lengthe eiuill driftes driue naught good plain way prospere florishe greate variaunce hath betwene alwaies greate cause tyme thynge righte well entended misconstured hath turned worse small displeasure doen either owne affection either instigacion euill tongue hath ben sore aggrauate wote well neuer greate cause hatred haue loue bee menne bee christen menne leaue preacher tell yet wote whether prechers woordes ought moue goyng place preche shal desire remembre one parte beyng bloude alies eche either kynred affinitee whiche spirituall affinitee kinred christe partaker sacramentes christe churche weighte whiche consanguinite yf beare woulde god shoulde bee moued spirituall charite fleshely consanguinitee lorde forbid loue worse together selfe cause oughte loue better yet often happeneth finde dedly debate emongest theim whiche nature lawe moste ought agre together suche serpente ambicion desire vainglory souereingtie emongest estate entred crepith furth far till deuision variauce turneth mischiefe firste longynge next beste afterwarde egall beste laste chief aboue beste whiche immoderate appetite worship debate discencion grewe losse sorowe trouble hath within fewe yeres growen within realme pray god well forget well remembre whiche thynge coulde well haue forsene haue pain pleasure proued god blessed lady common othe would neuer haue curtesies mennes knee losse many heddes sith thynges passed cannot bee called agayne muche ought wee bee ware occasion wee haue taken greate hurte wee eftsones fall occasion bee greues passed al quiet thanked bee god likely well prospere welthfull peace vnder cosins child yf god sende theim life loue concorde whiche two thynges lesse losse thei although god pleasure yet shoulde realme alwayes fynde kynges paraduenture good kynges thei yf emongest selfes chyldes reigne fall debate many good manne shall innocently perishe happely also land finde peace quiet agayne wherefore laste woordes euer looke speake exhorte require loue haue borne loue haue borne loue oure lorde beareth v tyme forward greues forgotten eche loue whiche verely trust yf thynge regarde god kynges affinitee kynrede realme owne conntree owne surete wealth kynge fayntenesse longer enduryng sitte vp layed hym downe righte side face toward theim none presente coulde forbeare weepynge lordes confortynge hym good wordes thei coulde answerynge tyme thoughte shoulde stande pleasure presence woordes apeared eche forgaue ioyned handes together appeared dedes harte far sunder whithin fewe day noble prince disceased westminster nynth daye aprill yere lorde mcccclxxxiii reigned xxii yeres one moneth eight day great funerall pompe conueighed windsore leuynge behynde hym twoo sonnes edward prince story entreateth chylde xiii yeres age richard duke yorke twoo yeres younger prince fiue daughter elizabeth whiche god grace maried kynge henry seuenthe mother kynge henry eighte cicile fortunate faire firste wedded vicounte welles one kyne liued greate wealthe bridget professed selfe close nonne sion anne maried lorde thomas hauwarde erle surrey duke northfolke katherine youngest daughter maried lorde william courtney sonne therle deuonshire whiche long tyme tossed either fortune somtyme wealth aduersite till benignitee nephewe kyng henry eighte broughte sure estate accordynge degre progeny kynge edwarde suche prince gouernaunce behaueoure ye tyme peace ye tyme warre eche must bee others enemie ye ther neuer kyng realme attainyng croune warre battaillthe discrip ion king edward hertely beloued sub aunce people hym self specially fauoured parte life tyme deathe whiche fauour affcction yet deathe crueltee mischiefe trouble tempe iou world folowed highly towardes hym encreased suche tyme died displeasure bare hym grudge kyng henry sixte sake deposed well assuaged effecte quenched within space xxii yeres whiche greate parte mannes life reconsiled growen fauoure whiche neuer straunge true herte demaunded goodly personage princely beholde harte courageous politique counsaill aduersitee nothynge abashed prosperite rather ioyfull proude p ace iuste mercifull warre sharpe fearce felde bolde hardy yet neuerthelesse rther reason policye would aduenture whose warres whosoeuer circumspectely aduisedly considereth shal lesse commend wisedome policie aduoided manhod vanquished visage full faced louely body mightie strong cleane made whith ouer liberall wanton diet waxed somewhat corpulent bourly neuerthelesse vncomely youth greately geuen fleshely wantonnes whiche healthe body greate prosperitee fortune withoute especiall gracehardely refraineth fault litle greued people neither coulde one mannes pleasure stretche extend displeasure many multitude bee greued priuate mannes fantesy volupteousnesse dooen withoute violence latter day left wild daliaunce fell grauitce brought realme wealthie prosperous estate feare outwarde enemy clerly extinguished warre hande none towarde suche manne looked people towarde prince constrained feare true louyng wil ull obedience emongeste theim selfe common good peace lordes knewe variaunce deathe bedde thought brought good concorde loue amitee litle deathe left gatheryng money subiectes onely thyng draweth harte englishe menne kinges prince nothyng either enterprised tooke hande whiche shoulde bee driuen vnto tribute fraunce litle recouered obteined yere died recouered agayn towne berwike kyng scottes albeit al tyme reigne benigne courteous familier parte vertues estemed highe humilitees yet condicion thende last day decaied whiche many prince longe continued soueraingtee decline proud porte behaueour condicions accustomed begynnynge yet lowlinesse gentlenesse far furth hym encreased sommer died beeynge hauerynge bower sente maire alderman london thether onely hunte make pastyme made theim hertye familiare aud frendly chere sent also wiues suche plenty venison one thyng many day gatte hym either mo harte hertie fauour emongest comon people often tymes esteme take greate kyndenesse litle courtesie greate profite benefite noble prince deceassed haue hearde tyme life moste desired people moste desired kepe hym whiche loue people entiere affection towarde hym hys noble chyldren hauynge theim selues also many giftes nature many princely vertues muche good towardenesse age coulde receyue merucilous fortresse sure armoure yf diuision dissencion frendes vnarmed theim left theim destitute execrable desire soueraingtie prouoked hym destruction whiche yf either kynde kyndnesse holden place muste nedes haue chiefe defence richard duke gloucester nature vncle office protectoure father greately beholden theim othe allegeaunce bounden bandes broken violated whiche bynde man man together withoute respecte god worlde vnnaturally contriued bereue theim onely dignitee preheminence also naturall liues worldely felicitee first shewe coniecture pretended thyng brother life ye shall vnderstande truth nighte kynge edwarde died one called mistelbrooke longe ere daye sprog came ye house one pottier dwellyng redcrosse strete without creple gate london hasty rappyng quickely let saied mistlebroke shewed vnto pottier kyng edward night deceased truth quod pottier master duke gloucester bee kyng warrant thee cause thynke harde saie whether beeyng seruaunte knewe suche thyng pretensed otherwise ynkelyng therof likelihod spake naught returne trewe historie wer duke gloucester old sore practised conclusion tyme moued vnto putte hope tender age young prince nephewes oportunitee likely spede putteth manne courage neuer entended certain beeynge northe party good gouernaunce countrye beynge aduertised brother deathe contriued destruction nephewes vsurpacion royall dignitee croune asmuche well wiste holpe maintain long continued grudge harte burning betwene quenes kynred kynges bloude either parte enuiyng others autoritee thought deede furtherly beginnynge pursute entente sure grounde situacion vnnaturall buyldynge yf mighte vnder pretence reuengynge olde displeasure abuse ignorauce anger one partie destruction wyn purpose many coulde suche coulde bee wonne mighte bee loste loked therefore one thynge certain yf entent wer perceiued hould haue made peace betwene bothe party owne bloud intente kept secrete till knewe frendes whiche henry duke buckyngham firste sente hym brother death trusty seruaunte called persiuall citee yorke duke gloucester kepte kynge brother funeralles persiuall came ihon warde secrete chamberer duke gloucester desirynge close couerte maner mighte speake duke master vpon ded nighte duke sente persiuall beeyng auoyded whiche shewed duke gloucester duke buckyngham master newe worlde woulde take suche parte woulde woulde farther wayte vpon hym thousande good felowes yf nede duke sente backe messanger greate thankes diuerse priuey instruction mouthe whiche persiuall somuche trauaill came duke buckyngham master march wale eftsones newe instruction met duke gloucester notyngham whiche come northecountree many knightes gentleman numbre sixe hundred horse iourney towarde london secrete metynge communicacion betwene hym duke gloucester returned suche spede brought duke buckyngham master mete duke gloucester far northampton thre hundred horsses twoo came together northampton thei first began vnhappy enterprice duke buckyngham contynued still duke gloucester til crouned kyng ye shal plaily perceiue herafter younge kynge deathe father kepte houshoulde ludlowe father sente hym thether iustice bee dooen march wale ende autoritee presence wilde welshemenne eiuell disposed personnes refrain accustomed murthers outrage gouernauce younge prince committed lord antony wooduile erle ryuers lorde scale brother quene wise hardy honourable personage valiaunte handes politique counsaill hym associate partie effect euery one nerer kynne vnto quene planted nexte aboute prince drift quene semed bee diuised whereby bloudde mighte righte tender youthe bee planted prince fauoure afterwarde shoulde hardely bee eradicated duke gloucester turned distruction vpo grounde set foundacion vnhappy buyldyng soeuer perceiued bee variaunce theim beare toward hym selfe fauoure brake vnto theim mouthe writynge secrete messenger neither reason yet suffered younge kynge master kynsman shoulde bee handes custody mother kyntede sequestered maner compaignie attendaunce whiche euery one oughte hym faithefull seruice many theim farre honorable parte kynne mother side whose bloud quod duke gloucester sauyng kyng pleasure farre vnmete bee matched bee remoued kyng leaste noble bee lefte aboute hym quod neither honourable maiestie v also hym lesse suretie haue noble mightiest frendes hym v litle ieopardie suffre specially well proued euill willers growe greate autoritee kynge youthe namely whiche lighte belefe soone persuaded ye remembre kyng edward hym self albeit bothe age discrecion yet ruled many thynges bende stode either honour profite commoditee anye manne el excepte onely immoderate auauncemente theim selues whiche whether thirsted sore owne weale harde thynke gesse yf folkes frendeshipe holden better place kynge respecte kynrede thei mighte paraduenture easely haue trapped broughte confusion v easely thei haue dooen nere blud royall lorde hath wroughte thanked bee grace perell paste howebeit greate growyng suffre young kyng enemy handes whiche without wittyng might abuse name commaundemente vndoyng whiche thinges god good prouision forbid whiche good prouision none v hath thynge lesse nede late attonemete made ye kyng pleasure place party hertes willes none v vnwise somuch ouersene trust newefred made old foo thinke onely kindenesse sodenly contracted houre continued scantly yet fourtnight bee deper set stomackes longe accustomed malice many yeres rooted perswasions writinges duke gloucester sette fire theim whiche easie kyndle especiall twain henry duke buckyngham willyam lord hastynges lord chamberlain bothe menne honoure greate power one longe succession aunceters thother office kynge fauoure two bearyng eache much loue hatred ye quenes bloud acc roed together duke gloucester thei would remoue kyng mother frendes vnder name enemy vpon duke gloucester beynge aduertised lordes aboute kynge entended brynge hym london co onacion accompaigned suche number frendes shoulde bee harde hym brynge purpose passe without assemblyng gatheryng people maner open warre wherof ende wyst doubtfull kyng beyng syde parte shoulde haue name face rebellion secretely therefore diuerse meanes caused quene persuaded neither nede also ieoperdeous ye kyng come vp strong euery lord loued none thyng studied triumphe coronation honoure kyng lordes kyng assemble kynges name muche people thei geue ye lordes betwixt ther bene tyme bebate occasion feare suspecte least gather people kynges saue gard man impugned destruction hauyng regarde olde variaunce new attonement cause parte might assemble men also defence whose powres wyst wel farre retched thus realme fal roare mischiefe therof shoulde ensue whiche likely lytle ye harme like fal least woulde world would put kynred blame saiyng thei vnwysely vntruely broken amytie peace whiche kynge husband prudently made betwene kynred whiche amyte kynne alwaies obserued quene beyng thus persuaded sent worde kyng brother cause nede assemble people also duke gloucester lordes bend wrote vnto ye kyng reuerently quenes frendes louyngly nothynge yearthly mistrustyng brought young kynge towarde london sober compaignie great hast good spede til came northampton thece remoued stony stratford whiche day two duke bende came northampton fainyng stony stratford could lodge al thei foud erle riuers entendynge nexte mornynge haue folowed kynge earely mornyng night duke made erle ryuers frendly chere assone departed familier greate curtesie open sight therle ryuers lodged two duke fewe priuy frendes fel councel wherin spent great parte night dawnynge daye sent aboute priuely seruauntes lodgynges hast horsebacke lordes maner redy ryde whervpo seruauntes ready lorde ryuers seruauntes awake nowe duke taken keyes ynne possession none shoulde yssue withoute consent ouer high way towarde stony stratford set certaine folkes cause copell retourne againe person passyng northampton stony stratforde saiyng duke self would fyrst come kyng northampton thus bare folkes hand earle ryuers vnderstode gate closed wayes euery syde beset neither seruauntes neither selfe suffered go perceyuinge great thynge withoute knowlege begon noughte comparynge present doyng laste nightes chere fewe houres greate chaunge marueilously myslyked howebeit syth coulde get awaye determined kepe selfe close least seme hyde selfe secret feare owne faute wherof saw cause selfe wherfore suretie owne conscience determined goo inquire matter might meane assone sawe beganne quarel affirmyng pretended set distaunce betwene kyng brynge confusion whiche shoulde lye powre beganne eloquente well spoken manne goodlywyse excuse hym selfe woulde heare aunswere toke hym force put hym ward mounted horsbacke came haste stony stratforde kynge goyng horsebacke would leaue lodgyng straight bothe copaignies thei came presence alighted compaignie aboute knee saluted hym gentely receiued nothing yerthly knowyng ner mistrustyng yet duke buckyngham said aloude afore gentlemenne yomen kepe roumes therwith ye kynges presence picked quarel lord richard grey quenes sonne brother lord marque halfe brother king saiyng marque brother lord ryuers vncle compassed rule kyng realme set variaunce betwene thestates subdue destroy noble bloude realme towarde thacomplishemente sayde lorde marque entred towre london thence taken treasure sent men sea whiche thynges duke knewe well done good purpose necessary appointed whole counsaill london somewhat muste saye vnto whiche wordes kynge answered brother marque hath done cannot saye good faythe dare well answere mine vncle riuers brother innocente suche mat er yee liege quod duke buckyngham haue kept dealyng matter farre knowlege youre good grace furthwith arrested lorde rychard sir thomas uaugham sir richard hawte knyghtes kyngs presence broughte kyng back northampton toke counsaill affaire sent kyng pleased set aboute suche seruauntes better pleased dealyng wepte content booted dynner duke glocester sent dyshe owne table lord ryuers praiyng bee good chere shoulde well thanked prayed messenger beare nephiewe lorde richard like wordes knewe haue nede co fort one suche aduersite straunge hym selfe bene day ennured therwith therfore could beare better al message duke gloucester sent ye lorde ryuers lord richard sir thomas uaugham sir richarde hawte northparties diuerse prisones last al came pou fret foure beheaded without iudgement maner haue hard duke gloucester toke gouernaunce yonge kyng much reuerence conu ied towardes london tidynges came hastely quene mydnighte sore reporte kynge sonne taken brother sonne frendes arested sent man wyste whether heauy tidynges quene bewayled chyldes ruyne frendes mischaunce owne infortune curffyng tyme euer persuaded leaue gatherynge people brynge vp kynge greate powre passed therfore nowe toke younger sonne duke yorke doughters went palays westminster sanctuary lodged abbotes place chyldren compaignie regestred sanctuarye person night came doctor rotheram archebyshop yorke lorde chauncelour messenger lorde chambrelayne yorke place besyde westminster messenger broughte bishoppes bedsyde declared duke gone backe young kyng northampton declared lorde hastynges maister sent hym worde shoulde feare nothyng well wel quod archebishop wel wyl wyll neuer wel haue sene messenger departed wherupon bishop called vp seruauntes toke hym great seale came day quene aboute round much heuynesse rumble haste busynesse conueighaunce cariage hir stuffe sanctuarye euery man busy carye beare conueigh stuffe chestes fardelles man vnoccupied caried commaunded another place quene sat alone belowe rush desolate dismayde archebishoppe conforted best maner coulde shewyng matter nothyng sore tooke putte good hope feare message sent hym lorde hastynges wo worth hym quod quene goeth destroy blodde madame quod good comforte assure yf crowne kynge sonne nowe haue shal morow croune brother haue great seale likewyse noble husband deliuered deliuer vse sonne therwith deliuered greate seale departed home dawning day opened wyndowes loked temys might see riuer full boates duke gloucester seruauntes watchyng person go sanctuary ner none passe vnserched greate rumoure commotion citee place people diuersely diuined vpon dealynge diuerse lordes knightes gentilmen either fauoute quene feare selfes assembled compaignies wente flockyng together harneies many also recompted demeanour attempted specially lordes kynge hym selfe dysturbaunce coronacion therefore assembled together common matter london archebishoppe yorke fearinge woulde ascribed dede ouermuch lightnes sodeinly yelded vp great seale quene custody therof nothing apperteigned withoute especial commaundemente kynge secretely sente seale againe broughte hym accustomed maner mete lordes metynge lorde hastynges whose trueth towarde kyng manne doubted neded doubte persuaded lordes beleue duke gloucester faithefull sure towardes prince lord ryuers lorde richard knightes apprehended matter attempted duke gloucester buckyngham put vnder arest suretie kynges ieopardie also sauegarde remayne tyll matter duke onely also lordes kynges councell indifferently examined discrecions ordred either iudged appesed one thynge auised beware iudged matter farfurthe knewe trueth turnynge priuate grudge common hurte irritynge prouokynge men vnto angre disturbyng kynges coronacion towarde duke commynge mighte paraduenture brynge matter farre oute ioynte shoulde neuer brought frame againe whiche yf shoulde happe likely come felde though al party thynges egual yet shoulde authorytee bee syde kynge hym selfe persuasion lorde hastynges whereof parte hym selfe beleued parte wyst well cotrary commocions appeased especiall duke buckyngham gloucester nere came shortely kynge none maner none voice sembleaunce coronacio causyng fame blowen aboute suche person apprehended contriued distruction duke gloucester buckyngham noble bloude realme entente alone woulde rule gouerne kynge coloure thereof suche duke seruauntes rode carte stuffe whiche taken among whiche stuffe marueyle though harneyes whiche breakynge vp suche housholde muste broughte awaye caste awaye shewed people went sayd lo barrelles harneyes traitours priuelye conueighed cariages destroye noble lordes withal diuerse although made matter wyse men vnlikely wel perceiuyng thentendours suche purpose woulde rather haue harneyes backes haue boud vp barrelles yet muche parte common people therewith right well satisfied kynge approched nere cytee london edmonde shawe goldesmythe mayre cytie aldermenne shreues skarlet fyue hundreth commoner murraye receyued grace reuerently harnesay parke conueighed cytee entred fourth day may fyrst last yere reigne lodged bishoppe london palayce ye duke gloucester bare open sight reuerently saiyng al rode behold prince souereigne lord made suche sembleaunce lowlynes prince greate obloquy late sodenly fallen greate trust councel next assembled made onely chiefe ruler thought mete protectoure kynge realme desteny foly lambe betaken wolfe kepe whiche councell archebishop yorke sore blamed deliueryng great seale quene seale taken deliuered doctor iohn russel bishop lyncolne wyse good much experience diuerse lordes knyghtes appointed diuerse roumes lorde chamberlayne kept oumes many nowe protectour whiche alwayes must take duke gloucester sore thristed acheuynge pretensed entrepryse thought euery daye yeare tyll perfourmed yet durste attempte long half pray hand well wittyng yf deposed one brother realme woulde fall yf remayned either sanctuarye shoulde happely shortly conueighed father libertie wherfore incontinent nexte metynge lordes councel purposed heynous thyng quene procedyng great malice toward kynges councelers kepe kynges brother sanctuarye whose speciall pleasure comforte haue brother done none intente brynge lordes obloquy murmoure people though trusted kynges brother whiche lordes whole assente noble realme appointed kynges nere frendes tuycion royall person prosperitee wherof quod standeth alonely kepynge enemy euill dyate partely also recreacion moderate pleasure whiche cannot take tendre youth compaignye old auncient person familiare conuersacion far vnder farre aboue age neuerthelesse estate conueniente accompany maiestie wherfore rather owne brother yf man thynke consideracion lighte thynke man thynketh loueth kynge let hym consider somtyme without smal thynges greater cannot stande verely redouneth greatly dishonoure kynges highnes v grace haue come man mouthe realme onely also landes euill wordes walke far ye kynges brother fayne kepe sanctuary euery man wyll iudge man wyll nought suche opinion fastened men harte harde wrested maye growe griete man diuine wherfore thinketh ye worst send quene honourable trustie personage ten dreth kynges weale honour coucell also credite fauoure whiche consideracions none femeth metely reuerende father lorde cardinall archebishop cauntorbury may matter moste good men yf please take payne whiche doubt goodnes refuse kynges sake wealth younge duke hym selfe kynges honorable brother conforte souereigne lorde hym selfe dearest nephiewe consideryng therby shalbe ceassed launderous rumore obloquy nowe going abrode hurtes auoyded therof might ensue must rest quietnesse growe realme yf percase obstinate precisely set owne wyll opinion neither wyse faithfull aduertisemente moue man reason satisfye shall myne aduice kynges authorytee fetche hym oute prison brynge hym noble presence whose continuall compaignye shalbee well cheryshed honorably intreated worlde shall honour reproche perceiue onely malice frowardnesse foly caused kepe mynd tyme except lordes thyng perceyue contrari neuer shal god grace wed self vnto myne owne wil shalbe ready chauge vpon better aduices protectour sayde councell affirmed mocion good reasonable kyng duke brother honourable thyng ceasse great murmoure realme yf mother might good meanes induced delyuer whiche thynge archebishop cauntorburye agreed also moost conuenient therunto tooke vpon hym moue therto vttermooste endeuoure howebeit yf coulde wyse intreated good wyll delyuer hym thought spiritualtie present wyse bee attempted take hym againste wyll woulde thyng turne grudge men highe displeasure god yf pryuilege place shoulde broken whiche many yeres bene kepte whiche bothe kynges pope graunted confirmed ground sanctifyed sainct peter himselfe fyue hundreth yeres agone syth tyme neuer vndeuoute kynge euer enterprised sacred priuilege violate holy byshop durste presume church consecrate therefore quod archebishop god forbyd manne shoulde yearthely enterprise breake immunyte libertie sacred sanctuary hath bene safegard many good man life trust quod shall nede maner nede would trust reason shalbe contented thynge good maner obteined yf hap brynge passe yet shall best power shal perceyue good wyll diligence indeuoure mother dreade womannishe feare shalbe let yf naye womannishe frowardnesse quod duke buckyngham dare take solle well knoweth nedeth thynge feare either sonne self man wyll warre woman would god men kynne woman sone rest howbeit none kynne lesse loued kynne awne euill deseruynge put case neither loued kynne yet cause shoulde hate kynges noble brother whose grace oure selfes kynne whose honoure yf desired dishonoure muche regarde toke wealth awne wyll coulde loth suffre absent kyng v yf wytte woulde god good wyll hath frowarde wytte thinketh selfe wyser whose faithful myndes nothing doubteth verely beleueth knowlegeth woulde sorye harme awne selfe yet would haue abyde thynke content bothe chyldren came thence abyde suche place may honoure nowe yf refuse deliueraunce hym folowe wysedome whose wysedome knoweth whose approbate fidelitee well trusteth easye percewe frowardenesse letteth feare goo suppose feareth may let feare awne shadowe oughte feare leaue hym handes yf cast suche fonde doubtes feare hurte wyll feare shall fet thence wyll soone thynke yf men set whiche god forbyd great mischiefe sanctuary wyl litle let whiche sanctuary good men thinketh might without synne somewhat lesse regard nowe doubt least might fetched likely wyl sende hym somewhere realme verely loke none doubt nowe sore myndeth mynde set therof might hap brynge purpose passe great mastery lettyng alone worlde would say sorte wyse cousaillers kyng let brother ast away vnder oure nose therfore ensure faithfully mynde wyll rather maugre stomacke fetche hym awaye leaue till feare fonde frowarde feare conuey awayof sanctuary yet breake sanctuary verely sithe priuelege place sorte haue log continued would goo aboute breake yf thei nowe begynne woulde make yet wyl say nay deede pitie men chauce sea euill debters haue brought pouertee haue place refuge kepe body daunger cruel creditours fortune croune come question hath done tyme whyle eche parte taketh traytours thynke necessarye haue place refuge bothe theues murtherers wherof place full whiche neuer falle crafte falle therunto pytee euer sanctuary serue especiall wylfull murtherers god commaundeth taken aulter put death otherwyse case nede sainctuaries apointed god olde lawe yf necessite owne defence misfortune driued hym deede pardon serueth either graunted course ye kyng pytee compassion geueth nowe loke howe fewe sainctuary menne necessitee misfortune compelled go thether see syd sorte commonely therein suche wylfull vnthrittynes hath brought naught rable theues murtherers malicious heynous traitours twoo place specially one elbowe cytee bowel dare well vowe yf way good hurte commeth ye shall fynde muche better lese bothe haue bothe saye although abused nowe longe haue bene feare euer wyll whyle men afearde set handes amendemente though god saincte peter patron vngracious liuynge nowe vnthriftes riote ronne debte vpon boldnes place yea ritche menne ronne thyther poore men goodes buylde spende byd creditours goo whystle men wyues ronne thither husbandes plate saye dare abyde husbandes betynge theues brynge thither stollen goodes lyue theron deuyse newe robbery nightely steale oute robbe riue kyll menne come agayne place though place gaue theim onely sauegard harme haue dooen licence also mischiefe howebeit muche greate abusion yf wyse menne woulde sette handes vnto mighte bee amended greate thankes god breche priuilege conclusion sithe long goo wote pope prince piteous politique hath graunted menne sence religious feare haue broken lette v take paine lette stande goddes name force far furthe reason whiche farfurthe maye serue lette v fetchynge furthe noble manne honoure wealthe place whiche nether bee sanctuarye priuileged man sanctnarye euer sernethe defende bodye manne standeth daunger abrode greate hurte onely lawfull hurte againste vnlawfull hurtes harmes pope ner kynge entended priuilege one place wherein lawefull one manne doo another manne wronge manne vnlawefully take hurte libertie kynge lawe verie nature fordiddeth euerye place maketh regarde euery manne euery place sanctuarye manne lawefull meanes perell nedeth tuicion speciall priuilege whiche onely grounde sanctuary whiche necessitee noble prince farre whose loue kynge nature kynred proueth whose innocencie worlde tender youthe affirmeth sanctuarye hym necessary ner none haue menne come sanctuarye come babtisme require godfather muste aske hym selfe muste haue reason sithe manne hath cause haue whose consience awne faute maketh hym haue nede require hath younder babe yf discreccion require yf nede dare saye woulde bee nowe righte angry theim kepe hym woulde thinke withoute scruple consience withoute breche priuilege bee somewhat homely theim bee sanctuarye menne deede yf one goo sanctuary another mannes goodes shoulde kyng leuyng body liberty satisfy party goodes euen within sanctuary nether king pope geue place priuilege shall discharge man debtes beeyng hable paie iuerse clergie presente whether saied pleasure thoughte agreed plainly lawe god churche goodes sanctuarye man deliuered paiment debtes stollen goodes owner onely libertie reserued hym get liuyng labour handes uerely quod duke thynke ye saye truth yf mannes wife take sanctuary list ronne fro husband would thynke yf allege none cause may laufully without displeasure dooen sainct peter take saincte peter churche arme yf body maie taken sanctuary saieth abide yf chylde take sanctuary feareth go schoole master must lette hym alone simple example yet lesse reason case though bee childeshe feare yet leaste feare herein feare verely haue harde sanctuarye menne neuer harde sanctuary child therefore conclusion mynde whosoeuer maie deserue haue nede thei thynke suretee let theim kepe sanctuary manne hath nother discresion desire ner malice deserue whose life ner libertie lawfull processe stande ieoperdye taketh one sanctuarye dooe hym good saie plainly breaketh sanctuary duke doen temporal menne wholy moste parte spirituall menne also thynkynge hurte earthely ment toward younge baby condiscended effecte yf wer deliuered shoulde bee fetched oute howebeit thoughte beste aduoydyng maner rumour cardinall shoulde firste assaie get hym good thervpon counsaill came ye sterre chamber westminster cardinal leauing protectour lordes sterre chamber departed sanctuarye ye quene accompaignied certain lordes respecte hys honoure shoulde persones many perceiue arrande onely one mannes mynde wer protectour entended matter truste one manne alone el finally determined kepe hym copaignie paraduenture secrete instruction incontinente maugree take hym leaue respite conueigh hym quene lordes come together presence cardinall shewed vnto thought lorde protectour whole counsaill kepyng kyng brother place highly sounded onely grudge people obloquy also importable grief displeasure kynge royall maiestye whose grace synguler comforte haue naturall brother compaignie bothes dishonoures also suffre hym sanctuary though one brother stode danger perell shewed farther whole counsaill sente hym require deliuerye might bee brought king presence libertie place whiche menne reconed prisone demeaned according estate degree doyng bothe dooe great good realme pleasure counsaill profite self succour frendes wer distresse ouer wiste well specially tendered onely greate comforte honoure kynge also younge duke hym selfe whose bothe greate wealth bee together aswell many greater cause also bothe disporte recreacion whiche thynges lordes estemed lighte though semed lighte well ponderynge youthe without recreacion plaie cannot endure ner estraunger conuenience age estate metely poinct either thother lord quod quene saie naie wer conueniente gentleman require compaignie kyng brother good faith thynketh wer great commoditee theim bothe yet bee custody mother tendre age considered elder theim bothe especiall younger whiche besides infancie also nedeth good lookynge hath sore deseased sickenes newlye rather litle amended well recouered dare putte persone earthely truste kepyng selfe onely consideryng phisicians saie also finde double perell resiluacion firste sickenes whiche desease nature beeyng sore laboured foreweried weakened waxeth lesse hable beare newe surfet albeit might bee founde woulde happely doo beste vnto hym yet none either knoweth better howe ordre hym longe haue kepte tendrely like cherishe hym owne mother bare hym man denieth good madame quod cardinall grace folke wer moste necessarie aboute chyldren woulde counsaill onely bee contente also glad might stand pleasure bee place might stande honoure yf apoincte selfe tary thynke couenient duke yorke wer kinge honorably libertie comforte theim bothe sanctuary man bothe dishonoure obloquy sith alway great necessite haue child mother occasion sometyme maie bee suche shoulde bee expedient kepe hym el whiche well apereth suche tyme moste derest sonne prince kyng shoulde honor good ordre countree kepe houshoulde wale far kepyng grace well content therewith self wel content quod quene yet case like one health theother sicke case maruaill greately lorde protectour desirous haue hym kepyng child sickenesse miscaried nature yet might ronne slauuder suspicion fraud call thyng sore childes honour also ye abideth place honoures suffre hym abyde doubteth shalbe best kept yet entende come furthe ieoperde self frendes whiche woulde god wer rather suretee ieoperdie theim madame quod lord haward knowe thyng bee ieopardie nay verely quod thei bee prisone neither thei nowe bee trowe greate marueill though feare least haue letted put theim duraunce withoute coloure let litle procure distruction withoute cause cardinall made countenaunce lord haward harpe vpon stryng saied quene nothyng doubted lordes kynne whiche remained vnder reste vpon matter examined doo well ynough towarde noble persone neither coulde bee maner ieoperdie whereby shoulde truste quod quene gyltesse though thei gyltie enemy better beloued hate theim sake nere kynge howe farre bee woulde helpe god sende grace hurte therefore yet purpose departe hence gentleman sonne mynde shal bee till see see men gredy withoute substanciall cause haue hym whiche maketh much scrupulous deliuer hym truely madame quod cardinall ye bee deliuer hym bee menne suffre kepe hym leaste causelesse feare mighte cause farther conueighe hym many thynke haue priuilege whiche haue neither aske yet malice offence nede therefore recon priuilege broken although fetche hym sanctuarie whiche yf finally refuse deliuer hym thynke verely counsaill enfraunchefe hym muche dread hath lorde vncle tendre loue beareth hym leaste grace shoulde sende hym awaye ah quod quene hath tendre zeale hym feareth nothynge leaste escape hym thynketh would send hym hece neither plight sende place could recon hym sure yf sure sanctuary wherof neuer tiraunte yet deuelishe durste attempt breake priuilege trust god strong withstand aduersaries euer sonne deserue sanctuary saye therefore haue forsothe lord protectour hath sent goodly glose whiche place maye defende thefe maie saue innocent ieoperdie hath nede therof would god troweth protectour pray god maie proue protectour rather destroyer vnto painted processe draweth honourable duke byde confortable theim bothe brother kyng lacketh plaie feloe yea sure praye god send hym better plai felowes hym maketh high matter vpon trifleyng pretexte though could none bee found plaie kyng brother hath luste plaie sickenesse must come sanctuary sauegard plaie hym though prince young thei bee could plaie without peeres child coulde playe without kynred parte agree much worse straungiers chylde saie cannot require priuilege tolde protectour aske hym shall hym aske shall yf ye howebeit straunge matter suppose coulde aske thynke would aske imagene would aske goo saye shal note yf aske priuilege self say againste taketh hym breaketh sanctuarie serueth libertie persone onely goodes maie fro hence take horsse yf stale hym owe nothyng foloweth maye take child also ward farre learned counsaill sheweth hath nothyng dissente holden knightes seruyce socage lawe maketh guarden maye manne lawfully suppose take warde place without breche sanctuary priuilege coulde serue hym aske hym self yet sith lawe committeth custodye hym maye require hym excepte lawe geue infaunte guarden onely goodes dischargynge hym cure sauekepyng body onely bothe goodes landes serue wherefore entende kepe hym sithe mannes lawe serueth guarden kepe infante lawe nature willeth mother kepe chyld goddes law priuilegeth sanctuary sanctuarye priuilegeth sonne sith feare put hym protectoures handes hath brother already whiche yf bothe failed inheritoure crowne heire male saythe cause feare manne hath doo examine yet feare ferther lawe feareth whiche learned menne tell forbiddeth euery manne custodye theim whose death maie enherite lesse lande kyngdome saie whosoeuer bee breaketh holy anctuary prai god sende hym shortely nede sanctuary maye come woulde mortall enemie shoulde bee taken oute sanctuary cardinall perceiued quene euer longer farther also began kyndle chafe spake sore bytynge woordes againste protectoure suche neither beleued also loth saied finall coclusion would dispute matter yf contente deliuer duke hym lordes presente durste laie owne body solle bothe pledge onely suretye also estate surely knewe suspected cause mighte dooe knewe saied woulde geue hym resolute aunswere contrary would therewith departe incontinente shifte woulde businesse afterwarde neuer entended moue matter whiche thoughte also saue selfe lacked either witte trueth witte yf wer dull yf nothynge coulde perceiue protector entended yf procure sonne bee deliuered handes thei perceiue towardes child euyll entended mighte thynke counsaill bothe euill aduised litle fidelitee prince quene woordes stode greate study forasmuch sawe lorde cardinall redier departe remanaunte protectoure hym selfe redy hande verely thought could kepe bee incontinente taken thence conueigh hym el neither tyme serue place determined persones appointed conueigh hym thyng vnredy messsage came sodainly nothyng lesse lookynge haue hym sanctuarye knewe menne sette al place could bee conueighed vntaken partely thoughte mighte fortune feare bee false well wiste either nedelesse bootelesse wherefore yf shoulde nedes goo hym demed beste deliuer hym specially cardinalles faithe nothyng doubtyng lordes sawe whiche feared le e mighte bee deceiued well assured woulde bee corrupted thought would make theim warely loke hym circumspectely see surety yf owne handes betooke hym truste laste toke young duke hand saied vnto lordes lorde quod lordes neither vnwyse mystruste wittes suspicious mistruste truthes whyche thyng purpose make suche proofe either bothe lacked might turne bothe greate sorowe realme muche harme great reproche lo quod gentlema doubt coulde kepe safe would whatsoeuer manne saie doubte also bee abroade dedly enemy vnto bloud yf wiste wher laye owne body would lette haue also experiece desire kyngdome knoweth kynrede brother hath brother bane maie nephewes bee sure vncle eche child others defence thei bee sunder eche liues lieth others body kepe one safe bothe sure nothyng bothe perilous bothe bee one place wise marchaunte neuer auentureth al gooddes one ship al notwithstandyng deliuer brother hym kepe handes whome shall aske theim bothe god worlde faithefull bee wote well knowe bee wise power strength yf liste kepe hym lacke helpe selues nede lacke helpe case yf cannot el maye yon leaue hym onely one thyng beseche truste father putte euer truste putte farre thynke feare muche ye bee well ware feare litle therewith saied chyld fare well myne awne swete sonne god sende good kepyng let kisse go god knoweth whe shal kisse together agayn therewith kyssed hym blessed hym turned backe wepte goyng waie leauyng poore innocet chylde wepyng faste mother cardinall lordes receyued younge duke brought starre chaumbre protectoure toke armes kissed hym wordes welcome lorde verie herte saied likelihod euen inwardely thought vpon furthwith brought kyng brother bishoppes palace paules thence cytee honorably tower daie neuer came abrode protectour chyldren possession yea sure place began thrist se ende enterprise auoyde al suspicion caused lordes whiche knewe bee faithfull kyng assemble baynardes castle comen ordre coronacion whyle complices affinitee crosby place contriued contrary make protectour kyng counsail adhibite fewe secrete began maner mutterynge emongest people though thyng long well though wy feared wherfore suche greate thynges mennes hertes secrete instinct nature misgeueth theim southwynde sometyme swelleth hym selfe tempeste one manne happely somewhat perceiuyng filled many menne suspicio thoughe shewed fewe menne knewe howbeit dealyng selfe made men muse matter though counsaill close litle litle folke drewe tower kyng drewe crosby place protectoure resorte kyng maner desolate whyle made suyte vnto theim doyng theim frendes secretly warned might happely turne good muche attendaunt kyng without protectoures apointemente whiche remoued diuerse kyng olde seruauntes sette newe toumes aboute hym thus many thynges comyng together partly chaunce partly purpose caused length comon people onely whiche wauer wynde wyse mene also lordes marke matter muse ther vpon much lorde stanley whiche afterwarde erle derby wysely mistrusted saied lord hastynges muche misliked two seuerall counsailes talke one matter one place litle wote whereof talke peace lorde lorde hastynges lyfe neuer doubte one manne neuer thence neither thyng mynded sounde amisse towarde myne eares well mouthes ment catesby whiche nere secrete counsail familierly vsed waightie matter puttyng manne speciall truste reconyng selfe man liefe sith wiste well man hym muche beholdyng catesby mane wel learned lawes lande speciall fauoure lorde hastynges good aucthoritie muche rule bare country lecestre northampton lorde hastynges power laye surely great pitie either trueth lesse wit hys dissimulacion onely kept mischief vp lorde hastynges put speciall truste lorde stanley diuerse lordes daparted countrees broken daunce many euill signes sawe whiche nowe construed beste surely thought could harme towarde hym counsaill entended catesbye trueth protectoure duke bukyngham made good sembleaunce vnto lorde hastynges kept hym muche compaignye vndoubtedly protectour loued hym well lothe haue loste hym sauyng feare leste lyfe haue quayled purpose whiche cause moued catesby proue wordes cast farre whether could thinke possible wynne lorde hastynges parte catesby whether assayed assayed reported vnto hym found fast herde speake terrible wordes durst farther breake truth lorde hastynges truste shewed vnto catesby mistruste began haue matter therefore fearyng leste mocios might lorde hastynges minishe credence vnto onely matter leaned procured protectour hastely ryd hym muche rather trusted hys death obtayne muche rule whiche lord hastynges bare hys countree onely desyre whereof thyng enduced procurer one speciallest contriuers thys horrible treason vpon lorde protectour caused counsaill set tower fridaye thirtene daye iune muche commonyng honourable solemnitee coronacion whiche tyme appoincted aproched nere pageauntes makyng daye night westminster vitaile killed whiche afterwarde caste awaye lordes thus sittyng comonyng matter protectour came emong theim nyne clocke salutyng theim curteously excusyng self theim long saiyng merely sleper daye litle talkyng theim sayed bishopp ely lorde haue verye good strawberies youre garden holborne require let v haue messe theim gladly lord would better thing redy pleasure hast sente seruaunt dishe strawberies protectour set lordes faste comonyng vpon prayed theim spare alitle departed came agayn betwene x eleuen clocke chambre chaunged sowre angry countenaunce knittyng browes frownyng fretyng gnawyng lip set hym doune place lordes dismaied sore marueyled maner sodeyne chaunge thyng hym ayle sitten whyle thus began worthy haue copasse ymagine destruccion beyng neare bloud kyng protectoure royall realme question lordes sate fore astonyed musyng muche question ment euery man knew self clere lorde hastynges familiaritie betwene theim thought might boldest hym aunswered sayd worthy punished heynous traytours soeuer affirmed yonder sorceres brother wife menyng quene woordes many lordes sore abashed whiche fauoured lorde hastynges better content hys mynde moued lued better albeit hys hart grudged afore made counsail matter well takyng kynred puttyng death whiche hys assent deuysed beheaded pomfrete selfe daye whiche ware deuised hym selfe daye beheaded london sayed protectour wyse sorceresse counsayle shore wyfe affinitie haue sorcery witchecrafte wasted body therwith plucked vp doublet sleue elbowe hys lette arme shewed weryshe wythered arme small neuer therupon euery mannes mynde mysgaue theim well perceyuyng matter quarell well wist quene wyse go folye also would yet would al folke make shore wyfe least counsaile woman hated cocubine kyng husband loued also manne knewe hys arme euer sith day birth neuerthelesse lorde hastynges death kyng edward kept shore wife somwhat doted kynges lyfe sauyng sayed forbare reuerence towarde kyng el certayne kynde fidelitie towarde frend yet nowe hart somewhat grudged haue loued highly accused knewe well vntruely therefore aunswered sayed certaynly lorde yf haue doone worthy heynous punishement protectour thou seruest wene yf tell haue done wyll make good thy bodye traytour therewith great anger clapped fyste borde great rappe whiche token geue one cried treason without chamber therwith doore clapped came rushyng men harneyes many chamber could hold anone protectoure sayed lorde hastynges arrest traytoure lorde yea traytoure protectour one let flye lorde stanley shroncke stroacke fell vnder table el hys head bene cleft teth shortly shrancke yet ranne bloud aboute eares archebishop yorke doctour morton bishopp ely lorde stanley taken diuers whiche bestowed dyuers chamber saue lorde hastynges protectour comaunded spede shryue hym apace sainct poule wyll dyne tyll se thy head boted hum aske heuily toke priest auenture made shorte shrift lenger woulde suffered protectour made muche hast dyner might go tyll murther done sauyng hys vngracious othe brought furthe grene besyde chapel within towre head layed doune logge tymber lay buildyng chapel tyrannously striken body head wer enterred wyndesore maister kyng edward forth whose soules iesu pardon amen merueilous case heare either warnynges haue voyded token could voyde next nighte death lorde stanley sent trusty messenger midnight hast requiryng hym ryse ryde awaye hym disposed vtterly lenger abyde fearfull dreame whiche thought bore tuskes rased bothe heades bloud ran aboute bothe shoulder asmuch protectour gaue bore cognisaunce ymagined dreame made suche fearfull impression hys harte throughly determyned lenger tary horse redy yf lorde hastynges would go would ryde farre night daunger next day good lord lord hastynges messenger leaneth lorde thy maister muche suche try e hath suche saithe dreames whiche either awne feare phantasieth ryse nightes rest reason dayes thought tell playne wichcraft beleue dreames token thinges come thynketh might likely make theim true oure goyng yf caught brought backe frendes fayle flier bore cause lykely race v tuskes folkes fled falshead wherefore either peryll none deede yf rather ingoyng abidyng nedes fall peril one way yet leauer se me falshed thynke either awne faute faynte feble hart therfore go thy maister comende praye mery haue feare assure hym assured man wotteth sure myne awne hand god send grace messenger departed certeyn also redyng towarde towre mornyng whiche beheaded hys horsse accustomed ryde ombled twyse thryse almost fallyng thyng although happeth dayly mischauce towarde yet hath bene olde euyll token obserued goyng toward mischiefe foloweth warnyng enuious scorne mornyng ere vp bed shore wife lay night came sir thomas haward sonne lorde haward whiche lord one priueyest lord protectours counsaill doyng curtesye accompaignye hym counsaile truthe sent lorde protectour hast hym th herward sir thomas lord hastynges slayed awhile commonyng priest met towr rete brake lordes le saiyng merely lord pray come wherfore talke long priest haue nede priest yet laughed vpon hym though would saye shall haue nede one sone lytle wyst ment night wordes well remebred hard true lord hastynges litle mistrusted neuer merier ner thought life suretie al dayes thyng often signe chauge shall rather let thyng passe vayne surety man mynde neare hys death vpo towre wharffe neare place head sone might wel ca balle pursyuaut awne called hastynges mette hym metyng place put remebraunce another tyme happened mete together place tyme lorde hastynges bene accused kyng edward lord ryuers quenes brother insomuche lasted long highly kynges indignacion nowe mette pursiuaut place ieoperdy well passed gaue great pleasure talke therof talked place matter therfore sayed ah hastynges art thou remebred mette heauy hart ye lorde remembre well thaked god gat good ner harme therby thou wouldest saye yf thou knewest muche whiche knowe yet mo shall shortly meant therle ryuers lord richard sir thomas uaughan day beheaded pomfrete thei dede acte wist wel done nothyng ware axe hong nere awne head faith neuer sory ner neuer stode greate daunger ly e dyd thou mette lo worlde turned nowe nowe stand myne enemy daunger thou maist happe hear hereafter neuer lyfe merier neuer great surerye praye god proue hastynges proue doubtest thou nay nay warraunt maner displeased entered towre long lyue haue heard lorde god blyndnesse mortal nature feared moste suretye reconed hym selfe moste surest lost lyfe within two houres thus ended honorable manne good knight gentle great aucthoritie prince liuyng somwhat dissolute playne open enemy sure secrete hys frende easy begyle good harte courage foresawe perilles louyng man passyng welbeloued faythfull trustie ynough trustyng muche hys destruction maye perceyue nowe flewe fame thys lordes death cytie farther lyke wynde euery man eare protectoure immediatly dyner entendyng set colour vpo matter sent haste many substancial men cytie towre comyng selfe duke buckyngham stode harnessed olde euill fauoured briganders would wene would haue vouchesafed haue put backes excepte sodeyne necessitie constraigned lord protector shewed lord hastynges conspiracy contriued haue sodeynly destroyed hym duke buckyngham daie counsail entended farther yet well knowen whiche treason neuer knowlege x clocke forenone sodeyn feare draue put suche harnesse came nexte handes defence god holpe mischiefe turned vpon woulde haue done thus required theim report euery man answered fayre though mistrusted matter trueth beleued yet appeasyng people myndes sent immediatly dynner heralde armes proclamacion cytie london whiche proclaymed kynges name lord hastynges diuers trayterous purpose conspired daye haue slayne protectour duke buckyngham sittyng counsaill haue taken vpon rule kyng realme pleasure therby pill spoyle lyst vncomptrolled muche matter deuised proclamacion slaunder lord hastynges euyll counsailoure kynges father entisyng hym many thynges highly redoundyng diminishyng hys honoure vniuersall hurte realme euyll compaignie sinister procuryng vngracious example aswell many thynges vicious liuyng inordinate abusyon body bothe many especiall shore wyfe whiche one secrete counsaill heynous treason laye nightly namely night passed next death lesse marueill yf vngracious liuynge brought hym vnhappy ende whiche put comaundemet kyng highnes honourable faithfull counsaile bothe demerites beynge openly taken false cotriued treason also least delaiyng execucion might haue encouraged mischeuous person parteners hys conspiracy gather assemble selues together makyng great commocion hys deliueraunce whose hope nowe beyng well deserued death pollytickely repressed realme shall goddes grace rest good quyet peace nowe thys proclamacion made within twoo houres beheaded curiously endyted fayre writen parchement fayre sette hande therewith selfe long processe euery chyld might perceyue prepared studyed men thought catesby tyme betwene hys death proclamacion proclaimyng coulde skant haue suffyced vnto bare wrytyng alone albeit bene paper scribeled furthe haste aduenture vpon proclaimyng thereof one scolemayster paules standyng comparyng shortenesse tyme length matter sayed theim stoode aboute hym gaye goodly cast foule cast awaye hast marchaunte stoode hym sayed wrytten inspiracyon prophesye nowe anger coueteous protectoure sent sir thomas hawarde house shore wyfe husbande dwelte whiche spoyled euer aboue valure twoo thre thousande markes sent bodye pryson protectoure layde maner sake counsaill lorde hastynges destroye hym conclusion coloure could fasten vpon matter layed heynously charge thyng could denye world knewe true notwithstandyng euery man laughed heare sodeynly highly taken naught body cause godly continent prince cleane fautlesse hym selfe sent heauen thys vicious worlde amendement men maners caused byshop london putte open penaunce goyng crosse one sondaye precession taper hand whiche went countenaunce peace womanly albeit aray sauyng kyrtel yet went fayre louely namely wondryng people cast comely red checkes whiche mysse great shame wanne much prayse amongest amorous body curious soule many good folke hated liuyng glad se synne correected yet pitied penaunce reioysed considered protector corrupt mynd vertuous affection woman borne londonthe descripcion sho e wyfe well frended honestly brought vp well maryed sauyng somewhat sone husbande honest yong citezen godly good substaunce forasmuche coupled well rype feruetly loued neuer longed thyng chaunce easely made encline kynges appetite required howbeit respect royaltie hope gaye apparell ease pleasure wanton wealth hable sone perce softe tendre hart whe kyng abused anone husband beyng honest manne one could good presumyng touche kynges concubyne left vp hym altogether kyng dyed lorde hastynges toke whiche kynges dayes albeit sore enamoured yet forbare either pryncely reuerence certayne frendely faithfulnesse proper fayre nothyng body could haue chaunged yf would haue wished somewhat higher saye knewe youthe soem sayed iudged bene well fauoured iudged contrary whole iudgement seameth like mene gesse beautye one long departed scaple taken chanell house iudgemet tyme kyng henry eyght xviii yere whose reigne dyed nothyng reueled skynne bone beautye pleased mene muche pleasaunt behauoure proper wytte coulde reade wryte mery compaigny redy quicke answere neyther mute full bable somtyme tantyng without displeasure without disportethe descripcion kyng edward thre concubin kyng edward would saye ye thre concubine diuerse proparties diuersly excelled one meriest wyliest thirde holyest harlot realme one man coulde get churche place lightly bed two somwhat greater personage mastres shore neuerthelesse humilitie content nameles forbeare prayse property meriest shore wyfe kyng therfore toke great pleasure many loued whose fauoure saye trueth synne lye deuil neuer abused ma hurt many men comforte elie e kyng toke displeasure would mitigate apeace mynde men fauour would bryng grace many highly offended obteyned pardon great forfeatures gat remission finally many weighty suite stode many mene great steade either none small rewarde rather gaye riche either content dede wel done delighted sued vnto shewe able kyng wanton woman welthy alwaies couetous doubt man wyl thynke woman slight written emong graue weyghtie matter whiche shall specially thynke happely sawe age aduersite semeth chaunce much worthy remembred much wealth fell pouertie rich beggery vn rended acquaintaunce great substaunce great fauour prince great suite sekyng dayes busynes spede many men tymes whiche famous onely infamy euill deedes doynges muche lesse albeit muche lesse remembred euyll men vse write euyll turne marble stone good turne wryte dust whiche worst proued wealth went beggyng many begged selfes holpen suche chaunce deuised protectoure counsaile day ye lord camberlayne headed towre london houre beheaded poumfrete earle ryuers lorde richarde quenes sonne syr thomas uaughan sir richard haute whiche heard taken northampton stony stratfort consent lord hastynges whiche execution done ordre presence sir richard ratclif knight whose seruice protectoure specially vsed counsail execution suche lawlesse enterprise man bene long secrete hym hauyng experiece world shrewed wytte shorte rude speche rough boysterous behauour bold michiefe farre pytie feare god knight brought foure person scaffolde daye apoincted shewed people traitours sufferyng lordes speake declare innocecy least wordes might haue enclined men pytie hate protectour part without iudgemet precesse lawe caused beheaded without yearthly gylt onely ye good true kyng nye quene insomuch sir thomas uaughan goyng death sayed wo worthe toke prophecie g destroy kyng edwardes childre meaning ye duke clarece lord george ye suspicion dead remaineth richard g duke cloucester se ye shal accoplishe prophecie destroye kyng edwardes child alyes fredes appereth v day appele high tribunal god wrongful murther true innocencye ratclyffe sayed haue well apeled lay doune youre head ye syr thomas dye right beware dye wrong good knight beheaded three buryed naked int monastery poumfret lord hastynges lordes knightes thus beheaded ryd waye protectour caused proclaymed coronacion diuers great vrgent cause deferred tyll seconde daye nouember thought whyle men mused matter meant lordes realme awne strengthes whyle man wyste thynke truste euer haue tyme space digest matter make partes best hastely pursue purpose put hym self possession f croune menne could haue tyme deuyse wyse resyste nowe study matter beyng selfe heynous might first broken people suche wyse might well taken counsaile toke diuerse thought mete trusted likely enduced parte hable stand theim steade eyther powre polycye emong made counsaile edmond shaa mayre london whiche vpon trust hys awne auauncement proude harte highly desirous toke hym frame cytie appetite spirituall men toke suche wytte aucthoritie emongest people opinion learnyng scrupulous conscience emongest toke raffe shaa clearke brother mayre freer pynkie prouinciall augustine freers bothe doctours diuinitie bothe great preacher bothe learnyng vertue fame learnyng yet learnyng trueth greatly estemed emong people neuer none two regarded shaa made sermonde prayse protectour coronacion pynkye made one coronacion bothe full tedious flattery good man eares coulde abyde pynkye sermonde loste voyce fayne leaue come doune myddest doctoure shaa sermonde loste honesty sone lyfe shame worlde whiche durst neuer muche come abroade freer forced shame harmed hym lesse howbeit doubt many thynke pynkey counsaill coronacion common maner fell flattery namely sermond incontinent vpon sainct mary spittle easter certayne doctour shaa cousaill beginnyng much determyned fyrst breake matter sermond poules crosse whiche ancthoritie hys preachyng induce people encline protectours ghostly purpose laboure study deuise conuenient pret te people content depose prince accept protectour kyng diuerse thinges deuised chief thyng weight inuencion rested shoulde allege bastardy kyng edwarde hym selfe chyldren bothe seme disabled enherite croune duke yorke prince lay bastardy kyng edward sounded openly rebuke protectours awne mother whiche mother theim bothe poinct could none coloure pretende awne mother auoutresse neuerthelesse would poinct lesse fynely closely handled euen fully playne directely touched ope craftely though menne spared poinct speake trueth feare displeasure poincte concernyng basterdy deuised surmysse kyng edward chyldren would openly declared enforced vttermost coloure pretexte wherof cannot well perceyued excepte wee repete thinges long dooen aboute kyng edward marriage kyng edwarde fourthe deposed kyng henry sixte peaceable possession f realme determinyng sel e mary requisite bothe hym selfe realme sente therle warwike diuerse noble men ambassade frenche kyng entreate mariage betwene kyng bona sister frenche quene beyng fraunce thyng therle warwike founde party towarde willyng spedely without difficultie accordyng instruccions brought matter good conclusion nowe happeneth meane season came make sute kyng peticion dame elizabeth grey whiche quene widdowe borne noble bloude specially mother whiche duchesse bedforde maried sir richarde wooduile lorde riuers father howbeit elizabeth beyng seruice quene margaret wife kyng henry sixte maried one ihon grey esquire kyng henry made knight la te battaill sainct albones litle enioyed knighthod thesame feld slain kyng edward kyng erle warwike beyng ambassad poore lady made sute kyng restored suche smal ladnes husbande geuen ioyntoure kyng behelde harde speake bothe faire good fauoure moderate stature well made wyse alonely pitied also wexed enamored takyng secretely syde began enter talkyng familierly whose appetite perceyued verteously denied hym dyd wysely good maner woordes wel set rather kyndeled desyre quenched finally many metyng much wowyng many greate promise well espied kyng affeccion towarde greately encreased durste somewhat bodely saye mynde hym whose hert perceyued feruently set fall worde conclu ion shewed plain wist self simple wife thought self good cocubine kyng much marueilyng constancy wonte el stiefly sayed nay muche estemed continency chastitee sette vertue steade possession richesse takyng coun aill owne desyre determined haste mary thus apoincted betwene twayn ensured asked counsaill hys secrete frendes suche maner might easly perceyue boted saye nay notwithstandyng duches yorke mother sore moued therewith disswaded mariage muche possible might allegyng honor profyte surety mary noble progeny hys realme vpon depended greate strengthe hys estate affinite great possibilite encrease dominios could well otherwise doe consideryng erle warwike farfurthe entered matter ready whiche lyke take well hys voyage suche wyse frus rate appoinctemente deluded sayed ferther tha princely mary owne subiecte greater occa io ledyng vnto possession ner commodite dependyng therupon onely riche manne would mary hys mayden onely litle wanton dotage vpon person whiche mariage many menne comend maydens fortune mannes wisedome yet sayed honesty honour mariage forum much ther betwene marchaunt mayde greate difference betwene kyng subiecte greate prince poore widowe whose persone allthough nothyng bee mi yked yet sayed nothyng excellent might found diuerse metely estate yea maiden also onely widowhed dame elizabeth grey although poinctes thynges conuenient suffice thynketh refrain mariage sith vnsittyng thyng great blemishe sacred maiestie prince ought nere approche priesthode clennesse doeth dignitie defiled bygamy first mariage kyng made mother answere part earnest part playe merely wyste hym selfe rule albeit would gladly take well yet ap inct owne mynde toke wel otherwyse howbeit somewhat satisfy saied albeit mariage beyng spiritual thyng ou ht rather made respecte god grace enclineth party ought encline loue together trusted case rather regard temporall auauntage yet neuertheles hym semed mariage well considered bee vnprofitable reconed amitee earthely nacion bee necessary hym frendeship awne whiche thoughte likely beare hym muche hartye fauour disdaigned mari one awne lande yet outward aliaunce wer thought requisite woulde finde meanes entre therunto muche better kinne party coulde bee contented mary hym selfe wherein shoulde neuer happely loue possibilitee possession lese fruite pleasure alreadye small plasure taketh manne al euer hath besyde yf bee wiued againste appetite doubte quod bee saie bee euery poinct comparable therefore lette like theim mary theim reason mislike manne mary liketh sure cousyn warwike neither loueth litle grudge loue ner vnreasonable loke choyse wife rather bee ruled yie myne awne though wer warde wer bounden mary apoynctement guarden would bee kyng codicion forbeare mine awne libertie choyse mine awne mariage possibilite eritaunce newe affinitee straunge landes oft occasion trouble proffite haue already title meanes ffiseth somuch suffiseth gette kepe wel one mannes day widdowe hath alredy child god blessed lady bacheler haue eche v hath proofe neither v like barren therefore madame praye contente trust god shall bryng furthe young prince shal please bigamy lette bishop hardely laie charge come take ordres vnderstande forbidden prieste put neuer wiste forbidden prince duchesse woordes nothynge apeased seynge kynge sette could plucke backe highly disdaigned vnder pretexte duety god warde deuised disturbe mariage rather helpe mary one dame elizabet lucy kynge longe gotten chylde wherefore kynge mother obiected openly againste mariage wer discarge consience king sure dame elizabeth lucy husband god reason whiche wordes suche obstacle made matter either bishoppe durste kyng would proceade solemnisacion mariage til fame clerely purged truth well opely testified vpon dame elizabeth lucye sente albeit kyng mother many put good comforte affirme assured kynge yet solemply sworne saie truth confessed neuer ensured howebeeit saied grace spake suche louynge woordes verely hoped woulde haue maried yf suche kinde woordes woulde neuer haue shewed suche kyndenesse hym lette kindely gette childe examinacion solemply
