tidynges kyng arragon know thei thei wer commaunded ruled englishemen thus liyng idlely abidyng aide kyng arragon tidynges came daily host duke dalua commyng great puissaunce ioyne englishe army inuade guyan englishe capitaines ioyfull tidynges muche aide spanyardes whiche thei litle regarded beastes cariage greate artilerie whiche thei brought theim hope kyng arragons promes thei beastes cariage greate ordinaunce accordyng appoyntement thei would haue doen otherwise whiche thyng sore greued harte thei thus lokyng duke dalua hard euery daie marched towarde theim within day iorney litle whiche englishe menne merueilous ioyfull duke whiche pretended another thyng sodainly remoued armie night suche diligece entered realme nauer citie pampilona chief citie nauer kyng wist whiche nothyng suspected pollicie thus kyng sodainly trapped supposyng tharmie spain haue reised inuade guyan hauyng nothyng defensable warre night fled posterne fraunce died citie pampilona coutrey nauer beyng vnprouided artilarie defence yelded theselfes spanyardes thus realme nauer wonne whiche thyng made lorde marque compaignie litle maruell shortely came lorde capitain englishemen diuerse lordes sent kyng arragon whiche saied kyng soueraigne lorde sendeth greate gramercies highly thaketh pain goddes grace good abode power hath taken conquered realme nauer countrey bee taken thei might haue intercepted suche ordinaunce victail kyng arragon master might haue sent bee suche suretie puyssaunce youres ye maie sauely ioyne whiche shall see shortly ye hymself proper person ioyne well said lorde marque capitain generall haue soieourned long abidyng commyng commission expresse commaundement kyng soueraigne lord wer nothyng without assent kyng master assure frenchmenne haue knowen englishemen haue lien long idlenes haue dooen kyng master doo reporte shalbee muche honor greate comforte lordes spayne departed armie englishemen thus laie campe village called sanctum maria whiche diuerse englishemen especially suche sicke resorted reposed theimself litle auauntage toune fortuned spanyard gaue euill language englisheman whiche gaue hym buffet face toune rose sett englisheman gathered suche multitude englisheman whiche first beginner slain onely three englishemen came rescue whiche wer hurte almaynes laie tounes ende strake alarum whiche heatyng campe cried harnes euery man tidynges brought campe thei toune slain englishman would bid battaill souldiers hearyng rage ranne toune suche maner capitaines could stay slewe robbed people without mercy people fled ouer water guyan capitaines seeyng priuie seruauntes kepte straightes whiche souldiers returned village naperie brasse pewter beddes plate houshold stuffe apparell commaunded laied doune lordes hepe lordes went toune se harme englishman doen thei found many biskaynes slain toune robbed people fled thei sobre meanes gentle exhortacion brought souldiers campe proclamacion made euery man vpon pain death bryng pillage wer xxi men one gentleman whiche taken awaie x thousande dukates fled toward gascoyne taken brought lorde capitain adiudged dye whiche vii wer put execucion xiiii haue died morow lordes spayne iudgement greate diligence labor gat pardon pillage almoste restored countrey pacified one daie frenchemen whiche hard riot trouble hoste issued bayon toward englishe mennes armie englishman hearyng therof marched toward frenchemen perceiued thei wer asskried thei sodainly returned thenglishemenne perceiuyng frenchemen would tary went good toune called sainct ihon de luce brent robbed killed inhabitauntes thence spoyled diuerse village aboute border guyan thus armie laie till moneth october winter began sore encrease lorde marque capitain generall fell sore sicke lorde haward vnder hym whole gouernaunce tharmie wer sent diuerse lordes priuie cousaill spain saiyng king master sendeth worde would gladly come season spent grounde moyste cariage cannot bee conueighed feldes barrain beastes cannot fede wether trobleous people cannot well lye abrode campe therfore would desire thynges considred breke vp felde seuer self tounes village cou trey till spryng yere whiche tyme shall resorte freshe succor englande hymself al ordinaunce necessary becommeth suche armie shall procede firste pretensed enterprise honor kyng master small fame renoume message hard whole counsaill manne contented lorde haward whiche whole gouernaunce vnder marque saied report honour make kyng arragon master desire come hether haue lien campe long space euer tariyng performaunce promise yet nothyng hath performed people dedde flixe greate nombre wee gentleman euerychone doth muche lament long idlenes reason whereof many tall man hauyng nothyng abidyng master pleasure hath fall mischief sickenes el misdoyng executed iustice shall kyng master reporte slothfulnes whiche hath spent hym innumerable treasure nothyng gained yet would make winter warre kyng arragon master v denieth suche thynges promised willeth v like cowardes dishonor reise campe without notable acte doen frenchemen whiche cause came spanyardes perceiuyng grudge englishemen saied tyme passed could bee reuoked thei lien idlely frontier guyan susteined suche damage many yeres thei shall recouer frenchman durst medle haue lost honor tary winter daily skirmishyng thei shall receiue greate damage duryng whiche time kyng master hath commaunded thynges mete necessarie commaundement spryng yere shall ioyne enemy shall well knowe puissaunce taketh enemy faire wordes counsaill spayne departed lorde haward beyng chief marque sicke counsailed lordes capitaines ende october thei agreed breake vp campe thei lorde marque people went sainct sebastian lorde haward retinew rendre lorde willoughby garschang sir willyam sandes many capitaines fruntrabie euery capitain retinew wer seuered diuerse village english souldiers sickenes miserie countrey euer desired returne englande kyng england aduertised kyng arragon entent would set forward first spryng sent wynsore herauld armes armie willyng tary would sende newe aide vnder conduite lorde harbert chamberlain whiche letter redde souldiers began murmure grudge suche sort saiyng thei would abide dye flixe wretched countrey bee defrauded mocked kyng arragon next yere thei wer yere spake suche outragious wordes capitain could staie muche thei fury slain lorde haward diuerse thei folowed myndes thei hired shippes putte lorde marque one whiche weake asked euery manne shipped whiche nouembre beginnyng decembre thei landed englande kyng arrogon sore discontent departyng thei spent muche money substaunce countrey saied opely thei taried would haue inuaded guyan englishemen glad thei departed suche countrey thei litle health lesse pleasure muche losse tyme liyng kyng arragon stale realme nauer englishemen left muche money sent englande daughter marque sailed spayne moneth maij tyme sir edward hawarde lorde admirall englande haue hard sailed toward britaine trinitie sundaie arriued bertram bay britain xx greate shippes sodainly set men lande britaynes made askrie sette beacon fire shot bulwarke thei fortified poynt baye englishe men whiche wer ship willyam gonstone grocer lodon toke first lande maugre manfully thei set bulwarke thei wan briton fled many slain admirall set men ordre passed countrey seuen myles burnyng wastyng tounes village returne skirmished diuerse men armes slewe diuerse theim notwithstandyng briton fought valiauntly defence coutrey yet thei lost nothyng wan lorde admirall returned shippe upon mondaie xxiii daie maie landed mornyng commaunded burne lorde pier meguns place toune conket diuerse place chased britones castle brest assembles showes briton made yet thei fuffered englishman peaceably returne praies gaines briton seyng hurte nauie englande theim saied ala kyng englande hath euer tyme succomed v intendeth destroye v shame come hym cause thereof first daie iune englishemen toke lande croyton bay lordes britain sent worde lorde admirall would abide thei would fight hym plain felde admirall rewarded messenger said go saie sent thee al daie thei shall finde tariyng commyng encourage diuerse gentleman dubbed theim knightes sir edwarde broke brother lorde cobham sir griffithe doune sir thomas wynda sir thomas lucie sir willyam pirton sir henry shirborne sir stephen bull sir ihon burdett lorde admirall highly incouraged men sawe briton come whiche wer x thousande least englishemen onely xxvc fewe aboue biddyng remembre honor renoume come theim thei gained iorney yet thei wer slain valiauntnes praised true diligence therr master seruice muche alowed briton sawe order englishemen banner displaied thei wer sodainly astonnied gentleman britain muche experience aduised capitaines fight returne litle take strong grounde watche englishemen thei returned shippes take thaunauntage capitaies began returne common sawe returne thei ranne waie faste thei might supposyng capitaines seen knowen greate perell toward thei priuy capitaines counsaill thei came home house saied battaill greate saied englishemen wer xl thousande lorde admirall seyng chaunce night came departed shippes yet thei knewe thei fled till hard truthe gentleman britain called greate counsaill saiyng englishemen daily wasted countrey sea cost trust commonaltie gentleman alone could defende countrey wherefore thei concluded sende messenger lorde admirall desiryng hym safe conduite diuerse persones speake hym whiche gently graunted certain lordes britain toke bote came ship lorde admirall set wth counsaill capitaines hym thei desired hym humbly urcest rigorous cruel warre especially burnyng tounes whiche proffite haue castle brest shall commaundement able defende desire nothyng muche peace naie saied lorde admirall wee sent hether make warre peace thei humbely required hym goddes sake graunt theim peace sixe day thei might sende kyng lorde aduertise trouble calamitie lorde admirall answered gentleman ought defende coutrey force rather sue peace whiche saiyng briton wer ashamed yet thei hartely thanked hym made banker thei departed thei sent lande freshe water freshe victailes hearyng wer men warre vpon sea coasted alongest al coastes normandy still skowryng sea enemie appered last came laie isle wight see enemy would appere thenglishe coast duryng whiche tyme diuerse shippes kept north sea vnder conduite sir edward ichyngham ihon lewes ihon louedaie whiche diligently skowred sea yere kyng solempne iustes grenewiche iune first came lady white red silke set vpon courser trapped thesame suite freated ouer gold folowed fountain curiously made russet sattin eight gargilles spoutyng water within fountain sat knight armed peces fountain folowed lady blacke silke dropped fine siluer courser trapped thesame folowed knight horse litter courser litter apparcled blacke siluer droppes fountain came tilt lady rode rounde aboute fountain knight within litter theim wer brought two goodly courser appareled iustes thei came tiltes ende twoo knightes mounted twoo courser abidyng commers kyng fountain sir charles bra litter sodainly greate noyse trompettes entered sir thomas kneuet castle cole blacke ouer castell written dolorous castle erle esex lorde haward rane course kyng sir charles brandon euer kyng brake moste speres kyng euer remembryng warres caused shippes galies rigged prepared maner ordinaunce artillery mete shippes warre emongest decked regent ship royall chief ship nauie caused souldiers mete thesame shippes muste blacke hethe appointed capitaines tyme sir anthony oughtred sir edward ichyngham willyam sidney diuerse gentleman whiche shortly shipped came isle wight passage galey lost negligence master kyng euer desiryng see nauie together roade portesmouthe appoynted capitaines regent sir thomas kneuet master horse sir ihon carew deuonshire another ship royal called souereigne appoynted sir charles bra sir henry guildforde theim souereigne put lx tallest yomen kynges gard many gentleman wer made capitaines kyng made greate banquet capitaines euery one sware another euer defend aide cofort one another without failyng thei promised kyng whiche committed theim god greate noyse minstrelsie thei toke shippes whiche wer xxv nombre greate burden well furnished thynges frenche kyng hearyng dammage thenglishmen doen britaine strongly furnished nauie hauen brest nombre xxxix saile chief ordeined carike brest apperteignyng quene wife whiche duches heire britayne called cordelier whiche strong ship furnished poyntes thei set forwarde brest x daie august came britayne bay whiche place self daie beyng daie laurence englishe nauie arriued englishe menne perceiued frenche nauie brest hauen lorde admirall ioyous euery man prepared accordyng duetie archer shote gonners lose men armes fight page went toppe castle dartes thus thynges beyng prouided set ordre englishemen approched toward frenchemen whiche came fiercely forwarde leuyng ancre foresaile onely take moste auauntage thei wer sight thei shote ordinaunce terrebly together sea coast sounded lorde admirall made greate ship depe chased stil sir henry guilford sir charles brandon made greate caricke brest beeyng souereigne laied stemme stemme caricke negligence master el smoke ordinaunce otherwise souereigne cast sterne caricke whiche auau tage frenche menne showted ioye sir thomas kneuet whiche ready haue borded greate ship depe sawe souereigne missed caricke whiche sir anthony oughtred chased hard starne bowged diuerse place set fire powder saie sodainly regent crappeled long boord thei carick perceiued thei could depart thei let slip ancre streme shippes turned caricke wetherside regent lye side fighte cruell archer englishe parte crossebowes freche part vttermost english men entered caricke whiche seyng varlet gonner beyng desperate put fire gonne powder saie set whole ship fire flame wherof set fire regent twoo noble shippes wer crappeled together thei could part wer consumed fire french nauie perceiuyng fled hast brest isle adioynyng englishman maner dismaied sent boates help regent fire great maner man durst approche sauyng iames hull wer certein frenchman could smymme saued burnyng caricke happie frenche nauie el thei ben better assailed thenglishemen whiche wer amased chaunce thei folowed capitain carick sir pier morgan hym ixc slain ded sir thomas kneuet sir ihon carow wer viic men drowned brent night englishemen laie bartrain baye frenche flete sparkeled haue hard lorde admirall called capitaines together desiryng bee abasshed chaunce warre thought worste fortune could happen theim therfore studie reuenged thei concluded go sea whiche thei coast britain toke many shippes thei could cary awaie thei set fire small greate greate nombre coast britain normandy picardy thus thei kept sea kyng englande heryng losse regent caused greate shippe made suche another neuer seen englande alled henry grace de dieu french kyng heryng flete thus deuided losse greate carick sent knight rhodes called prior ihon whiche three galies force diuerse foystes rowgalies well ordinauced suche peces seen shippes commyng laye coast barbary defende certein religion rhodes commyng tripoly frenche kynges request came britain taried nouembre kyng called high courte parliament concluded kyng hymself person armie royall would inuade realme fraunce fire sworde whiche thyng beeyng knowen subiectes especiall suche go hym man doubt preparacion made harneis weapon artillery banner thynges necessarie enterprice kyng parliament ended kept solempne christemas grenewiche chere noble twelfe daie night came hall mount called riche mount mount set ful riche flower silke especially full brome slippes full coddes braunches wer grene sattin flower flat gold damaske whiche signified plantagent top stode goodly bekon geuyng light rounde bekon sat kyng iue al coates cappes right crimosin veluet enbroudered flat gold damaske coates set full spangelles gold foure woodhouses drewe mount till came quene kyng compaignie discended daunced sodainly mount opened came sixe lady crimosin satin plunket enbroudered golde perle frenche hoddes heddes thei daunced alone lordes mount tooke lady daunced together lady reentred mount closed conueighed hall kyng shifted hym came quene sat banqute whiche sumpteous purificacion lady kyng created sir charles brandon uiscount lisle marche folowyng kynges nauie shippes royall mete warre set furth nombre xlii beside blangars lorde admirall chief hym sir water deueruex lorde ferr sir wolstan browne sir edwarde ichyngham sir antony poyntz sir ihon wallop sir thomas wyndam sir stephin bull willyam fitz willyam arthur plantagenet willyam sidney esquire diuerse noble valiaunt capitaines thei sailed portesmouthe laie abidyng wynde duryng whiche tyme kyng sent flaunders suche thynges neded caused brought caleis comyng wynde serued nauie royall englande wayed anker made saile britain came bertram bay lay anker sight frenche nauie must vnderstand great nauie whiche frenche kyng prepared laie hauen brest well furnished al thynges doubt wonder se thei wer ready sette furthe sawe englishe flete coast thei determined clerely saue theselfes brest hauen englishemen determined clerely sette hauen good ordre battaill sailed forward first entry one ship wherof arthur plantagenet capitai fell blynde rocke brast asunder reason wherof staied greate displeasure remnaunt litle ioye frenchme whiche shot without dooyng harme englishe capitai e perceiuyng hauen daungerous entre without expert lodesman cast aboute returned harborough bertram baye frenchman perceiuyng englishman intended assaile theim moored shippes nye castle brest thei could set bulwarkes land euery side shote englishman also thei frapped together xxiiii greate hulkes came baye salt set theim rowe intent englishe menne would haue assaulted theim thei would haue set theim fire let theim driue streme emongest englishe nauie prior ihon also laie still blacke sable whitesande baye plucked galies shore sette basiliskes ordinaunce mouthe baye whiche baye bulwarked euery side water possible wonne lorde admirall perceiuyng nauie fraunce lye feare willyng daryng come abrode lye prisoner dongeon wrote kyng come thether persone haue honor high entreprise whiche writyng kynges counsaill nothyng allowed puttyng kyng ieoperdy vpon chaunce sea wherefore kyng wrote sharply hym accomplishe whiche apperteined duetie whiche caused hym take courage put thynges aduenture shall pthe v yerethe v yere haue hard lorde admirall england laie still coast britain baye called bartrames baye feare hym englishe nauie neither greate shippes brest hauen durste moue sea ward yet prior ihon al strong galeies would sette saile sauyng sende furthe small foystes make shewe englishe nauy whiche chased bay englishe shippes greate thei could entre baye manned boates toke one best foystes greate daungier galies bulwarkes shot one time wo der englishemen escaped admirall englande perceiuyng frenche mennes pollicy called counsaill determined firste assaile prior ihon galies liyng whitsand baye set remnaunt haue brest first appoynted water lorde ferreis sir stephin bul capitaines go lande conuenient compaignie assault bulwarkes whitsand bay lorde admirall entered rowe barge litle galies bay frenchman assailed bothe water land thus fully agreed whole counsaill ala noble capitain counsailed spanishe knight called sir alphous charant whiche saied might entre baye wit litle ieopardy called hym wilyam fitz willyam willyam cooke ihon colley sir wolstan browne chief moste trustie frendes declared theim matter litle honor greate thei onely tooke theim enterprise let none knowe thei like men haute courage desiryng honour gladly assented sainct markes daie xxv daie aprill thesaid admirall put hymself small rowe barge three small rowyng shippes awne ship boate rowed sodainly baye prior ihon moored galies iust ground whiche galies bulwarkes lande shot terribly thei folowed wer fraied assone came galies entered draue frenche men willyam fitiz willyam within shippe sore hurte quarell day shalowe shippes could entre tide spent whiche thyng frenchman perceiuyng could come succoure admirall morris pike entered galies fought englishemen galies admirall perceiuyng approchyng thought haue entered rowe barge whiche violence tide driuen doune streme pike throwen ouer borde drouned forenamed alphous slain boates vesselles scaped hardely thei taried tide failed lost lorde ferreis capitaines muche dolent chaunce saied without counsaill hath sped therefore although thei would haue sette nauie brest hauen yet hauyng admirall commission thei determined nothyng farther till thei knew kynges pleasure sailed englande frenche nauie perceiuyng englishemen made toward england came hauens prior ihon set furthe galies foystes coasted britain normandy coasted ouer coast sussex al compaignie landed sea coast set fire poore cotages gentleman dwelte nere shortely reised countrey came coast droue prior ihon galeis al hurt stout capitain great fame england sauyng robbed certein poore fisshermen whitynges kyng hearyng death admirall litle sory consideryng bothe nobilitie birthe valiauntnes persone sorowe auaileth whe chaunce past therfore kyng heryng frenche nauie abrode called hym lorde thomas haward elder brother sir edward haward late admirall sonne heire apparant erle surrey made hym admirall willyng reuege brother death whiche greate reuerence thanked kyng high truste put hym immediatly went sea nobly valiauntly skower sea french men lust kepe coast englande fought theim awne porte kyng whiche thynges necessary mete warre entendyng passe sea propre person appoynted valiaut lorde george talbot erle shrewesbury high steward houshold capitain generall forward compaignie wer lorde thomas stanley erle derby lorde decowrey prior ihons sir rober radcliffe lorde fitzwater lorde hastynges lorde cobham sir rice ap thomas sir thomas blount sir richard sachiuerell sir ihon dighby sir ihon askewe sir lewes bagot sir thomas cornewall many knightes esquiers souldiers nombre viiim menne whiche passed sea caleis middle maij lorde herbert called sir charles somerset chief chamberlain kyng ende thesame monethe vim men passed sea whose compaignie erles northumberlande percie kent graye wilshire stafford lorde fitzwater lorde dudley lorde delawar sir thomas west sonne sir edward husey sir robert dimmocke sir dauie owen many gentlemenne speres horsebacke pike foote dimilaunces rereward good diligece made twoo capitaines compaignie furnished artilerie pouder tentes cariages thynges necessary warres wer landed caleis last daie maij thei soiourned certain day caleis al thynges requisite wer ready thei caused trompet blowe made proclamacion euery man departe toune begyn campe erle shrewesbury compaignie first toke felde hym folowed lorde herbert compaignie maner rereward hym folowed valiaunt sir rice ap thomas vc light horse archer horsebacke ioyned hym foreward ordre taken persones conduite victalers came caleis conduite victalers came flaunders without sufficient conduite creature durste bryng victaile armie twoo lordes thus embattailed remoued xvii daie iune sandisfelde xviii daie thei came margison farre side water though thei would haue passed streightly bulleyn thei thought otherwise nexte daie thei tooke another waie coasted countrey suche diligence xxii daie iune thei people ordinaunce habilimentes warre wer come strong citie tirwin pight tentes myle toune night embattailed themself certain capitaines wer counsail lorde herbertes tent sodainly toune shot gonne pellet wherof slewe noble capitain called baron carew sittyng counsaill whiche sodain aduenture dismaied muche assemble lorde herbert valiauntly coforted theim saiyng chaunce warre hit muste haue content noble harte warre neuer feard death countrey arthois picardie fortified holdes made shewes englishe army passed thei durst assaile citie tirwin strongly fortifed wale rampaires bulwarkes diuese fortress diches whiche wer brode plume stepe wondre behold lorde pountremy capitain generall hym wer within citie vic horsmen furnished twoo mvc almaines beside inhabitauntes citie walles tower wer ful ordinaunce whiche oftentymes great displeasure englishemen erle shrewesbury laied siege toune north west side lorde herbert easte side ende ward frenchman issued toune skirmished englishmenne archer shot fast thei draue frenchemen citie slewe toke diuerse lorde herbert laie open sight toune hauyng hill thyng succour defende hym caused greate trench made inawger enemy approched nere cite likewise therle shrewesbury forward gatte holowe ground valey nere citie daily frenchman shot thenglishmen diuerse tymes issued skirmished euer thei lost skirmishyng shotyng ordinaunce thei hurte diuerse englishman wherfore lordes commaunded pioners raise greate trenche whiche thei laied greate ordinaunce daily thei might thei approched sir rise ap thomas horseman daily skowered countrey many tymes encountered frenchemen slewe toke diuerse prisoner frenchman drewe toward siege turned another waie upon mundaie beeyng xxvii daie iune xxiiii carte charged victaill wer garrison caleis conduited guisnes crewe castle toune guisnes three c foote men vnder conduite sir edward belknappe beyng nombre iiiiclx men set furthe conduite thesaied victailes tharmie liyng tirwyn thei passed arde carter passed toune horseman fell drinkyng waie foote men wer duke uandosme capitain generall picardie whiche la bushement forest side guysnes viiic light horseman toke aduauntage set victailers carter perceiuyng losed horse fledd toune whiche myle left carte sir nicholas uaux capitain guysnes al could bryng foote men ordre frenchemen set quickly thei could set theim ordre horseman guysnes whiche wer onely xxiiii toke speres ioyned frenchemen archer englande whiche passed lx shot manfully noble capitain called baltier delien diuerse frenchemen many nombre good ordre thei flew viii gentleman garrison guysnes xxx archer slain many hurte thei distrussed victailes caused sir nicholas uaux sir edwarde belknappe flie toward guisnes misauenture fell tariyng horseman breakyng array tharchers taried together happened otherwise fewe archer held together flewe hurt diuerse frenchemen felde laie lxxxvii greate horse whiche neuer wet thence whiche appered frenchemenne went quite awaie without losse tidynges misauenture came lordes siege thei litle displeased sir rise ap thomas caused trompet blowe stirroppe horseman sought duke uandosme countrey whiche hearyng commyng sir rise greate hast retreted backe bangey abbey frenche kynges greate army laie sir rise heryng returned came next daye agayn sege rumour skyrmish sprong english pale toward flaunders wherfore tounes fiered ther bekons rang alarme diuers honorable men ye passed see wt copanies souldiours caleis marched forward order battaile heryng departig mousire de vadosme thei rested new prouisio made vitaile sent daily fro caleys turwyn conduite frenchman would meddill army also well vitaled flaunders henawde army england thus lay strong toune turwin noble kyng englad forgettyng entreprice prepared al thyng redy passe see proper persone caused sir ihon wilshire puruey iiic hoyes carry ouer artillery habilimets warre al shippes warre see skowering euery coste realme al thinges prest accompanied many noble men vic archer garde al white gabberdines cappes departed manour royal grenewich xv day iune quene smal iorneys came douer castell rested made quene gouerner realme commauded william warram bishop cantorbury sir thomas louell sage knyght diuers gyue attendaunce quene commaunded therle surrey drawe toward north partes left scottes woulde make entreprice absence king toke leue quene lady made sorow departyng lord husbandes greate dolor beholde army toke shippe last day iune beyng daye sainct paule mornyng kyng shipped made saile al ye army folowed nomber iiiic shippes winde brought euen coste picardy open vpon sainct ihons roade flud haled log coste whitsand wt trupettes blowyng gonne shotyng great feare bolleyn plainly might beholde passage came caleys haue kyng receiued bote couered arras set londe appareilled almayne ryuet crested vabrace thesame hedde chapeau motabyn riche coronal folde chapeau lined crimsyn sate riche brooch image sainct george ouer riuett garment white cloth gold redde crosse receiued procession wt hys deputie caleys called sir gylbert talbott noble gentleman towne countrey entred lanternegate passed stretes tyll came saincte nycholas churche ther alighted offered fro then went stapleinne supped kyng entred caleys al banished men entred wt hym restored liberty toune tell gonne shott toune shippes kynges landing great wonder good estimacio reported thei harde douer king lyeng thus caleys army except counsail gaue attendaunce hym laye encamped newnam bridge campe xi clock night rose eskrye towne caleys began alarme kyng waked came walles demaunded matter ment yoman te te called richarde gybson shewed howe certayne horsmen footme frauce profered come ouer haue archer laie next see side entred water defended passage wt defence frenchme returned kyng satisfied frechma whitsad bay one bullain take one called charles de bone peter vernowne confessed fro toune whitsand came lx horsmen iic footman garrison bulle countrey adioynyng entendyng passe rice banke low water marke ouer yt haue caleis certayn foord shewed spy serued yoma tetes vitailes shewed tentes piched vnder caleis walles betwene towne cape thei might burne quykly towne could issue cape remoue englishman kept good watch haue harde entreprice came none effect morow first day iuly noble lord haward admirall englad landed whitsand bay entred spoyled brent toune returned ship bullonoys recopensed imaginacio bayly whitsand bullonoys entreprised burnyng kynges tentes fryday night blew suche storme yt seuered nauy drowned upon viii day iuly lord marque dorsett therle essex lord lisle rode flauders ther toke mousters lord lynny lord walo sonne lord barow bastard emery wt ther retinue admitted kyngs wage lord linny wt ac l speres appoincted go lord herbert lord walon bastard emery wt ther bondes appointed go therle shrewsbury lieg tirwin stragers warlycke person light horse siege laye thus tyrwyn haue harde frenchman diuerse time issued horseback many staffe broken many proper feat armes done likewise almaynes foot would diuerse time issue wt handgonnes morish pycks assaile englishme force archer thei euer driuen home agayn euery day englishman shott towne dyd muche displeasure xxi day iuly thinges counsaill byn ordered concernyng order battayle kyng passed towne caleis goodly array battaile toke felde notwithstadyng ye forward rerewarde kynges great army tirwyn haue harde yet kyng awne battayle made iii battailles fasshion warre lord lisle marshall hoste capitaine forward vnder iiim men sir richard carew wt iiic men right hand wyng forward lord darcy wt iiic wyng left hand yt skoure forriders battaile north berland men light geldynges therle essex lieutenant general speres sir ihon p hy vicegouernour horsmen kyng went viiic almaynes al plupe self came standard wt redde drago next banner lady next banner ye trinitie vnder kyngs houshold seruautes went ba er armes englad borne sir henry guildford vnder baner kyng self wt diuers noble men nober iiim duke buckyngha vic kyngs left egall wt ye almaynes likewise ye right sir edward pounynges wt vic men egall almaynes lord burgainie wt viiic men wyng right hand sir willia copton wt ye retinue ye bishop wichester master wolsey king almoner ye nober viiic maner rereward sir anthony oughtred sir ihon neuell wt king speres folowed iiiic hole army xim iiic men master ordinaunce sett foorth kinges artilary fawcons ynges bobardes carte powder stone bowes arowes thinges necessary felde hole nomber cariages xiiic leders driuers xix c men rekened battaile good fightynge men ther full ixm thus order battaile kyng rode seutrey ther lodged first night friday garriso bulleyn mustered nye fine mill askryed northuberland marched toward frenchman returned saterdaie hoste remoued hambwell ther rested sonday mondaie entered french groude nye arde ther euery gentlema coate armes tydyngs brought ye kyng ye frech army approched ridinges pleased well desyred nothyng battaile tewsday xxvi day iuly kyng passed forward order battayle euer frenchman costed farre take englyshmen auantage thei kept close order could fynd array howbeit negligence carter yt mystooke waye greate curtall called ihon euangelist ouerthrowen depe ponde water coulde quickly recouered kyng heryng enemy approched leuyng gonne master carpenter sayde woulde shortely way water set forwarde hoste good order came dornahan fayre eastell standyng wodde countrey frenchme euer lurkyng woddes viewing kynge coduite order passed lefte towne dornahan right hande came village litle riuer ordinauce pitched king came ryuer perceyued many gentleman made dauger entre riuerthe courage kyng wherfore lighted downe horse without abode entred riuer entred came ouer tydynges brought hym frenchman nere hande would fight nyght kyng still abode order battaile euer lokynge commynge frenchman night woorde brought reculed entred tente wednesday xxvi daye iuly releffe speres brought askry wherfore kyng commaunded blow standarde auaunced banner toke faire feld banke abidyng comming frenchman capitaines generall army french kyng lord dela palice lord piens accompaignyed duke longuyle therle sainct polle lord floringes lord cleremounde richard dela pole traytour england sonne duke ihon suffolke capitaines comyng xim footman iiiim horsmen prest battayle came wt ii mile kyng englande footman staled came farther certaine horsmen nomber iiim aboue marched forward ende wodde shewed selfes open sight english army kyng perceiuyng demeanure commauded al footman remoue stand still frenchme remoued came sumwhat nerer place execucion master goner lo ed pece artilery two kynge lay thus still abydynge enemy horseman stode still sight greate armye fraunce approched whiche englishman could descrye cause hyll betwexte northerne men ran frechmen manly encontered strake downe maugre powre brought certaine prisoner kyng england therle essex capitaine kynges speres iic speres lay stale frenchman come nerer sodainly apered sight great comopany horsmen kynge knewe thei ye last perceyued valiant knyght sir rice app thomas retinue whiche came kyng aboute none gentilly receyued hym sent hym therle essex incontinentely departed compassed hill came therle ioyned drewe hyll accompaignyed sir thomas gylforde capitayne iic archer horsbacke thentent haue set frenchme perceiuyng yt dowghtyng nomber come sodainly drewe back ioyned wt great battaile therle essex thenglish horsmen folowed tyll came nere greate army fraunce staled sent light horseman knowe conduite french army frenchman armes retorned ther battaile footman horseman reculed order battell went back pace englyshe styrrers perceyuyng folowed iii leages returned therle makyng reporte sene brake vp stale came kyng declaryng frenshmen reculedthe dry wednesday daie called drye wednesday day wonderfull hoat kyng army order battaile vi clock mornyng tyll iii clock noone died lack moysture allmost generall euery man burned mouth hete stomack drynke lacked water nere kyng remoued towarde tyrwyn hauyng horsmen behynde lest frenshmen sodainly sett hym behynde kyng settyng forward lord walowne flaunders came kyng wt horsmen kynges wage kyng declared chaunced army passed negligence thesame day lane ouerthrowen one kynges great bobardes iron called redde gonne left night began approche kyng rested toke campe ii myles sainct omers northsyde thursdaye beyng xxviii daie iuly master carpeter hundred carpenter labores without knowlege marshall went waye vp great gonne ponde haue harde force engynes drewe vp laied carte redy cary sodainly wodde issued viiic frenchman speres crosbowes handgones assayled poore labourer valiantly defended selfes oppressed multitude parte flayne remnant taken pece ordinauce caried bulleyne misauenture fel master carpeter would woorke awne hedde without counsayll chaunce kyng sore displeased frenchme ioyous chaunce assembled great nomber take gonne lay still high way wherfore lord barnes beyng capiteyne pioners laborer heryng misauenture consideryng gonne lyeg behynd prepared al maner engine recouer thesame morowe kyng entended reyse camp harde ye great pece ordinaunce left behynde freshman assembled together greate musyng taryed commaunded almaynes retreate back succour went pece ordinaunce almaynes went foorth staled within two mile pece ordinaunce lay farther thei woulde goo earle essex company speres sir rice ap thomas wt compaignie sir ihon neuell northuberland men sett forward helpe lord barnes recouery gonne sodainly northren horsmen espied al great army frenshemen commyng forward reported therle essex sir ihon pechy lieutenant horseman speres capitaines place said goune left hundred horsme heryng therof sent woorde sir rice hering therof desired erle essex come take grounde place remoued greate haste meane season diligent labor ye lord barnes pece ordinaunce raysed carted furthe caried time french army apered sight therle essex saw great nomber frenchman hast sent lord walon willyng hym wt company come ayde lord waloun sayde messenger go tel capitayne come hither serue kyng england one daye therfore would thenglishmen would returne wt ye great power fraunce thei able fight esteme ix xm lest aunswere messenger departed made relacion erle essex capitaynes whiche wt sore discontent time scowrers french parte come harde hades englishman began light horsmen skyrmy ther folowyng reskuing party open sight party slayne marched forward hole battaile frenchman stadards penos banner waueryng sumptuous bardes riche harnys glyteryng men armes great nober range long redy chace charge sir rice ap thomas beyng great experience sagely perceyued case ye matter stode saide therle essex sir viic horsme let v folysh hardy comission fette gonne none let v folowe therle agreed therto softely flyeg maner retreted folowed gonne frechme perceiuyng cried al let v folowe pricked forward iim men armes came iuste backes ye englishman thenglishmen cried sainct george cast self made retorne ye frenchman sir william tyler sir ihon sharpe first charged englishemen dreadfull chase men armes fraunce flede fast glad might formost hole hoost seynge ther horsmen returnyng flight sodainly great hast returned without doyng erle essex staled hil ther caused tropet blowe standard feare subtyll dealyng thei gathered together vnto array returned xxix daye iuly kyng army came arkus embattailed selfe strong grounde hym came therle essex capitaines gonne made reporte ther aduenture thanked hartly ther lay tyll moday time came many noble men flaunders visite many common people came se hym mondaye fyrste daye auguste kynge remoued campe village myddell waly betwene sayncte omers tyrwyn ther fell suche rayne ordynaunce coulde scace remoued arable grounde softe thursday iiii day augusttirwyn kyng good order battaile came citie tyrwyn planted sege warlikewise campe enuironed artilerie fawcones serpentynes cast hagbushes tryde harow spien trestyls warlike defence sauegarde campe kyng hym selfe howse tymber hymney yron lodgynges great goodly tentes blewe water worke garnyshed wt yelowe white diuerse rome within thesame office necessary topp ye pauilions stode ye kynges bestes holdyng fanes lion dragon greyhounde antelope done kow within lodgynge poyncted full sunnes risynge lodgynge cxxv foot length king lyeng tirwyn great ordinauce sore bet towne walles thei within likewise shot towne ordinauce slewe diuers englyshmen trench among shottes thei one gonne euery day night ordinarely shotte certayne howres without fayle gonne thenglishmen called whystelyng gonne neuer harme kynges feld siege thus lyeng citee tyrwyn sir alexander baynam capitaine yners caused myne enterprised enter towne frenchman perceyuyng made countermyne destroyed myne diuers myners slayne within frenche army houed euer farre take englishman auantage thei went forragyng many skirmish done many good feates armes acheued bothe sydes diuers prisoner taken among frenchman certaine light horsmen called stradiotes shorte styroppes beuer hatts small speres swerdes like semiteries turkay dyuers tymes northre light horsme vnder ye conduite sir iho neuel skirmished stradiottes toke diuerse prisoner brought kyng kyng lay thus tyrwyn capitayne bullen knowynge hys espialles many garryson caleys kynge siege also daylye vitailes brought oute englande caleys succour campe imagened greate entreprice sent men warre vnder dominion rule declared honour shoulde obteyne yf hurted spoyled partes caleis kyng england beyng syde see men warre perceiuyng good courage ye capitaine assented purpose diligence nomber men euenyng set forward came newnam bridge iii clock morning founde watchme kept bridge slepe entred ye bulwerke slewe watchman toke ordinaunce ye bridge let ye bridge fall al entred would capitayn bulleyn kept vic men stale bridge sent ye marrisshes medowes cattell fedde frenshmen came caleys gate askryed watch rang alarme english souldiours ran walles saw frenshmen without toune walles thei knewe newnam brydge lost would haue issued sir gylbert talbott deputie would suffer gate opened happened without caleys gate richard hunnyng richard brycks caterie iii iiii kynges seruauntes whiche lay sende prouisions hoost heryng alarme called kynges barker cowper fewe shippemen lay hauen coragiously folowed frenchman thenglishmen past vi skore persones sett frenchman thei forragyng thei might assemble together slew doune right toke prisoner maner thei came newnam brydge toke put frenchman backe thenglishme thus gathered selfes together frenchman forraged riuer vp sainct peter driuen away cattell ordinaunce newnam brydge passed till came stale lay ther taried lokyng ther company gone forragyng caleys walles v clock morenyng gate caleys called bulleyn gate opened issuyd one culpiper vnder marshall iic archer banner sainct george great hast came newnam bridge thei founde kynges seruauntes wonne brydge together marched toward frenchman kepte stale frenchman thought ben awne company returned till saw banner sainct george knewe company ouerthrowen thei must nedes fight dy thenglishmen though thei smaller nomber valiantly set frenchman great force defended last thei discomfited xxiiii slayne xii skore taken prisoner ther ordinaunce hole booty recoueredthe foly cowper prisoner brought caleys sold open market among cowper towne caleys bought prisoner booty dwelt bulleyn prisoner c crownes raunsome mony paied frenchman praied cowper se hym saue deliuered conduite hym danger cowper gently graunted without knowlege frendes alone went wt frenchman tyll came beyonde cawsey ther woulde haue departed frenchman perceiued cowper aged reskewes ny force toke cowper prisoner caried bulleyn made hym paye iic crownes raunsome thus thorowe foly poore cowper deceaued xi daie august beyng thursday kynge lyeng siege tyrwyn knowlege maximilian theperour towne ayre kyng prepared al thinges necessarie mete thempe rour triumphe noble men kynges campe gorgeously apparelled ther courser barded cloth gold damaske broderie apparell tissue cloth gold syluer gold smithes woorke great cheynes balderickes gold belle bullion especial duke buckingham purple satten apparell barde full antelope swannes fyne gold bullion full spangyls littell belle gold meruelus costly pleasat behold kyng garment greate rich iuels perles stone armed light armure master hys horse folowed spare horse henxmen folowed beryng kyngs peces harnys euery one mounted greate courser one bare helme seconde graugarde thirde spere fourth axe euery one ome thyng belongyng man armes apparell ix henxmen white clothe gold crymsyn cloth gold richely embrawdered goldesmythes woorke trappets corsers mantell harneys coulpened euery vent longe bel fyne gold euery pendant depe tassel fyne gold bullion whiche trapper ryche kyng themperour mett betwene ayre camp fowlest wether lightly hath bene sene themperour gentely enterteined kyng kyng lykewyse hym littell communicacion betwene cause wether foule departed tyme emperour men daie black cloth emprice wife lately disseased kyng retorned campe daye twayne ther arryued army kyng armes scotlad called lyon cote armes back desyred speke kyng shorte tyme garter cheffe kynge armes brought kinges presence beyng almost dismayed seynge kyng nobly accompanied fewe woordes metely good reuerence deliuered letter king receiued ye letter redde selfe redde without delay hym selfe aunswered th sorte nowe perceyue kynge scottes brother lawe master person whome euer toke hym neuer estemed hym truthe nowe haue founde notwithstandynge othe promise woorde kyng awne hand seale yet nowe hath broke faithe promise great dishonour infamie euer entendeth inuade realme absence whiche dirst one attempte person beynge presente sheweth selfe degenerate condicions forefather whose faythes parte hath euer byn violated ther promise neuer obserued farther liste therfore tell thy master first shall neuer comprised league confederate also suspectyng treuth dede proueth haue left earle realme home whiche shalbe able defende powre haue prouided shall fynde land destitute people thynketh thus saye thy master owner scotlad holdeth homage much contrary bounden duety beinge vassall doth rebell wt god help shal returne expulse realme tell hym sir sayd kyng armes naturall subiecte naturall lord commaundeth say may boldely saye wt fauor commaundementes may dare saye souer igne lord letter may honour sent declare pleasure may say suche woordes reproche whome owe allegeaunce fayth sayd kyng wherfore came hyther wil receyue aunswere yes sayde lio answere requireth doyng writynge immediatly returne home well said kyng wyll returne domage pleasure thy master somonyng kyng commaunded garter take hym tente make hym good chere dyd cherished wel sore appalled departed kynge sent chefe capitaynes counsaill caused letter redde trewe tenor whereof foloweth woorde woorde letter kyng scottes right excellent right high mighty prince deerest brother cousyng commaunde v vnto mayst harty maner receyued fra raff heraulde letter quharuntill ye approue allow doynges commissioner lately beyng border bathe realmes makyng redresse quylke thought counsell continnet delaet xv daye october al ye write slaars see aught copere personally attorneis letter heraulde ilay ye ascertaine v ye nought entre treux taken betwext mast christian kyng father aragon ye others ha e liege nether ne may take peace treux abstinece warre common enemy without consent confederate emperour kyng aragon ye euery bounden make actuall warre instant sommer agaynst common enemie concluded openly sworne paules kyrke london vpon saincte markes daye last past ferther haue denyed saueconduyte vpon requestes seruitor might haue resorted presence herauld ilay reportes right excellet right high mightie prince derest brother cousyng thesayd metyng commissioner border peremptorily appoyncted betwyxt v eftir diuerse dietes reformacio contynued commissioner metynge effecte due redresse suld haue ben made sayde metynge lyke parte commissioner offered haue made tyme part na malefactour arrested sayde diet glose thesame ye nowe wright slaars see nede compere personally attourneys quylk agayne lawe god man gef crimenall accion slaars sulde nought compere personally na punicion sulde folowe slaughter vane seke farther metynges redresse hereby apperes dede shewes ye wyll nouther kepe gude weyes iustice equitie kyndnes v greate wronges vnkyndnes done v lyeges ponderate quhilk haue suffered long time vpberyng maynsweryng nounredressyng attemptates byll taken haldynge bastard heron complices cuntre quha slewe wardan vnder traist dayes metyng iustice therof filat ordaynt delyuered aynge liege noble men vnder colour folkes takynge vthers realme prisonet cheinet cragges cotre halding wife legacie promist youre diuerse letter dispite v slaughter andrewe barton awne commaund quha nought offended liege vnredressed breakynge amitie behalfe dede haldynge shippes artilarie vse quharupon eft diuerse requisition warden commissioner ambassador selfe ye wrate al shewe vthers vnto v ful redresse suld made sayde metynge commissioner sa hope reformacion left ye sake walde haue desisted fra inuasion frendes cousynges awne countreis haue nought offended firste required fauoure oure tendre cousynge duke geldre quham destroye disinherite ye send folkes dudde right sa latly desyred brother cousynge mast christen kynge fraunce quham ye haue caused tyne countre millaigne nowe inuades selfe quha v secunde degree blude hase ben vnto kynde witoute offense kyndar v notwithstandynge defense persone mon take parte therto ye vthers haue gyuen occasion v lyeges tyme past nouther doynge iustly kyndely towardes v procedynge alwayes vtter destruction nerest frendes quha mon doo v quhan shall necessarie euill example ye wyll hereafter better vnto v quham ye lightlye fauoure manifestly wranged sister sake incotrary writtes sayeng vnto herauld giue fayre wordes thinkes cotrary dede gaue wordes ye dudde v trustynge ye shoulde haue emended v worthin kyndar frendes sake sulde nougtight haue stopped oure seruitors passage laboure peax thei might papes halines exherted v breuites therapon contented haue ouersene harmes haue remitted thesame though vther informacion made haly father pape iuly cardinall yorke ambassadour sen ye haue put v fra gude beleue premiss specially denyenge saueconduyte seruauntes resorte presence ambassadour doctor west instantly desyred sulde sende one counsayll vnto apon greate matter appoynctyng differentes debatable betwyxt v furtheryng peax yf might betwyxte christen kyng neuer harde purpose saueconduite denied betwixte infideles herefore write tyme length playnes mynde require desyre desiste fra farther inuasion vtter destructio brother cousyng mayst christen kyng whome confederacion bloude alye also new bande quhilk ye haue compelled v lately take iniuries harmes without remedy done daily vnto v liege subdites bounde oblist mutuall defence ilke vthers like ye confederate oblist mutuall inuasions actuall warre certifieng take parte defence brother cousyng maist christen kyng wil thyng trayest may crast cause desist fra persuite denyt pospoynct iustice liege mon gyue letter marque accordyng amitie betwixte v quharto ye haue lyttell regarde tyme past haue ordaint herauld bearer hereof saye gife like gyf credence right excellent right high mightly prince derest brother cousyng trinitie haue kepyng geuen vnder signet edynborowe xxvi daie iuly kynge rede letter sente haste earle surrey england whyche lay pomfrett caused letter deuised kyng scottes copie whereof foloweth right excellent right high mighty prince c haue receiued writyng dated edenburgh xxvi daie iuly heraulde lyon bearer wherin rehersall accumulacio many surmised iniuries grefes damage doone v subiectes liege specialites whereof superfluous reherse remembryng theim euery theim effect reasonable aunswere founded vpon lawe coscience hath tofore ben made youre counsail ye requyre v desiste farther inuasion vtter destruction brother cousyng french kyng also certifie v take parte defence thesayd kyng thyng whiche ye trust may rahter cause v desiste persuite many contriued occasion comunications causeles sought imagened sownynge breache perpetuall peace passed concluded sworne betwixte v immagened querelles causeles deuised breake v contrarye othe promised al honor kyndnesse cannot maruayle consideryng auncient accustomable maners progenitours whiche neuer kept lenger faythe promise pleased theym howebeit yf loue dread god nighnes bloud honour world lawe reason bound suppose ye woulde neuer haue farre proceded specially absence wherin pope prince christened may well note dishonorable demeanour whan ye lyeng awayte seke way sayde absence whiche ye woulde haue ben well aduised attempte beynge within realme present theuident approbation hereof nede none proues ne witnesse youre owne writynges heretofore v sent beyng within realme wherein ye neuer made mencion takynge parte enemie frenche kynge pa ed tyme v tyll ter departure saide realme percase ye supposynge v soo farre sayde realme destitute defense agaynst inuasions haue vttered olde rancour mynde whiche couert maner ye haue longe kept secrete neuerthelesse remembrynge brytilnes promyse suspectynge though wholy beleuyng much vnstedfastnes thought right expedient necessarie put saide realme redynes resistyng sayde entreprises hauyng firme trust lorde god rightwysnes cause thassistence confederate alies wee shalbe able resyste malice scysmatyques adherentes beynge generall counsayll expressely excommunicate interdycted trustynge also tyme conueniente remember frendes requyte enemy whiche suche vnnaturall demeanour haue gyuen sufficiente cause dy erison posterite euer possybilitie ye thynke haue royalme whiche ye nowe attempte inuade yf example kyng nauarre beynge excluded royalme assistence gyuen frenche kyng cannot restrayne fro vnnaturall dealynge suppose ye shall haue lyke assistence syade frenche kynge kyng nauarre hath nowe kynge withoute realme frenche kynge peaceably suffereth hym contynue wherunto good regarde woulde taken lyke heretofore touched thys oure wrytyng nede make aunswere manyfolde greues surmysed letter asmuche yf lawe reason coulde haue remoued sensuall opinion ye haue ben many often tymes sufficientely aun swered thesame excepte onely pretended greues touchynge denyeng saufeconduyte ambassadoure bee last sent vnto v vnto make aunswere graunted thesayde saufeconduite yf herauld would haue taken thesame hym lyke hath ben accustomed sollicitee saufeconduytes marchauntes others hertofore ye might sone haue neuer denyed saufeconduyte liege come vnto v passe see wel lyke sayde herauld hath heretofore made sinister reporte contrary trouthe hath done nowe case manifest open fynally towchyng requisition desiste farther attemptyng againste enemy french kyng knowe competent iudge high aucthoritie requyre v behalfe wherfor god willyng purpose ayde assistence confederate alies persecute thesame ye v realme shalbe remebred acquited hereafter helpe lord patrone sainct george righte excellent right highe myghtie prynce c yeuen vnder signet campe tyrwyn xii daye august letter written sealed kynge sent lyon scottysh heraulde declared hym wel considered ma ets letter therto made reasonable answere gaue hym rewarde hundred angel rewarde humbly tha ked kyng raried gartier al might euer sayde sory thynke domage shoulde done englande master kynge returned nexte daye departed flaunders wyth hys letter haue taken shyppe sayle scotlande coulde haue shyp wynde hys master slayne defyaunce declared kyng scottes herauld king england wrote quene whiche left behynde counsayll prepare hast defence thesayde kynge scottes dyd wt great diligence shal shortly kyng lay thus siege tirwyn frenchme studied wayes possible vitayle towne tirwyn imagened night waye conuey vitayle towne wherfore euery day sent ther stradiates espie way thei might take auantage many time english horsmen mette wt stradiates slewe parte frenche kyng woulde wise kyng englande shoulde fought wherefore sent duke uandosme duke longuyle diuerse valiant captain blagoy ther conclusio taken duke lanson wyth vm men fight earle shrewsburye el kepe nother nother lord harbert ayde come kynges battayle kyng skyrmish duke uandosme longuyle meane season cariages vitayle might entre towne accomplyshyng entreprice frenchman made greate pur aunce horsebacke secretly cocluded kyng england ynkelyng therof sent woorde emperour whiche lay ayre knewe nothyng deuyse desyered hym come campe haue aduyse gladly aunswered woulde come morowe kyng contynually sent foorth light horse seke countrey se yf apparaunce euer brought tidynges thyng thei sawe alwaies forsene kyng people taken vnpuruyed frenchemen shoulde come sodainly vnaskryed thynges thus commonynge immagenyng themperour maximilian seruauntes whiche reteyned kyng england wage day euery person accordynge degree themperour kynges soldioure ware crosse sayncte george rose hys trayne came kynges campe xiii daye august beyng frydaye receyued eith greate magnyficence brought tente cloth golde ready apparelled accordynge estate tente within syled clothe golde blewe veluet blewe veluet embrowdered hk fyne golde hys cupboorde rychely furnyshed offycers appoyncted geue hym attendaunce taried tyll sonday thence went agayne ayre pleasure kyng counsaill informed espialles also yt confessed certayne prysoners howe frenche armye whiche lay blangoy entended vitayle cytee tyrwyn wherfore frydaye nyght xiii day august duke buckyngham earle essex marque dorsett lorde burgaynye lord willoghby dyuerse gentleman vi thousande men foote lorde walon lorde ligny ther horseman layed gyngate south syde tyrwyn nyghte order battayle awaytynge reskewe cytee englishman askryed frenchman brake purpose tyme duke buckyngham compaygnions returned campe monday xiii daye august infortune oute cause knowen fell greate debate betwene almaynes kynges felde thenglyshemen muche fell fyghtynge many men slayne almaynes sodaynely ran kynges ordynaunce toke yt embattayled selfes bent ordynaunce agaynste kynge campe thenglisheme greately fumed matter muche archer sett forwarde haue ioyned almaynes lykewyse prepared pykes capytaynes tooke suche payn fray appesed al thing done time comocion trouble emperour came ayre saw demener party glad se discrete handelyng capitaynes themperour come kynges felde kyng called theperour lordes counsayll togither asserteynyng credybly enformed frenchman entended reskewe cytee tyrwyn wherefore agreed master ordynaunce shoulde haste make fyue bridge ouer water army passe ouer thentent besege cytee syde carpenter dyd deuer nyght daye brydges made horseman passed ouer askryed countrey twesdaye xvi daye august kyng reysed hys campe greate ordinaunce artilerye cariage passed ryuer hym came sir ihon neuell hys lyghte horseman tolde behinde tower gyngate great plumpe horseman meane season sir ihon neuell tolde kynge tydynges nother waye therle essex sir ihon peche kynges speres passed skyrmyshed wyth plumpe speres sir ihon spake many profets made bothe sydes conclusion frenchemen compelled leaue stale one horseman taken sente kyng whiche hope pardon raunsome shewed howe frenche army wyth full power strength commynge blangoy nomber fyften thowsande horseman armes ayde tyrwyn syde water thentente armye lorde stuarde lorde chamberlayne shoulde ayde kynge appoyncted v thousande xv thousande horseman syde water tydynges tolde came one sir ryce sayde prisoner daye taken confessed cytee shoulde reskowed daye askryed nomber horseman hys iudgemente vppon poynct syx thowsand sodaynely came northren men whyche affirmed sene frenche armye order battayle commynge forwarde iudged past twelfe thowsande men kynges felde pytched ordynaunce sett counsaylled kynge take downe hys tentes kynge sayde wyll thys daye felde made sett royall wyse maye bee ryche tentes sett vpp whyche done kynge called lorde darcy commaunded hym kepe hys felde treasure ordynaunce stuffe whyche lothe goo hys master streyte commaundemente euerye man prepared hym selfe battayle resortynge standarde horseman marched footman space myle styll came curroures berynge tydynges frenche armye approched kynge sette forwarde auaunce hys banner name god sainct george almaynes seynge purpose yt knowen sodainly embatteled selfes left hande kyng left brest fronte kyngs battayle bare kyng thus marchyng forwarde towarde battaile came emperour maximilian xxx men armes companye armed sute redde cross counsayll emperour kynge caused certaine peces small ordinaunce laied toppe long hill banke skowerers thus kynges horseman archer horsebakce marched forwarde kyng woulde fayne haue afore horsmen counsayll perswaded contrary taried footme accompanied themperour frenchman came iii range xxxvi men thickenes well thei perceiued kynges battayle footman marchyng forwarde erle essex capitayne horsmen sir iho p kynges horsmen burgonyons nomber xic stode wyth banner displayed valey lorde walonne lorde ligny bastarde emery bende nomber iiiic horsmen seuered selfes stode syde englishman thenglishmen viic yet banner displayed remoued vp toppe hill mett sir ihon gylforde c talle archer horsebacke whiche askryed frenchemen nowe topp hill fayre plaine good grounde left hand lowe wodde right hand alowe felde lord walonne burgomons kept loofe appered sight frenchman banner standardes displaied came capitaynes thenglishmen armes english officer armes called clarenseux sayde god name sett forward victorie see abide goo coate armes horsmen sett forward archer lighted set order hedge long village side called bomye frenchman came xxxiii standardes displayed archer shotte pace galled ther horse english speres sett freshly cryeg sainct eorge fought valiantly frenchman threw downe ther standarde dust great crye sodainly frenchman shocked ther standarde fledde threw away speres swerdes ma cut bardes ther horse ronne lighter hinder parte saw former fly fledde also soner one cause english horsmen mounted vpp hill stradiates comyng downe wardes one syde hill french hoste sodainly saw banner english horsmen kynges battayle folowyng vpwarde wenyng horsmen cast self fledde frenchman fast array stradiates could haue entre thei ranne still thedes range french army behynde saw fall standardes stradiates whome th greate confidence retorne thei farthest fledde firste vp pranced burgonyons folowed chace battaile horsmen horsme eg l nomber frenchman x one byn sene tyme thenglishe horseman gatt victory men armes frauncethe iourney spurres frenchman call battaile iourney spurres cause thei rane away fast horsbacke battaile xvi daye august whiche battayle taken duke longuyle loys brother therle dunoys maried marque rutilons heyre lorde cleremounde many noble men nomber xii skore brought kynges presence lykewyse standardes banner brought kyng burgonios kept ther prisoner brought sight fame wet mousire dela palayce taken lett goo thenglyshemen folowed chace iii myle longe felde water valey frenchman sayde sir gyles capell one daye woulde haue daye whiche aunswered hym agayne frenche bragge fraunce thenglishemen returned kynge whiche commyng forward gaue thankes greate praisynges ther valiantnes ther made sir ihon peche bannarett made ihon car knyght sore hurt sir ihon peche guyd home taken diuers men hurt folowed farre kyng retreted gyngate whome came sir rise shewed hym hoat frenchman skyrmyshed hym daye syde ryuer therle shrewsbury banner displaied al daye prest order battayle haue fought duke alanson therle sainct polle lord florenges v men haue harde appoincted reskewe towne syde lord shrewsburye lay let hym come ayde kyng euer happened stode still came downe skyrmyshed sir rice citie tyrwyn daye hope ayde thei saw ther helper comyng n therthesame daye proudely issued lord harbert skirmyshed people valiantly within also shott ordinauce partes lorde harbert capitaines coragiously defended sore sett frenchme dra e force ther gate ther succour many slayne night kyng sent duke long uyle lord cleremounde diuerse nobleman duke supped kyngs borde nyght frenchman discomfyture assembled together returned blangoy xii myle coste talked loss knewe taken ayn therefore sent heraulde kyng knowe nomber prisoner kynges counsayll accordynge desyer sent name kyng beyng assertayned frenche kynges purpose yet agayne geue hym battayle commaunded best prisoner shoulde conueyed towne ayre flaunders thenglyshmen brought thyther capitayne denyed thenglishmen shoulde entre towne prisoner fraunce whome countrey peace yf frenchemen woulde desyre lodgyng ease shoulde permytted en thenglishmen fury aunswered yf wyll suffer v kepe prisoner slay frenchman mekely praied capitayne suffer englishemen entre sware kepers trewe prysoners entered conueyed england lorde powntremy howse cresquy capitayne generall tyrwyn perceyued discomfiture frenche partie perceyued howe earle shrewsburye lorde harbert brought thither greate ordinaunce nere toune nerer coulde brought walles suche batterie lyke continue yet manfully defended cytee shotte gonne euery daye accustomed neuer despayre tyll xviii daye thesayde moneth sawe kynge remoue campe gyngate layed campe southe syde towne betwene reskewe toune sawe consydered hys succour put backe towne sore febeled kynges greatest ordinaunce bent agaynst towne therfore aduyse capytaynes sent therle shrewsburye lorde harb rte trumpett desyerynge abstinence warre daye incon ynente sent kynge knowe pleasure kynge aunswered woulde graunte till knewe consideracion capitayne sent woorde saufeconduyte would come speke kynges counsayll whyche hym graunted sent certayne commyssioners whyche offered delyuer towne ordynaunce municions without fraude townes men woulde dwell myght haue life goodes safe men warre myght departe wyth horse harneys goodes sayde none horse harneys lytell valure greate prynce kyng counsayll debated matter aunswered commissioner allthough kynge knewe ther penury vitayle dayly mortalite among towne reason great battery able long resiste yet cause asked marcy woulde extende igor graunted requeste delyuered towne ordynaunce promysed whyche sworne returned thesame nyght therle shrewsburye entred toune walles tower banner saint george set highest place signe victory lord powtremy al garryson departed horse harneys accordyng appoinctemente lord george talbott erle shrewsburye iiic men ser hed towne fere treason inconuenience might vnto kyng people saw thing suer called al townes men together sware trewe kyng england done kyng xxiiii daye august entered cytye tyrwyn ix clocke noone great triuphe honour persone apparelled armure gylt grauen garment barde purple veluet full border place trauersed branch ronnyng worke fyne golde branch hawthorne wrought goldesmythes crafte wounde braunche rose euery ower lefe bury enbossed whome folowed henxmen peces armure accustomed thus greate glorye goodly prince entered toke possession towne tyrwyn receiued cathedrall church procession harde masse dyned bi oppes palyce none retorned campe leuynge towne earle shrewsbury retinue xxvi daye august kyng remoued agayn gyngate agreed walles gate rwyn bur ed bulwarkes tower tyrwyn defaced rased cast downe whiche conclusion emperour sent word sainct omers ayre beyng ioyous tidynges tyrwyn scorge sent thyther pyoners al maner instrumentes thenglish pioners brake downe walles gate tower foundacion filled diche fyered towne except cathedrall church palayce ordinauce kyng sent ayre kept vse concluded kyng person ley siege citee towne turney wherfore set forwarde three goodly battayles first conduyted therle shrewsbury seconde battayle ledde kyng hym selfe whome themperour rereward conduyted lord harbert first night theilaye campe besyde ayre whiche night vitaile skant diuerse englishman tarried tyrwyn kynge past pillage fyred certayne howses whome came sodainly french stradiates slew caste fier fledde scaped narrowly wednesday xiiii daie septeber kyng army came beatwyn plentie thynges morowe army passed forward came strayt foorde carriage must nedes come downe stepe hill foorde streyt one wagon scace alone might passe wether hoat beastes dronke daye wherfore foorde horse woulde drynke gre ther leders carriage wet hole together dowtfull case yet wise order thei passed streyte dyd army came place betwene cauon camblyne lodged night playne barren grounde next daye remoued campe forward passed bridge called pount auandien flaunders syde lay kyng lay ende bridge arthoys syde rereward lay fayre grounde behynde kyng saterday xvii day september tidinges came kyng frenchman assembled great puissauce would fight king wherfore king caused forward remoue farther sent almaynes kept passage pount dassaus great ordynaunce passed bridge pount auandien king remoued fro thence tentes wre takyng vp askrye made enemy sight noyse sodainly seased sir william sandes viic englishme stranger appoincted kepe bridge certayne ordinaunce appoincted kyng carriage passed lord harbert remoued ouer bridge encamped hym behynde kyng fayre mylle kynge ncamped thynges order came hym noble man flaunders called lorde rauesten humble reuerence done shewed kyng young prynce castel charles lady margarete gouernes thesayde prynce hartely desyred pastime long trauayle come repose towne lysle see brother prynce lady court burgoyne sayenge became lady visite hym marcyall campe whiche terryble kyng gentelly graunted request sent officer thether make prouision appoyncted duke buckyngham marque dorsett therle essex lord lysle dyuerse geue ther attendaunce committed campe counsayll mounted courser app rell barde cloth syluer small quadrant cuttes trauersed edged cutt clothe golde border set full redde roofes armore freshe sett full iuels master hys horse sir henry guylforde henshmen folowed haue hard courser richely apparelled many capitaynes wayted kyng waye mett kyng lorde rauesten many noble men myle withoute towne ther mette hym bourgesses lysle presented hym keyes towne sayeng themperour souereigne lord commaunded king praised obedies ther souereigne thaked emperour high presente keyes towne neuerthelesse suche confidence trusted lesse awne suby ctes delyuered keyes prouost towne whiche well accompanyed mette kyng great nomber noble flaunders brabant hollande henawde nobly receaued hym came coutye palatine paulsgraue one elector empyre ith xxx horse al men gorgiously appareilled fasshion countrey humbly saluted kyng gate lisle caput n towne stode garrison armure wel appoincte strets sett bothe sydes burnyng torch diuerse goo ly pagiantes pleasant beholde thus passed thorowe towne swerde e borne hym alighted hall dore swerde borne mett wt thep rour prince castel la margaret hubly saluted reuerence themperour kyng caused swerde put vp mace leyed downe kyng noble lodged feasted accordyng degree towne lisle noys iii gonners handgonnes haue slayne kyng rumour many attached nothynge proued tidynges came campe neuer mery tyl thei saw kyng agayne grett chere ba k ttes playes commodies maskes pastymes ed kyng courte burgoyne solace soiorni sondaye mondaye xix daye september xx ye sent woorde armye shoulde remoue towarde tournay remoued place conuenient betwene tournay lisle certayn capitaines appoicted kepe passage bridge auandien kyng taryed lisle iii day well reposed selfe toke leaue thanked emperour young pry ce lady margaret al lady high chere solace bout vi clock night departed lisle noble men rou ht kynge foorth returned capitayne kyng mile toune asked campe man could tell way guyde thei non night darke mistie thus kyng taryed log whyle wist whyther go last mette vitayler commyng campe whiche ther guyde brought thither ter ordynaunce shotte dyuerse peces ordynaunce harde safetie kyng company returned xxi daye september kyng remoued campe towarde tournay lodged within iii myles cytie corne grounde ryuer whiche nyght came kyng themperour paulsgraue whiche lodged ryche tentes nobly serued vyandes thynges necessarye people aboute tournay wyth goodes fledde cytie yet cytie men warre defende yt multytude inhabitauntes cytee well replenished kyng comaunded sir rice horseman vewe one quarter therle essex company another quarter lord walowne lord ligny quarter xxii day september iiii capitains one tyme sone ope ly wt banner displaied towne made long stale retorned kyng sent gartier kyng armes pursiuant armes trompett somon citee declared kyng england fraunce commaunded yelde hym citee receaue naturall lord woulde put ther citee swerde fyer bloude whome prowdely aunswered thei toke citee kepe none would thei reder wt answere departed fortyfied walles made prouysion vitaile corne wyne artilerie fortificacions might gotte citee selfe strong wel walled turryted wt good bulwarkes defense sawe kyng suche puilauce drawe nere ther cytee sore aba hed called generall cou sayll prou st sayde brethern knowe kyng englande sent heraulde somon v rendre hym cytee el woulde put v swerde fyer bloude aunswered would defence nowe come sight fulfull message sent herauld come time defence matter stadeth iii mischiefes one bouden deuty allegeauce owe souereigne lord kyng loys fraunce seconde life v wife child neighbour thirde defende finall distructio aucient cytee lickely fall cytee neuer conquired cytee hole liues sauity goodes awne determine whither wyl haue warr peace comon people cried war war war saide prouost take co passio wife childre old folke cosider yf haue quyck teskue came continue yoder puisauce al tho corages good hector hilles wisest citee hau cosidered sodainly ther counsaill vauntparler botcher heryng called great nomber affini ie went counsayll gate sett fi r suborbes sydes counsaill saw myndes common ther wayes might folowed comfort people maynteyned ther defence kyng raysed campe cam array battayle tornay earle shres ury forwarde littell space right hand brest kyngs battayle lorde harbert rerewarde le hande lyke manner daye fayer harneys glistered banner waued cytee sore af ayed thus stode kynges battayles array tourney kynge commaunded hys greate ordynaunce caried waye passynge towarde cytee euery thyng accordyng commaundemet accoplished kyng hym selfe fewe persones rode betwene ordynaunce towne rode great aduenture ne e walles might vewe walles tower well shotte tower peces ordinauce hurt came within leuell rong alarme bell harde wel felde citezens issued gate ryuer manfully profered skyrmish thei wt archer sone driuen backe gate english carrier came harbeshers take ground ranne gate tornay toke certayne wagon beere vitayle yet turnoyes dyrst resiste although greater nomber men cariage skyrmysh horse lorde ihon ray brother marque dorsett went defende cariours layne gonne hurt kyng person thus opardie auetured hym self vewed toune caused immediatly xxi peces great artilery brought plain feld towne thei charged thei immediatly shotte parte stone fell cytee thei shotte diuerse shottes one another kyng battayle planted hys siege northe parte citee therle shrew bury battayle warded towarde south syde ryuer lay nyght lorde harbert rerewarde plated hts battall west syde citee great ordynaunce daily bett walles tower citee morowe beynge xxiii daie lorde talbott erle shrewsbury accompanied noble men battaill whose name haue harde first passyng see passed ouer ryuer tornay planted siege southe syde stretchyng east ende citee bent artilery walles citee thus citee tornay beseged partes euer hope reskue valiantly defended selfe nowe must leue kynge siege turnay diuerte thinges done england absence declare howe kynge scottes inuaded realme englande howe defended fought al conclusion slayn vii daye moneth september kynge englande determined high court parliament passe see proper person recouery realme fraunce counsaill forgatt olde prankes scottes y euer inuade england kyng age also knowlege camphe e zeeland scottes dayly shipped long speres called colleyne clowystes armure artiler e whi h dealyng made grace counsaill dowt notwithstandyng th kyng scottes sworne sacramet kepe peace yet voydynge dowtes kyng appoincted lord thomas haward erle surrey sonne lorde iho haward duke norffolke high treasourer marshall englande hys lieut naunt north party agaynste thesayde kynge scottes fortuned inuade dyd dede accordinge olde traytorous accustome hys progenitor sayde erle reyse power contrey chester lancaster duresme northumberlande westmerlande comberland besyde aydes apoyncted quene whe kyng take ship douer toke erle hande sayde lorde trust scottes therfore pray negligent sayde erle shall duety grace shall fynde diligent fulfill shalbe gladnes therle coulde skantly speake whe toke leaue departing fro noble prynce hys souereigne lorde kyng floure nobilitie realme beyng redy suche honorable iorney somewhat settelled hys mode sayde hym sory may se hym dye cause abydinge behynde euer mete shall lyeth make hym sory meanynge thesame kynge scottes douer attendid quene london comfortynge best myght shortely sent hys gentelmen tenauntes whiche vc able men whiche mustered syr thomas louel knyght xxi daye iuly xxi daye rode thorough london northwarde came dancaster commaunded syr william bulmer knight make haste march scotlande lye castels fortress frontier ijc archer horsebacke erle open token dayly perceiued scottes entended warre sayde syr william spede departed came border erle came pomfret first daye august taried syr william bulmer come border one daye august lorde chamberlayne warden scotland vii viii men banner displayed entered england brent haryed great praye northumberland hering syr willia bulner called hym gentelmen border archer al thousand men nere assembled brought selfes brome felde called mylfeld scottes passe scottes proudely returned pray englishman brake oute scottes fote like men defended archer shotte holy together made scottes geue place v vi hundred slayne iiii hundred taken prisoner pray reskued beside great nu ber geldinges taken countrey lorde hume lorde chamberlayne fled banner taken fyrst open token warre shewed scottes whiche call iourney yll roade erle surrey beyng pomfred called hym parte gentelmen county hym apoynted rehersed declaringe kynges hygh commaundement shewynge beynge kynges lieutenaunt muste nedes haue ayde counsayll wherefore sware mooste wysest experte gentelmen suche cause kynges counsayll hys tyme better compassynge hys charge purpose brynge euery thynge dew order fyr toke determinacion syr philippe tylney knight treasurer warres howe charge shoulde payde secondarely syr nycholas applyarde master ordinaunce conueyaunce kynges royall ordinaunce pouder artillerie newcas ell forwarde case shoulde requyer whiche syr nycholas william blacknall clercke kynges spycerie sent saide ordinaunce artillerie durham thynges concerning office redynes erle forgat sende lordes spirituall temporall knyghtes gentelmen whiche tenauntes ruler tounes liberty able make men certifie number able men horsed haruesed able make within houres warnynge geue attendaunce hym also layed postes euery waye whiche postes stretched march wale counsayll reason whereof knowlege done euery coste erle enformed lorde dacres numbrynge preparynge men scotlande proclamacions soundinge breche peace yet though considered roade made lorde chamberlayne scotlande englande beyng distrussed syr william bulmer ore rehersed open breche perpetuall peace yet sayde lorde dacres auysed earle many greate weyghty cause reyse styrre power countrey hym appoynted tyll mighte perceyue openly know subtyle purpose entent scottes aforesaid lest scottes perceyued englishemen redy fighte woulde haue desisted theyr purpose tyme tyll englishemen returned theyr countreys sodaynely ryse agayne erle knowynge towne barwycke strog ynough sent capitayne norham certefienge hym thought castell anye daungier debylitie woulde put hym selfe readynes reskew beseged capitayn wrote erle thankynge hym prayed god kynge scottes woulde come wyth hys puyssaunce woulde kepe hym playe tyll tyme kynge englande came oute fraunce reskew whiche aunswer reioysed erle muche came fraunce reskewe whiche aunswer reioysed erle muche kynge scottes sent hys defyaunce kynge englande lyenge tyrwyn haue harde dayly made hys muster assembled hys people ouer hys realme whereof brute two hundred thousand suertye hundred thousand good lightynge men lest wyth hys hoste power entered englande threw doune pyle xxii daye august planted hys siege castell norham sore abated walles erle hard tydynges thereof fyue twenty day august beynge saynct barthelmewes daye wrote gentelmen shyres aforesayde hym newcastell fyrst daye septeber next retynew accordynge certificat morow fyue hundred men came yorke xxvi daye went toward newcastell withstandyng fowlest day nyght could wayes depe much hys guyde almost drouned hym yet neuer ceased kept hys
