marshall calayce capitaine bullain called fyrebrand badge sette furth calayce xi day iune xiic men went calayce sent pursiuant capitain bullain certifiyng commyng fyerbrand bad kepe promise officer declared message came furth marched sir edward til came marguison taryed see whether capitain bullayne would come sawe came set fyer toune light horseman forrayed beastes pillage brent village whiche wel perceiued countrey farre towarde night crew came home good pillage morow sir edwarde gyldford deliuered prisoner franke free condicion tell capitaine bullain marguison fyerbrand whiche truely message whiche capitaine brake head castels fortress englishe pale well manned vitailed lacked artillerie frenchemen could theim harme emperor kyng laye byshops waltham ioyntly sent letter defiaunce duke lorraine alye confederate frenche kyng fyrst day iuly emperor nauy sailed hampton wer clxxx goodly shippes emperor shippes come tooke leaue kyng great gyftes geuen muche money lent vi day iuly toke shippe nauy made saile towarde spayne ariued safetie x day kyng tyme sent citie london borow xxm poudes whiche sore chafed citizen somme promised payment mayer sent none men substaunce howbeit craftes solde muche plate summe payde kyng sent letter promisyng payment thesame cardinall poore men content payment sayd let riche churles pay may well lyke loane practised al realme priuy seales deliuered repayment season xxi day maye citie geane gotten emperor capitain called octauiano de columna whiche iiiim iiiic spaniardes vm italyans iiiim lanceknightes citie taken porter de nauarro frenche kynges familiar capitaine lordes geane whiche fauored frenche kyng taken prisoner slaine especially one octa iano faragoso whiche ruled frenche kyng euil punished spoyle citie souldiers iiiim dukates beside pillage whiche great thyng let v returne lorde admyrall englande whiche departed fro hampton haue heard nauy sayled skoured sea last came costes britaigne commaunded wysest master marriners boy hauen morles whiche done next night flete came hauen morles safetie moored shippes together men commaunded harnes auaunce standardes souldiers geue attendance capitaines lorde admyral appointed caused xiiii piece ordinaunce called faucons brought land drawen furth stregth men menne go forwarde landed lorde amyrall banner displayed tooke lande estside hauen fyrst day iulye fayre band souldiers lorde fitz water baron curson sir richard wyngfelde sir richard iernyngham sir wyllyam barantine sir adrian foskew sir edwarde donne sir edwarde chamberlayne fraunces bryan richard cornewall sir anthony poynes sir hery sherborne vice admyrall sir willyam fitzwillyam sir edmond bray sir gyles capel sir willyam pyrton sir ihon cornewalles sir ihon wallop sir edward echyngham sir willyam sidnay anthony broune gyles huse thomas ihon russell edward bray henry owen george cobham thomas owdayle thomas louell robert iernyngham anthony kneuit sir ihon tremaile master kynges ordinaunce sir willyam skeuyngton ihon fabian serieant armes enterprise chiefly moued reported many gentleman souldiers nombre viim lorde admyral sir richard wyngfeld brought men good order battail caused christopher morres master gunner see thinges redy prepared viii clocke sayd fyrst day marched towarde morles good ordre battail banner displaied alarme rose countrey came toune morles wherby gentleman countrey shewed theimselfes prickyng heard gunnes fledde though neuer vsed warre morles armed theimselfes went walles shut gate laide ordinaunce moste ieopardie englishemen gone fiue long myle nowe come subberbes toune englishemen archer shot brytons defended admyrall commaunded toune assauted lord fitz water baron curson quartered toune side englishemen shot long bowes brytons crosse bowes whiche defended themsel e manfully port moruet meason de dieu gate gaue assaut sir richard wyngfelde nycholas carew frau ce bryan sir ihon wallop bendes hauyng thre piece ordinaune called faucons whiche master gunner oft tymes shot briton set gate full hacbushes gunner sayd haue wicket smoke gunnes let v entre gate gentleman assented sayd sir christopher gunner strake locke wicketmo le as uted gotten flew open smoke ranne gate sayd christopher forenamed gentleman christopher came gate found wicket open entred gentleman folowed brytons defended selfes thei put backe slaine great gate opened entered souldiers side toune brytons walles sawe towne gotten fled posterne another way best way could therle surray baner displayed toke market place souldiers fell pillage rifled chestes ware house marchauntes toune morles riche specially lynnen clothe gentleman suffered souldiers would souldiers taken pleasure toune muche trueth could beare away lorde admiral comaunded trumpettes blow comaunded men set fyer al place toune holy place except fayre market place set fyer subburbes brent ardatly wherfore men commaunded standardes aboute vi clocke army retreted thei passed brent village place night approched drewe together night lay land abidyng enemy next day honor tooke shippes menne shipped fewe none missed lorde admyrall comaunded xvi xvii shippes small great liyng hauen brent sailed furth came anker saint polle de lyon commaunded foyst smal shippes great botes manned enter harborow shippes called pympoll pympole sone done boates entred ye place laded brytons strong tooke boates bet briton shore brytons shotte great ordinaunce englishemen harme yet englishman brent shippe cc many small vessel tyme came whole flete sailed hauen brest barkes rowe barge entered hauen toke land englishemen muche set yer hou e nere castle euen thenglishemen sayled cost brytons askryed fortefied ladyng place yet dayly englishemen skyrmished brytons came safely shippes againe watre duchy brytaigne sore troubled lorde admirall wonne toune morles haue heard called certaine squyers hardynes noble courage made knightes yrst sir fraunces bryan sir anthony broune sir richard cornwall sir thomas sir eyles huse sir ihon russel sir ihon raynsford sir george cobham sir iho cornwalles sir edward rigley diuers wrote letter kyng good spede whiche muche praised gentleman souldiers hardynes sayled sea letter sent king retreyte came withall flete vnder isle wyght place called kow departed shippe came estamstede xxi day iulye kyng well welcomed may sure mounday xxiii day iuly kyng came london cardynals place sat counsaile determine done kyng dyned cardinall xxiii day iulye rehersed knowlege amyrall britaigne morles c horseman c crosbowes yet fledde kyng muche comended lorde admyral paind hardynes praised theim garde specially fiftie whiche left pylferyng neuer went lorde capitaine third day iuly enterprise done morles certaine frenchemen nomber ccc horseman came nere castle guysnes kept theim selfe close couert appered viii x horseman came nere guysnes castle came viii englishe archer issued gate fell frenche horseman skyrmished frenchemennes reskue came iiii men armes skyrmished archer whiche fote guysnes issued xii dimilances welshemen rane boldely ye frenchemen reskue fotemen whole bend frenchemen issued set welshemen fotemen shotte arrowes lasted faine fight swordes welshman kept themselfes together entred bend frenchemen brake speres fought swordes made away thei escaped bend ccc horseman frenchemen slayne iii men v horse fotemen ouerpressed solde liues dere frenchemen slew would take none prisoner angry kyllyng horse also xxv day iuly sir wylly sandes treasorer caleys sir edward guilforde marshall banner spred issued caleys xiiiic menne went frenche pale lokyng mounsire foyat whiche great mocker coward appeared went whitsand baye set fyer people fled churche whiche fortified stode defence body churche wonne toke steple yelded themselfes remnant counsail priest mainteined long steple fyred priest cried succour late frenche people fayne lepe steple diuers perished saued wer led caleys prisoner farther xxiii daye thesame moneth thwaites capitaine englishe shippe tooke land beside bullein went vp thre myle countrey toune called newe castle forryed countrey returne set fyer toune brent great part therof maugre bullenoys bowes men whiche vi score put backe lxxx hagbushes ccc men warre countrey came shippe botie lost notwithstandyng sore folowed shippe vi day iuly cardynall satte starre chamber westminster sayd lordes reason know honorable enterprise done lorde admiral compaigny brytaigne whiche hath dispoyled destroyed great toune morles brytaigne village countrey adioynyng thesame whiche frenche dominion whiche mischiefe neuer risen fraunces frenche kyng kept othe promise bound neuer retayne swyches emperor shall inuade emperor landes dominion whiche hath done hath inuaded coutrey henaude cambrises taken hedyng fountraby many iniuryes kyng sent great costes last yere caleys treate vnitie peace betwene theim saiynges frenche kyng turned mocquery also cotrary promise hath suffered duke ihon albany enter realme scotland great perill yong kyng nephieu soueraigne lorde also entendeth mary quene scottes contrary kynges honor sayd frenche kyng also witholdeth kynges dueties systers dower wherfore necessitie kyng entered warre prince suffre wrong french kyng offereth vntrue forsworne prince wherfore owne welth must ayde prince trustyng punishe chastice great honor fame commaundement wer frechemen scottes imprisoned goodes seazed suche denizen commaunded shewe letter patentes suche allowed goodes frenchemen scottes maryed englishewomen wife child halfe goodes deliuered vnto euery denizen fynde suertie good abearyng al would bayled fynde suerties trueth allegeaunce el kept prison porte kept could flye kyng nowe beyng entered warres thought slepe let frenche kyng alone wherfore letter commauded certain persones power come lodon august wer appointed came accordyngly euery man suche nomber appointed mustered london kynges commissioner nere xiim menne pyoners wer sent lorde admyral whiche lay douer iiiim haruest done ye vitaile caleys litle great armye wherfore lay kent tounes good space whiche made vitaile dere sommer lorde rosse lorde dacres north whiche appointed kepe border scotland valiantly burned good toune kelsy lxxx village ouerthrew xviii tower stone barnkyns bulwerkes kyng also moneth credibly enformed duke albany prepared army royal scottes frenchemen inuade england wherfore kyng appointed erle shrewsbury lorde steward lieutenaunt generall sayd duke inuasions whiche directed letter shyres yorke darby stafford shropshyre al beyond trent menne readynes xx day august cardynall sent maior alderman moste substanciallest comminers citie london declared theim kyng appointed commissioner whole realem england swere euery manne value mouables readynes defence realme kyng loue beareth would haue syt himselfe certayne affayres warres done letted hath appointed commissioner wherefore conuenient tyme certifye nomber suche worth one hundreth poundes vpwarde entent may sweare theim value fyrst kyng asketh louyng heartes due obeysaunce whiche shall appeare conformitie requestes value taken desyreth onely tenth part goodes landes whiche least reasonable thyng ayde prince thynke euerye one wyll offer lesse spiritualtie euery manne shyres sworne shall wyll gladly pay fowerth part kyng liue iii partes nowe part sure wyll grudge therfore name menne substaunce meanet sorte meaner commissioner shall appointed sir sayd marchaunt may please shal tenth part kyng deliuered money plate iuels sayd cardinall value lorde sayd alderman yet two monethes sithe kyng citie xx thousand pound ready money loane whereby citie bare money goddes sake remembre riche marchauntes ware bare money well sayd cardynall must done therefore go alderman resorted wardes named suche iudged value whiche came cardynall moste humbly besought might sworne true value substaunce true valuacion theim vnknowen many honest mennes credence better substance therefore doubted paril periury well sayd cardinall sythe dread cryme periurye signe grace therefore borowe kyng lytie make bylles owne value likely report fame busynes nedeth see two costly armyes kyng hath ready bothe fraunce scotland therfore nowe shewe selfes lyke louyng subiectes able inough dare sweare substance london lesse worth two myllions golde sayd citezens would god citie sore appaired great occupiyng straungers well sayd cardinal shalbe redressed liue saterday next shall appoint one receiue bylles credence substance let resorte secrete good thus citezens departed great agony saiyng last loane lent fifth part nowe haue tenth part muche note wel x thousand poundes lent taken xx euery mannes substauce allowed part x part valuacion performe vp whole x part great mournyng common people euer suche case paymentes ende one doctor tonnys secretary cardinal came chapiter house poules citezens brought bylles honestie receiued whiche value afterwarde turned displeasure spiritualtie made suite lorde cardinal temporal men sit examyne made priuy possession goodes wherfore bishoppes abbottes appointed commissioner take value snbstaunce season great plentie vitaile sent caleys lorde admyral sent tentes pauilions lxx lodgynges nobleman friday beyng xxii day august certain welshemen lodged poore village named cause caleys verye narow lodgyng thesame night cccc frenchman passed caleys haue lacke good watche came thesame village set fyer house welshemen lay whiche ranne awaye naked marishe saued themselfes horse wer taken chaunce happened lacke good watche lorde admyrall brought menne shippes souldiors come englande ordinaunce set land came caleys hauen xiiii shyppes spayne emperor whiche set land ccc spanyardes whiche sent serue lorde admyrall vnder put thinges ready lorde admyral set order battels forewarde appointed sir robert ratcleffe lorde fitzwater capitayne diuers knightes gentleman whiche capitaine kept men good order battail folowed ordinaunce artilerie truss vitail necessary capitaine horseman appoined sir edward gyldford currers vewers countrey appointed myddle warde ledde lorde admyrall himselfe compaignie lorde edmond hawarde brother many worshipfull knightes squiers tall yomen last battail ledde two valiaunt knightes garter sir wyllyam sandes sir richard wyngfelde theim sir richard iernyngham many good order battail passed ouer newnam bridge xxx day august place called calkewell lodged betwene ye wyndmyl marrishe thesame day came lorde admyrall certain nombe wilde persones menne seruice apprentises ranne fro master ydle persones desired might retained kinges wage answered kyng appointed nobre suche haue wage whiche fully complete aduised theim returne england loyter sayd tall yoman lorde many good felowes fauor would ieopard get lose mynde reuenged frenchemen enemy kyng realme good felowe sayd lorde admyrall myndes good lacke conduite cast awaye losse kyng great corage frenchemen compaignie cried let v go name god sainct george counsail take gaue penon sainct george bad aduenture whiche called aduenturers farther bad theim got botie euer bryng tharmy thei payde vttermost gaue money comaunded weapon sayd xxxi day sayd aduenturers iiiic nombre mo sette forwarde host shall heare afterwarde monday fyrst day september armye remoued towarde guisnes day hote drinke lacked water nere died faintnes night laye guysnes tewsday second day september armye passed towarde arde golden ualay kyng england frenchekyng met two yeres met tharmy england two capitaines burgonions one called erle egemond seneschal henaude lorde bauers admyral flau ders vc horseman like men warre lord admyral gentle maner receiued two capitaines compaignie ioyned theimselfes englishe armye day tooke lodgyng arde south toune wel vitailed lay wednisday day burgonyons lay vnder castle mountorrey next day remoued vale lyekes encaped themselfes sir george cobham thesame day wt iim men admyralles comaudement came toune selloys set fyer toune toune fyer assauted castle within made resistence auayled walles wer entred souldiers taken castle set fyer gunpouder ouerthrew walles wt hast remoued toune called brune bridge set fyer also brent toune called senekerke also tounes botyngham manstier returned lorde admyrall whiche gaue great thankes frenchemen appered plumpes yet durst reskue tounes saterday lorde admyrall remoued whole army ground beside sainct nerbyns lay sonday beyng vii day september sent diuers company whiche forraged coutreys brent many village farre thei might trauail lorde admyrall caused toune narbyn brent tooke castle rased vtterly destroyed monday viii day remoued dauerne brent tounes passed liyng brent toune dauerne cast doune castle columberge castle rew church dauerne house nonnes saued comaundement thesame day brent saint marie de boy countrey twelue myle light fyer people fledde left tounes castelles full wyne corne necessary dauerne englishman found great plentie whiche went away set fyer ix day septembre whole armye came toune boyardes whiche church liker castle church depe dyched drawe brydges bulwarkes fortefied lope warlike admyrall beholdyng sayd like house praier commauded people entre dyches plucke doune drawe bridge set fyer ye churche gunpouder ouerthrew brent toune village adiacent people cried fledde well might saue himselfe x day thei came toune uaus nye toune called foucamberge company frenchman askried wod shewed themselfes taryed long without profer encountre departed wherfore whole army toke campe lay till xiii day saterday euery day ndyng plu pe set fyer countrey day toke ay frynge f ynges brent toune destroyed castle whiche strong sonday beyng xiiii day lorde admyral compaigny great raine yll wether passed hilles valeys verye painefully great labor came toune called blaniow taried monday day day counsailed capitaines england flauders burgon best done tewsday mornyng came trumpet castle hedyng desired speake capitainemessage fro hedyng whiche incontinent sent lorde capitaine sayd trumpet capitaine hedyng desireth come thither see place walles wil bryng good lucke prayeth hurt dere parke hurt careth well sayd lorde admyrall send answere trumpetthe answ r incontinent called trumpet bad go hedyng mounsire de bee say would come castle hedyng slay menne artillerie let trust gette castle shall saue neither man woman childe message trumpet departed declared mounsire de bee whiche sayd spoken noble corage trumpet returned thesame day campe remoued whole army came castle hedynghedyng whiche tyme toune hedyng sore infecte pestilence wherefore generall commaundement geuen one come toune howbeit burgonyans set fyre house siege planted ordinaunce light wayes depe grounde wet great ordinaunce could caried thing well debated lord admiral capitaines xi dayes fyrst considered castle could obtained without great ordinaunce whiche wise could caried also light ordinauce shotyng spend pouder get castle theim might reckened great foly also great ieopardie passe without ordinaunce plage began sore armye wherfore determined leaue siege returne lay toune bet doune roffes gallery chymnies suche thinges light ordinaunce would bete doune whiche sore defaced beautie castle thei also destroied dere parke whiche falowe dere left none capitaine englishemen clerely determined haue assauted castle burgonions would haue done thesamethe cause castle assa ted refused whiche seyng englishman left assaut alone though englishemen gotten haue deliuered emperours vse treatie fbr claymed inheritaunce whiche caused englishemen leaue assaut xxii day september rered siege set theim selfes good order battail passed styl onwarde til came dorlans brent tounethe siege raised rased castle fro thence came good toune darrier brent spoyled thesame thus brent way passed euer wether worse men fell sicke wherfore burgonions spaniardes returned flaunders betwyn lorde admyrall saw tyme kepe felde turned bacward good ordre battail came calaice xvi day october lay calayce sent sir willya sandes sir morice barkeley sir willyam fitzwillyam iiim men whiche brent marguyson whiche newly edified fortefied thei brent also toune sainct iohnes rhode temple toune many village voiage wer take many prisoner xiiiim shepe xiiii c great cattal oxe kyen xiiic hogges vic mare horse great botie crew returned calayce safetie lord admyral sent sir ihon walop ixc men saint omers lye guysnes hammes marke oy left another nombre left capitaines ouerse al soudiers monethes wage payde returned england aduenturers taried stil gat many good prayes brought garrison lacked nothyng muche drad common people great prayes dayly learned feates warre whiche made bolder lorde admirall set thinges order side sea toke shippe nauy came riuer thames kyng well welcommed vnworthy season banished southwarke xii scottes whiche dwelt long season wer conueied fro parishe parishe constable like men hadabiured realme vttermost garment white crosse another behynd thus conucyed london northwarde till came scotlande lord admyral fraunce destroiyng countrey noble erle shrewsbury lorde george talbot steward kynges houshold prepared kynges commaundement great army toward scotland kyng enformed duke ihon albany whiche ye parliament scotland made lord gouernor realme yong kyng duryng nonage raised mightie puissaunt host scottes nomber lxxxm men well knowen whiche warlike appointed vc frenchemen handgunnes great artillerie comyng forward inuade west march england adioynyng towarde scotland wherefore kyng sent worde therle shrewsbury diligece like noble capitain set forward towarde yorke wrote therles northumberland westmerland darby lorde dacres lumley clyfford scrope latemer ogle darcy conyers gentleman ready wtin viii houres warnyng power iorniyng power whiche great came citie yorke abidyng ordinaunce lordes thynges necessary suche case meane season scottes wer come nigh citie carleyle lodged nigh water eske farre sulway sandes made abode therle westmerland ye lord dacres lorde roos lorde mountaigle knightes lancashere westmerland cumberland ready xxviiim men haue geuen battail scottes sawe could come englad battail lordes scotland drew counsail amongest one wyseman sayd lordes hether come comaundement lorde gouernor duke albanythe saiyngor scottishe erle ause warre know al remebre last warre ye realme scotland muche preiudiciall kyng iames iiii brought realme scotlad best euer warre brought ye worst almost may warre nobilitie slaine whiche scotlad sore lameteth wherfore myne aduice let v go ye duke know cause thei al came duke court therle arrayn aucient spake al sayd lord gouernor wil comaudement assebled almost ye nobilitie scotland wt power vpo pretence entre englad lordes would know ye cause quarel war begon might please goodnes shuld wel satisfie mides duke studied good sayd questio would haue demauded nowthe answere duke albany well know yt loue bere ye realme scotlad whiche haue name honor linage haue passed ye sea ye noble realme frauce realme scotlad one great cause bryng vnitie wer deuision reason deuision realme likely co quered destroyed also ye frenche kyng suite interessio wil ioyne wt ayde thenglishe nacion war determined ye parliament made capitain authorisyng inuade englad wt baner displaied questio demauded right quarel haue assent agrement iustifie answer demaude thynke haue iust cause inuade englad fyer sworde bloud getfull without beare dishonor reproche euer know realme scotlad inheritauce porcion worlde alotted nacion aucetors succede may better warre mainteine natural inheritauce daily seen great inuasions thenglishmen v make ye great maslaughters murder robbery spoiles dayly cause warre defed coutrey office king honor noble men seruice chiualry dutie natural ye cominaltie thinke iust quarel might coquere realme englad annex realme make monarchie sith ye beginning habitacion isle britaigne nacio haue enemy v haue euer hated yet haue euer withstode til ye last battail branxston chauce lost soueraigne lorde many noble men treason lord chaberlain yet thinke wan ye felde murther thinke noble men ought reuenge therfore would coragiously auauce self quarel get honor reueged sad called president cousail sayd lorde fortune war led ledeth striketh stroke worke miracle lordes englad redy encountre v surely fight power shal encreace daily hyest god geue v ye victory trust wil yet haue feld redy coming ye lord talbot erle shrewsbury muche drad frauce know wel great puissaut army doubt kyng englad wil send bryng another army chauce gette yrst battail get ii feld wil wtout losse many noble reason wherof realme shalbe weaker ouercome many shalbe slaine god knoweth fle worthy reputed traitor ye king wilfulnes folishe hardynes realme shalbe ieopardie vndone say kyng wtin age ought moue war sith war may bring distruccion ala sayd duke al ye puissauce scotlad returne shal encorage enemy realme scotlad shal euer rebuked defamed communicacion cousail written one sir lother priest scot secretary ye quene scottes whiche secretary host tyme scottishe priest dwelt lodon farther wrote scottishe king muche frenche kynges pleasure draw lordes englad wt power toward partie put kyng englad charge inuade fraunce comunicacion quene scottes whiche doubted sequele matter set worde duke required comon peace wt warden thenglishe march whiche sent herauld lord daker warden west march lord daker agreed vpo hostage wet duke albany cape quene scottes tyme come ther abstinence war taken season meane tyme duke quene promised send ambassa or kyng england colude peace thus scottes returned house truce take xi day septeber betwene englad scotlad xiiii yere kyng therle shrewsbury hearing truce lord dacres letter returned al copany sory gone forward scottes season comissioners sat loane x part euery man substaunce euery shyre people sworne auaunsed selfes thei worth pride remembryng comyng commissioner could set people vttermoste whiche afterwarde turned people muche heauines reason great summes money leuied moste part content loane sodainly payed vnder value v pound lent peny vii day october iiiim pound payde citie london whiche lent priuate cause loane x part yere baker london came tolde mayre corne would dere whervpon thaldermen made prouision xvc quarter come thei would bye none made comon people beleue musty would vtter owne lorde cardynal faine proue found baker false commaunded bye xvi day october kyng lay hitchyn hartford shyre see haukes lye chaunce kynges lodgyng fyer great feare opardie kyng came shortly london sent mayre dyuers comyners gaue thankes many kyndnes whiche thought well deserued warre thus cotinuyng betwene frenche kyng kyng england valiaunt capitane constable castle hammes vnder lorde mount oy called sir richard whethyll frechemen somuche hated thei deuised policie take christmasday night issued bullain cc horsmen ccc fotemen somuche trauailed together come place hoppes grew nere hammes castle called catte hall come thither kept theimselfes couert mornyng brake vp turne pyke sainct gertrudes sent hammes marshe ix x fotemen take cattell castle alarme rang embushment kept theim stil close constable perceiued alarme ment armed archer toke horse thre getlemen went fote frenchman purpose driued cattel though would driuen sir richard whethyll pursued driuers sawe droue cattel great felde bushment horsmen fotemen betwene sainct gertrudes sodaynly brake thre gentleman foote fought valiantly slaine knight alighted fought fote manfully borne doune pykes sore wounded compelled yelde himselfe prisoner tyme wer xxx archer come castle sawe great nomber frenchemen knewe capitaine betrayed returned christmas whiche kept eltham cardinal made dyuers reformacions kynges housholde master commaunded auoyde xxvii day february sir ihon walop knight sent lx auenturers guysnes seke auentures mette gentlemanne called thomas palmer whiche went castle betwene bullaine marguyson called hadyngham came lxxx frenchemen pykes crosbowes sette palmer whiche defended al copany sauyng xxiii person wer gone seke pray xxiii persones manfully succoured frenchemen slaine horse wounded company slewe iii frenchemen toke xxv liue whiche hurt wer thenglishmen frenchemen fought sore prisoner brought guisnes remnant thaduenturers returned muche cattel last day february lx englishman archer bilmen came place called saint anthony nere marguison entred ye house fell spoilyng frenchman wer therof aduertised spy came set englishman wer together noise thenglishmen approched xl persones came freshe embushment frenchman set thenglishmen slewe xi toke xx prisoner scapedthe duke albany returned time ye duke albany sailed scotlad frauce french king somuche fauored yt shewed kyng englad trueth ye frenche king rode parys rode one hand richard de la pole traytor englad parliament attainted duke asked freche kyng vm horseman xm almaines promised ye french kyng xvm men would one iii thynges either sley kyng englad battail el take prisoner el driue realme shamefull bragges noble man folishe ye haue hard truce taken ye duke albany lord da re season betwene englad scotlad ambassador sent ye king englad october accordyng accustomed doublenes sent iii personage small behauor semed ambassador fro scotlad wer smally regarded shortly departed comission know whether tyme abstinece warre ye king asseted notambassade fro otlad comission thei none thus thei ment craftely may perceiue suche troublous tyme may steale vnpunished whiche may tyme peace wherfore kyng sure sent hery v erle northuberland made warden whole march thakefully accepted thesame departed lord warden soeuer happened made suite kyng cousail neuer left till discharged thesame therle surray lord admyral englad made general warden lord marque dorset made warden thest march myddil lorde dacres west march whiche iii lordes sped thether vi day march defence border refusyng office th rle northuberland regarded owne tenautes disdained blod muche lameted foly men estemed without hart loue honor chiualrie kyng sent comissions gather ye loane called practisyng loanethe oane gathered sore emptied men purse moneth muster taken realme euery commauded ready within dayes warnyng kyng seruice harnes caused euery man honesty bye harnes weapon lorde marque dorset warden east march betwene england scotland accompanied sir willyam bulmer sir arthur darcy many noble men second day april beyng shere thursday entred tyuedale x myle galoway brent euery side townes village scottes great nomber shewed themselfes hylles approche night taried scottishe ground good friday returned botie whiche iiiim head nete england brent grymslay mowhouse dufforde mylles ackeforthe crowlyng nowes maner midder crowling marbottel low bog sefforth maner myddyl rigge primsed broket shawes haruel wide open haught tounes village yet lost many men xv day april beganne parliament blacke fryer lodon day masse holy ghost song lordes beyng present parliament robe masse finished kyng came parliament chamber satte doune seate royall throne fete right side satte cardynal yorke archebishop cantorbury raile behind stode doctor tustal bishop lodon made whole parliament eloquent oracion declaryng people office kyng fyrst must man iudgement accordyng saiyng prophet dauid deus iudicium tuum regi da c oracion doctor tustal bishop london also must man great learnyng according saiyng prophete erudimini qui iudicatis erram accordyng whiche saiynges sayd god sent v prince great iudgment great lernyng great experience whiche accordyng princely dutie forgat studye sette forwarde thynges whiche might profitable people realme least myght layde charge saiyng seneca e rex non habes tempus esse rex art thou kyng hast tyme kyng asmuch say art thou kyng doest nothyng profitable thy people art thou kyng seest people haue insufficient lawe art thou kyng wilt prouide remedy mischiefe thy people thynges haue moued kynges highnes call high court parliament remedy mischiefes whiche comon law recoueries forain voucher corrupt trial making orderyng new estatutes whiche may high auauncement common wealth wherfore wylleth common repare comon house elect theim speaker comon mouth certifie lorde chauncellour whiche thereof make report kynges moste noble grace whiche declare pleasure would haue presented persone cause parlyament sayd surely thinges worde spoken whole parlyament effect good act made except graunt great subsidie one accordyng instruccion common departed common house chose speaker sir thomas moore knight presented saterday parliament chamber accordyng old vsage disabled himselfe witthe oracion sir thomas learnyng discrecion speake kyng brought purpose one phormio desired hanniball come readyng whiche thereto assented hannyball come began reade de militari chiualrie hannyball perceiued called arrogant foole would presume teache whiche master chiualrie feates warre speaker sayd speake kyng learnyng orderyng comon welth suche like kyng beyng well learned suche prudence experience might say hannyball sayd phormio wherfore desired grace common might chose another speaker cardinall answered kyng knewe witte learnyng discrecion long experience seruice wherfore thought common chosen moste metest admit sir th ma moore gaue kyng moste humble thankes desired two peticions one de sent common king message mistake entent might kynges pleasure resort againe common knowlege true meanyng communicacion reasonyng man comon house speake largely dutie ought suche offence pardoned entred recorde whiche two peticions graunted thus began parlyament continued shal heare euil chauce happened great rebuke christen princesthe rhodes besieged entend briefly declare thesame miserable chaunce beginnyng yere sultan solyman pac called ye great turke whiche viii ye ligne ottoman fyrst toke vpo great capitain ruler sultan selyme father lost thempyres constantinoble trapesonde alexandry babylon many diuers kyngdomes realmes whiche sultan solymon yere gotten toune belgrado beyng key hungary sawe ye great prince christendome discordewhy ye turke cou ted rhodes thought honor profite make warre isle ye rodes take thesame whiche isle kept space ccxiiii yeres brother knightes order sainct iohnes ierusale dyuers thinges moued take enterprice one isle stode religious oftentymes toke destroyed shippes came golde rich egypt sirie estparties constantinoble theim isle sustayned hurt christendome sayd isle stode entry toward consta tinople another mocion father died charged assay take rhodes reuenged shame done graundfather mahomet great turke whiche dishonor beten fro siege rhodes greatest occasion exhortacion great counsailer religio called andrewe amyral borne portyngale whiche knewe whole estate case toune stode cause andrew amyral bare malice religion death frier fabrica de laretto lorde master religion elected honor one philip de uyllyers de lisle adam fraunce named lorde master wherfore sayd andrew prouoked turke come rhodes great turke seyng great occasio offered desiryng honor also knowing fortresse rhodes lacke municions surely brother sayd order wer suche wealth pride also liued suche vngracious godly fashion thei toke neither heede vow solempne fession also se thyng come great welth euil liuyng blinded thei thought ye turke durst one attept set garrison beyng eleuate point pride left toune vnfurnished wer sodainly surprised shal heare wherfore ye sayd turke couerty uided iiic saile al caried artilery thinges necessary ye whiche army wer lxm myners pyoners prepared onely intent digge myne rest army turke came lad place called fysco stadeth directly rhodes fyer many seen fro one side fro whiche place turke sent letter ye abouenamed philip de uylliers lord master sayd religion signifiyng would haue sayd isle great damage thei done peoplethe turke letter would yeld sayd isle promised fayth mahomet fyrst prophet haue damage hurt would depart shuld go safetie would tary serue haue good wage refused sware would subuert walles fortresse destroy al make slaues whiche letter dated constantinople fyrst day iune sayd lorde master compaignie greatly abashed letter yet like hardy gentleman intended defende made preparacions thei could short space wrote prince christen nede distres turke like wyly serpent knowyng great deuision amogest christen prince knew could sende succour rhodes sent ccm turkes whiche arriued isle rhodes mydsomerday whiche feastful day rhodians honor ihon baptist whiche sodain commyng sore abashed rhodyans beyng vic knightes vm mete beare armes yet noble corage trusting god thei determined defend enemy god xxviii day iuly turke arriued owne person whiche muche encoraged people turke arriued bent ordinaunce towarde toune great harme saw walles defence ordinaunce litle harme caused pyoners cast yerth one banke ouer another styll till came within bowshot wallthe moutes although many pyoners slain ordinaunce toune neuer ceased tyll made banke yearth higher x foote wall toune thei layde ordinaunce persone durst styrre walles bulworkes thus mountaines yerth toune enuironed behynd mountaines lay basheaux chiefe capitaines turke whiche euer redy take aduauntage dayly shot toune bet doune house slewe people streates vpon mount might easely see toune beside thisthe mynes turke caused many mynes mynes made diuers place within able make countermynes lacke people insomuche wemen set worke dygge cary reason wherof great part walles ouerthrowen thei within made countermine toune gotten within short space also turkes september gaue rhodyans foure great assautes like valiaunt warriersthe assautes christen men within valiantly defended euery assaut thei lost lest iim men fourth assaut lost xm turkes great turke seyng losse men assautes sent mo staffa basshaw whose counsail toke enterprice muche blamed made beleue might haue toune within xii dayes moneth ye wherfore furie would hue put death bass awe entreated coclusion ye turke determined clerely rayse siege depart done night sir andrew amyrall heard iewe beyng within rhodes written letter shot quarelles turkes army whiche letter turke knew necessitie toune feblenes people whiche caused chaunge purposetreason espyed treason espyed traytors taken put terrible execucion turke caused many mynes made although tooke none effecte yet ouerthrew bothe bulwarkes walles tower might entre toune sainct andrewes euen caused great assaut geuen whiche fierce yet christen men valiauntly defended thei slewe three thousand turkes mo kept enteryng daie citezens rhodes assaulte came lorde master praied hym haue compassion wiues child shewed hym toune wer taken assault like thei al cruelly murdered lorde master muche regarded honor comforted people faire wordes chaunce thesame tyme great turke sent letter rhodes willyng theim deliuer toune thei haue liues goodes thei would tary tary quiet thei would departe sauely depart letter knowen people cried lorde master take offre wherfore callyng counsaill together seyng possible kepe toune longe lacke artilary vitaile also nomber minished scace souldiers kepe walles wherefore greate aduice determined take turkes offer sent hym twoo religion farther conclusion assuraunce thesamethe yeldyng vp rhodes whiche well entertained writynges sealed al thynges thei desired whiche twoo knightes aymeche bassaw sware faith slain siege lxiiii thousande turkes xl thousande dedde mortalitie mo christmas daie greate turke hymself entered rhodes toke possession therof lorde master religion first daie ianuary tooke ship sailed candy conclusion came rome declared chaunce aduenture thus toune isle rhodes taken great turke whiche greate succor christian men resortyng este partes world whiche chaunce muche lamented thorowe christendom muche blame put prince thei sent succor aide isle yere bishoppe duresme died kyng gaue bishoprike cardinall resigned bishoprike bathe doctor ihon clerke master rolles made sir henry marney vicechamberleyn lorde priuie seale created hym lorde marney thende yere doctor blithe bishopp chester attached treason acquite hymself aboute season cardinall yorke beyng legate proued testamentes call hym executor administrator euery dioces within realme bishoppes ordinary proue great willes dioces except wer compounded litle disauauntage also power legantine gaue prouencions benefice belongyng spirituall persones whiche doyng onely hatred spiritualtie also ran daunger premunire whiche sore repented shall appere xxi yere kyng pthe xv yere parliament beyng begonthe xv yere haue hard rehersed cardinall accompaignied diuerse lordesthe cardinall oracio aswell spiritualtie temporaltie came xxix daie aprill common house cloquently declared common frenche kyng fraunces first called moste christened kyng often tymes broken promise kyng england welbeloued nephew charles emperor kyng honor could loger suffre first declared metyng thesaied twoo prince guysnes thesaid frenche kyng sworne kepe al article conteined tripartie league made betwene hym emperour kyng englande sithe whiche tyme hath made warre themperors dominios robert de la marche capitain also hath holden tribute paimentes whiche paie kyng englande redempcion tornay tirwin content hath alonely robbed spoyled kynges subiectes also hath sent ihon duke albany scotlande make warr inuade realme wherefore kyng necessitie driuen warre defence whiche wise could mainteined without great somes moneythe dema de thought lesse viiicm ed fifth parte euery mannes goodes landes saie iiiis euery pounde saied yere folowyng kyng emperor make suche warre fraunce hath seen declared matter length exhortyng common aide prince tyme necessitie departed co mon house morowe sir thomas beyng speker declared cardinalles oracion common enforced demaund strongly saiyng duetie men ought deny paie iiii pounde denied proued manifestly fifth parte substaunce realme viiic men paie kyng fifth parte goodes money plate proued muche money kynges handes realme fifth parte euery mannes goodes money plate although fiue men wer well monyed fiue thousand wer gentleman landes hath fifth parte value coyne merchaunt riche silke wolle tynne clothe suche merchaundise hath fifth part money husbande man riche corne cattell yet lacketh likewise viteilers artificer riche housholde stuffe money consequently moeny wer brought kynges handes men must barter clothe vitaile bread chefe one thyng another cosider valuacion kyng hath waie loane ii pound whiche iiiicm haue iiii whiche amounteth whole xiicm whiche first last vi whiche almoste third part euery mannes good whiche coyne cannot bee within realme profe whereof alleged englande xvm parish euery parishe geue c marke xvcm marke whiche xcm many parish englande another able spare c markes citees tounes written englande bee xl parishe church proued wer xiii parishe church vaie accompt whole cannot amounte aboue xcm kyng demau deth viiicm accordyng valuacion hath iiiicm pounde therefore thought impossible leuied coyne wer kynges handes men liue also kyng spirituall men last yere iiiis pounde long reasonyng wer certain appoynted declare impossibilite demaunde cardinal whiche accordyng commission declared hym substancially pouertie skarcenes realme whiche reason demonstracions litle regarded thesaid persones moste kely beseched grace moue kynges highnes bee content easier whiche currishly answered would rather haue tongue plucked hedde paire pinsons moue kyng take lesse whiche answere thei almoste dismaied came made reporte common house euery daie reasonyng nothyng concluded wherefore cardinall came common house desired reasoned withall answered fashion nether house heare reason emong themselfes shewed realme greate rich firste kynges customes greater thei tyme also alleged sumpteous buildynges plate riche apparell menne woman child seruauntes fatte feastes dilicate dish whiche thynges token greate aboundance whiche repetyng mennes substaunce though repined disdained man fare well well clothed hymself common greatly grudged departed house proued honest apparell commodity realme aboundance plate honest viandes profitable realme prodigall long debatyng common concluded graunte ii pound euery mannes landes goodes worth xx pounde might dispende xx pounde taken kyng vpwarde euery xx twoo xl xx pounde euery xxsxiid vnder xl euery hed xvi yeres vpward iiiid bee paied two yeres graunt reported cardinall whiche therwith sore discontent saied lordes graunted iii pound whiche proued vntrue dede thei graunted nothyng harkened vpon common knight called sir ihon huse lincolneshire saied please cardinal somewhat let v gentleman fiftie pound lande vpwardes geue kyng landes xiid pounde paied thre yere whiche mocion diuerse gentleman wer sore discontent question asked ten xii gentleman saied yea naie asked common saied nothyng thei would condempne let getlemen charge themselfes x xii persones gentleman wer burdened xiid whiche graunt sir ihon huse muche euill ter graunte made xxi daie maie whitsontide parliament proroged tenth daie iune duryng whiche prorogacion common people saied burgess sir heare saie graunt iiiis pound aduise doo maie go home many euill woordes threatenynges season cardinall power legatine dissolued conuocacion paules called archebishop cantorbury called hym clergie conuocacio westminster neuer seen englande wherof master skelto mery poet wrote gentle paule laie doune thy sweard peter westminster hath shauen thy beard parliament begonne landed menne fiftie pounde vpward seyng thei charged xiid euery pounde landes moued suche worth fiftie poude goodes vpward paie also xiid pounde iiii yere whiche mocion muche reasonyng last xxvii daie iune question asked doubtfull whether yea nay moste house diuided al common seuered theimselfes knightes sheres one yea part remained onely knightes shire comons stifly affirmed mocioners demaunde wer enemy realme last speaker called theim together long perswadyng priuie laboryng frendes agreed xiid pounde paied fourth yere fiftie pounde goodes parliamet xxxi daie iuly adiorned westminster continued till xiii daie august daie ix clocke night dissolued duryng tyme parliament xxvii daie aprill sir arthur plantagenet bastarde sonne kyng edward fourth bridewell created viscount lisle right wife whiche wife edmond dudley behedded season true worde brought christmas daie laste past strong toune rhodes deliuered great turke called sultan soliman whole islande greate hurt christian nacions cause losse uill liuyng brother knightes negligece prouision defence enuie treason emongest themselfes written reported yere cristierne kyng denmarke wife whiche sister emperor charles thre child xviii shippes arriued flaunders clene banished realmes dominion vncle frederick duke ho st awne subiectes crueltie written whiche cristierne wife well entertained duches sauoy pencion assigned hym liue brabant hollande duryng tyme soiornyng made muche suite come englande see speake kyng whiche request hym graunted quene foure gentlewomenthe kyng denmarkes commyng england trayne fourtie persones poore euil appareled landed douer xv daie iune nobely receiued erle deuonshire bishoppes excester rochester diuerse knightes esquiers brought grenewiche kyng quene standyng vnder clothes estate receiued greate hall grenewiche kyng cristerne quene isabell wife dined kyng quene bothe set vnder clothe estate sumpteously serued dilicate viandes soiorned season euery daie feasted court conueighed londo lodged bathe place hearyng watche london sainct peter euen desired se accompainied duke suffolk erles oxford e ex kent diuerse lordes lady brought kynges hed chepe citee london made hym wife costly banket seen watche saied would god many archer pike halberders sawe night trust would ponishe suche haue wrogfully dispossessed realme countrey solaced hymself london resorted kyng many great giftes likewise wife quene aunte tooke leaue conueighed douer englande xii day tooke shippyng sailed flaunders preisyng muche kyng englande court duryng season session parliament warre fierce bothe betwene england fraunce england scotlande muche eche parte asmuche theim laie hurte border scotlande laie valiaunt erle surrey greate admirall englande marque dorset three brother sir willyam co ton sir willyam kyngston diuerse knightes esquiers sent theim kyng whiche daily inuaded realme scotlande threwe doune castle orberne castle west nesgate castle b akkater tower mackewalles tower est nesgate many brent nomber xxxvii village haried countrey este march west neuer skirmishe thei oftetymes shewed themselfes plumpes waityng auantage iorney fewe englishemen lost wherfore lordes perceiuyng scottes entended make armie englande fortified frontier euery parte men thynges necessary defence stealyng small rodes al whiche thynges set perfectnes thei returned toward kyng came ende parliament seasona ship sonken stone alice hauen frenchemen hauyng greate desire haue kynges toune calice deuised first destroy hauen thei supposed calice might haue lightly gotten faulte reskewe whereupon thei laded old ship iiiic tonne great cane stone port depe whiche ship mast came forsaile though mast cut cast ouer bord sea tempest came calice euery man sawe thought wether driuen lost mast tepest aboute x clocke night xxiiii daie maie thesaid shippe came calice haue though would entre harborow enteryng missed chanell turned sandes towarde rise banke frechemen supposyng thei chanell launched boate sodainly set shippe fire lepte boate skaped shore thei calice sawe fire thei sore troubled last water gone thei perceiued ship consumed goodly cane stone liyng whole wherfore lorde barnes deputie calice lorde barkley leuetenaunt castle lorde sandes thresorer calice commaunded laborer might gotten breake remnaunt ship cary awaie stone thesaied stone brought calice wherupon thesaied capitaines sent letter capitain bull ine calice pursiuant armes desiryng hym geue thankes monsire lodowyke capitain depe sendyng faire ship goodly stone calice whiche stone thesaied lordes sent worde thei receiued toune calice muche profite fortificacion thesaied toune desiryng hym sende thei would receiue thesame price whiche letter capitain bulleine answered haue nothyng lost thei haue nothyng gotten tell hym hath lost whiche answere pursiuant departed wherupon thenglishemen beyng greued issued calice c light menne warre called auenturers came nere bulleine obteined greate botie wherof garrison bullein beyng aduertised issued folowed englishman sharpely encountered englishemen shot frenche men whiche fiue hundred lighted fought sore appered euidently wer dedde ground xlvi frenchemen xxii englishemen frenchemen toke xx englishemen prisoner residue englishemen kept gether came calice capitain enterprise lathebery lorde sandes thresorer calice entendyng reuenged frenchemen called counsaill calice hym declared frenchemen especiall monsire de bee capitain bullein daily imagened destroye englishe pale thei englishe part nothyng doen yet wherfore aduised act hymself would present formoste man leder capitain whereupon concluded commaunded euery manne readines foundyng trompet vpon whiche warnyng thesaied lorde sandes ix daie iuly early mornyng sent furth twoo hundred light horse englishe pale stoppe people goyng one towarde least enterprise bee askried people wer kept daie euenyng aboute seuen clocke capitain called guiot thomas palmer ripton raufe broke set forward light ordinaunce vitaile embattailed themselfes good arraie marched towarde sandifelde xi clocke refreshed themselfes good ordre thei came water sclaukes farre bullein whiche tenth daie iuly thei askried alarme rong countrey capitain bullein sent furth lxx menne armes foure hundred footemen morice pike crosebowes hande gunnes wherefore capitain guyot sent bend horseman aide thenglishe footemen whiche farre behynde capitain ripton appoynted fight frenchemen sir thomas palmer raufe broke remnaut horseman stode stale capitain ripton profered forwarde speres calice frenchman came valiauntly began sore skirmishe frechemen bothe horseman footemen defended passage water sclaukes whiche gut made force lande water long fight englishemen gat ouer water pure force toke frenchemens standerd gentleman whiche man armes bullein called charles maruiel euer sir thomas palmer raufe broke stode aided necessitie moste thus skirmishe continued foure clocke mornyng till ix clocke none euer frenchemen encreased last thei retreited themselfes toward bullein whiche returne diuerse wer slain skirmishe ended came lorde sandes fotemen spere thigh helme hed greatly encoraged compaignie duryng whiche conflict diuerse picardy gathered together taken church odirsaell whiche well fortefied strong place whereof lorde sandes beyng aduertised marched thether ward waie burned might brent sent officer armes kept churche odirsaell yeld churche hym whiche hym answered thei would stande defence commaunded assault whiche quickly doen frenchemen defended selfes hand gonne crosebowes pike englishme could entre lorde sandes commaunded curtal whiche hym shotte churche perced thei within sawe defence could hold yelded theselfes goodes churche came lxxii frenchemen whiche taken prisoner goodes whiche thei caried churche taken botie thus one cl cke thesaid tenth daie iuly churche odirsaell taken also frenchemen manned steple odyngham whiche strong tower muche like castle lorde sandes sent officer armes commaunde yelde fortresse thei answered thei wer frenchemen hym thei would none yeld came thether thei would withstand wherupon armie marched thether ward aboute foure clocke none assaulted steple frenchman selfes valiauntly defended sodainly chauce vnknowen eple sire frenchemen fled doune quire englishemen lightly entered body churche assaulted frech menne whiche cried mercie yelded theimselfes twelue clocke midnight assaulte ended yelded churche fortie prisoner whiche tyme lorde sandes encamped hymself made good watche feare enemy mornyng called hym priestes whiche wer bothe church stode defence said thei ought bee men warre notwithstandyng theim prisoner yet god sake released admonishyng euer thei wer taken defence thei hanged nexte galowes whiche monicion doen deliuered frely viii clocke mornyng marched forward good ordre battaill came castle hardyngham whiche brent spoyled xi daie iuly copaignie whiche passed xiic men whiche lost onely xii returned calice greate store bestiall pillage season frenche kyng sent armie xviiim men towardes party flaunders whiche secretly enterprised take place called newdike whiche strong passage betwene fraunce flaunders kept flemynges whereof thei beyng aduertised eised greate power xiiim came passage slewe frenchemen vic frenchemen reculed seuered theimselfes went mount orry sainct omers brent subbarbes thei within mount orry defended themselfes hurte capitain bulleine called monsire de bee slewe horse wherfore frenchemen wente thence brent village called arkus thus rountiers full frenchemen somuche monethe august thei bette toune guisnes scourer scoute watche whereof began alarme frenchman whiche many nobre lighted though thei would geue assaut maintenant fiersly proffered toward diches ordinaunce beganne shote nede bid theim go englishemen coragiously folowed chace sodainly came embushement frenchemen toke twoo englishemen thus al armie fraunce remoued gyngate beside tyrwyn frenche kyng seyng kyng england daily encoraged make war hym dominion scottes nothyng pleasure lacke duke ihon albany scottes called gouernor therfore caused greate preparacio made party men shippes harnes artilery sendyng duke ihon albany scotlande whiche duke greate presumpcion promised frenche kyng driue kyng englande realme whiche promise kept kyng englande hearyng duke albany passe englande make warre realme thought haue met sea therfore prepared flete tal strog shippes mete encounter thesaied duke power made admirall iorney sir willyam fitz willyam hym sir fraunces brian sir antony pounez seriant rot ihon hopton willyam goustone anthony kniuet thomas west whiche great diligence laie waite mete thesaid duke albany thei sailed frenche coste thei determined lande doo harme tray port thei houered thei espied capitain toune fired beakes sent aide al res strengthed manned toune warlike notwithstandyng sir william fitz william capitaines left enterprice xxiii daie august beyng sondaie seuen clocke mornyng thei toke lande hauen treyport frenchemen shot ordinaunce quarelles stone english men botes shot likewise encoraged capitaines assauted frenchemen bulwerkes frenchemen valiantly defended thenglishe capitaines men without fere theim assailed yet nomber nothyng egall englishemen viic men frenchman vim well fightyng frech men bulwerkes wer taken ordinaunce sezed wer fled toune treiport euer thenglishmen folowed shotyng arowes sleyng whiche skirmishe seriant rotte bowe hande striken gonne capitaines ried sainct george gate treyport euery manne unced forward thei goyng cristopher morres master gon er espied pece maste whiche caused bee taken vp anthony k euet fraunces neudigate men ranne thesaid maste gate gate strong could broken also euery loupe late pece ordinaunce whiche continually shot englishemen whiche caused theim leaue gate thei tte fire subbarbes whiche faire str te brent subbarbes brent englishemen wet hauen would haue shippes water lacked wherefore thei set fire theim brent seuen faire shippes bestoe skirmishyng gate much murder bothe side frenchemen fityng bulwerkes toune lost lxxx per one many wer hurte arrowes men countrey came thether still somuche nomber became great whiche sir willyam fitz willyam pe ceiuyng caused trompet blowe retrete suche prisoner pillage ordinaunce thei gotten thei returned boates capitaines sent souldiers frenchemen perceiuyng englishemen returned issued founde lande fraunces neudigate thomas wagham seriant rotte capitaines nomber twelue ran hastely toward theim greate nomber whiche perceiuyng bended themselfes fell liues dere sir willyam fitz willya perceiuyng greate ieoperdy thei wer turned boate towarde lande discharged ordinaunce muche pain saued gentleman toke boates notwithstandyng great nomber frenchemen whiche wer water let hym thus whole armie returned shippes thei v houres land brought xxvii pe e faire ordinaunce wer bulwarkes lost men fully xx persones euery capitain toke awne ship coasted sea euer lokyng duke albany thei hard tidynges hym parliamet haue hard cocludedi ney su l e kyng necessitie muste nedes make strong warre realme fraunce wherefore noble charles duke suffolk appoynted capitain generall passe armie royall fraunce thende august whiche diligence prepared thynges necessary suche royall enterprice furniture armie appoynted geue attendaunce hym lorde montacute sir arthur po e brother lorde herbert sonne erle worcester lorde ferreis lorde marney lorde sandes lorde barkeley lorde powes baron curson knightes sir richarde wyngfelde chaunceller duchie lancaster sir ihon ueer sir edward neuell sir willyam kyngston sir richard welson sir andrew wynsore sir robert wyngfeld sir anthony wyngfeld sir edward guyldford sir edward gryuell sir edward chamberlein sir thomas luce sir euerard dighby sir adrian foscew sir willyam skeuyngto master ordinance sir thomas cheiney sir richard cornwall sir william cortney sir willyam sidney sir henry owen lordes knightes many knightes coragious e quiers actiue gentleman came accordyng kynges commaun demet last people retinue douer thei mustered seuerall tymes thei passed sea nombre take saie dimy lance vic archer horsebacke twoo c archer foote three bill men fiue pioners laborer iimvic viewe taken side sea adioyned nomber xviic whiche might spared fortress krewes ham guysnes calice al army wer xiiim c well harnesed appareled warre pioners onely excepte duke hymself arriued calice xxiiii august retinue counsaill abidyng armie caused thynges vitaill prepared thesame muche commonyng englande whether army go man except fewe knew secretnes said bull n paris euery man iudged accordyng awne opinion common vse season mortalitie greate calice duke suffolk caused armie lodged tentes pauilions vpo faire grene beside sainct peter churche healthe accompaignied diuerse noble men viii daie september od grau lyng thether came hym cristerne kyng denmark lorde il ten capitain generall flaunders whiche amiably enterteigned thesaied duke thei secretly commoned diuerse matter concernyng diuerse army inuade fraunce sondry place duke toke leaue kyng came calice armie laie without calice thei daily came toune happened symple felowe cut purseariot alice made bye apple whiche incotinent taken brought maiors hous ward whiche thyng diuerse welshemen perceiuyng knowyng apperteigned iustice ranne greate compaignies maiors house would haue broken house officer toune entreated welshemen approched nombre welshemen greate watche calice strake alarme lorde deputie lorde sandes laye bryng theim conformitie thei rude thei nothyng regardedthe sacrament priestes brought furthe blessed sacrament whiche also regarded wherfore lorde ferreis straightly commauded appese rage hym thei came thether whiche greate pain entreatie theim appesed welshemen commaunded felde depart toune wer al capitaines diuerse hed rioter wer appreh ded sore punished exaple al thynges necessary wer prepared duke issued calice toke feld ordeined marshal capitain vantgard lord sandes capitain right wyng sir willia kyngston capitain lefte wyng sir eueraid dighby sir edward guyldford marshal calice capitain al horsme sir richard wingfeld capitain ye rereward duke al army capitain ye middle ward standerdes baners penons displaied marched forward good ordre battail came place called kalkewell lodged xix day september whiche place diuerse souldiers carter vp lande men whiche wer vnmete warre euery thyng theim pain fell sicke disseased wherfore duke gaue leaue pasport returne xxii daie september tooke vp campe came hamswell pitched felde thus liyng abode armie flaunders promised ioyne hym whiche wer come omers entendyng lye still idlely nt clare seux kyng armes somon castle called bell castle yelde hym el would destroy fire sword officer armes message accordyngly capitain answered would deliuer castle duke duke came thether nothyng get saied sure suche rescue duke auantage whiche answer returned toward duke waie met lorde sandes lord ferreis array battail vc horsmen im footemen rehersed answer said lordes must copel otherwise wil master thordinance comauded prepare batrie doen thether came vc horseman burgonios vc fotemen thordinance great difficultie brought nere castle al though wer night gonnescesed bet place sore thei within defended best thei might day bega spryng lordes caused blow thassault hearyng capitain castle said copanions thei wer able abide thassault succor failed wherefore necessitie thei muste deliuer castle whereto thei agreed yelded castle life onely saued mercie duke whiche pardoned theim toke prisoner deliuered castle sir willyam skeuyngto whiche shortly rased doune ground xxvii daie septeber mondaie beyng xxviii daie septeber proclamacion made tharmy fraunces duke burbon constable fraunce become frend kyng englande enemy frech kyng sworne kyng england wage kyng england xm almaines inuade frauce let french kynges purpose intent hym sent money litle common people said neuer frenchman true englande true long liued make proclamacion apparant must vnderstande season frenche king ruled mother cou tesse angulesme admyrall fraunce called lorde bonyu whiche reported sayd loued sayd lady paramor whiche court fraunce spake muche two persones ruled kyng thei sayd done iudgement setence passed parliament parys without assent nothing done without whiche thing noble frauce sore disdained especially lorde fraunces duke burbon constable fraunce whiche hauing suite therledome montpelyer could heard speake counsail neither l st beyng sore displeased vnkynd vniust handlyng came french kyng besechyng iustice fauor whiche flateryng sayd al power would gladly accomplish answer none encreace grudge ye frenche kinges mother made title whole duchy burbon auerne admyral entised kyng sayd opely duke burbon shortly poore meanest gentleman fraunce whiche wordes reported caused hate mortally frenche kyng mother displeasure departed owne countrey kyng england beyng eof aduertised sent duke burbon knight chamber called sir ihon russell man well languaged whiche wisely couertly behaued came duke molyns knew al entent would forsake kyng serue king englad emperor frenche kyng therevpon tooke othe frenche kyng mistrusting allegeance duke burbon sent duke prepare go italye prepared great army passe mountaines duke myllaine army vim men armes xxvm fotemen duke hearyng hereof fained himselfe sicke frenche kyng passyng molyns visited coforted duke promised come shortly lyon power caused horselitter caried emptie iii dayes amongest certain souldiers though himselfe fled secretly countye burgoyne pertainyng emperor retained xm almaines inuade fraunce assone frenche kyng passed mountaines frenche kyng heard sent admyrall italy army sent great master seaze al duke lades doynges sir ihon russell brought true worde present duke also sawe frenche armye returned vnespied wherfore deserued king cousail great thankes wherevpon kyng caused proclamacion made army might knowe power fraunce trouble warres italy duke burbons power might lust vnfought withal whiche proued whiche tidynges muche encoraged thenglishe souldiers proclacion tidynges brought army trueth one hierome uicount great familiar frende wt duke myllayne entised frenche kyng almost slaine frauces duke myllaine dagger behynd backe whiche doyng frenche kyng aboue persones fained himselfe displeased morowe beyng xxix day september duke whole army remoued arde lodged last day september remoued village called alrke thence fyrst day october came village betwene tyrwyn saint omers called esqwerdes cordes duke lay encaped himselfe abidyng enemy nowe must returne tell done betwene england scotland season whyle duke suffolke thus inuadyng realme frauce scottes thinkyng war turned fraunce nothyng attempted began robbe spoile march england whereof kyng hearyng sent againe thither valiant erle surray treasorer admyrall england whiche hast sped west march sent army vim men banner displayed entred dry march betyng doune castle fortress euery side alth ugh scottes men high corage yet seyng wise conduict noble erle surray chosen company durst one enco ter hi passed quietly dale tyll came strong toune iedworthe whiche lay great garrison scottishmen whiche al hurt could englishman hardely great nomber skyrmished thenglishmen partes diuers wer slaine end abbay castle toune iedworth brent rased sonder open sight scottes would returne encamped scottishe ground abidyng battail lay ther xxii day september xxv day ryng whiche tyme tyme sent lorde daker gyldersland strong hold doncar called fernhurst whiche castle stode euil come wayes wer hylly stony full marishes scottes bent ordinaunce way yet englishman fiersly set gat castle notwithstandyng scottes fought valiauntly many theim taken dan car lorde lorde gradon diuers whiche taken lorde daker returned prisoner ordained kepe watche night whiche set watch wardes surely night sodainly ccc good geldynges brake pasture whiche custodie sayd lord dacres campe beastes wodde sauage ranne enraged notwithstandyng men asmuche might stoppe yet ranne though array battail whereof noyse night great armye souned alar horse styll array ranne cape erle lay bare doune many persones waye sodainly ranne away whether vnknowen lorde dacres men sayd deuil sene amongest third day erle returned england erle surray departed border august haue heard heretofore scottes wrote duke albany affaire whiche commyng scotland heard nauy england lay wayte fight durst auenture sate styll heard capitaines name border england toward scotland deuised policie shippes remoued hauen brest sayd himselfe caused noysed would saile scotlad yere rane voice al coastes normandy britaigne passed tyll ende septembre kyng england enformed suche knew none duke albany broken iorney would passe yere scotland wherfore kyng england middest september caused shippes layde vp hauens tyl next spryng duke albany beyng therof aduertised boldly tooke shippes shipped people lxxii saile sight passed west partes england coasted wale great labor landed kyrcowbre west parte scotland people xxi day septeber whiche nomber iiim traytor richard delapole knowen scotland lorde gouernor landed muche gladnes amongest people duke highly receiued people wel cherished beganne parlyament kyng england hearyng duke albany landed scotlande vnfought withall litle displeased suspected suche enformed duke would passe yere deceiued remedye wherfore made prouisions put thynges readynes would attempt thing realme duke albany gouernor scotland beyng parliament realme great eloquence declared loue fauor frauces frenche kyng bare realme scotland insomuch beyng aduertised great murder slaughter burnynges done englishemen thought suffered lesse hurt damage accomptyng self one membres likewise membres realme reuenging thesame partener member credite shewed frenche kynges fauorable letter affirmyng laracion letter wer red start vp baron scotland called lorde forbos whiche sayd realme scotland loue fraunce suffereth great paine daily doeth appere noble slain taken cominaltie murdered lades ouerrune house fortress brent rased profites owne lades lese mischief nede haue loue frauce helpeth fraunce farre frend sone fet mightie nieghbor may cruel enemy affirme would kepe amitie realme england daungers god forbyd sayd duke albany scotland euer seke new frende pro er amitie destroyer coutrey nacion lordes scotlad sufficient selfe maintain lades libertie fredome comon enemy thenglishemen therfore let v together reuenge hurtes done v countrey myne honor shal go therfore haue brought bothe treasure men artillerie realme thinke shall christendome shall speake noble coquest duke request ye court parliament agreed wer comissions sent scotland cryes made men shuld assemble doglas dale vitaile xxviii dayes scotes al hast prepared lordes wer come place appointed xviii day october vitaile gunnes artillerie came easy iorneys riuer twede ground beside hume castle fro thence came cawdestrene lodged doyng kyng england knewe well wherfore diligece caused assembled people north part beyond trent whero iiim beryng cote armes wt power strength whiche al wer comaunded resort erle surray spede noble marque dorset thomas appointed kepe berwicke vim men lest ye scottes therto would lay siege duke albany whiche lay frontier hearyng erle surreyes preparyng sent herauld promisyng honor geue battail tooke battail would put curteous raunsome body safe erle answered muche thanked duke offer would abide battail msyng would geue battail durst abide ye sayd duke taken prisoner menne would strike head send kyng england master bad trust none whiche answere duke albany scottes toke great dispite erle surray beyng alnwyke came therles northumberland westmerland lorde clyfford lorde dacres lorde lumley lorde ogle lorde darcy many noble knightes squiers yomen nomber xlm kynges court sent batail sir nicholas carew master horse sir fraunces bryan sir edwarde baynton diuers armye laye border abidyng scottes comyng englande whiche lay styll scotland nothyng till last day october beyng saterday night scottes sent ouer water england iii iiiim men lay siege lytle castle called ye castle warke whiche stadeth nere border great ordinauce scotland sore bet castle dan car frenchemen whiche came fraunce duke albany gaue castle strong assaut within castle sir willia lyle c persones scottes many nomber got vttermoste warde called barnkyns beastes barnes whiche seyng capitaine sent hast erle surrey aduertisyng distres whiche hast assembled capitaines reskue castle therby hopyng duke ihon albany would enter england frenchman scottes lay styll castle cotinually shotyng ordinaunce sonday monday fyrst second day nouember scottes thinkyng place assautable coragiously set castle strength entred second warde sir willya lyle perceiuyng ye scottes gotten false brayes nothing remained inner warde dogeon sayd company sir honor mahod let v issue fight proude scottes stately frenchman shall honor dye fight murthered gunnes whiche company left agreed c men lost almost xl assautes issued boldly shot coragiously men shot vauntage shotyng fightyng draue enemy clene place slew chiefly frenchman ccc whiche lay dead sight erle came thither beside suche dyed woundes drouned scottes remoued ordinaunce great hast ouer water tyme erle surrey come wt vm men horsbacke great army folowed sory enemy gone muche praised sir willyam lyle valiauntnes duke albany lordes scotland knew erle surrey approched puissant army thought conuenient ieoparde nobilitie scotlande one felde consideryng chaunce x yeres therfore cocluded returne sayd secod day nouember night duke armye retreated suertie honor horseman scotland kept fordes passe greue fotemen returned baggage wer gone cast selfes plumpe returned day appeared englishman might plainly see scottes fled fiftie mennes thickenes many lusty englishman would faine haue folowed horsbacke would therle surray heart comission defend realme inuade scotland whiche thing sore displeased thus brake vp great army scotland great rebuke duke albany noble scotland whiche ii yere together made bragges assembles durst abide battaile scottes made much bragges beaten doune walles warke castle spake nothyng men left cowardly returned would abide returne quene margaret scotlad mother yong kyng sent brother kyng england abstinence warre taken betwene realme england scotland thentent way might taken amitie might betwene whiche request graunted great armye england dissolued erle surrey returned coast season emperor charles sent kyng englad ii mule trapped crimosyn veluet curiously enbrodereda pre ent sent b empe kyng al bukcles stiroppes suche garnishynges siluer gilt meruailous conyng worke set also xl g nettes ful goodly behold trapped russet veluet richely wrought iiii speres ii iauelynes straunge tymber worke richely garnished v brace greyhou de quene sent two mule riche trapper high chayers spanishe fashion presetes wet thankefully receiued kyng quene let v returne duke suffolke whiche lay cordes esqwerdes xx day september thither came army flaunders wherof capitaine lorde il teyne spaniardes almaines cleues iiim fotemen vc horseman well apparelled warres pointes duke suffolke beyng thus furnished passed forward wete wether makyng bridge wayes euer lokyng battel xvii day october sent lorde sandes marshall armye iiim men good toune called anker whiche accompanied diuers knightes gentleman good order battail marched towarde toune frenchman perceiuyng englishman comyng toward toune fled fast might left toune desolate entred englishman great botie toke ca le called bone gard therin put garrison englishemen whereof capitaine lorde leonard gray brother marque dorset conduict vitailers armye whiche nowe farre succour englishe part toune abbay monkes whiche receiued humbly lordes noble england whiche hurt dammage returned duke xix day duke armye passed village called qwede long cousailyng determined whole army passe rong toune wel fortefied called bray whiche toune well ordinaunced xvic men warre capitaine therof called adrian succour toune come mounsire po tdormy vicount larnerdam vicount turraine mousire applyngcort mounsire dapney vc horsmen toune beside inhabitauntes wer iim good men toune standeth riuer xxiiii englishe myle arras xiiii myles aboue amyas toune well diched strengthned euery side xx day moneth duke comaunded al great ordinauce brought iiii clocke mornyng toune bray charge therof manfully acquited notwithstadyng ye damage enemy could brought ordinaunce toune houre appointed eche part shot dredfully englishe guners shot wel walles toune beaten doune rased ordinaunce insomuche ix clocke toune made assautable duke caused blow thassaut englishman flemynges burgonions lept furth quickely notwithstandyng diches wer depe yet coragiously entered good comfort lorde sade noble men gat di he frenchman perceiuyng toune gotten hastely made traynes gunpouder strete strete house house saiyng englishman entry ye toune would fal pillage sodainly sodain fyer destroy prouision frechmen tyme englishman wer enteryng walles frenchman stode yet defence pike cro owes handgunnes halberdes weke partes entred thenglishmen sodainly frenchman fledde englishemen folowed killed slew euery part nowe must vnderstand toune bray standeth riuer whiche deuided diuers braunches betwene euery brauche marishe ground farside yetoune fortefied bulwarke ful ordinaunce kepe passage ouer ye water frenchman losed plankes bridge nere myle aboue bray horsmen frauce passed myle frechfotemen great ayd thei stode kept passage til ye foteme wer come ouer bridge plucked away plackes bridge noma shuld folow euer thenglishmen folowed cast plakes bridge passed ouer bridge passyng diuers wer drouned wt great trauail men passed horsmen fotemen fiersly assauted bulwarke toke ordinaunce taken capitaine adrian capitaine ulterlew englishe horsmen folowed frenchman diuers wer slaine take sir robert iernyngham brake spere lorde pountdormy lorde leonard gray valiautly day must remember frenchman issued toune forgatte lay matche traine gunnepouder whiche made whiche short space set toune al fyer thenglishmen returned al fyer ha litle profite wyne whiche great pleasure toune bray taken destroyed xx day october duke consideryng litle succour souldiers toune bray sayd toune consumed fyer therfore comaunded bridge wel repayred passe ouer great riuer realme frauce passage sure lord sandes xxi day october mornyng prest passe ouer vaward gentleman sayd would passe farther forward diuers souldiers thesame opinion asked feare answered past ouer riuer past succour vitail none could brought reason noyse souldiers stayed whiche ye lord sade perceiuyng sayd welshman whiche wer euil willyng passe ye riuer sir sayd behold toke banner sainct george sayd many loue kyng england true croune folow sir wylliam kyngston set forward passed water whiche tunneth thre streames persones coragiously folowed ordinaunce vitailes foreward folowed duke al battail tyme army sore minished reason many wer diseased host departed host strength settyng calayce thenglishemen passed folowed burgonions good order night army came toune called kappe encamped theimselfes inhabitauntes fled bothe toune castle thenglishemen found c tonne wyne good pillage garrison lay anker knowyng duke passed riuer rased toune castle came ioyned duke army kappe duke caused proclamacions made armye people fraunce would vitaile armye englande well entreated haue vitailes well payed safe goyng comyng whiche proclamacion host well vitailed people countrey resorted thynges necessarie duke thus liyng cap sent toune roy yeld kyng england toune perceiuyng power able withstand great armye duke assented deliuer toune duke strong toune well walled dyched ordinaunced manned duke sent thither sir richard cornwall iiiic men receiue toune whiche went thither good array toune deliuered sette banner sainct george highest part toune full well garrison kept toune roy til duke came thither whole armye duke armye xxv day sayd moneth remoued village called lyhome great pillage toune muche haunted marchauntes kept great markettes next day remoued dauenker xxvii day remoued came strong toune mountdedier defece warre lacked neither diches walles bulwarkes horsmen englishe army rode toune vew capitaines caused diuers piece losed whiche shewed well strength duke sent officer armes somon capitain deliuer ye toune officer departed trumpet whiche blew gate person would answere would haue sommons made officer armes returned made report duke skyrers made profer afore toune whiche issued great compaignie horseman skyrmished duke horseman fought valiantly last xl horseman taken whiche lorde roche baron capitaine toune sore displeased yet thought able maintaine toune whole armye duke suffolke pytched felde layd siege rounde toune mountdedier kept good watche warde euery side whiche thyng lorde roche baron
