perceiuyng comforted menne warre bad afrayd good corage sayd duke get othyng duke thus planted siege considered farre reskew liyng still nothyng oyng profitable knewe also report prisoner toune moundedier two thousand footemen one thousand horseman wherefore sent lordes capitaines muche praised hardynes sayd noble corrage sawe theim muche auaunce sette forwarde thynges praise wherof therfore nowe encoraged againe continue still valiaunt doyng goddes grace entended bend ordinaunce next mornyng toune whiche lordes agreed praised muche duke corage forwardnes sir willyam skeuyngton knight maister ordinaunce comaunded prepare battery whiche diligece made trench prepared thinges mete purpose season sir ihon walop knight almost proper men hardy hauyng litle wage none whiche liued alonely auenture wherfore called aduenturers called kreekars men wer light hardy politike manhod hardines robbed many tounes taken many prisoner great boties daily brought army horse mare vitaile cloth corne necessary whiche might misled company frenchemen especially village passegers wer sore afrayde neuer idle doyng thyng one part lorde pountdormy pountreny hearyng mountdedyer besieged called diuers great lordes capitaines nomber vc menne armes dimy launce great nomber fotemen entendyng bryng gunnepouder necessary toune moutdedier wer thither comyng night thomas palmer capitain skout watche thenglishe army askried skyrmished although wer nomber manfully fought frenchemen compelled flee backe englishman olowed slewe diuers two speres broken brother lorde pountdorny swyftnes horse saued himselfe chase c prisoner taken whiche muche reioysed englishman master ordinaunce thinges ready houre iiii clocke mornyng discharged ordinauce continually suche fashion viii clocke xxviii day october walles made lowe toune assautable whiche great ordinaunce shot still toune tyll walles toune beaten doune capitaine toune perceiuyng called al capitaines declaryng toune iiii houres made assautable surely englishman would assaute toune whiche cofusion wherfore asked aduise best done al thei answered went tower caused trompet blowe set furth banner truce duke comaunded ordinaunce cease sir willya skeuyngton came walles demaunded would lord roche baron sayd pleased duke loue kyng england honor graut thother gentleman wer licence depart life bagge baggage thei would deliuer toune mountdedier sir willya skeuyngton made report duke whiche therto cosented saiyng men warre rich great lorde sandes diuers weee appointed receiue toune entred set stadardes top gate toke key strong house tower bulwarkes frenchemen readye depart trussages cariages crosbowes pykes handgunnes whiche doyng lorde sandes englishemen wer within toune wer cotent sayd frenchman passe without weapon point muche alteracio frenchemen stayed lorde roche baron gaue many fayre wordes passed forwarde red standard white crosse seyng sir thomas palmer ranne stadard plucked piece sayd lorde roche baron vngently done answered beare standard like conqueror long disputacion frenchemen sayd promised theim haue weapon baggage vpon suffered depart fotemen likewise standard whiche rent sir robert iernyngham nomber whiche departed truely accompted two thousand footemen fiue hundreth horseman odde wel warlike appointed left muche baggage behynd sawe englishemen fast come toune feare losse frenchman wer departed duke whole army entred toune englishemen founde fine f beddes napery coueringes muche houshold stuffe especially wyne great plentie armye tested till last day october gate toune rased throwen doune bulwarkes likewise duke caused ordinaunce taken remoued toune roye e armye rested wherof glad trauailed sore wether wette colde feast sainctes called alhalon daye duke chiefe churche r made knightes lorde harbert lorde powes olyuer manner arthur pole richard sandes robert iernyngham robert sailsbury edmond benyngfelde richard corbet thomas wentworthe wyllyam storton water mantell george warran edward seymour erle hartford duke sommerset moste worthy gouernor kynges maiesties persone protector al realmes dominion subiectes morowe armye remoued place called neele burgonions beganne waxe wery englishemen euery day foule wether raine bothe day night wherfore dyuers company fell grudgyng saiyng nowe may see remouyng shall ledde place place wynter whiche vtter losse lyues dayly see company dyeth smal nomber trueth dyed many sayd farther burgonions haue great gaine lest haue wagon carye boties countrey whiche nere hand go ight haue meanes conuey thing cout ey lacke carryage bete bushe take byrdes grudge seassed gentle wordes tyme iorneys comonly spoken duke burbon xm almaynes would haue inuaded fraunce ioyned army truth cotrary turned host another way went prouince layde siege marcelles wherof duke b yng aduertised litle mused also seyng menne daily fall cke sory yet comforted theim euery man glad folowe entent vi day nouember lorde sandes beyng capitaine foreward duke middle ward sir richard wyngfeld capitaine rereward came order battail prest fight village called ueane rested night morow whole army returned againe ouer water came place called beaufford passage duke made knightes ihon dudley robert utreyght esquiers viii day ye duke remoued place called mount sainct martyne mete place armye duke iustruccions loked vpo capitaines perceiuyng hard nothyng duke burbons commyng ayde counsail thought determined send lorde sandes post kyng declare case stode necessitie accordyng selfe knew saw pointes whiche lorde sandes tooke great paine made good diligence toward kyng ridyng duke remoued armye place called permount lodged tyme rest army well vitailed euer w shemen muttered grudged great raynes wyndes fallen came feruent frosta great frost sore many souldier dyed colde lost fyngers toe many lost nailes handes whiche great grefe duke notwithstandyng remembryng came thither lye styl xiii day remoued place two myle castle bowhen still frised insomuche master ordinaunce compelled necessitie set wheles ordinaunce hardels sinkyng mornyng welshemen set shout cryed home home krekers hearyng cryed hang hang whiche matter deuision like haue fallen policie ceased sir edward gyldfod capitaine horsmen vewed castle bowhen boghan whiche euer thought impregnable iudged might wonne castle inuironed marryses man iudgement possible wynne nowe perceiued frost great strong might beseaged night fresed againe wherfore desired duke geue leaue assaute whiche thereto agreed caused ordinauce set furth ouer marrish within castle perceiued marrishe fayled theim sore dismayed sir edward guildeford shot thre great piece castle castilian shot thre piece againe englishe gunner wer preparing battery capitain seyng castle could hold reason ishe failed could defende none assault deliuer castle behofe emperor kyng england small communicacion betwene sayd sir edwarde guyldforde capitaine capitaine retinue departed leuyng behynd ordinaunce bombardes curtawes deiny curtaux slinges canon volgers ordinaunce lxxvi piece plentie pellettes pouder duke suffolke perceiuyng castle stode border henaude wherfore please henawers made capitaine thesame castle boghan seneshal henaude behofe emperor kyng england place army euil vitailed frenchemen stopped water vitaile passe ouer riuer wherfore duke sent henaude specially theim ualencien haue ayde vitaile litle sent army litle yet seruice feruent frost bitter windes co tinued caused many people dye yet still lay army abidyng answer lord sandes whiche haue heard rode post somuche trauailed came king england castle wyndsore declared kyng message whiche people wer frenche ground abode muche misery wether wet wayes depe long nightes short dayes great iorneys litle vitaile caused souldiers daily dye also trusted passed sea accordyng instruccions haue ayde duke burbon sith departyng neuer heard worde wherfore duke suffolke noble army haue set highnes declare state condicion good tary euil chaunces whiche daily happeneth god enemy well sayd kyng knewe comyng wherfore haue appointed lorde mountioy vim men passe sea relefe army whiche lorde mountioy almost redynes nowise army shall breake kyng came westminster cardinal place receiued letter duke suffolke sir robert iernyngham gettyng castle boghan bowen wherfore incotinent kyng counsail determined lord mouioy make spede whiche suche diligence many souldiers come lodon wel harnissed weponed redy passe sea wherfore kyng sent hast sir robert iernyngham declare duke kinges pleasure ayde comyng towarde sir robert iernyngham could come duke armye remoued bohan brent toune came citie ualencine henaude layde vp ordinaunce thence came citie turnay whiche vnder emperor frenche kynges handes toke iornay homewarde thorow flaunders army broken dispatched duke mette sir robert iernyngham bridge flaunders knewe kynges mynde entent might retreate souldiers could many englishemen shipped andwarpe many sluyes newport hauens calayce steyed tyme duke sawe could bryng army together scacely iiii part licensed remnaunt depart breakyngvp armye letter sent kyng whiche incontinent stopped lorde mountioy sent men countrey againe duke capitaines hearyng kynges displeasure sore abashed write frendes perfite knowlege duke burbon broken vppe campe extremitie wynter also shewed souldiers dyed vita l failid whiche caused breake army trueth souldiers would abide whiche reason kyng somewhat appeased good hope duke came calayce xii day december abode long till frendes sued kyng returne graunted returned duke capitaines came kynges presence long season great heauynes displeasure last thinges taken good part well receiued great loue fauor familiaritie kyng whyle duke suffolke fraunce erle surrey march scotland cardinall sent comissions moneth october realme euery man worth xl l pay whole subsidie graunted hand dayes payment payment called anticipacionan anticipacion say thing taken thing comyng tyme season terme new commaltie thei payd wel learnyng money paied hand wtout delay kyng yere kept christmas solempnely castle wyndsore thither came third day ianuarye erle pountiuer royal bloud brytaigne pretedyng duke whiche nere cosyn duke burbon bannished fraunce erle came hastely duke burbon well entertained feasted kyng answere made kyng went cardinal hampton court great spede returned sayd duke countrey prouince season brought court gentleman scotland called andrew stewart taken sea diuers letter one water iago yoman kynges diuers letter duke albany frenche kyng reason wherof kyng knew muche counsail gentleman payed raunsome sone redemed xix day ianuary vi fayre shippes fraunce well appointed mette shippe kynges england called kateryne galley shippe xl tonne capitain wherof one ihon mariner small company many company land encoraged menne feare sette aside euer frenchemen approched bet theim arrowes pykes fightyng styll continued fro iiii clocke mornyng till ix clocke euer cost englad englishman best could saue themselfes tyme spent pouder arrowes shotyng bylles hewyng pykes kepyng comyng aborde al company almost sore hurte capitaine wounded death remedy sayle chace perceiued one called capitain markam capitain barke sandwyche whiche mafully called men together sandwyche hauen good wynde came reskue kateryne galley vi shippes perceiuyng left chace made barke sandwyche capitaine coragiously comforted men made quarter ship defensable frenchman sette fiersly toppes higher toppe englishe ship went ordinaunce quarels dartes frenche shippes englishman shot fiersly againe frenchemen profered enter englishman bet bylles frenchemen last great gunne bet doune toppe barke slewe men thesame lastly strake doune mast conflict continued x clocke tyll two noone could make shift saile euer englishman shot arrowes thenglishmen arrowes frenchemen durst enter arrowes spent frenchemen came aborde one entred barke fight slaine frenchman hand xxvii lxxx sore hurt englishe slaine xxiii say englishemen fought valiauntly weake vi tall shippes wherfore taken brought depe prise frenchman sayd neuer bought prise dere ihon maryner capitaine kateryne galey dyed many frenchemen wer hurt dyed depe neither part wanne greatly last moneth called december taken certain traytors citie couentryan insurre cion moued couentry one called fraunces philippe scholemaster kynges henxmen one christopher pykeryng clerke larder one antony maynuile gentleman persuasion sayd fraunces philip entended haue taken kynges treasure subsidie collector thesame came towarde london haue araised men taken castle kylingworth haue made battaile kyng wherfore sayd fraunces christopher anthony wer hanged drawen quartered tyborne xi day februarye residue taken sent citie couentry wer executed one kynges henxmen called dygby one conspirator fled realme pardon xvii day ianuary ther fayer market toune marguyson frenche kynges dominion beside calayce defence people marchaundise appointed cc men harnes wel weaponed souldiers guysnes hearyng departed night came nere toune marguyson closly kept themselfes tyll market fayre best englishman whiche wer lxx archer bylles set sodainly market seyng frenchemen stode manfully defence wt handgunnes pykes englishman shotte wholy together draue frenchman toune would succor haue taken churche englishemen betwene theim churche none remedye flee many frenchemen slaine capitain ihon de pound capitain iho de babage diuers taken prisoner diuers marchauntes sell goodes also taken goodes brought frenchemennes wagon guysnes englishman slaine diuers sore hurt fyrst day februay valiant knight sir robert iernyngha fifty demylauces garrison calayce skoured countrey odirsaell toke c hedde beastes doyng ask rose countrey wherby frenchemen gathered together nomber xii score sir robert company came houndyngbrige beset round necessitie must fight frenchman set hadgunnes crosbowes pykes strong encountre englishman nne desperate nomber fought fiersly caused frenchman geue backe slewe many toke xiii prisoner chace toke vii whiche made vp xxi sayd sir robert returned botie prisoner lost noman almoste hurt x day marche kyng hauyng newe harnes made deuise fashion sucheas armorer tyme seen thought assaye thesame tilte appointed iustes serue fote appointed lorde marque dorset erle surrey kyng came one ende tylt duke suffolke gentleman sayd duke sir kyng come tyltes ende see sayd duke fayth head piece taketh fro sight wordes god knoweth chaunce kyng spere deliuered lorde marque vi er headpece beyng vp doune fa ened face clene naked gentleman sayd duke sir king commeth duke set forward charged spere kyng likewise vnaduisedly set toward ye duke people perceiuyng kynges face bare cryed hold hold duke neither saw heard whether kyng remembred viser vp could tell ala sorow people saw spleters duke spere strike kynges hedpiece suertie duke strake kyng brow right vnder de ece hedpece verye coyffe u l ba enetpece wherevnto barbet power defence charneld whiche coyffe bassenet neuer armorer taketh hede euermore couered viser barbet volant pece pece defended forseth charge spere place lighted great ieopardy death insomuche face bare duke spere brake shyuers bare kynges viser barbet farre backe countre buffe kynges headpece full spleters armorer matter muche blamed lorde marque deliueryng spere face open kyng sayd none blame entended haue sayed selfe sight duke incontinently vnarmed came kyng shewyng closenes sight sware would neuer runne kyng kyng lytle hurt kynges seruauntes would haue put duke ieopardy kyng called armorer put peces together toke spere ranne vi course well whiche men might perceiue hurt whiche great ioy comfort subiectes present ende februarye foure frenche shippes chased fysher botes rye verye shore fludde gone would haue taken botes came land pike fisher threw stone one archer shotte slewe frencheman whiche helde vp basket bad shote englisheman shote englisheman shot basket slewe saued botes fludde came frenchemen sette vp sailes passyng englishemen warre mette theim tooke two sayd shippes two fled yere kyng sent lorde morlay sir wyllyam hosy knight doctor lee almoner done ferdinando archduke austrice brother emperour charles order garter whiche toune norryngberge receiued prince germanye assembled counsel dyet bishop rome germaynes put c greues xiii day aprill one capitain breerton one capitaines auenturers guysnes xvi tall men came village called waste toke bootie beastes whiche takyng askry rose chaunce certain garrison bulleyn abrode cry people came englishemen frenchemen wer cc horseman great cryes enuiro ed englishemen englishemen could make defence capitain brearton called capitain frenchemen sayd sir getleman enterprice myne haue brought good felowes ieopardy wherfore yelde v al prisoner deliuered weapon capitain gentleman gently receiued menne warre drewe pe santz chorles coutrey nye hand nomber vii viii score whiche desired bye englishman wer take frenchman content toke money englishman deliuered vplandishe people men warre rode away menne warre departed rybaudes pykes iauelynscapitaine brearton murdered knyues fell englishemen whiche weapon slewe xvii cutte theim piece moste shamefully euer sene knowlege hereof brought capitain guisnes sir ihon gage sent auenturers willyng theim reuenge capitaines death aduenturers xiiii day gathered together nomber xl archer pykes good guide next day mornyng came village wast toke xxxvii prisoner moste part murder brearton companythe murder euenged xxxvii slew xxxvi left one caried departed set toune fyer spared nothyng ire great menne warre fraunce costed englishman would medle rage came guysnes sware frencheman left liue declare message capitaine bullein whiche day would saue neither man woman child came handes great crueltie peysantz done capitaine brearton company whiche message frenchman discontent sayd villaynes deserued haue vengeaunce crueltie yere bookes emphimerydes pronosticacions made calculate astronomer people sore affrayde sayd writer declared yere suche eclipse watery signes suche coniunctions water fluddes many people perishe insomuche many persones vitailed selfes went high groundes feare drounyng specially one bolton prior saint bartholomewes smythfeld builded house vpo harow hill feare fludbolton prior saint bartholomewes thether went made prouision thinges necessarye within space two monethes faythfull people put trust confidence onely god raine wryters pronosticate february wherfore began raine february people wer muche afrayd sayd beginneth many wisemen whiche thought worlde could drouned againe contrary goddes promise put trust onely thei thought great raines might fall enclinacions starres water milles might stande styll grinde prouided meale yet god thanked fairer season many yeres last astronomer excuse sayd computacion mistaken miscounted nomber hundreth yeres emperor charles whiche also enemy frenche kyng seyng great army kyng england confederate fraunce thought honorable make warre also part frauce ioyneth spain especially imagined recouer toune fountraby whiche frenchemen tyme gotten wherfore assembled great puissaunce made capitain lorde barnardine de belasco constable castyle great diligence came toune fountraby whiche strongly fortefied capitain therof naueroys capitaine compaigny sawe toune besieged suche puissaunce also sea narowly kept could haue vitail succour determined geue vp toune yet capitaine high stomacke shotte ordinaunce sent trompet capitain spanyardes know prisoner communicacion thereof desired abstinence warre tyl communed counsail spanish host whiche graunted communicacion fiue dayes nothyng ended spanyardes haute one syde frenchemen proude syde vi day concluded toune deliuered ordinaunce artillery men war depart bagge baggage xxvii day february ye toune fountraby brought againe handes emperor capitain fountraby afterwarde restored landes nauer emperor became man bishop rome called pope clement seyng great warres yere party especial betwene emperor kyng england one partie fraunces freche kyng alyes sent archebishop realme naples fyrst frenche kyng emperor whiche declared frenche kyng manyfolde mischiefes ryse warre great stroke vengeaunce god strike vniust warre specially death innocentes effusion christen bloud shewed farther sayd frenche kyng made daily warre emperor kyng england without cause onely himselfe would right subiectes frenche kyng counsail taken answered lorde legate assure make warre warre made v stande defence notwithstandyng right kept v duchy myllain realme naples emperor vsurped duke whiche haue good title kyng england warreth v without cause notwithstading haue geuen many lordes cousail diuers fayre pencions afrayde would haue loue amitie perceiued toke part emperor mortal enemy withdrewe pencions right might power would conquere good whiche reason clayme nothing well sayd ambassador speake fyrst emperor kyng england declare rightes demaundes whiche frenche kyng semed content sayd ambassadour tooke leaue post came emperor spaine exhorted peace many goodly reason affirmyng warre vniust without reasonable cause made frenche kyng sayd kyng affirmed emperor like noble prince answered warres neuer beginnyng frenche kyng wyst taken toune fountraby also sent army coquere realme nauer e contented reteyned swyches whiche emperor subiectes caused enemy thempyre also withhelde duchy haut burgoyne countie arthoys diuers countreys seignories belongyng wherfore quarel alway iust college rome perceiue whole cause warres deliuered sayd ambassador seedule whiche departed refusyng giftes whiche emperor offered came frenche kyng rehersed emperor saiyng french kyng selfe highly excused sayd might lese predecessor left bishop rome ambassador toke leaue came england legate departed fro emperor court came thither ambassador portyngale whiche highly behaued selfe came emperor speche proudly saydthe proposicion portyngale sir greatest prince christendome ought aboue men iustice right wrong man well knowen labor studye learnyng cosmography astronomy v portyngales trade party inde india fyrst sought found fyrst labor behalf great innumerable rich whiche spent searchyng findyng thesame employed spent kyng portyngale progenitor whiche trauail haue wonne straung lades wherby christendome greatly enriched wt iuels stone perles straung commodity thought iust righteous persone take v comoditie haue derely bought yet moste puissant lorde mightie emperor subiectes daily trauail thither wrong fully take away gayne whiche neuer labored toke pain findyng serching thesame wherfore iustice must comaunde subiectes alonely leue trade thitherwarde also make v portyngales sufficient recompence harmes haue susteined ambassador saydthe emperor answer lytle deliberacion emperor answered pouertie countrey portyngale suche selfes able liue wherfore necessitie driuen seke liuyng landes prince able purchase lande lordes able conquere wherfore sea compelled seke whiche found say haue found lades say landes foud shipwrekes sea beyng cast thereon thought suche ground sought farther succour necessitie yet say haue wone haue wone would subiectes repare thither ascertaine man shall prohibite subictes saile thei lyst auauntage subiectes may warned place wt haue peace amitie mine enemy frend letteth libertie well sayd ambassador wil let subiectes passe thither nay sayd emperor wil trye farre able disturbe doynges nerer hand suertie portyngales enemy christendome indyans cary nothyng coyne whiche hurt countreys wherfore tyme may depart till better aduised answere geuen portyngales offered great summes money emperor leaue trade indyans therto nowyse would agree xvi yere beginnyng xvi yere kyng lay maner newhall essex kept feast sainct george hearyng bishop rome ambassador commyng england remoued manor grenewyche sayd archbishop legate came highly entertained declared wisely eloquently message entent master whiche make peace co cord betwene prince christendome especially betwene emperor kyng englad frenche kyng cause emperor also french kyng whiche sayd affirmed without cause kyng england made warre consideryng thentent haue amitie fauor noble hath liberally geuen theim honorable pencions whiche dutie affirmeth may clayme beniuolence bountie also sayeth clayme croune realme possession whiche toucheth highly claymeth nothyng therfore thynketh right ought make warre wherfore may please highnes tell mynde shall declare whole court rome god willyng forget nothyng kyng called cousail diuers cosultacions ambassador sent shewed many recordes prouyng kyng england inheritor realme frauce bloud also cofirmed diuers charter tyme kyng charles vii cocernyng ye pencion shewed diuers charter pencion frendship due rent duches normady guyan coutreys aniew maine whiche kyng englandes enheritaunce farthermore wer shewed diuers bondes sayd french kynges payment citie turnay duty whiche ought kyng england whiche article fulfyll frenche kyng hath oftentymes required ambassador yet euer dissebled would conforme himselfe reason thinges wer note written deliuered bishop rome ambassador toke leue kyng returned post accompanied iii persones reason comyng ambassador men hoped peace ensue succeded yere third day may garrison bullein diuers moste secrete wise could came place within englishe pale called sentricas sodainly strake vp drome drounslade people hearyng night wer sore abashed fled naked clothed moste part fled churche frenchemen folowed toke xxi prisoner set fyer churche tyme pale raised whiche thyng frenchemen perceiuyng left botie returned hast prisoner bullein season lordes flaunders lay siege tyrwyn likely haue taken famyne whereof frenche kyng beyng aduertised assembled armye xxiim horseman fotemen vnder conduicte duke uandosme lorde pountdormy frenche kyng himselfe came doune amyas caused noysed would besege toune ualencyen henaude duke suffolke last yere left kyng englandes ordinaunce kyng england hearyng sayd frenche kyng beseged ualencyen person would go thither reskue ordinaunce lorde fynes lordes fl unders whiche lay tyrwyn ixm menne aduertised frenche armye fame host shuld go ualencyen sent nomore succor frenchemen thynges ready lefte waye ualencyen tooke way directly tyrwyn lordes flaunders perceiued sore abashed knewe disceiued able abyde puissaunce frenche army wherefore raysed siege put theselfes order battail ye southest side tyrwyn french armye passed forward vi day may towarde tyrwyn made semblaunce fight howbeit theim skyrmished horseman flaunders last entered toune whervnto welcome lordes flaunders departed sore displeased remedy ranne brute frenche army would lay sege guysnes wherfore kyng caused men thynges put readynes spedye reskue thereof chaunsed frenchemen toke better aduice moneth may sir robert iernyngham capitain newnam bridge comuned christopher coo capitaine diuers englishe shippes kept sea whiche calayce hauen vitaile sayd capitain coo know bulleners haue visited nere calayce englishe pale haue burned sentrycas promise set many menne lande hauen bullein xix day maye many furnishe mete basse bulleine tyme houre betwene v appointed whiche sayd christopher agreed faithfully promised prepared accordyngly euerye thyng necessarye sayled towarde bulleyn sir robert iernyngham sent worde enterprise sir willyam fitzwillyam capitaine guysnes know would ayde part toward iorney whiche sent worde would thesame auenture himselfe gentleman desired capitaine enterprise whiche thakefully weth heart receiued men warre aduenturers bayly marke assembled together come together wer ccc horseman coutrey marke iiic auenturers clx one viic men persones mette houre appointed sandyngfelde night short day came nere bullein set good order battail thei askried came nere bullein chaunsed christopher coo shippes whiche winde come iiii shippes bullein somwhat day bulleners kept watche espied manned boates men ordinaunce stretched toward land tyme basse bullein harnes ready defend englishman londyng capitaine coo might almost people basse bullein wer shore seyng garrison made ready bent ordinaunce sir willya fitzwillyam hearyng gunnes toward hauenside knew wel cristopher coo busines encoraged euery man well marched forwarde wt asmuche spede might insomuche englishemen hylles bullein sondry plumpes ued horsmen bullein betwene castle cardons tower light horsmen englishe part theim encountred good fight frenchemen shotte crosbowes englishemen long bowes great ordinaunce shot terri ly englishemen approched toune walles skyrmishe erse euer archer ayded horseman whyle horseman thus skyrmishyng viii score auenturers whiche hardy valiaunt men cast themselfes came basse bullein hardely receiued frenchman yet notwithstadyng lost barrier englishman entred shotyng al side strong fight frenchman cried bullein thenglishmen sainct george calayce last frenchman driuen backe many slaine xliiii taken prisoner returned capitaine sir willyam fitzwillyam christopher coo lond sea cost bet ye frenchman vp toune tide turned came againe safetie shippes englishe horseman long fightyng tooke thre frenchemen armes reculed toune tyme reason alarme countrey pycardye raysed muche people resorted bullein sydes whiche doyng sir willyam fitzwillyam wisely perceiuyng sound trumpette brought menne together plumpe sent hither thither fette driftes beastes nere countrey euery side whiche quickely done aduenturers brought ox kyne horse many pillage brent grange village mette together botie returned sauetie tewesdaie folowyng beyng laste daie maie sir willyam fitz willyam c fiftie horseman auenturers hundred persones mo came place called samer de boy saied capitain wisely considered place frenchemen diuerse tymes lurked taken auantage englishman wherfore laied horseman archer horsebacke woodde waite frenchemen folowed stale sent furth auenturers whiche passed farther capitain would thei haue doen sodainly thei askried came frenchemen auenturers sware thei would flee bent theimselfes defed enemy whiche wer iiic horseman frenchman knewe well hardines yet thei called theim crakers whiche missoundyng commonly called krekers suretie men wer hardy full pollicie far e would ieoperd frenchemen sent aboute valey ic best horseman iic footemen wer krekers betwene twoo bendes frenchman sir willyam fitz willya beyng assured conduite frenchemen muche doubted chaunce auenturers wherefore greate hast sent stale horseman left couered frenchman wer krekers came set fast hope horseman wer gone hill valey englishemen theim valiantly defended horseman compassed hill auenturers wer come plain horseman wer come sir willia fitz willyam set french horseman hard ferce encounter frenchman fought sore length thei fled chace wer taken lvi horsmen xliiii slain one many englishemen sore hurte diuerse slain thus krekers scaped narowe hasarde thesame season second daie maie sir thomas palmer one capitaines frontier ridyng frende master ierome burgon capitain turnahan hym xx englishe men light horse roade sodainly espied xxx horseman garrison tirwyn bullein thei nere together englishemen espied theim remedy encounter sir thomas palmer wel comforted compaignie frenche men set great force truly thei fought long without one hauyng auauntage last frenchemen began faint alitle withdrawe themselfes perceiuyng englishe men set coragiously thei slewe three hande vi men armes taken prisoner eight dimy lance whiche prisoner englishemen returned guysnes kepte purpose turnahan hurte wounded iune sir willyam fitz willyam capitain guysnes sir ihon walop sir ihon gage secretly called ixc men warre suche thei trusted midsomer day passed lowe countrey picardy vnto castle hardyngha rigsam thei caried one pece ordinaunce called curtall gonne thei bente castle whiche well furnished harnes ordinaunce artilerie thynges nedefull capitain also valiant hardie gentleman englishemen euer shot pece remoued place place greate pain conclusion made batery walles thei might assault trompet blewe assault capitain compaignie stoode defence sir ihon wallop sir ihon gage auenturers krekers entred diche archer shot euery loupe arrowes frenchemen likewise shot quarelles englishman set vp laders walles frenchemen threwe doune assault slain gentleman called butler xv englishman assaulte lefte clymed pike amended ladder cried assault sir william fitz william chief capitain enterprise perceiued thei lacked engynes thynges spedy assault castle willyng lose men without cause caused staye capitaines counsailed together thei concluded attempt assault thei hard newes twoo thousande horse men twoo thousande footemen wer hande fight thei perceiuyng ixc men beyng wery wer power encounter foure thousande frenchemen thei good ordre returned englishe fortress monsire de bee capiiain bullein well considered enterprices englishman doen picardy fraunce late determined requite theim honor fame purpose sent erle dammartyne lorde pontremie lorde chastillion whiche concluded entre englishe pale shewe themselfes calice wherefore thei assembled men armes souldiers garrison aboute thei wer viiic good horseman pike gonne crossebowes viiic footemen compaignie assembled monsire de bee capitain iorney lordes fourthe daie august banner displaied came toward calice euenyng next daie mornyng sixe clocke thei came village within englishe pale called bonynges alarme rose englishe pale came calice lordes fraunce sente foreriders serche ouer se coutrey thei laied embushement iiic horseman thesaid toune bonynges bend abode monsire pontremie monsire de bee rode kalkewell iiic horseman taried erle dammartine iiic freshe horseman footemen ba ner displaied roade forraged countrey whiche three hundred speres thei let one c go large kept residue alarme came calice euery man made horse harnes sir robert iernyngham lxxx horseman spede rode calice behold compaignie frenchemen sent furth light horseman whiche met skourers frech men frenchemen semed fewe nombre englishe rider profered toward whiche fled towarde sandiffeld englishemen chased beeyng knowlege mbushementes laye bonynges kalkewell sir robert iernyngham sawe light horseman chace folowed softly kepe horse brethe sodainly french men chace returned aide nere theim englishemen whiche passed xvi horse sawe frenchemen returne thei encountered theim manfully frenchemen came still mo mo englishemen constrained flie another waie hye lande greate ieoperdy frenchman pursued helpe light geldynges englishemen gat sea side sea sandes beyond skales wer englishman glad returned fought frenchman hande hande frenchemen behynde folowed chace onely twentie horse men pure fightyng englishemen toke one frenche horseman came hym calice wer saued sir robert iernyngham sawe men chace haue hard sawe thei wer great ieoperdy auaunsed rescue might whiche sauyng light horseman frenhemen lefte theim encounter sir robert iernyngham went farre forward frenchemen betwene hym calice sawe al bendes embushmentes breake said compaignie sers sainct george borowe lette frenche galantes knowe wee englishemen bee sir saied compaignie thei shall bye v dere marched towarde high lande approched greate nombre horseman fraunce englishemen theim valiauntly receiued manfully defended euer frechmen came freshe freshe englishemen beyng wery oppressed multitude faine flie chace taken thomas cheiney archer whose horse tiered two archer horsbacke one called george kar rowlande atkynson thre englishe pale sir robert remnaunt saued themselfes best thei could sir robert returned frenchemen souned trompet uled bullein sent woorde calice thei would visite oftener sir robert iernyngham remembryng chaunce thought reuenged thesame aduisyng hymself place repare remembred whensoeuer englishman made iorney margyson frenchemen would flie ouer water creke high ground boates wer island saue theselfes side thei might euer haue succor creke water beyond toune calice therfore thesaied sir robert caused fiue greate boates bee caried wagon capitaines calice guysnes nombre iiic fotemen krekers lx horseman xii daie august banner displayed toke waie toune margison night light horseman gaue alarme toune bullein toke two souldiers prisoner brought theim certain cattaill compaignie thenglishemen marched forward toward margyson seyng frenchemen toke boates trust water passed ouer englishemen perceiued lanched boates like auenturers entered force passed mo mo till clx wer passed ouer countrey began gather frenchemen thre hundred whiche fought englishman would haue letted boates land archer side draue backe englishemen slewe first encounter lx men toke fortie prisoner yet frenchemen fled met newe succor began newe battail frenchman fought hardely thende thei fled moste porest people side water fled churche abode defence fire set church frenchemen lept churche destruccion three hundred saued sixtie liue whole power bullein come doune nere place thei perceiued late englishemen returned thei came farther sir robert iarnyngham euen frenchemen brought good botie many prisoner calice whiche sore greued capitain bullein frenchemen perceiuyng thei gat litle englishemennes handes thought take auauntage flemmynges wher fore thei assembled garrison bullein tirwyn vc fotemen three hundred horseman good ordre marched toward sainct omers thei sent go aforragyng ic footman many horseman rest kepte themselfes stale frenchemen came arkus nigh sainct omers forraged al countrey alarme sprang countrey turnahan capitain turnaha sent woorde sir willyam fitzwillyan capitain guysnes frenchemen abrode whiche made answere frenchemen came nere hym surely would speke whiche answer capitain turnahan beyng encoraged sent furth cc flemynges foote stil frenchemen marched toward turnaha flemmynges wer sent turnahan marched toward waie frenchemen come thynkyng capitain guysnes set thei would haue lien chace receipt thesaied capitain guisnes valiantly marched forward c horseman iiiic footemen entendyng mete frenchman sodainly passyng forward worde brought hym erle damarten garrison mustrel abuile nomber vic horseman commyng forward towarde guysnes hearyng sir willyam fitzwillyam sware erle take pain come guisnes would mete way meane left first enterprice marched toward therle damartin frenchemen tirwyn beyng therof aduertised spy called people together botie came forwarde towarde turnahan sodainly thei askried poore flemynges whiche wer sent castle turnahan thei perceiued french men commyng toward thei turned backes fled like shepe frenchemen folowed apace slewe moste parte theim fewe escaped capitain guysnes came faire grene fiue myle guisnes good ordre battaill taried erles commyng whiche hearyng capitain guysnes redy receiue hym made returne backeward without thyng doyng capitain knewe truthe erles returne hast sped hym mete frenchemen commyng turnahan meane waie hard tidynges chaunce flemynges frenchman wer uled toward tirwyn whiche auenture sore hym displeased remedy wherfore returned guisnes sory frenchemen went awaie vnfought withall frenchemen litle medled tyme wherefore let v returne shewe warres wer kept frontier betwene englande scotlande ceason xxi daie maie beyng trinite sondaie vc scottes mornyng seuerall fordes entered englande laye couertly high waie distresse merchauntes merket men passe berwike daie faire euery trinite sondaie ther kepte greate faire whiche scottes knewe well thei laye thus lurkyng thei robbed many merchauntes toke riche prisoner last thei wer perceiued alarme rose people bega gather scottes drewe together toward branxston thenglishmen theim assailed whiche manfully theim defended yong lorde fulbery come one c light horsmen scottes gone awaie botie began sore fight many hurt bothe side slain last scottes fled chace twoo hundred scottes taken prisoner residue fled saued themselfes v daie iuly sir ihon fenwicke leonard musgraue bastard heron diuerse gathered together ixc entred scotland countrey called marche robbed spoyled countrey chaunce thesame season scottes assembled twoo thousande men inuade englande none knewe till thei auenture met together began strong medley scottes fought valiauntly greate englishemen hardeli assailed last fine force caused theim leaue grounde flie flight wer taken cc scottes many slain whiche prisoner diuerse wer gentleme sir raufe fanwicke leonard musgraue bastarde heron xxx englishemen wel horssed folowed farre chace thei paste rescue compaignie whiche perceiuyng scottes sodainly returned sette englishemen whiche oppressed multitude sone ouercome taken sir raufe fanwicke leonard musgraue sixe bastarde heron seuen slain remnant chaunce eskaped englishman twoo hundred prysoners returned sauely englande slaying bastard heron pleasure scottes takyng two hundred displeasure thei hated hym vii daie iuly lorde maxwell scotlande sir alexander iorden banner displayed scottes nombre foure thousande entered englande west march carleile began burne euery side englishemen assembled euery side thei nombre iim men fiercely set scottes greate fighte space houre last englishemen brake arraie scottes discomfited toke ccc scottes prisoner englishemen taken prisoner went awaie prisoner sir alexander iorden sonne diuerse taken prisoner departyng compaignie englishemen muche minished lorde maxwell beyng politique man perceiued sodainly called people together encoraged began newe skirmishe recouered al prisoner almost toke diuerse englishe men prisoner chaunce warre iorney courte parliament scotlande muche commonyng warres whiche betwene englande scotlande noble saied fraunce neuer muche good scotlande xx yeres scotlande lost englande one yere loue cause frauce wherfore thought couenietto make perpetuall league amitie kyng englande leaue frenche kynges parte noble whiche pencions fraunce declared olde amitie betwene fraunce scotlande frenche kyng brought vp many gentleman scotlande courte geuyng theim greate liuynges whiche kyng englande would thei also alleged franches priuileges scottes haue frauce specially thei shewed kyng scottes breake fraunce happened kyng englande inuade scotlande whiche beeyng without aide frend might well power englande conquered many long reason thought expedient sue kyng englande truce whiche doen truce graunted til andrewes daie yere first day september docter thomas hanibal master rolles receiued london erles bishoppes diuerse noble gentlemena rose brought rome ambassador clement bishop rome whiche brought hym rose gold token kyng people passed thought haue seen rose shewed till came kyng wynsore daie natiuitie lady whiche daie solempne masse song cardinall yorke thesaid present deliuered kyng whiche tree forged fine golde wrought branch leaues flower resemblyng rose tree set pot gold pot thre fete antike fashion pot measure halfe pinte vppermost rose faire saphier loupe perced bignes acorne tree height halfe englishe yard bredth foote thesaied ambassador deliueryng thesame rose made oracion declaryng good mynd loue fauor bishop rome bare kyng token whereof sent hym present whiche kyng thankefully receiued deliuered hym bare open kyng college greate chamber deliuered master iuell house ended legacion befor tyme moneth iuly lorde archebalde douglas erle anguishe whiche maried quene scottes sister kyng englande sent fraunce duke albany kepte contrary pleasure thence hardely escaped came kyng england maner grenewiche besought hym aide comfort kyng made gentle answere erle fauor wife quene scottes wherefore caused hym bee sent fraunce saied loued duke albany better hym soeuer matter wrote frenche kyng therle euer came scotlande frenche kyng haue plesure scotlande might let erle beyng fraunce ieoperdie life wherfore secretly fled came englande haue hard one daie castle wynsore declared counsaill fraunce thei happened communicacion talke warres betwene emperor frenche king betwene kyng england frenche kyng lorde counsaill stode vp saied better one persone suffered rather realme bee daily mischief asked meante one persone answered frenche quene whiche lame vgly dedde way might bee founde frenche kyng mary themperors sister haue duchy millain money mariage kyng england paied peace might concluded answere made whether true false truthe freche quene ded xxvi daie iuly buried de ise duke burbon sommer made sharpe warre fre che kynges dominion high enterprise wherefore kyng englande sent letter diuerse lordes gentleman seaso tenor whereof ensueth trustie c asmuche lorde god thanked armie vnder leadyng cosyn duke burbon hath onely entered realme fraunce gainyng attaynyng many tounes citees castle place whole countrey prouince without resistence auncient enemie frenche kyng also goeth daily marchyng continually dooth chace driue suche men warre said enemie hath prepared defence resistence cosyn duke burbon oure saied armie suche wise thought vndoubtedly bee moste conuenient tyme season either persone although yere somewhat past leuetenaunt puissant armie inuade fraunce side bothe recoueryng croune compell saied enemie knowlege obstinate wilfull cronious demeanure wherfore commaunde redy suche power able make vpon next proclamacion made dated tenth daie september whiche letter sent furthe euery man made preparacion accordyngly people murmured saied muche better kyng maintein warres awne subiectes spende treasure trust duke burbon beyng straungier spende money kyng beyng wynsore hym came sir anthony fitz herbert one iustices comon place man excellent lernyng lawe appereth workes sir raufe egerton knight doctor de ton deane lichfeld beginnyng yere wer sent commissioner irelande whiche wisely endeuored theimselfes thei reformed many iniuries doen countrey brought diuerse wilde irishe faire meanes submission made kynges aucthoritie erle kildare deputie lande greate oneele bare sworde lorde pier butler called erle ormound whiche deputie irelande thesaied commissioner made high threasorer irelande thei set thynges good ordre moneth september thei toke shippyng thesame monethe came kyng whiche gaue theim hartie thankes good doynges monethe kyng sent master ihon magnus priest roger ratcliffe esquier scotlande suretie nephew kyng scottes diuerse lordes scotland wrote kyng thei doubted suretie kyng duke albany whiche heire apparant realme scotlande kyng gouernaunce also thei thought beyng frencheman borne rule realme wherefore thei emongest theselfes murmured sore matter duke hearyng lordes scotlande written kyng englande also thei repined grudged doynges sodainly threasure could make departed scotlande sailed fraunce whiche departyng common nothyng sory sone departyng ambassador englande ioyously receiued scotlande thesaied ambassador taried till marche twelue monethe whiche tyme wer many conclusion driuen betwene two realmes let v returne fraunce xxiiii daie september thre horseman garrison bullein whiche wel knewe hauen calice came nepe tide passed ouer calice hauen rise banke night went behynd est wyndmill tooke lande went litle village called middilwaie passed turne pike entered whelers house tooke man wife xxl money sterlyng went waie clere without askrie perceiuyng watche calice manne wist thei become till trompet bullein brought worde demaunded ransome laste daie september fiftie light horseman calice apperteignyng sir rober iernyngham rode towarde bullein passed water margyso came water sclakes nere bullein sodainly thei encountered lx frenchman garrison bullein shotyng long bowes crosebowes euery side strong fight last frenchemen fled englishemen folowed toke thre light horseman thei perceiued alarme euery side thei put themselfes arraie botie came calice thesame daie sir thomas palmer lx horseman guysnes encountered capitain bertram leader horseman therle dammartyn lx horseman strong fight twoo howers together ende frenchemen fled englishemen folowed toke xviii prisoner xvi good horse bot e thei returned guysnes busie season auenturers hearyng horseman party doen inespeciall perceiuyng thenglishe horseman taken good prisoner commoned emongest theimselfes doen one capitaines said openly sir se long wee haue wage haue none liuyng riseth gain enemy sithe beginnyng wee haue good chaunce enterprise god bee thanked wynter draweth nere let v auenture get good botie make v mery cold wether shall enterprise thyng truste v shalbee profitable compaignie cried turthe turth banner sainct george thei marched toward village liyng toward mustrell hauyng onely xxv light horseman bee skou e thei wer fully two hundred men compaignie folowyng skourers went farre gotten faire botie ox kyne beastiall wer nere returne chaunce thesame daie erle dammartyn capitain mustrell power duke uandosme goyng toward sainct omers burne destroy countrey purpose thei gathered together xvc horsmen viiic footman howbeit footemen wer large mile behynd horseman frenchman horsebacke espied englishe horsmen whiche perceiuyng greate nombre fled thesaid frenchman marched forward thei espied auenturers foote made toward thenglishemen seyng greate nombre horseman studied get hedge strong place fortifie theim suche place sight also thei suche tyme doo wherefore capitain saied good felowes brother wee haue long tyme called auenturers tyme come auenture frenchemen rausome v nothyng emongest feared thyng saue liues must god hardines therefore saied se begyn flie slaie hande euery manne cried god mercie kneled donne kissed yearth strake handes eche token departe made theimselfes prest defence frenchman came euery side thenglishmen shot arrowes defended aswel thei could frenchman perceiuyng englishemen kept theselfes close caused diuerse horse men light fote thei fought speres pike shotte crosebowes euery side ala englishemen arrowes shote thei broken close without perill arrowes wer spent englishman fought valiauntly slewe many frenchemen lighted foote conclusion horseman entered killed al maner many compaignie tooke fewe prisonersthe ende aueturers thend compaignions called krekers auenturers whiche wer hardie men euer serued prince capitain duke burbon marque picardy moneth october greate puyssaunce laied siege strong toune marcell prouince laye greate space frenche kyng reised greate armie sware would reise siege whereof hearyng duke burbon sent marque piscare capitains declared intet geue frenche kyng battaill marque piscare saied frenche kynges puyssaunce greate small said although duke burbon whiche banished man countrey remeady reuenge hym battaill yet saied would put al emperor men whiche guyde suche hasard till remnant emperours power wer come well saied duke burbon haue written bothe emperor kyng england whiche shalbe reproche honor naie saied marque kepe reproche said docter richard pace ambassador kyng englande lorde haue kyng master wage would bee glad heare waie would take woll tell said marque frech kyng hath great armie gone italy hymself foloweth another come fight v dare assure onely take duchie millain vnprouided whiche shall hym pleasure slain v also emperor shall lese x marceles worthe frenche kynges power shalbe elated set emperor kyng englande therfore aduise breake vp siege spede preuet hym italy bee entered tounes put municions thesame shall lye colde feldes shall se shall become hym beastes dye vitaill spent counsaill duke capitaines agreed brake vp siege hast departed italy fortified tounes duchie millain men necessary frenche kyng hearyng armie passed mountaignes camped nere millain chaunced monethe nouember xiii daie aboute toune calice fell great mist whiche mist frenchman came village called kause beside newna bridge tooke xl beastes alarme brought calice whiche hearyng marshall calice called hym sir robert iernyngham thei icxx horseman sent sir anthony broune tell capitain guysnes thei intended thei aried compaignie guynes marched far forward thei came water sclaukes whiche nere bullein thei sette stale mornyng betyme thei sent furth gentleman called richard lamberd xx light horseman swifte geldynges thei came moone light nere bullein thei sawe men bullein put te feld englishemen greate diligence brought beastes together began driue theim together toward embushement alarme began bullein men warr issued toune fought thenglishemen horse wer freshe wherfore thei great auantage incoclusion three french menne slain horse taken light horseman came cattaill nere embushement frenchemen folowed seyng englishemen kept stale came hast rescued light horseman draue frenchemen backe made returne beastes thei returnyng thei worde brought sir willyam fitzwillyam capitain guysnes retinue besiegyng pile called castle capell wherfore thei sped thether hast thei wer come thether capitain guysnes theim hartely welcomed thei concluded geue assault castle good courage set frenchemen defended valiantly greate laste englishman gat ouer diches scaled walles frenchemen still defended till englishemen gotten highest dongion slaiyng pace wer liii persones slain hande reuengyng greate obstinacie frenchemen castle rased brent sir willyam fitzwillyam botie sir ihon wallop marshall calice sir ihon iernyngham returned guysnes thei calice thesame daie xiiii burgonions xiiii spaniardes horseman guysnes came churche falske farre durnam high masse tyme drewe swordes muche men churche nomber fiftie yelded theimselfes prisoner whiche nomber thei toke eight persones whiche gage remnant viii thei came guisnes xix daie december wer receiued london lorde gilbert keuet erle castelles sir robert cockeburne bishop dunkel abbot campskenell ambassador iames fifth kyng scottes bishop lyncolne lorde sainct ihones diuerse noble men wer conueighed lodgynges taylers haule xxiii daie december thesaied ambassador wer conueighed grenewiche accompaignied thesaied lordes water thei came vtter gate thei wer receiued officer house passed haule well furnished people vttermost chamber greate chamber presence thei wer receiued welcomed al price noble realme within short space kyng came furth set hym self throne three steppe high vnder clothe estate whiche veri rich apparell excedig riche goldsmithes worke perle stone scottes wel auised thei wisely humbly made obeisance bishop good plain latin made solempne oracion whiche declared although realme scotland often time hard renoune fame hym courte bothe giftes grace nature whiche wer persone yet saied princely countenance louely fauor whiche hymself se muche surmount fame name whiche hath hard reporte declared although fortune hym fauored conqueryng region vanquishyng battailes yet thyng honorable hym profitable realme good peace whiche pleaseth bothe god man cause shewed kyng iames fifth nephew felowe kyng englande sent ambassador entreate peace couenient mariage might made betwene hym lady mary daughter kyng whiche lincke necessary knit together realme scotlande england perpetuall loue amitie whiche oracion bishop london docter tunstal answered saied kyng desire content haue peace vpon reasonable condicions touchy g mariage daughter would answere theim thei bee contented kyng rose place welcomed theim honest persones train communicacion thei tooke leaue tyme toke barge came london feast christmas lorde leonard grey lorde ihon grey brethre marque dorcet sir george cobham sonne lorde cobham willyam cary sir ihon dudley thomas wiat france pointz france sidney sir anthony broune sir edward seimour oliuer manner perciuall harte sebastian nudigate thomas calen esquire kynges housholde enterprised chalenge feactes armes feast christmas wherefore thei sent wyndsore herault sainct th ma daie christmas quenes great chamber kyng beyng present whiche herault coate armes red silke beaten goodly castle foure turrettes siluer euery turret faire lady standyng gorgiously appareled herault trumpet blowen saied kyng souereigne lorde bountifull goodnes hath geuen foure maiden court castle loyaltie dispose pleasure thesaied maiden haue geuen custodie therof capitain fiftene gentleman hym whiche capitain sent furthe herault called chasteau blanche declare kynges prince gentleman noble corage thesaied capitain nere castle aise mount whiche shall stande unicorne supportyng foure faire shildes firste shilde shalbe white whosoeuer toucheth shelde shalbe answered sixe course tilt castle hostyng harnes double peces second shilde red betokenyng turnay whosoeuer toucheth shild shalbe answered tenne stroke turnay sworde edge poynt abated third shild yelow signifiyng barrier toucheth shilde shalbee answered twelue stroke barrier sworde edge poynt abated fourth shilde blewe betokenyng assaulte suche wepons capitain castle shal occupie morrice pike sworde target poynt edge abated also thesaied capitain compaignie promise defend thesaid castle commers beeyng gentleman name armes assaulter deuise maner engynes assaultyng edge tole breake house ground onely except also weapon shalbe vsed suche patron shalbe sette vp thesaied unicorne manne medle fire within without match gonne euery prisoner taken either partie paye raunsom iiii yardes right satten euery capitain xiii yardes accordyng proclamacion mounte thynges deuised sumpteously greate craggy braunche whiche wer ha ged shildes armes capitain castle enterprise set vp tilte yard grenewiche castle square euery waie xx foote fiftie foote heigh strong great timber well fastened yron embatelinentes loupe euery place men entre wer set greate rolles turned assone thei wer touched semyng man could entre tower embatilmentes north southe side twoo greate diches xv foote depe brynke botome thei stepe betwene diche castle set pale whiche rampaired yearth stepe thicke likely gotten diches twoo drawe bridge weste side greate rampire banke stepe without within like vamure fortresse vamure diches wer xxiiii fote depe strength castle wel beholden many made dangerous assault saied could wonne sporte ernest kyng mynded haue assaulted deuised engins therfore carpenter wer dull thei vnderstode intent wrought thyng contrary tyme assaulte prolonged poyntes chalenge held morow sainct ihon euangelistes daie christmas came castle sixe men armes castle horsebacke armed al poyntes speres ready discharge came ende tilt abidyng commers sodainly entered feld twoo lady twoo palfreis greate robe purple damaske leadyng two ancient knightes beardes siluer thesame apparell thei came quene thei put vp bill effect whereof although youth lefte age come would lette theim doo feactes armes yet courage desire good abode theim bad theim take vpon theim breake speres whiche thei would gladly doo pleased geue theim license quene lady seen bill thei praised corage gaue license knightes threw awaie robe knowen kyng duke suffolk whose bardes base golde embraudered purple siluer blacke curiously folowed erle deuonshire lorde montacute lorde roos sir nicholas carewe sir france brian henry norreis anthony kneuet fiue euery man ran eight course whiche course kyng brake seuen speres euery man day well scottes muche preised men armes englande moste thei preised marueiled kynges strength thei saw speres wer broke force speres wer course wer roune kyng disarmed went supper supper kyng hauyng hym ambassador scotlande came quenes chamber lordes diuerse lady daunced came maske xvi appareled clothe golde riche tynsell crimosyn veluet cut slit tied curiously buskin shoen wer golde cappes whoddes gold riche counterfeted nomber kyng duke suffolke wer twoo kers toke lady daunsed greate season doen brought wyne spice straungiers well cherished conueighed toward lodgyng thei went thei asked gentlema whiche accompaignied warre tyme kyng lordes wer mery suche ioyous pastyme kepte suche royall housholde well appareled countrey thei saied tyme warre nothyng wailyng mournyng also thei thought realme fraunce realme sport maske gentleman answered kyng courte vsed theim still warre tyme thei dooe thei set frenche kyng one bene kyng england maie sit chaire dammage frenche kyng lordes cominaltie england praie continuance warre warres fraunce thei wynne lese whiche saiyng scottes muche mused fridaie xxx daie december therle castels one scottishe ambassador toke leaue departed toward scotlande common counsaill scotlande thynges whiche commission left behynd hym bishoppe dunkell abbot campskenell saied tharticle scottes forsake frenche kyng kyng scottes come englande whatsoeuer euery man knewe second daie ianuary muche talkyng assault castle long debate sir france brian france poynt enterprised defende weste braie castle pike target nd sworde poynt edge abated sir george cobham george harbert ihon poyntz willyam kneuet thei armed trumpettes blewe toward braie marched foure gentleman pike swordes cried harr harr foynyng lasshyng strikyng thei within fought mightely without clymed vp banke thei within bet doune thei within sometyme beten doune almo e surely thei fought valiantly thei seased began assaulte george harbert willyam kneuet hel e theim twoo within hard thei could scant put heddes ouer braye bulwerke thei twoo thus still fought twoo felowes sir george cobham ihon poyntz swordes digged hole banke clyme vp thei dooen twoo compaignions fought brethe sir france brian france poyntz fought two digged came thother twoo brethed themselfes ierce fight ihon poyntz gat footyng bancke aboue toke holde pa e fought hande hande france poyntz brother euer george harbert susteined hym banke pike sir edward cobham gat banke fought hardely la ouerthrowen vp gat coragiously gat pale thei twoo within fought valiauntly thei wer ouer matched ei fought pale without aide felowes gatte ouer pale battail ended thynke neuer battaill pleasure better fought next daie another fight foure eight sore oughten last braye taken combates disarmed sodainly young persones without threwe stone within ca le thei theim many honest men whiche threwe wer hurt muche pein thei without wer apeised knewe hurlyng began fifth daie ianuary knightes castle came ba er abide al men thether came kyng many lordes gentleman daie castle deliuered lviii gentleman lviii battailes fought valiantly kyng hymself fought coragiou eight daie february ge tlemen castle folowyng chalenge came feld eady commers turnay came kyng base bard wer cloth siluer blacke veluet ruffed plain ouer worke purple veluet embraudered richely golde cutte knottes ol e fa ened bossed frounced stately behold kyng came xix richely appareled kyng sir anthony broune turnaied together kyng sword poynt edge abated almoste cut poldron stroke greate euery man turnaied course came many sworde broken many good stripe geuen euery man striken full nomber twelue stroke thei wer seuered thei disarmed monethe cardinall legate power legantyne would haue visited frier obseruauntesthe obseruaunt frie would obeye cardinall thei nowise would therein condiscende wherefore xix thesame religion accursed paules crosse one thesame religion called frier forest frier forest ye shall thirtie yere kyng season frenche kyng italy nobilitie hym millain yelded pestilence would entre departed laied siege strong toune pauia wherof capitain valiat spanyard called anthony de leua freche kynges mother beyng regent fraunce perceiuyng king soonne good capitaines italy doubted kyng englande nexte spryng tyme would inuade fraunce wherfore auice counsaill frauce muche kyng england stuard houshold called ihon iokin saueconduit come englande whiche kept close house docter larke prebendary sainct steuens euery daie priuely spake cardinall secretly remained til xxiiii daie ianuary whiche daie came london president roan called monsire brynyon ambassador france french kyng lodged ihon iokyn ihon iokyn kepte priuie man knowe manne fraunce sollicite cause frenche kyng whiche grewe greate trouble shewed hymself straungiers whiche fauored frenche partie last openly knowen kynges counsaill almoste men emperor ambassador knewe darke dealyng mused litle saied cardinall driue priuie driftes meanes onley ihon iokyn come englande entreate peace secret maner kynges frendes might knowe al people saied ihon iokyn cast awaie ieane liuyng liue lady regent marueiled kept close muche cherished cardinall kepyng close iokyn englishemen wer rebuked marte flaunders brabant emperor ambassador bishop rome ambassador also sore murmured ihon iokyn bee kept spirite close consideryng open warre betwene twoo kynges feared kynges counsaill corrupt ihon iokyn muche cardinall neuer seen kyng counsaill secretnes monsire pratt themperors ambassadour knewe offer made peace whiche deede wer greate offered pencions diuerse young aboute kyng whiche wer glad noyse reson suche offer ran peace likely ensue shorte space monsire pratt wrote matter hast emperor whiche letter highly commended kyng england stedfastnes said kynges counsaill loued neither emperour kyng englande wrote hym farther maner ye secret kepyng iho iokyn letter last wer brought cardinall chaunce openly knowen sent monsire pratt declared hym matter whiche answered hym counsailer ambassador emperour parte assertein emperor euery thyng might sound preiudicial maiestie howsoeuer answere taken fauored cardinall saied openly well ment emperor stop packet letter open spanyardes saied emperor sent englande slepe hym seruice bishop rome ambassador wrote master peace likely bee concluded betwene englande fraunce willed hym bee firste frende frenche kyng rather seconde whiche writyng came harme shall heare moneth tidynges came kyng howe marque piscaire italy gotten frenche kyng castle called castle angell whiche greate fortificacion siege pauie monethe flemyng heddyng castle whiche came often tymes sainct omers promised thei would come heddyng would deliuer castle vpon worde thei saincte omerstreason heddyng ca le gathered together seuen hundred footemen fiue hundred horseman poynted spie fourthe daie february thei would come thether whe false knaue knewe daie told monsire pontdormie capitain heddyng whiche incontment filled castle men warre laied busshementes euery side laied ordinaunce one side castle waie flemynges come men warre sainct omers conueighed spie mistrustyng nothyng posterne litle vsed many frenchemen thought sufficient thei let fall portcolis monsire pontdromie cried slaie slaie flemynges wist thei wer betraied put selfes fight liues seyng monsire pontdromie comau ded fire ordinaunce suche haste fury flame greate fierce brent thesaied lorde pontdromie xxvii compaignions gentleman trayne hastely fiered thei leasure auoyde fight tenne flemynges slain thirtie kept theselfes hardely together liues graunted taken prisoner remnant entred lept ouer castle wal saued themselfes told newes horsmen whiche wer without whiche hearyng mischaunce returned toward sainct omers sundaie fifth daie marcheambassadors flauders wer receiued london monsire de beuer lorde camphere admirall flaunders president malynes called master ihon de la coo master ihon de la gache ambassador lady margaret name emperor cause lowe countreis brabant flaunders zelande tewesdaie thei wer brought kyng bridewell whiche nobely theim enterteined thei shewed themperors maiestie commaunded theim obey kyng england protertor gouernor wherfore thei wer comaundement thei doen wise obeyed hym gouernor thei asked hym mercy kyng thei talked together secretly thei departed ambassador demauded thre thynges first thei demaunded ladie mary kynges onely daughter deliuered theim hande named emprise take possession lowe countreis gouernor thesame article agreed cause also suche somme money kyng geue mariage dower made paied incontinet article also denied thirdly kyng englande hymself passe sea made warre fraunce nexte sommer kyng saied would take auisement thursday ix daie marche vii clocke mornyng came gentleman poste lady margaret gouernesse flauders brought letter shewyng xxiiii daie february siege pauia frenche kyng lien long raised force battaill frenche kyng hymself take prisoner duke burbon uiceroy naples called myngnouale marque piscaire emperor capitaines whole power fraunce discomfited duke albany seuen thousande men goyng naples bishop rome become french emperor sent cosyn aide freche kyng great power thesame daie president roan ihon iokyn wer goyng court thei yet spoke kyng holburne way tidynges brought takyng kyng master losse feld whiche hearyng misauenture returned lodgyng sorowfull within shorte space returned regent frauce thought surely kyng england would haue peace frenche kyng chaunce happened people englande grudged flaunders euill entreatyng tyme warre also kyng displeased theim enhaunsyng coyne whiche cause money daily conueighed realme many cause grudge xi daie marchea triumph takyng frenche kyng london tydynges wer made greate iers triumph maior alderman road citee trumpettes yne laied diuerse place citee euery man might tower hill ambassadours rome flaunders greate ba ket made goodly ent whiche pleased theim thei returned homewarde stretes full harnessed men cressettes attendyng constable whiche thei preised muche sondaie xii marche kyng accompaignied ambassador rome emperor scotland uenice millain florence road estate paules churche cardinall sang masse xi prelate waited hym pontificalles masse doen quere sang te deum mynstrelles plaied euery side doen kyng returned bride well kept solempne dinner bishop scotland muche marked daie whensoeuer came court time apparell sumpteous whodde euer veluet crimosyn satyn takyng frenche kyng ware onely blacke chamlet whiche token men iudged frenche harte ix daie marche xvi daie kyng mo letter maner battaill pauie daie receiued letter duke burbon gentleman called gropayne kyng redde letterthe true report takyng fr che kyng came quenes chamber thesaied gropayne declared maner siege wel planted themperors men entered frenche campe force threwe doune bastiles fought frenchman within campe tooke kyng prisoner thesame many whiche maruell frenche kyng entered italy gard xic men speres furnished twoo miicl light horseman eight hundred xx footemen lviim duke albany eight thousande remayned frenche kyng xlixmixc fiftie men wherof taken xiiiim mo beside greate rich goodly ordinance whiche xii greate bombardes brasse xxiiii greate canon peces xxiiii double curtalles foure double canon peces twoo middle canon peces eight peces feld doen french kyng put custodie uiceroy naples whiche muche comforted hym preised valiauntnes praied hym content haue gentle ende desired write mother whiche hym graunted wordes wer aduertise infortunate chaunce nothyng left honor life saued newes shall recomforte haue desired write letter whiche liberally hath graunted besechyng regard extremitie self ensuyng accustomed wisedome hope length god forget recommendyng litle en ante myne suppliyng geue saueconduite passe returne spain berar goeth toward emperor knowe wise shalbe intreated thus right hubly good grace haue recommended subscribed humble obedient sonne france season cardinal beyng kynges fauorthe cardinal f rst bega suppresse bbeies obteined licece make college oxford another ipswyche would geue landes thesaid college obteined bishop rome licese suppresse put doune diuerse abbayes priory monastery nomber wherfore sodainly entered comissioners thesaied house put religious tooke goodes moueables scarcely gaue ton poore wretch thyng except wer heddes house caused thexcheter sit finde house voyde relynquished founde kyng founder men wer founder landes endewed college whiche bega sumpteous scholers proude euery persone iudged thende would good shall heare fiue yeres hereafter erle castelles whiche sent scotlandethe scotte returned scotlande returned england xix daie marche frenche kyng taken commission moste part determined al compaignie toke leaue kyng without reward returned scotlande fourth daie aprill monethe marche kyng sent cutberd tunstall bishop london sir richard wyngfeld chanceller duchy lancastre knight gartier spain emperour greate cause concernyng takyng frenche kyng especiall warres made frauce euery side kyng england counsaill wer agreed determined thesame moneth ambassador departed flaunders counsaill remembryng determined kyng proper persone passe sea thei considered aboue thynges greate threasure plentie money must nedes readines wherefore cardinall deuised strange commissionscommissios sent ende marche euery shire commissioner appoynted whiche wer greatest men euery shire priuie instruccions sent theim saie ordre people tenor sixt part euery mannes substaunce without delaie bee payed money plate kyng furniture warre wherefore cardinal chief commissioner london sent sir willyam bayly knightthe proposicio cardinall maior citee alderman diuerse hedde comminers saied maner folowyng kynges welbeloued frendes subiectes citee lodon must declare kyng contrary awne mynd compelled ie force determined entre new war explanacion truthe shall vnderstande france frenche kyng obteigned croune scepter realme fraunce moste humbly sued kyng master peace loue amitie promisyng vpon euange e kepe league concluded also paie lady mary quene dowager fraunce due pencion doware graunted kyng lewes husbande ambassador humbly desired citee turnay whiche kyng lewes tyme loste kyng whiche would citee turnay bee cause grudge betwene hym frenche kyng consented certaine somme money deliuered farther bynd amitie betwene theim kyng content communicacion mariage betwene dolphyn fraunce ladie marie prince englande yet entreate loue familiaritie acquaintance kyng greate cost charge passed sea met persone frenche kyng thynkyng reason personall sight actuall communicacion stable ferme loue growe betwene writyng whiche time vndoubtedly thought could loue knit betwene two persones couenauntes amde sworne kyng master saied frenche kyngthe saiyng kyng englande brother knit require kepe ferme peace amitie nephewe themperor also suffre duke ihon albany go scotlande puttyng young kyng nephewe ieoperdie persone wherefore loue men especiall kepe two article obserue article couenauntes betwene v agreed assure neuer prince surer frende shall haue methe othe french kyng frenche kyng aied hande ine said cardinal sware othe kyng would obserue kepe fermely poyntes many mo kynges departed emperoure come kyng calice frenche kyng sent monsire de la roche ba letter declaryng perfecte league amitie emperor withstandyng within lesse space halfe yere sent robert de la marche inuade emperor lande made warre neuert place kyng ouer master hearyng mere charitie sent noble greate trayne calice knowe warr began promised enemie hym brake firste whiche place came frenche kyng chanceller monsire de la palice many noble menne emperor came chanceller lorde cheuers open counsaill emperor ambassador shewe frenche kynges letter signed sealed whiche enforced began warre whiche poynte frenche ambassadours could answere saie warre open bothe party sent frenche kyng ambassador entreate peace nowise would concet wherfore compaignie returned meane season although doubted nothyng frenche kynges faithe towarde master yet suertie obteigned saueconduit englishe merchauntes thei go burdeaux vpon suertie merchantes passed yet contrary saucconduit toke merchantes goodes put body prison whiche turke would haue doen kyng sent gentely hym herault clarenseux desiryng hym redresse enormity paie hym somme money due hym quene sister dower whiche doo refused denied whiche thynges knowe kyng honor might suffre wherfore mightely hath three yeres kept warre continually bothe lande sea inuaded fraunce two army royall bet tounes castle fortress destroyed people passed water somme proffered battaill frenchemen awne countrey hath brought countrey suche penury wretchednes many yeres recouered hurt damage french kyng kyng hath wage duke burbon whiche greatest strengthe frenche part whose power aide whiche great somme money kyng master frenche kyng persone taken noble effect pauia kept prisoner emperor kyng master greate reaso master sent sir gregory de cassado ambassador uiceioy naples duke burbon marque piscaire hundred thousand crounes thei would fight frenche kyng whiche money thei assented gaue b ttaill whiche thei slewe xii thousande men drouned vii thousande xiii thousande taken prisoner sithe god hath geue v victory kyng remembryng saiyng poet saieth mastery vse victorie gotten get thynketh necessarie hast make armie royall person passe sea recouer right inheritance bothe croune frauce normandie guyen gascone aniowe mayne writynges whereof comprehendyng title maie se present ye list doubt knowe well inough aske questio whether thynke couenient kyng passe armie kyng doo thauise subieetes whiche many saied yea yea wel said cardinalthe cardinal demaud must made able go like prince whiche cannot without aide shewe archbishoppe cantorbury whiche bee primate realme haue doen haue geuen landes landes apperteignyng churche third parte nd temporall lordes haue geuen landes goodes sixt parte opa body pain trauaill sithe thei whiche shall life doth profer sixt part thei geu whiche abide home soth thinke halfe sub aunce litle meanyng kyng asketh demaundeth onely fi ie sixt part vpon euery l aboue fiftie l soeuer amounte sixt part iii iiii l xx l fiftie pounde vpward ii viii pounde xx pounde xx xii pounde leuied accordyng first valuacion appereth awne valuacion whiche small matter thing meant thei beyng astonied last one said lord sithe last valuacion diuerse merchantes decaied sea suertiship way valuacion cannot bee answered cardinall sers speake breake thyng concluded shal paie tenth parte wer better suffre digence kyng tyme lacke therefore beware ist ruffill case maie fortune cost heddesthe cardinalles ea nynges speke kyng bee good go ouer sea persone shall haue money redeliuered firste let money bee gathered laie kyng nede maie take cardinall thus perswaded maior brethe hedde cominers thei toke leaue euery daie space fortenight sent certain nomber comyners told like tale spake suche woordes hym goyng hym thei sent ward commissioner sent clergiethe saiyng clergie fourthe parte landes moueables euery alsembly priestes answered thei would paie nothyng except graunted conuocacion wise thei saied neuer kyng england aske mannes goodes ordre lawe commission ordre lawe wherefore thei saied cardinall doer thereof enemy kyng common wealthe infamie spoken preachynges euery matter opened englandethe grudoe commo people howe greate men toke maruell poore curssed riche repugned light wittes railed conclusion people curssed cardinall coadherentes subuersor lawes libertie englande thei saied men geue goodes commission wer worse tax fraunce england bond free happened redyng barkeshire commissioner satte money graunted people wise would consent sixt parte awne mere mynde loue thei bare kyng thei graunted twe neth parte xx pounde commissioner hearyng said thei would sende cardinal desiryng hym content offre lord li e wrote letter six richard weston would beare letter request gentleman coutrey thesaid sir richard toke vpo cary road cardinall whiche therewith sore greued said lorde liue wrote matter communed concluded cost lorde lille hedde landes solde paie kyng value hym fo ishe commissioner lost liues kynges wordes sore astonied sir richard westo said litle cardinall wrote letter l commissioner realme thei kepe first in ru cio wise swarue one iote vpon pain liues euery man valued accordyng valuacion taken xiiii yere la e poynte sore touched citee london cardinall xiiii yere sent one docter tune secret chapelein chapter house paules pron yng londoner whatsoeuer thei valued themselfes man knowe kyng cardinall vpon whiche promesse many persones credite higher estemed valued theimselfes greater substaunce thei worthe thynkyng neuer lende paie confession loane subsidie paied accordyng men sessed ma er tune boke whe men valued theselfes knowyng uccede tyme subtile valuacion laied charge whiche thei perceiued thei murmured muche said thei would paie nothyng except kynges lawes vnder whiche thei borne determined notwithstandyng commissioner went euery shire leuie thesaied money could perswaded saied lied flatered maunde could bee assented saiyngthe people thei sent furthe suche commissioner subuerters lawe worthy bee punished traytors realme billes set vp al place billes sai kyng paied borowed saied subsedy amounted treble bestowed saied whatsoeuer grau ted good came said cardinall sent al money rome thus mutteryng realme curse wepynges pitie beholde duryng season commissioner sat bishop london kynges ambassador abidyng wynde saile spain emperor haue hard rehersed mon ire pratt emperours
