ambassadour whiche sore angrie ihon iokyns commyng englande haue harde departed priuely realme englande ix daie aprill without speakyng kyng cardinall muche saueconduite passed fraunce poste came emperor ambassadours englande came thether whether report otherwise accustomed fauor themperor counsaill shewed englishemen began decaie shewe theimselfes vnkynde englishe nacion without cause shall perceiue yere kyng folowing haukethe ieoperdy liyng lept ouer diche beside hychyn polle polle brake one edmond mody foteman lept water lift vp hed whiche fast clay drouned god goodnes preserued yere whitsontyde died thomas duke norffolke honorably buried ford suffolke pthe xvii yere beginnyng xvii yerethe xvii yere commissioner shire satte leuie sixt parte euery mannes goodes burden greuous de ied commos euery place moued like haue growen rebellion mischief shewed kyng saied neuer knewe demaunde therefore greate diligence sent letter citee london place whiche kyng gentely wrote would demaude certain suche louyng subiectes would graunt hym good mindes toward maintenaunce warres wherfore cardinal twentie sixe daie aprill sent maior london alderman counsail moste sub anciall persones common counsail thei come place westminster saied kyng louereigne lorde moste graciously considereth greate loue zeale obe ience beare vnto hym like louyng subiectes without grudge againsaie louyng myndes haue graunted sixt parte youre goodes substaunce frely bee p ed accordyng firste valuacion whiche louyng graunt good mynde kyndly accepted maruell le sel cosider great loss charge daily hath doth grow notwithstandyng losse charge happeneth yet neuer withstoode againsai kynges demaundes commission appereth late whiche dooyngesthe saiyng cardinal lo doners haue highly kyng enformed whiche gaue hartie thakes kneled doune grace shewyng hym bothe good myndes towarde hym also charge continuelly sustein whiche desire peticion content call abrogate thesame commission reason awne grau te might haue demaunded thesaied somme verie debte yet content release pardon thesame wil nothyng take beneuolence wherfore take kynges letter let redde common doubt gladly louyng subiectes note cardinall said kyng released pardoned first demaunde citezens would haue answered cardinall thei neuer made suche graunt suretie thei thei helde peace departed toward london sore grudgyng liyng cardinal openly saiyng verie cause occasio demaunde would plucke people harte kyng xxviii daie aprillthe common counsaill common counsaill citee redde kynges letter accordyng effect aboue rehersed wherfore citizen sent foure alderman xii cominers hampton courte geue thankes lorde cardinall whiche busines saied could speake hym wherefore thei returned content euery alderman assembled ward place accustomed gentely moued beneuolence graunted kyng thei openly denied saiyng thei paied inough many euill wordes viii daie maie cardinall sent maior brother whiche shewed thei doen saied cardinall haue suche commission examyn man youre commissioner examyne one one self shall knowe good wil beare prince aske beneuolence name answered cardinall counsailer citee lawe might suche beneuolece asked men examined contrary statute made first yere kyng richarde thirde also persones commyng grace maie feare graunt day life thei shall repent wynne fauor graunt thei bee able paie awne ronne mennes debtes dredfull gladnes fearefull boldnes men shall master themselfes menne dismaied shall graunt wife child shall sore rewe cardinall hard saiyng verie paciently answered sir maruell speake richard third whiche vsurper murtherer awne nephewes euill man actes good make suche allegacions actes honorable please grace said cou sailer although euill yet tyme wer many good actes made hym onely consent body whole realme whiche parliament sir willyam bayly lorde maior kneled doune besought grace sithe enacted common counsaill london euery alderman sit awne ward beneuolence grauted whiche perceiued lawe thesame acte thesame common counsall might reuoked otherwise well saied cardinall content entre kynges commission maior master alderman geue lorde saied maior praie pardo entre graunt might fortune cost life life saied cardinall maruelous worde toward kyng citezens put ieoperdy life w straunge thei would waie must kyng come rog power oppresse wherfore speake suche wordesthe flatteryng cardinall studied litle saied lorde maior let citezens greued thyng demaunde humbly good fashio come shall entreate shalbe content displeasure arise praie pou shewe neighbor maior daie departed maior wisely assent graunt thyng although alderman assented common counsaill would neuer haue assented next morowe declared common cousaill act made euery alderman sit beneuolence graunted statute lawe wherevpon thesaid act anulled declared euery man come cardinall graut priuily would saiyng citezens wer sore greued maior gentely shewed durst warrant thei bee entreated gentely exhorted theim go thether thei sent whiche saiyng nothyng pleased theim furie thei would haue richarde gresham ihon hewster mercer richarde gibson seriant armes merchant tailor banished common counsail without answere made thei would thei departed home thesame season realme demaunde vtterly de ed commissioner could bryng nothyng passe yet thei assaied bothe faire way ou e ome spake faire flatered spake cruell threatened yet could bryng purpose aboute kent lorde cobham commissioner han led men roughly reason one iho udder answered hym ubbishly sent hym tower london whiche dooyng people muttered grudged lorde cobham saied expre thei would paie money thei began accopt loanes sub edies graunted thei reken kynges tresure innumerable thei accompted kyng take realme twentie fiftenes sithe xiiii yere reigne grudge thei euill entreated sir thomas bullein maidestone essex people would assemble commissioner house open place huntyngdon shire diuerse resisted commissioner sitinsu eccion suffolke whiche wer apprehended sent fl te duke suffolke sat suffolke season like commission gentle handlyng caused riche clothier assent graunt geue sixt parte thei came home house thei called spinner carders fuller weuers tificers whiche wont set woorke haue liuynges cloth makyng saied sir able set woorke goodes taken v wherefore trust selfes v otherwise wil began woman wepe young folkes crie men woorke began rage assemble theimselfes compaignies duke suffolke hearyng commaunded constable euery mannes harnes taken knowen rumor waxed greater people railed openly duke suffolke sir robert dru ie threatened death cardinall also lanam sudbery hadley ounes aboute rebelled foure thousande men put theimselfes harnes ang belle alarme began togather still duke suffolke perceiuyng began reise men could gette small nombre thei came hym saied thei would defende hym pe illes hurte neighbor neighbor thei would fight yet gentleman duke muche al bridge wer broken assemble letted duke norffolke high threasorer admirall englande hearyng gathered greate power norffolke came towarde common noblenes sent comons knowe intent answered thei would liue dye kynges cause kyng obedient duke wist came al spake wist thei meant asked capitain bad speke well aged manne fiftie yeres aboue asked licence duke speake whiche grauted good lorde saied man whose name ihon grene si aske capitain soth name pouertie cosyn necessitie hath brought v dooyng persones many mo whiche would liue selfes wee liue substanciall occupier countrey yet thei geue v litle wage workmaship scacely able liue thus penurie passe tyme wife childre thei liue brought case thei litle cannot helpe v earne liuyng must perishe dye miserably speke lorde cloth maker haue put people farre greater nomber fro worke husbande men haue put awaie seruauntes geuen vp houshold thei say kyng asketh muche thei able thei haue doen tyme necessitie must dye wretchedly wherfore lorde accordyng wisedom consider necessitie duke sory heare complaint well knewe true saied neighbor seuer selfes sonder let euery man depart home chose furthe foure shall answer remnant honor send kyng make hu ble intercession pardon whiche truste obtein depart al thei answered thei would thei departed home twoo duke requestes commissioner great aucthoritie wer sent theim duke norffolke duke suffolke came bery thether came many people countrey shirtes halter neckes mekely desiryng pardon offence duke wisely handeled themselfes common wer ppeised especiall one master iermyn toke muche pain ridyng goyng betwene lordes common demaunde money seased realme well perceiued common would none paie twoo duke came london brought theim chief capitaines rebellio whiche wer put flete kyng came westminster cardinal place wherupon matterthe sore wodes kyng assembled great counsaill openly said mynd neuer aske thyng common whiche might sounde dishonor breche lawes wherfore would knowe long commission straight demaunde sixt parte euery mannes substauncethe cardinal cardinall excused hymself saied moued counsaill make kyng kynges counsaill especially iudges aied might lawfully demaunde commission assent whole counsaill dooen toke god witnes neuer maligned desired hynderance common like true counsailer deuised enriche kyng spirituall men saie standeth goddes lawe ioseph caused kyng egip e take fifth parte euery mannes goodes euery manne laieth burden hym cotent take endure noyes people good wil toward kyng comfort lordes kynges counsailers eternall god knoweth well said kyng haue enformed realme neuer riche neuer trouble haue risen demaunde men would pay first request finde contrary euery man helde peace kyng sore mouedthe kyng sore moued subiectes stirred also enformed deniall spirituall men made saiynges wherefore thought touched honoure counsaill attempt suche doubtfull matter name bee denied bothe spiritualtie temporaltie although graunted feare commissioner yet thei wer departed thei denied kyng saied trouble let letter bee sent shire matter maie bee spoken ofthe pardon greate demaunde pardon theim haue denied demaunde openly secretly lordes kn l doune hartely thanked kyng letter sent commissioner cease instruccions declare kynges pardon whiche declaracion shewed cardinal neuer assented first demaunde instruccions comprehended lordes iudges kynges counsaill diuised thesame demaunde cardinall folowed mynd whole counsaill two poyn e contrary one another whiche well marked farther instruccions humble peticion suppli acion cardinall thesaied greate somme whiche demaunded kynges auchoritie royall wer clerely pardoned remitted wherefore commissioner willed people praie cardinall people toke mocke saied god saue kyng cardinall knowen well inough common would heare praise spoken cardinall thei hated hym muche xix daie maiethe saiyng maio london cardinall sent maior brother certain comminers made maior doune hym declared kyng determined proper perso passe sea fraunce whiche cause asked citezens london subiectes aide toward charge whiche request saied londoner wer tymes conformable like louyng subiectes sithe kyng considereth greate fall frenche kyng whiche yet prisoner daily hath suite made hym peace greatly honor profite trust right title shalbe hym deliuered thyng agreed truste shall haue peace therefore request kyng hath pardoned me money demaunded grace passed sea although money gathered surely haue restored co sequently kyng thanketh ha tely prince maie thanke subiectes asmuche peace yet concluded counsail shewe selfes enemy frenchman saie kyngesthe prea e fea e cardinall bodie goodes pleasure youre louyng myndes towardes hym maie frenchman appere wot well meane saied cardinall maior compaignie kneled doun moste hattely thaked kyng hym departed next daie rehersed comon counsail whiche humbly thanked kyng pardon twoo thynges sore displeased one cardinall bad theim saie thei kynges body goodes thei saied thei vsed dissimulacion thei would saie thei kynges thei thought kynges deede saiyng seconde cardinall excused hymself ignorant first comission thei knewe wer present made first mo ion whatsoeuer saied recorder excuse take cloke rain ssimulacion mocke wisemen perceiued handelyng matter kyng pardoned euery offendour xxix daie maie lordes sat starre chamber wer brought one deuereux gentleman huntyngdo shire whiche would suffre commissioner sit haue hard ihon scudder kent twoo wer brought tower bare footed shirtes london starre chamber cardinall shewed theim offence terrible woordes shewed kynges mercie extended declared pardon thei wer deliuered morowe beyng xxx daie wer chief rebelles suffolke brought starre chamber barre kynges counsaill learned laied sore theim offence cardinall declared kynges pardon kynges attorney asked suertie good aberyng thei answered thei could finde none saied cardinall one countrey men lorde norffolke bee another thei discharged money bryng home ende commissio ende inward grudge hatered common bare cardinall gentleman whiche vehemetly set furth commission demaunde troubelous season vplandishe men germany called bowres ose greate nomber almoste hundred thousande rebelled prince germany whiche great nomber wer slain destroyed aprill last past tyndale men aide scottes nober eight hundred daily greate robe y englande represse nest theues wer sent sir richard bulmer sir cristopher da re greate compaignie englishman diuerse men came submitted themselfes greate theues kept moutaignes cheuiot daily sk rmished englishemen could sone taken long liyng abrode thei seuered many wer taken verie season frenchemen kept greate nomber men warre bullein aboute v daie maie foure hundred horseman embushed theimselfes forest guysnes daie lxxx horseman crewe guysnes roade furthe sekyng auentures frenchemen let theim passe till thei theim auauntage thei issued cried kill kill englishemen valiauntly defended almoste twoo houres last frenchemen oppressed theim multitude brake arraye slewe fiftie remnant saued themselfes chaunce nothyng pleasant englishe capitaines frenchemen wer su mounted iorney xx daie maie men warre garrison picardy assembled together came within english pale aunderne calice frenchemen wer suche nombre englishe pale spred ouer baiyngham frenchemen draue awaie cattell englishemen thought theselfes weke encounter whiche whole strength picardy assension daie came newnam bridge thr e hundred horseman set stale ordinaunce thei made go backe came foure hundred french en turne pike thei gotten cattell together bend sir robert iernyngham seyng frenchemen nere calice set forward past lx horseman thei fiersly set frenchemen whiche fledde thei chased reskued cattell frenchemen taken greate difficultie brought marshe beside calice xxviii daie maie vc horseman xvic footemen came village called froyton within englishe pale many auentured ouer water haue taken cattell marrishes hamnes guysnes calice whiche greate nomber frenchemen made auenture night wer askried al saue two frenchemen returned great furie sware thei would robbe marri el thei would dye returned bullein whether come newe fiue c horsmen called stradiats whiche fortified wel frenche party muche thei passed nomber fiue tymes englishman haue hard beforeriot ac beggam cardinall suppressed many monastery whiche one called beggam sussex whiche verie commodious countrey befell cause riotus compaignie disguysed vnknowen painted face visures came thesame monasterie brought chanons put place promised theim whensoeuer thei rang bell thei would come great power defende doyng came eare kynges counsail whiche caused chanons taken thei confessed capitaines whiche wer emprisoned sore punished cardinall aboute season power legantyne sent chappelein called doctor ihon alein man learnyng vertue good conscience visite place religious priest roade goune veluet greate trayne receiued euery religion procession though legate toke suche greate somme visitacion religious sore greued murmured muche especiall thei charged greate somme money kyng sodain visitacion predacionpredation robbery cleane shaued common people spake muche also thei saied cardinall uisitacions makyng abbottes probate testamentes grauntyng faculty liceses pollynges courtes legantines made threasore egall kynges yet euery yere sent greate somme rome communicacion euer cardinall high aucthoritie spirituall men moste disdained shall vnderstande kyng freshe youth cheynes loue faire damosell called elizabeth blount daughter sir ihon blunt knight whiche damosell syngyng daunsyng goodly pastymes exceded whiche goodly pastymes wan kynges harte shewed hym suche fauour hym bare goodly manne child beautie like father mother child well brought vp like prince child whe vi yere age kyng made hym knight called hym lorde henry fitz roy sondaie beyng xviii daie iune manor place bridewell thesaied lorde ledde twoo erles created erle notyngha brought backe thesaied twoo erles duke norffolke suffolk led hym great chamber kyng created hym duke richemond somersetthe creacion duke richemond thesame daie lorde henry courtenay erle deuonshire cosyn germain kyng created marque excester lorde henry brandon sonne duke suffolke frenche quene kynges sister childe twoo yere old created erle lincolne sir thomas manner lord roos created erle rutlande sir henry clifford created erle cumberlande lorde fitz water sir robert radclif created uiscount fitz water sir thomas bullein threasorer kynges houshold created uiscount rocheforde creacions wer kept greate feastes disguisynges cardinall toke vpon kynges chief counsailer e reformacion ordre kynges houshode wherein made certain ordinaunces also made newe officer house duke richemond whiche newly begon also tyme ordeined cousaill stablished another houshold ladie mary beyng prince realme thyng en doen hym without assent nothyng doen tooke muche vpon hym made kyng beleue thynges honor neded take pain hym charge thynges committed whiche wise menne becked light men laughed thynkyng great foly high presupcion tyme thesaied cardinall gaue kyng lease manor hampton court whiche lease lord sainct ihones whiche doen greate coste therefore kyng getle nature licensed hym lie manor richemod pleasure laie certain tymes common people especiall suche kyng henry seuethes seruauntes sawe cardinal kepe house manor royal richmond whiche kyng henry seuenth highly estemed maruell thei grudged saied see bochers dogge lye manor richemond many approbrious wordes spoken cardinall whose pride high nothyng regarded yet hated moste men season frenche kynges mother regent fraunce three estate realme assembled together concernyng estate realme first thei sent solepne ambassador themperor article thei thought resonable ye deliuerauce frech kyng also peace thei sent also messenger kyng englande saueconduite ambassadour sent englande treatie peace whiche messenger graunted diliuered came ouer ambassadour fraunce ihon iokyn called monsire de uaux whiche haue hard last yere kept secret master larkes house came englande welcomed cardinall betwene theim suche communicacions sute thesaied ihon iokyn truce concluded xiii daie iuly fortie day betwene england fraunce bothe sea beyonde sea full well wist ihon iokyn meant desired peace fortie day season pikardes might haue quiet haruest cary corne whiche thei haue garrisos calice guysnes within englishe pale restreined warre also fisherman depe bullein traiport quiete fi hyng truce nauie englade come home harborough truce greued menne warre bothe party sodain thei wist well flemynges hard tell truce thei comprehended thesame thei began rayle said kyng englande doen truly take truce without knowlege englishemen answered thei ambassadour englande thei thei haue made priuie kyng would sende theim woorde affaire thei would sende knowe ought master suche seruice frenchemen season enterprised enter flaunders newe dike thei manfully defended flemynges frenchemen passed englishe pale nothyng doen flemynges wer sore displeased engl shemen calice latter ende iuly came englande monsire bryond chief president roan brought cardinalles presence manor richemond commission shewed doubted whether aucthoritie wer sufficiet ky g master prisoner spain shewed aucthoritie geuen lady regent certain noble realme fraunce frenche kyng open parliament goyng italy thynges id mighte concerne realme duryng absence commission thought reasonable rehersed frenchemen double e vnstedfastnes thei behaued theimselfes toward kyng englande thei answered wee haue offended haue v punished haue br nt tounes slain people destroyed countrey haue brought lowe party long miserie without recouery therefore sithe lesers offence yet sue peace least punished long consult cion thei offered many offer first pay suche somme money wer due bothe yerely tribute also citee turnay frenche quenes dowar farther recompence kyng englande expences doen warres duryng treatie woorde brought kyng englande truce ainly concluded betwene realme frauce adie margaret duches sauoy gouerner flaunde lowe countreis space v monethes ntercourse betwene merchantes saueconduite proclamacion proclamed sainct omers irste daie august herupon kyng contented peace bee taken xiiii daie august firste daie december whiche proclamed london truce euery englishema without sauecondute might passe fraunce thei likewise england truce proclaymed people said hath frenchemen gotten fishyng quictly thei kept thei vndoen aire wordes thei helpe themselfes whiche haue warre shall hurte v herryng shall vitaill tounes next yere common people talked purpose yere kyng sent docter henry standisheambassadors demark bishop sainct asse sir ihon baker knight realme denmarke comen entreate noble countery reduccion kyng cristierne realme croune dignitie could said perswaded could bryng dane reson thei hated hym greate crueltie especiall greate tiranny committed stokeholme swethen desired greate nomber noble banket baket strake heddes ambassadours englande sawe thei could bryng hym thei began require sonne might haue croune dominion whiche neuer offended progeny borne lady isabell sister emperor charles v whiche also made greate labor instaunce thesame dane answered thei would none procreacion thei said sonne would folow father el least would reuenge father wrong answere thei departed muche ambassador fraunce bothe offer entreatyes kyng england counsaill condiscende peace soner thei sawe warre continue money must demaunded comons whiche leuer rebell pay money haue hard last yere whe peace concluded proclamacions thesame sent euery citee good toune viii daye september thys peace proclaymed solemply trumpet citee london effecte wherof vpon humble suite large profers made lady regent fraunce three estate peace league amitie concluded betwene bothe kynges england frauce countreys subiectes subiectes either realme maie lawfully passe repasse others realme dominion bye sell frankely frely without let interrupcion league wise breche league taken wyth emperor lady margaret gouernesse flaunders point thesaied emperour lady margaret kynges old auncient confederate alies wer comprehended thesame due restitucion made frechmen appoyncted reuerende father cutberd bishop lodon forrestitucion made englisheme appoynted chief presidet roan xi daie september truce proclamed spain toune uale dolito betwene themperor frenche kyng daie ende december next ensuyng whiche time emperor seen frenche kyng whiche conueighed sea italy spain castle called madrill remaygned shortly fell sore sicke greate ieoperdy whiche frechmen cared litle thei saied died thei paie raunsome realme shoulde quiet peace betwene england fraunce nothing pleased flemynges wherefore thei dronke well thei spake largely bosted thei victailed english army found carte cariages thought kyndly doen refuse old frendes make peace wyth old enemy thei considre money englishemen left countrey frenchman dred englishemen would inuade flaunders thei lyued quietly thei considered thesame moneth peace proclamed paris lios roan amia peace kyng englande receiue certain day xx hundred thousande crounes whiche foure hundred thousand pound sterlyng whiche one paiment fiftie thousande pounde paied hande peace taken men warre aboute retinue calice hammes guysnes called home shippes brought hauens many kreker wist lyue moneth october wer sent fraunce sir willyam fitzwillyam threasorer kynges house docter tayllor ambassador kyng england wer receiued fraunce honorably long iorneis last came citie lios xxiiii daie nouember wer presented wine fishe fleshe ware thei wer visited diuerse noble men xxvi daie thei conueighed courte twoo erles gate receiued twoo cardinalles brought lady regent whiche muche honor theim receiued thei deliuered kynges letter whiche tooke greate reuerence counsaill departed priuie chamber taried almost two houres came docter tailor made eloquent oracion latin commodity peace declared kyng master loue dred nede co discend peace bishop besanson chaunceller lady regent made answere doen ambassador feasted serued men greate estate thei wer conueighed lodgynges sondaie next ensuyng ambassador wer conueighed courtethe league sworne thence lady regent court rode solemply cathedrall churche lion cardinall sang solempne masse masse dooen lady regent toke twoo ambassador one right hande left hande went vp high aultar laied hande canon crucifix masse boke sware obserue fulfill kepe article agrementes concluded league treatie peace commissioner whe doen bishop bisanson made eloquent sermon takyng antitheme quis est homo qui uult uitam diligit dy uidere bonos inquire pacem c sermon muche praised kyng englade whiche assented peace lauded cardinall called legate god counsailyng hym peace frauce free aall hostilitie seased sermon doen te deum song trumpettes blewe instrumentes musaicall lady regent trayne returned palace ambassador highly feasted sir willyam fitz willyam toke leaue came shortly englande leauyng behynde hym doctor tayler whiche taried till frenche kyng deliuered article peace wer knowen themperor counsaill full well wist thei kyng englande would frend frenche kyng wherefore subiectes shewed themselfes straunge vnkynde englishemen thei accustomed somuche englishe merchauntes put vp supplicacion emperor shewyng hym goodes taken letter marke shippes restrained newe imposicions taken theim moste thei complained acte made spain called premetica whiche ordeineth euery cloth bee certain nomber thredes clothes englande could bee solde great hynderaunce englishe merchauntes clothier england knowe nomber appoynted statute thei make cloth thei knowe countrey cloth shalbe sold thynges englishe merchauntes desired redresse daie appoynted englishman answere deliuered writyng conteignyng certain article firste wronges bee dooen vnto iustice open euery place second touchyng letter marke auised counsaill third touchyng shippes frely graunt shal haue fredship liberally awne shippes goodes maie go youre pleasure passyng makyng abode touchyng customes imposicions newe accident maie cause v doo shalbee suspence finally touchyng premetica made lordes counsaill v affirmed wee breake wee suffre intent englishe mer hauntes maie bryng true well made clothe whiche shall bee better welcome answere englishe merchauntes emperor counsaill wynter greate death london wherefore terme adiorned king eschew plague kept chrstmas eltham small nomber manne might come thether suche wer appoynted name christmas kynges house called still christmas cardinall sea laye manor richemond kept open housholde lordes lady would come play disguisyng royall maner whiche sore greued people especial kynges seruauntes se hym kepe open court kyng secret court cardinall came eltham viii daie ianuary taried till xxii daie whiche season cardinall kynges cousaill sat direccion taken kynges house first considered greate nomber yomen gard chargeable many officer farre striken age whiche seruauntes courte kyng serued seruauntes awne seruauntes whiche thought conuenient wherfore first officer seruauntes wer put courte many old officer put liue countreys kyng bountie enhaunsed liuynges three pound wage sixe pound annuitie without attendaunce xl foure pound euery man rate young menne put rome lxiiii gard whiche xiid daie checked put wage thei vid daie vnchecked dwell countreys come court til thei wer sent except wer suite whiche cardinall promised helper ala sorowe lamentacion made persones depart court saied poore seruauntes wer vndoen must steale saied thei wer found reuercions officer seruice nothyng set bres er greate charit ynde saied yomen gard whiche put wer able fynde themselfes horse doo kyng seruice saied thei would polle pill countreys oppresse poore people thus euery anm saiyng season cardinall made many ordin linces concernyng kynges house whiche bee daie called statute eltham whiche saied wer profitable honor ble monethe ianuary peace concluded betwene realmes england scotlande three yeres sixe monethes whiche scottes wer glad especially borderer thei wer sore hurt warre yere kyng shrouetewesdaie kept solempne iustes manour grenewiche hymself xi wer one part marque excester xi parte kynges barde base bende wer cloth gold siluer richely embraudered mannes harte presse f ames letter written declare le nose englishe declare dare marque bend wer grene ueluet c mosyn sattyn embro ered harte burnyng ouer euery hatte lady haned commyng cloude holdyng garden water pot whiche dropped siluer droppes harte iustes many spere broken chaunce shiueryng spere sir france brian lost one yes iustes kyng made quene lordes lady costly banket seruice quene lady hymself monethe february xi daie beyng sondaie cardinall greate pompe came cathedrall churche paules bi oppes abbottes great nomber doctor gaue atten aunce sat pont calibus vnder cloth estate c othe golde frier barnes frier augustyne certain poyntes heresie bishoppes saied twoo merchauntes stilierd bare fagottes eatyng fleshe fridaie bishop rochester doctor fisher made sermon reprouyng martin luther opinio frier germany whiche wrote power bishoppe rome sermon spake muche honor pope cardinalles dignitie prehenminence forgat speake thyng gospell whiche toke hand declare whiche sermo muche praised cardinall bishoppes wherefore cardinall gaue people benediccion departed yere continuall suite made emperor cou sail lady regent fraunce realme deliueraunce france frenche kyng many communicacions whiche toke none effect sent spain ambassade noble lady margaret late duches alaunson sister french kyng greate compaignie noble honorable personage themperor charles met thesaied lady market place cite toleto right hartely welcomed duches compaignie refused agree certain article whiche frenche kyng offered hymself thesaied duches license emperor go madrill frenche kyng kepte prisoner knowe mynd diuised suche waie frenche kyng haue scaped poste horse wer laied euery secrete emperor thereof enformed toke certain frenchemen whiche confessed thynges haue brought passe duches alaunson hearyng priuitie opened post horse spede returned fraunce leuyng whole matter large lordes fraunce ceased daily sue deliueraunce souereigne lorde last emperor deliuered boke frenche kynges deliueraunce emperor saied would nothyng demaund hym hauyng hym could geue hym frenche kyng counsaill offered boke conteignyng many article emperoure emperor well vnderstande contentes thesame saied frenche ambassador full agrement master thei answered yea well saied emperor awne offre truste kepe themperor thought best bryng frenche kyng libertie visite hym hymself whiche doen tyme sickenes xiiii daie february emperor accompaignied greate constable frauce duke enphantaso duke ciuill duke na duke aluoy duke alberkirke duke medena duke massedonia marque aguler marque uillas ea marque sturgus erle barselona erle boniuent erle ieniuer erle salenas erle arrowffe erle saluator xii bishoppes greate nomber noble came castle madrill frenche kyng brought noble repaire emperor made lo reuerence declared hym victory consist hande god greate debate warre strief lond continued betwene said hady worke god deliuer hym captiuitie restaint libertie generall peace cocluded christendome sithe haue offered v reasonable con icions entendyng punishement restraint libertie haue gently rece ued offer signed awne hande whiche noble shall heare redde primis frenche kyng sware kepe peace bothe land water emperor subiectes landes territory dominion belongyng emperor empire item thesaied frenche kyng clerely renounced right title interest whiche pretended realme naples kyngdome scicile item thesaied frenche kyng clerely renounced right title duchie millain conntie ast item thesame kyng surrendered themperors handes whole duchie burgoyn countie charoloys castle lordshippes apperteinyng thesame maner souereigntie apperteignyng croune fraunce reason thesame item thesaied kyng surrendered relased souereignetie whiche claimed county flaunders arthoys thother lowe countreis thei thence furthe neuer sue parliament fraunce appele resorte county guysnes arde bullonoys alwaie except ite released right title citee tournay turnesyns tounes hedyng arras castle dominion apperteignyng thesame title souereignetie resort thesame parliamentes fraunce item sware promised neuer helpe aide lorde dalbrethe called kyng nauerr couyn wise themperor heires successor item none assent maintein aide co fort charles duke geldres maintein sir robert de la marche meanes emperor countreys dominion item promised awne costes charge finde fiue hundred men armes tenne thousande footemen emperour seruice whensoeuer toke iorney toward rome obteignyng croune sceprer imperiall paie wage sixe monethes ite promised enemie persones whiche would go entend wise let di urbe thesaied iorney rome item promised discharge emperor kyng englande twoo hundred thousande crounes whiche ought kyng englande deliuer emperor sure acquitaunce thesame whiche amounteth starlyng money lml item released pencions whiche claimed realmes naples scicile whiche yerely hundred thousand dukattes item surer performaunce article agreed th frenche kyng departyng deliuer emperor handes dolphin uien henry duke orleaunce twoo elder sonnes whiche remain spain till article wer performed came realme three estate fraunce would condiscend agree article offered sworne shortly come spain yeld hymself prisoner child redeliuered fraunce item fortificacion concorde amitie betwene twoo prince realmes emperor offered mariage frenche kyng noble prince lady elinor late quene portyngall greate dowar offered hym mariage three faire lordeshippes called ansames maconoyes barsur whiche frenche kyng ioyfully accepted offre condicionally whole agrement toke effecte el saied heard frenche quene poysoned intent euill tongue neuer saied well al article many mo frenche kyng sware emperor noble xiiii daie february tyme entreatie came spayne charles duke burbon whiche appeled frenche kyng contrary al right iustice procured imagened death destruccion thesaied duke without cause onely possede soueraigneties dominion reason whereof thesaied duke compelled liue exile countrey regent fraunce contrary iustice proclaimed hym traitor seazed good landes wherefore desired frenche kyng might hym make condigne recompence emperour answered prisoner might bee appeled yet good seruice emperor muche article concluded duke burbo bee restored firste title state honor dignitie duches county seigniory dominion frenche kyng frely pardoned hym al offence sware al proces proclamacions impeticions dooen hym bee voyde annulled repeled farther frenche kyng recopence al wronges doen restitucion goodes promised sware paie thesame duke cc thousande crounes al rente profites receiued landes thesaied duke tyme exile article wer concluded sworne appoynted emperour iudged frenche kyng would neuer loue duke burbon newe found faute priuy enemie might bee brought confusion wherefore noble liberalitie consideryng good seruice duke doen hym might possession dominion gaue vnto duke whole duchie millain thesaied duke finde yerely foure thousande footemen fiue hundred men armes paie emperor yerely foure thousande ducates neuer obteigned possession lacke inuesture creacion also emperoure gaue uiceroy naples duchie boysee countie ast many greate rewardes good seruice peace thus concluded betwene empe frenche kyng openly proclaimed spain fraunce flaunders emperours dominion whereof subiectes glad made fiers triumphes countreys kyng englande like wise whiche included thesame league g ad peace caused cardinall noble prelate assemble cathedrall churche saincte paule te deum song cardinall gaue benediccion people night ites made london common people said thei thought saied peace honorable emperoure saied frenche kyng would kepe promise deliuered proued kyng england hearyng ye frenche kyng poynt deliue ed set knight chamber called sir thomas cheyney french kyng ce tefiyng great gladnes ye ha deliuery also cofort conclusion peace whiche kynd remembraunce french kyng muche reioysed french kyng toke leaue themperor toke iorney fraunce ward came uictoria whiche season fame went dolphin whiche haue deliuered one hostage frech kyng father disseased frenche kyng staied xv day till truth knowen saied cause wer betwene fontrabie bayon xxxm men doubted lest brought doune foutraby might haue rescued whatsoeuer cause restraigned haue harde last daie came diliuerythe deliue french kyng discretely moued speake child feare lamentacion sorowe might suche wise rise hurte might ensue whe daie come deliuered betwene border fraunce spain lake great depenes middes whereof laied greate emptie boate anker euery shore another boate french kyng come banke entered boate spanishe side sixe spaniardes hym like wise frenche part twoo prince sonnes frenche kyng entered boate sixe frenchman bothe boates came boat liyng middes frenche kyng entered one ende child passed great boate euen middest boate thei met hande blessed theim without speakyng wordes sadly regarded theim entered boate frenchemen child boate spaniardes eche shortly shore mounted horsebacke frenche kyng rode bayon nobely receiued almost noble realme especiall mother ii child fountraby vpward well cherished thynges great constable spain wife thus france frenche kyng coueighed realme xxi daie marche whiche taken xxiiii daie february yere last past themperor concluded taken leaue frenche kyng rode faire citee ciuill greate triuph maried lady isabell daughter kyng emanuell portyngallthe mariage themperor greate threasures somme money great frendship portyngalles xi hundred thousande ducates mariage mariage knowen englande englishemen sore murmured emperor beyng wynsore xiiii yere king faithfully promised mary lady mary daughter kyng englande verie truthe emperoures counsaill content answere made monsire de beuers last yere counsailed emperour tary lady mary whiche young also thei saied begotten kyng englande brother wife also acte made spain depart countrey till issue thynges laied hym whiche caused hym encline mariage seyng great offer kyng portyngal made hym agreyng maried lady isabell sister kyng ihon portyngall pthe xviii yere xxviii daie aprillthe xviii yere beginnyng xviii yere came court grenewiche monsire brenion chief president roan ihon iokyn called monsire de uaux whiche president roan kyng sette throne accompaignied noble ambassador rome emperor uenice florece beyng present made latyn toungue solempne oracion effect wherof shewedthe oracion president roan dredfull warres betwene realmes englande fraunce greate losse realme fraunce susteigned thesaied warres declared farther power kyng englande conquest might haue made fraunce kyng beyng prisoner knowleged kyng englandes right warres wronges humbly thanked hym pitie copassion neccss e ic ion would concent peace oracion chan eller duchie lancastre name sir thomas made answere saiyng muche reioysed kyng thei first co sidered power might haue oppressed pi ie releued wherefore would kindnes thei shewe hym none vnkindnes inuiolatly kepe league whiche concluded next daie beeyng sondaiethe peace worne cardinall song solempne masse kynges chapell grenewiche masse kyng sware frenche ambassador foure ambassador aboue rehersed beyng present kepe peace league concluded betwene hym brother perpetuall alie french kyng duryng life yere masse ambassadoures made greate feast moneth maie proclamacio made al vnlawfull game accordyng statute made behalf commissios warded euery shire execucion thesame place table dice cardes boule wer taken brent wherfore people murmured cardinall saiyug grudged euery mannes pleasure sauyng awne proclamacion small tyme endured young men forbidden boule suche game fell drinkyng ferettyng meu e cony stealyng dere parkes vnthriftines al sommer kyng tooke pastyme huntyng nothyng happened worthye bee written returne frenche kyng comen realme paris saied wrote emperour would obserue kepe promise euery point thought iudge shortly set urth boke called appollogie defence conuencion agrement made betwene emperor hym madrill allegyng copelled make agrement el neuer haue diliuered alleged farther lawers realme clerely determined promise couenauntes made persone awne hurt hym power made compulsio none effect performed also saied gouernors lawe determined othe promise effecte manne ieoperdie life perpetuall imprisonement bondage moste especiall doen compulsion thretenyngmoreouer saied might geue awaie nothyng apperteignyng croune without thassent peeres three estate realme whiche sworne time coronacio whiche would therto wise assent therfore saied othe promes voyd declared uiceroy naples beyng ambassadour emperor offered raunsome paye asmuche money euer frenche kyng paied diuerse article newe diuised article came emperor refused saied desired nothyng impossible frenche kyng might would noy kepe appoyntemet betwene theun made yet bad hym kepe poynt couenaunt whiche onely depended yelde hymself prisoner againe haue child deliuered would reasonably commen hym newe article agrement appollegie set furthe frenche kyng othe promesse voyde made compulsion threatenyng answered another boke called refutacion ouercommyng apollogie conue ncion madrill whiche twoo woorkes eloquently set furth suche many perswacions allegacions bothe one part would comber wise man except perfectly indifferent iudge whiche parte moste encline geue credence therefore leaue large frenche kyng deliuered peace concluded emperor fully determined passe sea italy rome crouned emperor wherof hearyng bishop rome called pope clement seuenth man great wit vice litle vertue learnyng much doubted hymself damage might come hym emperor bothe naples scicill duchie millain also wer crouned emperor wherefore sent uenicians floretines fraunces sforce duke millain whiche committed treason themperor depriued iudgeme name dignitie thesame geuen duke burbon yet power kept muche possession declared puyssaunce emperor would come italy greate possession euery ende italy wer crouned emperor would loke haue seigniorie italy wherefore thei consulted debated awne suretie banishe italy power thei wer debatyng matter thei hard worde french kyng returned fraunce sought way meanes breake emperour thei sawe open accion offered theim al diligence thei sent seuerall ambassador saie pope twain duke uenice called andrew gritty one whiche secretorie florentynes one duke millaine one fiue ambassadours came frenche kyng delcared ioye gladnes master safe returne realme thei shewed thei bishop rome exhortacion diuised league whiche set perpetuall peace betwene prince christen expedicion thei set furth agreed vpo article whole league frenche kyng saw article would haue thought whole power confederate child deliuered yet haue medelyng italy wherefore greate gladnes solempnitie entered league sware kepe gaue ambassador greate rewardes first article league themperor kyng englande kynges prince might entre thesame kyng englande would sould bee admitted protector thesame league yet e perour bee admitted till deliuered frenche kynges child hauyng reasonable somme money thesame restored duke millain whole duchie franckly frely persones italy like maner thei wer last warres began shal come italy coronacion wise suche traine pope duke uenice shall thynke conuenient three monethes hath entered league shall paie kyng englande suche somme ought hym ye time item themperor would entre thesaid cofederates assemble greate armie italy accordyng euery one bee assessed armie mainteigned till emperor power driuen italy item emperor shalbe warned deliuer freche kynges child fall reasonable poynt hym whiche thynges deny dooe confederate certifie hym thei shall neuer cease till brought reason item greate nauie prepared coastes italy common costes confederate item fraunces sforce shall enioy duchie millain payng yerely frenche kyng fiftie thousande ducattes french kyng neuer claime thesame item frenche kyng duke orleaunce hys sonne shall haue countie item emperour bee expelled oute naples scicil realmes gift pope paiyng yerely french kyng lxxv thousand ducattes item kyng englande wyll take vpon hym protector league sonne duke richemond haue duchie principalitie realme naples hym heires somme thirtie thousande ducattes least cardinal yorke haue yerely pencion x thousand ducates league concluded cogmace xxii daie maie yere league thus concluded sent kyng englande whiche greate deliberacion like wise prince consulted muche hys counsail waightie matter whe al thinges wer fully perceiued answered thambassadours thanked muche confederate good would entre league would indifferent entreator betwene bothe party meane peace wrote emperor whiche hartely thanked toke greate kyndnes league called holy league clement bishop rome sawe league concluded would shewe confederate iust cause warre emperor thynges doen italy sent hym letter dated rome xxiii daie iune whiche letter moste craftely laied emperours charge doen hym pope sithe promoted dignitie left nothyng vnremembred either frendly meant actualy doen emperor accused muche vnkyndnes especiall would pardo france sforce duke millain request accused hym also coueteous desire haue obtein whole monarchie italy many pretie inuencions whiche cause saied compelled uretie italy especiall churche rome ioyne hymself greate prince make warre defence thesame letter deliuered emperour spede emperour answered letter dated xiiii daie september conteinyng xxiiii shetes paper suche wise wise men maie se thesame romishe bishop accused themperour haue blamed hymself emperor laied greate nomber ingratitude vntruthes hym clerely auoyded thynges laied charge pope sent ambassador another letter first letter deliuered retain god would manifestyng truthe letter deliuered tenne dayes first letter writte holy father rome raised al hast armie eight thousande footemen valiaunt compaignie horsmen whiche passed riuer poo ioyned themselfes power uenicians wherof capitain france duke urbine thei together marched toward millain meane season thei sent octauian sforcia bishop aretyne whiche frenche kyng retain xiiii swysses thei wer commyng swyserlande ioyne armie italy thintent armie driue emperor power duchie millain deuises proued cotrary shall plainly perceiue shall vnderstande although frenche kyng taken pauia yere tyme frenchemen driuen duchie millain yet emperour left duchie without armie left anthony de leua whiche capitain pauia siege laied frenche kyng fernando daual alphons brother two valiant capitaines fernando died pitie capitaines spaniardes almaines nomber eight tenne thousande laie still till newe confederacie set forwarde especially thei sore moued france sforce duke millain whiche possession moste part fortress duchie would e one cofederates wherfore thei thought best begin get possession hand wherefore alphons daual sent themperors army together thei came al together warre whe sent moron chief counsailer duke millain whiche mistrustyng nothing came laied duke master false emperor moron denied kept prisoner whether wer cautele cannot tel wrote duke perceiued emperoure like preuaile aduised hym auoydyng al mistrust also shewe self veri frende emperor obedient subiect deliuer strong holdes captaines handes duke hearyng counsaill willyng haue enmitie emperiall capitaines assented deliuered dauall fortress except castelles millain cremona saied kepte onely healthe body ben long sicke dauall powre almains spaniardes came citie milaine lodged people eueri house fearing duke imagened thing kepyng two strongest castels delyuered two castelles army confederate emperoures capitaynes people greate dauger wherfore gentlye greate perswasio desired haue keping castell millayn whiche duke would nowise assent mistrustyng shoulde lese duchie al wherefore daual al spede layed sege castell duke ye tyme thys sege capitaynes euer toke monney thinges fro citezyns sore therat grudged saied wold suffer almaine came smith docate smith cried helpe toune rose capitaynes came citie se done souldiers kepte sege seyng ranne citie much entreting partes duke hering noies citie seing besegers gone came castel thinking frendes come reskue sawe succour harde noyes seased etred castell agayne capitaines long intreated people ons coteted meanes one sedicious felowe thei begane sore fight night cam faste partes seuered selues citizen sore greued spaniardes saied opely shortly trus ed se themperours frendes driue italie many yll woordes rebuked souldiais cam citie thei hurt anthony deleua dauall perceiuyng deuysed reveged wherfore euenyng entred thousad spaniard slewe one citize set hed polle caused borne afore set iii iiii house ire whe citizes pe c iued thei wer greatly aferd ran harnesse cast doune stone barres hand gonne shot fast thei durst loke almaines set fire many house least thei haue leyser fight spaniardes kept tower slewe citezens ala citee greate perill wel perceiued leua dauall remnant spaniardes come whole citee burned vtterly destroyed wherfore thei caused souldiers cease whiche content thei harnes sunne set till nyne clocke next daie seaso tharmy cofederates made hast help duke millain meane waie citee lawde yelded duke urbin dauall wet thether wtih small copaignie reskew citee sawe past reskew returned saiyng wer better lese lawde millain brought al people millain emperoure tyme tyme aduertised thynges doen italy wherfore great diligence sent duke burbon thether ten saile landed sauona brought xm men wherof millaners wer glad besought good gaue many good wordes sware praied god braynes might striken gonne except deliuer shortly great burden oppression spaniardes thei would deliuer hym xxxm ducates wage souldiers brought hym whiche wishe thought haue happened hym rome breakyng promes receiued money litle space millaners wer good quiet shortly thei wer worse afore muche substanciall menne feare liues hanged themselfes whe millaners hard citee lawde taken spaniardes put thei thought vm spaniardes iiim almaines great nomber horseman beyng without wage vitaile could defende great citee long whole power prince confederate power confederate wer slowly commyng millain ward duke compaignie lacked victaile wherfore necessitie thei sawe watche negligently kept thei sent castle cc men whiche strength passed siege came armie confederate shewed case castle whiche bad theim bee good chere thei marched forwarde towarde gate millain called rome gate ihon de medices whiche led forward shot sixe gonne tower haue ouerthrowen thesame haue entered waie emperor men came place onely defended thesame valiantly set forward fight enemy skirmished sore italian seyng spaniardes wer fierce thought best fight tary till swysses come thei thought theselfes sure victorie shame inough thei returned meligia returne imperialles fortified citee many place duke millein seyng lacked victaile succor failed sent duke burbon worde would deliuer castle bound farther inconuenience thei agreed haue bagge baggage haue citee come abode til wer tried themperor accusacions hym allegedthe castle millain yelded thempeours vse vpon whiche condicion yelded castle went directly tharmy confederate ye went come accordyng appoyntment spaniardes whiche kepte toune would suffre hym entre wherefore necessitie compelled returne tharmy confederate became enemie themperors meny al sommer tharmie italy gat nothyng citee lawde thei durste fight spanyardes wherfore thei went besieged cremona whiche wer im almaines vc spanyardes swisshes viiim pope men horseman malatesta wer sent siege wherof capitain ye said malatesta ballio perusine whiche would haue entered castle salin im men bende wherfore duke urbyne whole army uenicians wer sent whiche made greate nomber suche ordinance thei within began treate appoyntment deliuered citee whole army italia confederate determ ned clerely besiege millain sodainly bishop rome sent army cause shal also thei hard say george fronsberge valiant capitain almain serued theperor last warres comyng x iim lanceknightes wer paied wage afore hand iiii monethes aide themperors part confederate army hard thei wer astonied durst enterprise siege certain abbay twoo mile fro citee millain thei made fortificacion iiim fotemen fiue hundred horseman lye surely wynter suffre recourse come citee whiche citee somer season well fortified victaled pope army departed cremona haue hard came tharmy confederate michael anthonio marque saluce capitain generall freche kyng brought hym iiim eascons vc men armes xvc light horse accordyng league whole army hearyng almaines wer commyng forward greate ordinance greate nomber horsmen passed straightes mountaignes maugre uenicians couradine lepontine whiche deliuered vp cremona im almaines ioyned capitain george whe tharmy confederate wer well informed greate armie coming toward millain capitaines clerely determined mete battaill otherwise let passyng riuer poo ioyne themperors armie wherefore thei marched forwarde founde almaynes come territory mantua duke urbyn ihon de medi cosin pope thought wery almaines light skirmish ihon de medi skirmished nere tharmie get name aboue hit gonne shortely died almaines came florenciola toke counsaill thought best soiorne wynter duchie millain al thyng scace reason continuall warres wherefore thei determined take pope tounes aucthor mischief warre surely thei taken toune plesance tharmie confederate strongly bothe men artilery fortified toune thynges wer doyng continued greate hatered betwene bishop rome noble famely colume rome whiche famely imperiall muche bishop saied pompey cardinal colume would take awaie cardinalles hatan answer cardinal bishop rome thother answered would put helmet ouerthrowe thre crounes malice long continued bishop rome began lacke money maintein warres sore fered columes domesticall enemy awne mocion began breake matter ascayn colume sonne prosper de columna name whole bloud columes saiyng wer conuenient bothe party agree abide chauce battaill whiche thei bothe party columes men warre themperors battaill bishop tharmy confederate euery daie retain souldiers home eche feare greate charge losse ascaine hearyng saied would speake kynred communicacion take effect hugo de moncado hugo litle sent themperor pope certain article co clude peace whiche pope would agre saiyng came late sawe bishop proude answer perceiued enemie master sought occasion oppresse bishop power moued cardinall colume ascain colume inuade rome sodain fraie take pope clement wer ware thei beyng glad please themperor gathererd secretly iim souldiers entered rome suche spede thei wet ihon laterece nere pope palace man spied theim began crie cardinall colume cometh great power pope thynkyng late sende aide fled secret vaw e castle angell hym fled cardinalles bishoppes palace great nomber victaile inough theim bishop clement sawe shortly thei famished castle sent hugo de moncado whiche declared thauctor act mindyng hurt pope make hym themperors frend el cause hym surcesse doyng themperor damage thesaid hugo offered kepe peace emperor confederate foure monethes meane season treate peace also call armie ouer poo performance deliuered columes good hostage returned armie cremona haue hard deliuered large leaue emperor armie liyng italy speke greate mischief fell hongary greate turke sultan soliman pac hearyng strie warre betwene christen prince imagened tyme come greate act christendo wher ore assembled puissant armie cxxm men entered hungary sore destroiyng countrey wherof hearyng lewes kyng hongary couragious knight xxvi yere age small nomber marched forwarde iune great army turkes wist good corage ioyned battaill oppressed multitude compelled flie marreis horse man wer drouned many hym body found buried saiyng betraied erle awne called ihon de uoada likely turke afterwarde made hym kyng hongarythe kyng hogary slain enioyed one part called trasiluan fernando themperors brother whiche maried sister heire kyng lewes ye slain kept chief part hongary greate turke hymself fight hard kyng slain reioysed muche spoyled countrey brought many christian soule captiuitie turkey victory wrote uenicians frendes whiche letter red openly uenice doctor pace ambassador kyng englande whether thei wer ioyous sorowfull tidynges cannot well tell somer great grudge merchant stranger lodo somuch ye ye matter well pacified much busines might haue folowed cause grudge ther act made iiii yere kyng henry ye stranger bryng wyne woade alien ship ye thenglishmen ye went tholose brought much woade london serued al clothier repairyng london yere meanes gentleman king ranger license bryng woade stragers bottomes al lodon ful woade also thei sent woade cou trey ye thenglishmennes woade londo lay vnbought wherfore sir iho alen knight beyng maior sent great sort stranger wer chief merchantes shewed vnto gaines thei gotten citee reason wherof thei auaunce citee hurt wherfore willed sel woade merchates lo thei paied continent resort place countrey woade hinderance londoner stranger proudely answered maior ye thei would seke euery place auatage mockyng maner depa ted maior perceiuyng ye called comen counsaill moneth august wer many billes laied stranger last enacted citezen freman hould bye sell place exchage meddle certain stranger called anthony bonuice laurence bouice anthony uiuald anthony caueler fraces de bard thomas calnecant great sort mo whose name let passe person meddle occupie contrary acte lese fredome libertie citee london whiche acte stranger wer brideled thei came reasonable poynt conclusion season angel noble iust sixt part ouce troythe firste aunsyng angell sixe angel wer iust ounce xl sterlyng angel worth ii ounce siluer ye sixe angel xii ounce whiche xl siluer flaunders braband zeland angel worth vii iiii merchantes daily caried ouer much money great hynderance merchandise realme moste men caried gold ther losse euery noble viii bryng hether thenglishmen spake ruler leaue thenhaucyng kynges coyne thei laughed skorne kyng counsail perceiued end enhauncement flau ders wer met shortly would bryng ye rich realme wherfore moneth september proclamacion enhaunced angell viiisiiiid royal xi croune iiiis iiiid proclamacion made al england bryng flaunders greate nober englishe golde whiche therethe seconde inhaunsyng kyng proclamacion fift daie nouember enhaunced angell viisvid euery ounce gold xlvs ounce siluer iii ix value yere michaelmas euen thomas hynd whiche chosen shrife called take oth made defaute wherefore suno rice chosen refused one george robinson mercer chosen whiche toke oth able comons wer fury ye thei sware ye thei would haue mercer master nicholas labert alderman grocer dispensacion shriualtie ye yere seyng discord said comos master although tyme bee come yet appease strief chose take chosen great thankes season sodain rumor bega spain themperor would haue war kyng england wherof hearyng thenglishe merchantes whiche lay spain diuerse porte cocluded sende doctor edward lee ambassador kyng england theperors court knowe certentie gently answered trusted ye cause ye thei aferd kyng master themperor wer yet perfite loue amitie farther sent worde ye kyng englad entered league italy confederate thei would haue hym laboreth make vniuersall peace whiche could conuenlently wer protector cotractor league answere sent theim granado v daie september moneth december kyng kept solempne christmas manor grenewiche greate pletie victaile reuels maskes disguysynges bankettes xxx daie december enterprise iustes made tilt sixe gentleman al co mers whiche valiantly furnished thesame bothe spere sworde like iustes wer kept third daie ianuary ccc speres broken night kyng many young gentleman hym came bridewell put hym xv al maskyng apparell toke barge towed cardinalles place wer supper great compaignie lordes lady masker dauced made goodly pastyme whe thei well danced lady plucked awaie visor thei knowen kyng made greate banket xiii daie ianuary came court hugo de mendosa greate man borne spain noble famely persone se ambassador emperor kyng englande large commission themperor put kyng englandes determinacion whether demaundes whiche required frenche kyng wer reasonable declaracion thereof knowe kyng englandes request entreatie concerning peace noble man sent englande whiche many tymes consulted kyng counsaill taried twoo yeres full christmas goodly disguisyng plaied greis innea plaie grayes inne whiche compiled moste part master ihon roo seriant law xx yere past long cardinall aucthoritie effecte plaie lorde gouernance ruled dissipacion negligence whose misgouernance euill order lady publike wele put gouernance caused rumor populi inward grudge disdain wanton souereignetie rise greate multitude expell negligence dissipacion restore publik welth estate doen plaie set furth riche costly apparel straunge diuises maskes morrishes highly praised menne sauyng cardinall whiche imagined plaie diuised hym greate furie sent thesaied master roo toke hym coyfe sent hym flete sent yong gentleman plaied plaie highly rebuked thretened sen one called thomas moyle kent flete meanes frendes master roo wer deliuered last plaie sore displeased cardinall yet neuer meante hym haue harde wherfore many wisemen grudged see hym take hartely euer cardinall saied kyng highly displeased spake nothyng hymself yere second day marche wer receiued londonambassadore fro frenche kyng great compaignie noble men bishop tarbe france visout toraine master anthony uescy secod president paris ambassador frenche kyng brought london tailers hall lodged afterward wer coueighed grenewiche kyng thei wer right haitely enterteined letter red requestes haro thei departed season london shrouetewes aiea iustes kyng hymself newe harnes gilte strange fashion seen hym viii gentleman cloth golde one suite embrodered knottes siluer marque excester viii hym blewe veluet white saten like waues sea men armes came tilte ran many freshe course till cclxxxvi speres wer broken thei disarmed wet quenes chamber prouided costly banket freche ambassador hauyng recourse kyng counsaill muche labored haue mariage lady mary daughter kyng long counsailyng matter put suspece president paris doubted whether mariage betwene kyng mother beyng brother wife good first mocion grewe muche busines wer ended shall afterward common people repugned sore demaund thei said heire apparant father dye thei would haue frencheman kyng englande thus common people spake myndes serued frenche ambassadours laie thus london happened one euenyng thei wer commyng blacke frier supper tailers hall two boyes wer gutter castyng doune rubbishe whiche rain driuen vnware hit lackay belonging viscount tourain hurte hym nothyng scantly touched cote frenche lordes toke matter highly thyng doen dispite sent worde cardinal whiche beyng hastie credence sent sir thomas seimer knight lord maior citee hast commaunded hym vpon allegeance take husband wife child seruauntes house theim emprison till knewe farther kinges pleasure ii boyes apprentice sent tower whiche comaundement accomplished without fauor man wife seruauntes wer kept counter till sixt daie maie whiche sixe wekes ful neighbour gentlenes kepte house meane tyme one appretices died tower almost lame crueltie cardinall pride frenchemen muche people spake would haue reuenged frenchemen wisemen citee appeased faire wordes xiiii daie marche wer conueighed lodon grenewicheambassadors fro kyng hong therle rutlande lorde gabliel de salamanka erle ottonbrough ihon burgraue siluerberge ihon faber famous clerke bishop uien ambassador fro fernando brother emperor newly electe kyng hungarye beame death brother lawe kyng lewes whiche slain turke last sommer haue hard compaignie welcomed high officer brought kynges presence nobilitie beyng present great reuerence madean oracion made master faber thesaied clerke master faber made notable oracion takyng ground gospell exiit seminare semen suum declared christe disciple went furthe sowe sede good fell good ground brought furth good fruite whiche christen faithe declared contrary sowyng machomete sowen seede whiche brought furthe euil sede shewed beginnyng turkes haue encresed power realmes thei conquered people thei subdued euen daie declared farther actes ye great turk liuyng doen especial noted gettyng belgrade rhodes slaiyng kyng hungary great rebuke said al kynges christened set furth also power turke diuersities copaignies armure capitaines thought without marueilous great nomber people could ouerthrowe wherfore moste humbly beseched kyng sainct george knight defender faithe assist kyng master godly warre verteous purpose oracion kyngthe answere mouthe sir thomas answered muche lamented losse happened hongarie wer warres whiche wer betwene two great prince thought turke would haue enterprised acte wherfore al studie would take pain first set vnitie peace throughout christendom bothe money men would ready helpe toward glorious warre asmuche prince christendom doen ambassadours well cherished diuerse tymes resorted courte greate chere good rewardes third daie maie next ensuyng thei toke leaue departed homeward season fame wentthemperors letter freche kyng themperor written french kyng admonishyng hym regarde othe promes toward god honor fame toward worlde allegyng kept promise towarde hym finde hym suche frende fraunce reioyse would kepe former promes whiche made sware madrill toke god witnesse would neuer leaue warre til fire sworde brought hym accomplishe promes el driue hym realme dominios wyth strength puissaunce letter french kyng nothyng regarded saiyng emperoure nexte yere shoulde haue warre inough fame went letter came london emperoures army italy xii day april met uenicians goyng homewarde betwene cruell fyght fyne force uenicians put lyght maruell uenicyans answere sai cause ther peace concluded six monethes betwene byshop rome hugo demountcado viceroy naples come rome co ferme truce therfore sent ordinauce harnes loked war taried together tyl wer payed wage vnprouided set ouercome end yere people sore troubled pouertye greate paymentes money past also wynter seade season fell abound an rayne septebre nouembre decembre xvi daie ianiuer fell suche great rayne ensued greate fluddes whiche distroyed corne feldes pasture drouned many shepe beastes dry tyll xii day aprill thence rayned euery day nyght tyll third day iune may rayned xxx houres contynually oute ceasyng whiche caused greate fluddes muche ha corne sore fayled next yere shall perceiue hereafter xix yere time bill set vp londo muche contrary honor cardinall whiche cardinall warned counsaile king mary daughter fraunce shoulde shewe hym selfe enemy kyng realme many threatnyng wordes thys bill delyuered cardinall sir thomas seimer maior citie thanked made much serch author bill coulde founde whiche sore displeased cardinall vpo occasio last day april night caused great watch kept westminster cart gonne read charged caused diuerse watch kept londo newington iones strete westminster giles iseldon place nere lo watch kept gentelme seruautes householder al feare lodoners bicause bil whe citizes knew thei saied thei marueiled whi cardinal hated thei saied mistrusted loued loue hatred thei affirmed thei neuer enteded harme toward mused chauce v vi lewde persones made alarme citie etred watche trayne might haue spoiled citie without cause wherfore much murmured cardinall vndiscrete doinges sonday fift daye maye solempe se song grenewiche cardinall archebishop canterbury x prelate mi e ed beyng present frenche ambassador name freche kyng master sware obserue peace legaue concluded betwene terme two prince liues opely bishop terby gaue kyng hartie thakes great fauor showed kyng master tyme visitacion called priso said kyng mercy conquered whole harte realme could stregth thebassadors also desired haue harde mariage lady mary duke orleance ii sonne french kyng said mete elf many man marueled denayed secod sonne seyng x yere kyng cocluded mary dolphin beyng first sonne demaund concluded answered deferred tendre age tyll another tyme enterteinyng french ambassador king caused solepne iustes doen sir nicholas carew sir robert iernyngham sir anthony broune nicholas haruy valiaunt esquier chalengers whiche appareled base bardes one suite right side ryche tyssue embaudered compasse roundell blacke veluet compas ryght hand holdyng sworde boute sword penne peces money diuerse coynes embrawdered vnder hand embraudered loialte side bard written embraudery bi pen pain treasure truth shall violated otherside base bardes cloth gold cloth siluer foure chalengars come tilt entered marque excester xiii hym armed barded based one suit saie right side cloth golde cut cloudes engrayled damaske golde otherside cloth syluer set mountaynes full oliue braunches made gold mouyng men armes ranne many faire course little missyng twoo houres half notwithstandyng yt rained apace thei brake iii hundreth speres least nyght approched disarmed went courte kyng agaynst night caused banket house bee made one syde tylt yarde grenewyche hundreth foote length xxx foote bredth roofe purple cloth ful rose pomgarnettes wyndowes wer clere story curious monneles strangely wrought iawe peces crestes karued wyth uinettes trailes sauage worke richely gilted gold bise thys woorke corbolyng bare candelstykes antyke woorke whiche bare litle torchettes white waxe candelstickes wer polished lyke aumbre one syde haute place herawldes minstrelles house richly hanged therin raised cupbord seuen stage high xiii foote long set standyng cuppes bolles flaggons greate pottes fyne golde garnyshed one stone stone perles side nother cupbord ix stage high set full high pottes flago bolles massy plate siluer gilte high brode maruaile beholde nether ende two broade arch vpon thre antike pillers gold burnished swaged grauen full gargills serpentes supportyng edifice arch vawted armorie bice golde aboue arch made many sondri antikes diuises chambre thre ewry bordes one kyng another quene third prince first bourde ix greate ewer basin al gilt playne seconde bourde seauen greate gilt basin chased thre paire couered basyns chasid al gilt cuppes assaie thei great euery lorde grudged beare theim third ewery ix basyns two payre coueryd basines cuppes assaie ewery gold ba in massye thei troubled sore bearer hole supper serued vessel gold reherse fare straugenes dish deuises beastes fowles long wherefore let passe ouer supper songes minstrelsie whe supper done kyng quene ambassador washed talked pleasure thei rose went banket chambre forsaied arch thei betwene vttermoste dore arch kyng caused turne backe loke syde arch thei sawe tyrwin beseged maner euery man camp connyngly wroughte whiche woorke pleased remembring thing dede then thei passed long galerie richely hanged chambre faire large dore whereof made masonrie emba ayled iasper within porche tipe crokettes gilt chambre raised stage v degree euery syde rayled coutrerailed borne pillar azute ful starres flower delice gold euery pillar toppe basin siluer wherein stode greate brauches white waxe degree marble oler railes like white marble middest chamber gate arch whereof stretched side side arche figured masonrie water table haunses receiuyng pillers wrapped beyng dormants antike ouer gate stode picture hercules scipio iulius ompe suche coquererours ventes embowes strange worke leaues balles garnishinges golde hole arche nothing fine bice golde rofe chambre conninglie made kynges astronimer grounde rofe made hole earth enuironed sea like mappe carte conning makyng nother cloth zodiacke xii signes fiue circle girdelles two pole apered earth water compassing zodiak twelue signes curiously made aboue made seuen planettes mar iupiter sol mercurius venus saturnus luna euery one proper house made accordyng property connyng thing plesant syght holde kyng quene set vnder clothes estate rich goodly ambassadours set righte side chambre entred person clothed cloth golde ouer mantell blew silke full eye golde ouer hed cap gold garland laurell set beries fyue gold peron made solempne oracioan oracion latin tongue declaryng ioye people realmes england fraunce knowe great loue league amitie betwene two kynges realmes geuyng greate praise kyng england graunting peace also frenche kyng suyng thesame also cardinal beyng mediator thesame doen entred eight kynges chappel song brought theim one richly appareled likewise side entred eight saied chappel bringyng nother personea dialogue likewise appareled two persones plaied dialog theffect wherof whether rich better loue could agre vpon conclusion eche called thre knightes armed thre woulde haue entred gate arche middel chambre iii resisted sodely betwene six knightesthe fight barriars arche fell doune bar gilte whiche barre sir kinghtes fought fair battail thei departed went place came olde man siluer berd concluded loue rich necessarie prince saie loue obeied serued rich rewarde louers frendes conclusion dialogue ended nether endea rich mount lettyng doune courtaine apered goodly mout walled tower vamures al gilt al thinges necessarie afortresse al mount set ful christal coralles rich rockes rubie cureously conterfaited full rose pomgranates though thei grewe rocke sat eight lordes appareled cloth tissue siluer cut quater foylesmaskers gold engrailed siluer siluer gold al loose white satin ther heddes cappes blake veluet set perle stone thei also mantelles blame saten thei sodenly descended mounte toke ladyes dauced diuers daunces caue issued ladie mary doughter kyng seuen lady appareled romayne fashion riche cloth gold oftissue crimosin tinsel bendy here wrapped calles golde bonete crimosin veluet heddes set full pearle stone eight lady dau ced eight lordes mount thei daunced sodenly entred sixe personage appareled cloth siluer blacke nsell satin whodes heddes tippetes cloth gold garmentes long fashion ireland persones visers syluer berdes thei knowne masker tooke lady daunsed lustely place sodenly kyng viscount torayne conueighed place chambre thereby quicklie thei ii six maskyng apparel cloth gold purple tinsell sattin greate log large uenicians fashio ouer great robe face visard wt beardes gold minstrelsie viii noble personage entred daunsed long lady thei daunsed fill quene plucked kynges visar lady visars lordes al knowe kyng gaue viscout torayn maskyng apparel kyng hym self ware also apparel viscount hym selfe masked riche whiche thanked hym kyng quene ambassadours returned banket chamber thei found banked ready set borde many marueilous dish wonder se kyng sat doune ioy myrth melody doen kyng went rest night spent day euen breakyng morowe ambassadours toke leaue kyng greate rewardes geuen came london ther rested two dayes departed hast homeward two house cupbordes hagynges al thinges kyng commaunded stand still thre foure day al honest persones might see beholde house rich thether came great nombre people see behold rich costely deuices ambassadours fraunce departed kyng set ambassade frauce say sir thomas boleyne knight viscout rochforth sir anthony broune knight came paris bishop bathe whiche lay fraunce ambassadour kyng englad thre went court saw frenche kyng persone swere kepe league amitie concluded betwene hym kyng englande thei greate chere maskes shewed vnto litle rewardes geuen viscount rochforth retorned englad bishop bathe shortly leauyng sir anthony broue behind ligier moneth maie x day kyng sent sir frauces poynes knightan ambassad sent themperour abassadour fro kyng englad charles themperor set clarenseaux king armes demaud one halfe treasure ordinauce take pauia somuch warr made well kynges charge themperors charge demaunded also duke orleauce deliuered also demauded themperour deliuer bishop rome take moneth shal also bring armie italy refused poinctes clareseauxin kynges name englande make defiaunce knowen warr like betwene emperour kyng england common england sore lamentyd chauce marchandise rest rayned passe themperours dominios marchautes wer desired cardinal kepe ther martes caleis nowise thei would assenf moneth kyng sent two fayre shippes well manned vitailed hauing diuers connyng men seke strange regionsshippes set seke straug rigions furth thei set tha twentie day may thei sped well shall retorne xxii day may cam post kyng fraunce bishop tarbie whiche beginnyng moneth bishop brought kyng england article frenche kyng offered emperour wer contrarie article sworne madryll xvii yere kyng farther moued kyng englande enemy themperour request well men say muche furtherd cadinall warres italie betwene pope theperour bishop made short tariyng kyng post ga e returned paris sir france poynes clareseaux whiche taried ther thei al toke ther io ay toward spayne retorne duke burbo themperou armie last winter liued ingreat pouertie clothes victaile wage thei maner desperat went toward parme bononie belongyng sea rome bishop rome hearyng set messenger duke redeme pope townes thei shoulde spoyled hurte duke capitaine axed thre hundreth fiftie thowsad ducates sauyng pope lad thei might haue much money thei would depart naples thei sawe thei coulde haue money spede turned toward florence xxii aprill whereof hearyng romaine thei wer glad thei thought florentine wold hold good war tha pope romaine woulde geue lokyng chause turned shall suertie duke burbon thought haue gon florence cause ther gentlema florence called peter de saluiata brother serued themperor warres promised deliuer citie determined cause common rebell citie gaynst heddes meane seaso duke co pany shulde scale walles whe peter knew themperours army armye come place called le chase within twelue myle citie bryng purpose conclusyon suche trayned cryed citie liber ate de populo english lybertie people voyce people styrred came palace great nombre tooke vi lordes counsell rule publyke welthe citie call slew one familie medices whiche pope kynred tyme sore fraied thus peter de saluiota common gate palace rang comen bell season florence capitayn frenche kynges called frederico de bodsoo hym iiic men saw rebellyon came common sayde syrs continew case fayre citie lyke subuerted enemyes hande notwithstandynge beare fauoure themperour appeareth yet needinesse pouertie soch without mercy thei wyll robbe sley wyfes chyldren sette fyer beautifull citie capitayne moche steyed citie notwithstandyng xx persones sleyne ruffle yet well auoyded sodeyngly entered citie duke urbyne lay vi myle florence xviii myle themperours armye coasted thought aduauntage medle duke brought hym vm footemen vic horseman entered citie crye made thynges pardoned euery man departed home delyuered weapon whiche dooen thus citie appeased xxviii day apryll doyng within citie vnknowne themperours armye beyonne ended iiii v houres lacke knowledge enterprise lost happye florentynes sore displeased themperours capitaynes knew channce also duke urbyne entered citie florence defence thei coulde doo shortly thei departed came citie seynes xxx myle lost great ordynaunce tooke counsell go rome notwithstandynge trewce concluded betwene pope uiceroy naples hugo de moncada haue hearde moche traucyled nyghtes dayes commenly passyng xl myle day nyght good wyll soche vi daye maie banner displaied came citie rome beynge saturdaye day sonday romaynes made bulwarkes rampiers defence
