handes frenche kinges tyme tribulacion ioyned together citie rome wt gouernors brought vtter ruyne decay whiche sayd pope clement al college cardinal senator ye citie wt al citezens rendered kyng hartie thakes mised loue fauor amitie perpetual oracion cocernyng trouble rome set forth suche lamentacio suche abhominable actes tyranyes part hearer thought eloquent true whiche oracion doctor fox prouost cambridge made discrete answerethe answere fyrst point declared kyng muche lamented heare frendes yea christen men ordered hadeled suche tyrany oppression touchyng second point sayd kyng duetie christen prince releue fredes beyng captiuitie whiche would whole citie rome geue thankes god whiche answere made two legate communed secretely kyng long space departed lodgyng comyng legate common people beyng ignorant truth especial woman fauored quene talked largely sayd kyng would pleasure haue another wife sent legate deuorsed fro quene many folishe wordes insomuche whosoeuer spake mariage comon people abhored reproued whiche comon rumour folishe comunicacions wer related kyng wherfore like prudet prince circumsp doer affaire willyng men know entent purpose caused nobilitie iudges counsailors diuers persones come palace brydewell sonday viii day noueber noone great chamber sayd nere witte could beare away wordes folowyng trustie welbeloued subiectes nobilitie meaner sortthe kynges oracion co cernyng first mariage vnknowen goddes prouision true lawfull inheritaunce haue reigned ouer realme england almost terme xx yeres duryng whiche tyme haue ordered v thanked god outwarde enemye hath oppressed taken thyng v haue inuaded realme haue victory honor thinke none predecessor neuer liued quietly wealthy estimacion vnder noble progen tor remember mortali ie must dye thinke doynges life tyme clerely defaced worthy memorie leue trouble tyme death true heyre knowen tyme death se mischiefe trouble shall succede child experience therof haue sene death noble graundfather kyng edward iiii haue heard mischief manslaughter continues realme betwene house yorke lancaster whiche discencion realme like haue clerely destroyed although hath pleased almighty god send v fayre doughter noble woman begotten great comfort ioy yet hath tolde v diuers great clerkes neither lawful doughter mother lawful wife liue together abhominably detestably open adultry insomuche ambassade last fraunce mocion made duke orleance mary sayd doughter one chiefe cousailors frenche kyng sayd wer well done know whither kyng englad lawful doughter well knowen begat brother wife whiche directly god law precept thinke lordes wordes touche body soule thinke doynges daily hourly trouble conscience vexe spirites yes doubt wer owne cause euery would seke remedy peril soule losse inheritauce openly layde cause protest god worde prince haue asked counsail greatest clerkes christendome cause haue sent legate man indifferent know truth settle conscience none cause god iudge touchyng quene adiudged law god lawfull wife neuer thyng pleasaunt acceptable life discharge cleryng conscience also good quality condicions whiche know assure allthe pr rse quene beside noble parentage whiche discended knowe woman moste gentlenes moste humilitie buxumnes yea al good quality appertainyng nobilitie without comparison xx yeres almoste haue true experiment mary againe mariage might good would surely chsoe aboue woman determined iudgement mariage goddes law clerely voyde shall onely sorowe departyng good lady louyng copanion muche lament bewaile nfortunate chaunce haue long liued adultry goddes great displeasure haue true heyre body inherite realme sore vexe mynde panges trouble coscience greues seke remedy therfore require trust confidence declare subiectes mynde entent accordyng true meanyng desyre pray v trueth may knowen discharge conscience sauyng soule declaracion hereof haue assembled together may depart see countenaunce made amongest hearer oracion straunge sight sighthed sayd nothyng sory heare kyng troubled conscience auored quene muche sorowed matter opened euery man spake heart serued kyng euer labored know trueth discharge conscience shortly two legate came quene place brydewellthe saiyng legate declared deputed iudges indifferent betwene kyng heare determyn whether mariage betwene siode goddes lawe heard cause comyng merueil though astonnied touched nere paused answered al lordes question whether kynges lawful wife haue maried almost xx yeres meane season neuer questio made dyuers prelate yet beyng aliue lordes also priuie cousailors kyng tyme adiudged mariage lawful honest say detestable abhominable thynke greate maruell especiall consider wise prince kynges father also loue naturall affeccion kyng fernando father bare vnto thynke self neither father vncircumspect vnwise small imaginacion thei forsawe might folowe mariage especiall kyng father sent courte rome long suite greate cost charge obteigned license dispensacion beyng one brother wife perauenture carnally knowen might without scrupull conscience mary brother lawfully whiche license vnder lead haue yet shewe whiche thynges make saie surely beleue mariage bothe lawfull good godly trouble onely maie thanke lorde cardinall yorke haue wondered high pride vainglory abhorre volupteous life abhominable lechery litle regard presupteous power tyranny therefore malice haue kyndeled fire set matter broche especiall greate malice beare nephewe emperour perfectly knowe hate worse scorpion would satisfie ambicion make pope force therefore haue saied would trouble hym frendes haue kept hym true promise warres vexacios onely may thanke poore aunte kynswoman trouble put newe found doubt god knoweth commit cause accordyng truth cardinall yorke excused hymself saiyng beginner mouer doubte sore euer mariage come question saied superior bishop rome deputied iudge heare cause whiche sware profession heare indifferently whatsoeuer saied beleued hym legate toke leaue departed woordes spoken frenche written cardinall campeius secretory whiche present translated nere could kyng notwithstandyng mynd vnquiet yet kept good countenaunce toward quene asmuche loue honor gentlenes could shewed suche prince absteined bed till truth tried accordyng ghostly counsail auised hym whiche hym litle pain surely loued well prince might loue wife hym therefore greate pitie mariage good quicken spirites recreacion kyng kepte christmas grenewiche muche solempnitie greate plentie viandes thether came twoo legate whiche wer receiued twoo duke diuerse erles baron gentleman kyng shewed greate pleasure bothe iustes tornay bankettes maskes disguisyngescardinal soonne word knight xii daie made lawfull sonne cardinal campeius borne wedlocke knight gaue hym coller golde quene shewed maner countenaunce made great ioye nothyng mynd troubled doyng england spred ouer al christendo letter euery region excepte spain emperor dominion thei adiudged kyng wise verteous prudent prince triyng truthe consideryng question onely doubtfull learned menne diuinitie vpon vncertaintie thesame depended ruine realme successio thesame whiche waightie thyng consider wisedome let greate doubte lye vndiscussed christmas lent till easter none thyng commoned onely kynges mariage archebishop cantorbury sent famous docters bothe uniuersities lambeth wer euery daie disputacions comonynges matter kyng perceiued knewe well quene wedded awne opinion would nothyng without counsail bad chose best clerkes realme counsaill licensed best part thei could accordyng truthe elected willyam warha archbishop catorbury nicholas west bishop elie docters lawes ihon fi bishop rochester henry standishe bishop sainct asse docters diuinitie many docters well learned men whiche suertie like men wel learned defended cause far learnyng might defend shall yere folowyng yere sir iames spenser maior londo whose tyme watche london midsomer night laied doune pthe xxi yerethe xxi yere beginnyng yere greate hall within blacke frier london ordeined solempne place twoo legate sit twoo cheyers couered clothe gold cusshions thesame dormant table rai ed like solempne courte couered carpettes tapisserythe courte blacke frier right hande court hanged clothe estate chayer cusshions riche tissue kyng left hande courte set riche chayer quene place redy kyng quene wer ascited docter sampson appere legate forenamed place twentie eight daie maie beyng morow feast corpus christi proper perso proctor daie assigned legate came forenamed place cross pillers ax ceremony belongyng degree thei wer set cardinal yorke sittyng right hand commission redde cause commyng thether openly declared effect whereof courte rome instructed greate clerkes learned men enformed kyng mariage brother wife vnlawfull dapnable directly againat lawe god wherefore thei directed appoynted thesaied courte bee iudges cause bothe party could bee alleged dooen kyng called name twoo procters appered quene called whiche within shorte space beyng accompaignied foure bishoppes counsaill greate compaignie lady gentle woman folowyng herthe quene appealed came personally legate obeisance sadly greate grauitie doen appeled iudges competent cause courte rome doen departed notwithstadyng appele legate sat wekely euery daie argumentes bothe partes nothyng el doen king whiche onely desired haue ende matter discharge conscience came courte iune quene also standyng vnder clothe estate saied wordes effect folowyngthe kynges oracion lordes legate sea appostolike whiche deputied iudges greate waightie matter moste hartely beseche ponder mynde entent whiche onely haue finall ende discharge coscience euery good christen man knoweth pain vnquietnes suffreth hath conscience greued assure myne honoure matter hath vexed mynd troubled spirites scantely studie thyng whiche bee proffitable realme people haue quietnes body soule desire request grudge beare haue maried dare saie womanhode wisedom nobilitie gentlenes neuer prince suche another therfore would willyngly chaunge wer wise wherfore suite lordes tyme haue spedy ende accordyng right quietnes mynde conscience onely cause god knoweth kyng saied quene departed without thyng saiyng called knowe whether would bide appeale answere legate procter answered would byde appeale notwithstandyng counsailers bothe side euery daie almoste met debated matter substancially last diuines opinion mariage lawe god carnally knowen first brother whiche thyng clerely denied answered prince arthur husbande confessed act doen called drynke earely mornyng saiyng spaine night whiche hote countrey meanyng carnally vsed father tyme death prince arthur thought iudged childe cause kyng deferred title creacion prince wale almoste halfe yere whiche thyng could haue iudged carnally knowen also self caused bull bee purchased whiche woordes vel forsan cogni whiche asmuche saie perauenture carnally knowen whiche woordes firste bull graunted iuly seconde mariage kyng whiche seconde bull clause onely purchased dispence second matrimony although carnall copulacion whiche bull neded haue purchased carnall copulacion irst bull sufficient diuines side beaten grounde thei fell perswasions naturall reason vndoen three cause one bee broken onely childe kyng bee bastarde whiche greate mischief realme secondly seperacion bee cause great vnkyndnes betwene kynred realme thirde cause continuaunce long space made mariage honest perswasions many sette furthe quenes counsaill especiall bishop rochester whiche stode stiffe cause yet goddes precept answered wherfore thei left ground fell pleadyng court rome dispensed mariage lawers saied yearthely persone able dispence positiue lawe god legate heard opinion diuines sawe opinion moste part matrimony nowe question brought dispute aucthoritie court rome thei beganne litle quicken thei consi ered thei aie determyne court rome might dispence case fewe menne would thynke thei might dispence case bee theim greate losse hurt wherfore thei dissimuled matter euer told kyng haue ende shortly tracted furthe tyme oracions sophisticall argumentes till august beganne approche cardinall campeius saied thei might sit iuly till october whiche season vacacion courte rome courte beeyng member courte rome thei muste nedes dooe thesame saiyng reported kyng whiche saiyng knewe perfectly haue ende complained duke norfolk suffolk noble counsaill delayed willed theim nexte session require make ende cause iudgement soeuer thei gaue would gladly accepte quietnes conscience noble menne came place legate sat xxx daie august beyng fridaie cardinal campeius declared eloquent latin sware honor faithe bare churhce rome course courtes thende iuly suspende cause till iiii daie october cause bee treated iudged meane season iudgement clerely voyde therfore required kyng take pacience till time trustyng thei procede toward sentece bee contented noble menne desired theim make ende whatsoeuer daie nexte daie whiche last daie iuly thei answered thei could sitte till october whiche answere sore displeased noble menne whiche kyng sent thether muche charles duke suffolke seeyng delaye gaue greate clappe table hande said masse see olde saied sawe true neuer legate cardinall good englande saiyng temporall lordes departed kyng leauyng legate sittyng one lookyng sore astonnied thei sawe temporall lordes depart anger maie bee sure kyng well content hard delaye yet like wise prince tooke paciently trustyng haue ende october ensuyng heard tell letter sent cardinall campeius spede returne italy prouided iorney openly perceiued legate dissimuled tyme haue matter courte rome mainteinaunce aucthoritie knoweyng perfectly bee foded furthe argumentes long bee maner wery also tyme bee vnquiet conscience whiche greatest care seconde care tooke see cardinall yorke highly fauoured trusted highly promoted bothe archbishopriche yorke bishopriches winchester duresme abbay saincte albones many greate dignity promocions beside chauncellorshippe englande vnfaithfully dissimule hym open truthe whiche caused hym clerely cast hym fauor whiche long whe noble prelate perceiued kynges fauor cardinall sore minished euery manne kynges counsaill beganne laye hym suche offence thei knewe hym accusacions written boke handes set nombre thirtie foure whiche boke thei presented kyng kyng sawe boke marueiled litle article conteigned thesame euidently perceiued high pride coueteousnes cardinall sawe openly dissimulacion clokyng handeled kynges cause faire liyng woordes blynded defrauded kyng moste vntruly whiche accusacions sore moued kyng hym yet kepte close tyme kyng rode progresse quene woodstocke feast natiuitie lady came grafton beside stony stratforde thether came twoo legate meanely receiued sauyng kyng made theim good semblaunce especiall cardinall campeius came englande request dinner saied campeius toke leaue kyng kyng conueighed chamber dore thei departed cardinall yorke also wente compaignion tocester morowe came grafton speake kyng whiche rydyng huntyng sent hym woorde henry norreis accompaignie campeius london kyng came london would comen hym thus almoste dismaied cardinall yorke returned compaignion tocester thei came together london cardinall campeius deliuered greate rewardes toke iorney toward sea side kynges counsail caused chestes cariages opened se letter cardinal yorke sent court rome wer fewe letter found thei sent poste many chestes wer found old hosen old coates suche vile stuffe honest man would eary haue serche muche displeased ca peius coffer wer like wise opened chepe rashenes moile heard tenth yere kyng thus departed englande high displeasure craftie cardinall campeiusthe last time card nall came kynges presence leauyng behynde hym subtle felowe whiche departyng kyng grafton neuer sawe kyng came presence greate session legate commued christendome especiall spain emperor dominion sore grudged quene bee diuorsed kyng surely moste part laye people englande whiche knewe lawe god sore murmored matter muche gentle woman courte called anne bulleyne daughter sir thomas bulleyne uiscount rocheforde kyng muche fauoured honestie surely none otherwise worlde well knewe cause quenes lady gentlewoman seruauntes largely spake saied entised kyng brought suche amour onely sake occasion would diuorsed quene foolishe communicacion people contrary truth haue hard declared kyng whiche twentie yere paste ruled especiall cardinall yorke began ruler kyng yea kyng suche witte wisedome pollicie like hath reigned ouer realme shall playnly perceiue aswell settyng furthe true doctryne also augmentacion croune perceiued howe cardinalles handeled hym sawe plainly lawe god clere might mary brother wife thought sende ambassadours uniuersities fraunce italy knowe determinacions cause sent doctor stokesley doctor foxe twoo greate cler e fraunce whiche sped shall declared tter serueth kyng continually studiyng matterthe kyng begynneth rule called counsaill chief noble begin westminster firste daie october next ensuyng also somoned parliamet begin third daie nouember immediatly folowyng declared thesame cou saill deuise diuerse actes necessary nedefull bee passed thesaied parliament reformacion certain exaccions dooen clergie laye people whiche counsaill parliament cardinall warned somoned whiche muche conforted hym outwardly litle abashed al counsaill came cou saill chamber westminsterthe cardinalles prid abated diuerse day communed diuerse thynges nothyng fully concluded cardinall shewed hymself muche humblier wont lordes shewed themselfes higher straunger thei wont bee abashed countenaunce came westminster hall trayne firste daie terme none kynges seruauntes would go thei wont sat chauncery starre chamber lordes kynges counsaill gone wynsore kyng thei enformed kyng thynges dooen almoste power legantyne case premunire prouison cardinall forfected landes tenementesthe cardinall premunire goodes catelles kyng wherefore kyng willyng ordre accordyng ordre lawes caused attorney cristopher hale sue writte premunire hym whiche licensed hym make attorney farther seuentene daie nouember sent twoo duke norffolke suffolk place westminster fetche awaie greate seale englande whiche lothe deliuer may remedy conclusion deliuered twoo duke whiche deliuered thesame docter tailor master rolles cary kyng whiche next daie beside kyng sent sir william fitz willyam knight garter thresorer house docter stephin gardiner newle made secretary se goodes embesiled house farther ordeined cardinall remoue ashire beside kyngston tary kynges pleasure haue thynes deliuered hym whiche wer necessary hym old popeous superfluous fashion goodes wer seazed kynges vse whe seale thus taken cardinall duke norffolke suffolk many erles bishoppes baron came starre chamber xix daie october duke norffolke declared kynges highnes diueise sondery offence taken fro hym greate seale deposed hym office least menne might complain lacke iustice appoynted hym duke suffolke assent lordes sit starre cha ber heare determine cause indifferently thynges kynges pleasure commaundement thei kepe handes close rewardes takyng maintenaunce weke thei sat starre chamber determined cause daie thesame moneth cardinall remoued house called yorke placethe cardinalles remouyng yorke place one crosse saiyng would neuer borne meanyng crosse bare legate whiche degre taking confusion se openly toke barge went putney water toke horse rode asher remaigned till lent duryng whiche tyme beeyng called answere kynges bench premunire geuyng benefice preuension disturbance mennes enheritaunce diuerse open cause premunire accordyng kynges license constituted ihon scute edmond ienny apprentice lawe attorneis whiche awne warrant signed hande confessed thynges concernyng thesaid suite thei wer ope cloked hidden iudgement geuen forfet al lades tenemetes goodes catalles kynges proteccio kyng sent hym sufficient proteccion gentlenes left hym bishoprikes yorke winchester gaue hym plate stuffe conueniet degree bishoprike duresme gaue docter tunstall bishop london abbey sainct albones gaue prior norwiche london promoted docter ihon stokesley ambassador uniuersities kynges mariage haue hard kyndnes shewed cardinall yet still maligned kyng shall perceiue vntrue doynges whiche brought hym confusion twentie three daie october kyng came manor grenewiche muche consulted counsaill mete manne bee chauncellour wise manne spiritualtie long debate kyng resoluted hymself vpon sir thomas knight chauncellour duchie lancastre manne well learned toungues also common lawe whose witte fyne full imaginacions reason wherof muche geuen mockyng whiche grauitie greate blemishesir thomas made chauncellor sondaie twentie foure daie thesame monethe kyng made hym chauncellour deliuered hym greate seale whiche lorde chauncellour next morow ledde chauncery two duke norffolk suffolke sworne mace borne hym let v returne treatie cambray whiche appoynted bee kepte last sommer conclusion peace betwene emperor one part kyng englande frenche kyng parte whiche conclusion came cambrey lady margaret duches sauoy aunte emperour lady loyse duches angulesme mother frenche kyng docter tunstall bishoppe london bishoppe duresme sir thomas knight made chauncellour englande diuerse kyng englande mette beginnyng iuly accompaignied diuerse great prince counsailers euery parte long debatyng bothe side good conclusion taken fifth daie august whiche concluded treatie madrill stande full strength vertue sauyng thirde fourthe leuenth fourtenth article whiche touche duchie burgoyne lordshippes item agreed frenche kyng haue child deliuered paiyng emperoure twoo millyons crounes gold whereof paie deliueryng child twelue hundred thousande crounes item frenche kyng acquite emperoure kyng englande foure skore tenne thousande crounes whiche emperoure ought kyng englande kyng englande deliuer suche bondes gage emperours item touchyng remnant whiche fiue hundred tenne thousande crounes emperor haue xxv thousande crounes rent yerely whiche haue landes duches uandosme liyng flaunders brabant bounde item flaunders diuerse coutreys behold chief haue resort croune fraunce item realme naples duchie millain countie ast euer remain emperor item frenche kyng drawe suche souldiers italy item lady elianor bee brought fraunce frenche kynges child tyme conuenient maried frenche kyng item frenche kyng aide emperor twelue gallies go italy item prisoner bothe party acquited item frenche kyng ayde robert de la marche bishop luke item al goodes moueable vnmoueable charles late duke burbon bee restored heires thei paiyng lorde henry marque dapenete erle nassaw lorde chamberlayne emperor tenne thousande ducates whiche lent thesaied duke burbon item ihon erle panthieure bee remitted al suche goodes erle rene father item lorde laurence de gorowod greate master emperoure bee restored lordeshippes chalmount monteualle whiche bought duke burbon el haue money item phillip de chalon prince orenge uiceroy naples restored landes burgoyne item duches uandosme loys erle nau r haue suche right accions thei haue warre began emperours countreys thynges written sealed finished solempne masse song cathedrall churche cambrey twoo lady ambassador kyng englade sittyng greate estate masse peace proclaimed betwene three prince te deum song money cast people greate fire made citee thesame night frenche kyng came cambrey well nobly accompaignied saluted lady made diuerse bankettes persones departed countrey glad concord peace called womennes peacethe womennes peace notwithstandyng conclusion yet neither emperoure trusted frenche kyng neither trusted loued hym subiectes wer thesame case proclamacion proclaymed solempnely herauldes tropettes citee london whiche proclamacion muche reioysed englishe merchantes repairyng spain flaunders brabant zelande emperor dominion duryng warres merchantes euill handeled bothe party whiche caused desirous peace remembred present tyme willya tyndale newly translated imprinted newe testament englishe bishop londoncutbard tu stall bishop lodo bought newe testamentes burne pleased translacion thereof debated hymself might compasse deuise destroye false erronious translacion saied happened one augustine packyngton mercer merchant london greate honestie thesame tyme andwarp bishope packyngton man highly fauored william tindale bishop vtterly shewed hymself contrary bishop desirous haue purpose brought passe commoned new testamentes gladly would bye packyngton hearyng wished saied vnto bishop lorde bee pleasure matter dooe dare saie moste merchauntes englande knowe dutche men straungiers haue bought theim tyndale haue theim sell lordshippes pleasure paye otherwise cannot come must disburse money theim assure haue euery boke imprinted vnsolde bishop thinkyng god deede thought deuell fifte saied gentle master packyngton diligence get harte paie whatsoeuer thei cost bokes erronious naughtes entende surely destroy theim allaugustyne packyngton bishop londos merchaunt burne theim paules crosse agustine packyngton came willyam tyndale saied willyam knowe thou arte poore man hast hepe newe testamentes bokes thee whiche thou hast bothe indaungered thy frendes beggered thy self haue gotten thee merchaunt whiche ready money shall dispatche thee thou hast thynke proffitable hour self merchant said tindale bishoppe london saied packyngton burne saied thyndale ye mary packyngton gladder said tyndale two benefites shall come therof shall get money hym bokes bryng self debt whole worlde shall crie vpon burnyng goddes worde ouerplus money shall remain shall make studious correct thesaid newe testament newly imprint thesame trust second muche better like euer first forward went bargain bishop bokes packyngton thankes tyndale money afterward mo newe testamentes imprinted thei came thicke threfold englande bishop london hearyng still many newe testamentes abrode sent augustyne packyngton saied vnto sir commeth many newe testamentes abrode promised assured bought al said packyngto promes bought bee perceiue thei haue made sence neuer bee better long thei haue letter stampes therefore wer best lordeshippe bye stampes sure bishop smiled hym saied well packyngton well ended matter shortly fortuned one george constatinegeorge constantyne apprehended sir thomas whiche lorde chauncellor england suspicio certain heresy constantine beyng diuerse examinacions diuerse thynges emong master saied wise constantine constantine would haue thee plain one thyng aske thee promes thee shewe thee fauor thynges whereof thou art accused beyond sea tyndale ioye great many mo knowe thei cannot liue without helpe sendeth theim money succoureth theim thy self beyng one haddest parte thereof ore knowest whence came praie thee thei thus helpe lorde constatine shal tell truethe yea praie thee lorde mary constantyne truly bishoppe london hath holpen v hath owed emong v greate deale money new testamentes burne theim hath yet onely succoure comfort trothe thynke eue thesame said muche bishop went bye treatie thus communicacion cambrey themperor whiche knewe people lacked aide italy also perceiued people germany italy hym suche honor thei would wer crouned emperor al writynges thei called hym onely charles elected emperor wherefore determined go italy greate puyssaunce bothe receiue imperiall croune also aide people whiche remained acc paignied many prince noble men spain men war toke shipp barcilona sailed geane receiued seigniorie cittethe pope ame onony greate triumphe honor great presentes geuen hym pope clement hearyng emperor come italy cardinalles whole courte came citee bononie taried emperor commyng emperor laie geane thether came hym diuerse great prince italy greate power thynges wer redy set forward good ordre battaill towarde bononie euery toune receiued presented greate giftes feasted long iorneis came nere bononie firste met hym clergie citie procession vniuersitie habites al horsebake came child citie white sattin fringed gold marchautes citie al rimosyn damaske folowed potestates gouernors citie crimosyn veluet within myle citie met hym foure twentie cardinalles triumph themperor coueighed cathedrall church wher steppe west dore chair sat pope clement emperour lighted kissed fotethemperour kiss th pope fete thei embraced together went church together went pallace thei wer lodged daily kepte great counsayles together cardinall lay bononie ther came fraunces sforse duke millane excuse hym selfe thynges hym obiected muche entreatyng pope request pardoned hym offence restored dignitie possession paiyng hym nine hundreth thousand ducates till thei wer paied castel millayne toune crome abide themperours possessio agrement emperoure set anthony de leua made capitayne ordinaunce duchy millayne brought quiet season kyng englad sent sir nicholas carew knight master horse doctor sapson bononie ratificacion league concluded cambray performance whereof emperour solemplie sworne ambassadours departed lykewise themperour set england peter lord rosebec likewise sawe kyng england sworne performe according somons kyng englade began high court parliamet third day nouembre day came water place bridewell noble put robe parliamet came blacke freers church wher masse holy ghost solemplie song kynges chappell masse kyng lordes parliament common somoned apere day came parliamet cha bre wher kyng sat throne seate royal sir thomas chauncelor standyng righthand kyng behynde barre made eloquent oracionan oracion declaryng like good shepard whiche alonely kepeth attendeth well shepe also forseeth prouideth althyng either may hurtful noysome stoke may preserue defende thesame agaynst peryles may chaunce come kyng whiche sheaperd ruler gouernour realme vigilatly forseyng thinges come cosidered diuers lawes tyme wer made nowe log co tinuance tyme mutacion thinges insufficient vnperfight also frayl condicion man diuers new enormity sprog amongest people law yet made reforme thesame cause tyme kyng somoned high courte parliament resembled king shepard heard man cause prince compared hys rich richeman prince compared honour honorable man compare multitude people numbre flocke ruler gouernor might puissaunce people maketh prince multitude shepe commeth name shepherd se emongest great flocke shepe rotte fauty good sheperd sendeth good shepe great wether late fallen knowe craftely scabedly ye vntruly iuggeled kyng men must nedes gesse thinke thought self wit perceiue craftie doyng el presumed kyng woulde se know fraudulent iuggeling attemptes deceiued grace sight quike penetrable saw ye saw without thing open according desert hath gentle correction small ponishmet kyng example offendoures clerly declareth whosoeuer shall make like attempt commit like offence shall escape lyke ponyshment common house grosse multitude cannot speake one time therfore kynges pleasure shall resorte totn nether house ther emongest self accordyng olde auncient custome chose able perso comon mouth speaker youre election made aduertise grace therof wyll declare pleasure day wil haue hym preset place done common resorted nether house thei chose speaker thomas audeleythomas audelei chosen speake esquier attorney duchie lancaster day parliamet adiourned westminster sixt day moneth king came parliament chambre lordes robe ther common nether house presented speker whiche made eloquent oracionan oracion cosisted two poynctes first poynct muche praysed kyng equitie iustice mixed mercy pitie none offence forgotten left vnponished punishment extremitie rigor lawe cruelly extended whiche shuld cause bridel men like also comforte ffendors confesse crime offence occasion amendment reconciliacion second poinct disabled selfe lacke wit learnyng discrecio high office beseching kyng cause c mon resort eftsones ther common house chose speaker parliament kyng mouth lorde chauncelor answered disabled hym selfe wit learnyng awne ornate oracion made testified contrary touching discrecio quality kyng selfe well knowe doynges sith seruice wise discrete hable man accepted speaker admitted common assembled nether house thei began common grefes wherwith spiritualtie tyme greuously oppressed cotrarie lawe realme cotrarie al righte especial thei sore moued sixe greate cause first excesse fynes ordinary toke probat testamentes insomuche sir henry guilford knight gartir comptrollor kinges house declared open parliament fidelitle beyng executor sir william compton knight paied probate wil cardinal archbishop cauntorburie thousand marke sterlyng declaracion shewed many extorcions done ordinary probate willes muche rehearse second cause great polling extreme exaccion spirituall men vsed takyng corp presentes mortuary child defunct al dye hunger go beggyng rather thei woulde charitie geue sely kow dead man ought one charitie third cause priestes beyng surueiors stuardes officer bishoppes abbotes spirituall heddes occupied fermes graunges grasing euery contrey poore husbandman coulde haue nothyng yet thei shulde pay derely fourth cause abbotes prior spiritual men kept tanne house bought soulde woll clothe maner marchaundise temporall marchauntees fift cause beause spiritual persones promoted great benefice hauyng liuyng flocke liyng courte lordes house toke al parishoners nothin spent al lack residece poore parish lacked refreshyng vniuersally al parishioner lacked preaching true instruccio godes worde greate pe ell soules sixt cause se one priest beyng litle learned haue tenne twelue benefice resident none know many well learned scholers vniuersitie able preche teache haue nether benefice exhibicion thinges time might nowise towched yet talked man except would made heritike ro lese al bishopes chauncelors rule kyng man durst presume attempt thing contrary proffit commoditie god illumined eies kyng ther subtell doinges espied men began charitably desyre reformacion parliamet men bega shew ther grudge vpon burgess parliament appoincted suche learned law common house drawe one bill probate testamentes nother mortuary thirde none residece plurality takyng fermes spiritual men learned men toke muche payne firste sett furthe bill mortuary whiche passed common house sent vp lordes bill spirituall lordes made fayre face saiyng surely priestes curate toke thei therefore well done take reasonable ordre thus thei spake touched litle two day set vp bill concerning probate testamentes archbishop cauntorburre especiall bishoppes generall frowned gruntyd touched ther proffite insomuch doctor ihon fisher bishop rochesterthe saiyug fisher b rochester saied openlie parliament chambre woordes lordes se daily billes come hither commo house distruction churche godes sake se realme kyngdome boheme church went doune fell glory kyngdome common nothing doune church semeth lacke faith wordes reported common nether house bishop say ther doynges lacke faith thei toke matter gre ously thei imagined bishop estemed heretikes slaunderous woordes would haue perswaded temporall lordes haue restrained consent saied two billes whiche thei passed haue hard wherefore common long debate determined send speaker parliament kinges highnes greuous complaynt agaynst bishop rochester day kyng laysera complayne kyng thomas audeley speaker common thirtie chief common house came kynges presence palace westminster whiche called yorke place eloquently declared dishonour kyng realme say thei elected wysest men boroughes within realme englad shoulde declared noble open presence lacke faith whiche equiualent say thei infidelles christian turkes sarasins payne studie euer thei toke common wealth actes lawes euer thei made stablished shulde taken lawes made panyms hethen people worthi kept christian men wherfore hymbly besought kinges highnes cal saied bishop cause speake discretly nombre como house kyng well contented saiyng bishop yet gently answered speaker woulde send bishop send worde answere made thei departed agayne kyng sent archebishope cauntorburie sixe bishopes bishop rochester also declared grudge commonsthe bishop excuse bishop answered ment doinges bohemian lacke faith doynges common house whiche saiyng confirmed bishopes present greate reputacio saiyng kyng accepted excuse therfore sent woord comons sir william fitz william knight treasoror househoulde blind excuse pleased common nothyng diuers assembly wer kept betwene certein lordes certayne common billes probate testamentes mortuary temporaltie laied tot spiritualtie ther awne lawes constitucions spiritualtie sore defended prescripsion vsage whome answere made gentleman greyes inne vsage hath euer ben theues robbe shoters hill ergo lawfull answere spirituall men sore offended doynges called robbery temporall men stode still saiynges muche saied gentle man saied archebishop cauntorburie exaccion probate testamentes takyng mortuary thei vsed open robbery theft long disputacion temporall lordes began leane comons al billes remayned vnconcluded meane seasonthe oane released bill assented lordes sent doune common theffect wherof whole realme saied acte release tot kyng suche somes money borowed loane fiftene yere raigne haue hard bill sore argued common house parte common kynges seruauntes labored bill assented realease loane knowen common realme lorde thei grudged spake ill hole parliament almoste euery man counted dette reconed suerly payment therefore made willes thesame set ouer debt many men losse caused sore murmur ther remedy kyng like good discrete prince seing common parliament house released loane entendyng somewhat requite thesame graunted generall pardon offence certayn great offence debtes except also aidid redresse greues spiritualtie caused two newe billes made indifferently probate testamentes mor uaries billes resonable spirituall lordes assented though thei sore myndes especiall probate testamentes sore displeased bishopes mortuary sore displeased persones vicar actes thus agreed common made nother acte pluralitis benefice none residence biyng selling takyng f rmes spirituall persones whiche acte displeased spiritualtie priestes railed common common house called heretikes scismatikes diuerse priestes ponished acte sore debated aboue parliament chambre lordes spirituall woulde nowise consent wherfore kyng perceiuing grudge common caused eight lordes eight common mete starre chambre none ther sore debatyng cause insomuche temporall lordes vpper house toke parte common agaynst spirituall lordes force reason caused assent bil litle qualifiyng whiche bill nexte day wholy greed lordes house great reioisyng lay people greate displeasor spirituall persones duryng parliament brought doune common boke article whiche lordes put kyng agaynste cardinall chief article first without kynges assent procured legate reason whereof toke away right bishopes spiritual persones item writynges wrot rome foreyn prince wrot ego et rex meus kyng woulde say kyng seruaunt item hath sclaundered church england courte rome suggestion legat reforme churche englande worte f cta reprobum censum item without kynges assent caried kynges great seale withe hym flaunders sent ambassad emperoure item without kynges assent sent commission sir gregory de cassado knighte conclude league betwene kyng duke farrar without kynges knowlege item hauyng frenche pockes presumed come breth kyng item caused cardinalles hat put kynges coyne item woulde suffer kynges clarke market sit sainct talbons item sent innumerable substaunce rome obteinyng dignity greate enpouerishment realme article many red common house signed cardinalles hande confessed hym also ther shewed writyng sealed seale whiche gaue kyng mouables vnmouables day concepcion oure lady kyng yorke place westminster parliament tyme created vicount rochforth earle wilshire vicount fitzwater created earle sussex lorde hastynges created earle huntyngton althynges concluded parliament house kyng came parliament chambre seuentene day decembre put royall assent althynges done lordes common proroged court parliament tyll next yere parliament thus ended kyng remoued grenewiche ther kept christemas quene greate triumph great plenti viaundes diuerse disguisynges enterludes greate reioisyng people haue harde emperour pope bononie wher emperour made great proparacion solempnisyng coronacion whiche appoincted sainct mathias day foure twentie day february whych day borne day also french kyng taken day ben euer fortunate appoincted coronacion day apoincted also place woulde soner passe almayne appece suche striefes debate risen betwene prince wha day came euery thing redy crowned emperor churche peter citie bononi pope clemet vii al ceremony therto beloging coronacio wer present duke sauoy millayn duke frederik brother palatine rine deputy seuen elector parte al noble italy spayne coronacion done great solemnity feastyng iustyng torney althinges might sounde honoure shewed bothe apparell viaunde emperoure pope hole college cardinalles al noble men beyng present rode procession hie stretes bononi suche pompe triumph bene sene italy many yeres emperour lay thus bononie kyng englande aduertised ambassadoures whiche sent diuers vniuersities assoluyng doubte cocernyng mariage saied vniuersities wer agreed clerly concluded one brother mary brother wife carnally knowne directlie god lawe pope court rome could wise dispence wherefore kyng knowyng themperour bishop rome gether bononie determined send thether asolempne ambassade declare law god determinacion vniuersities also require bishop rome iustice acco yng treuth also shewe emperoure kyng moue matter displeasure bare quene awnt discharge conscience quietnes realme purpose agreed kynges counsayle kyng appoincted sir thomas bulleyne late created earle wylshier doctor stoksley elected bishop london doctor edward lee almoner two great clarkes ambassadours set diuers doctor lawe diuinitie ambassadoures made greate preparacion begynnyng februarie thei set forward muche thei trauailed thei came sauoy wher duke fayre toune cambrey caused honorably bee receiued fested thei passed mountaynes duchie millain long iorneis thei came bononie lent wher thei wer honorably receiued master emperoures house diuers lordes gentleman belongyng pope within short space saied ambassadoures first conueighed pope declared ther message shewed determinacion great doctor famous vniuersities pope clement whiche man learnyng great wit made gentle answerethe pop wear saied woulde matter disputed came rome according right woulde iustice entent al contrarie knew wel geue sentence pope iuly coulde dispence breache godes lawe aucthoritie courte rome would litle regarded also feared emperours displeasure shoulde geue sentence againste awnte feare losing aucthoritie themperors displeasure bishop clement durst iudge according goddes lawe thei bene pope thei came emperour whiche gently receiued thei done message answered wise would agaynst lawe god court rome would adiudge matrimonie good would cotet thought al otherwise solicited pope al cardinalles wer frendes stad dispesacio iudged strong goddes law answere thei toke ther leaue emperor nexte weke departed bononie towarde almayne good ordre battail selfe gilt harnes noble white harnes riche cote trapper curiously besene themperour gon bononie ambassadoures england toke leaue bishop rome went toward rome agayne retorned toward england duchy millayn whiche receiued earle lodouick greate counsaylor duke millain earle coducted whole duchie millayne paied al charge duke comaudemet whe ambassador wer passed mountaynes thei receiued letter fro kyng appoincted earle wilshire go ambassade frenche king lay burdeaux makyng prouision money redemyng child bishop london appoyncted go padua vniuersities italy know ther opinion kynges cace kinges almoner apoincted retorne englad thus end ambassad haue hard cardinall attainted premunire put office chauncelor lay asher lent season kyng aduice counsayle licenced go diocesse orke gaue commaundemet kepe hym diocesse returne southwarde without kynges speciall licence writyng made great great prouision go northwarde appareled seruauntes newly bought many costely thinges houshold might wel inoughthomas cromwel came kynges seruice kynges getlenes bishopprickes yorke winchester wer small thinges time diuers seruautes departed kynges seruice especiall thomas crumwel one chief counsayle chefe doer suppressio abbeis al thinges necessarie iornay wer prepard toke iorney northward til came southwel dioces ther cotinued yere euer grudging fall shall lades geue college oxforde ypswych come kynges handes atteinder premunire yet kyng gentlenes fauour bare good learnyng erected agayne college oxford named cardinalles college called kynges college endewed faire possession put newe statute ordinaunces college ypswich thought nothing proffitable therefore lefte dissolued last somer peace treated cambray haue hard ferdinando brother emperour recouered certayne tounes turkes taken hym hyngry put flighte ennemy ihon uainoda whiche falsly named selfe kyng hungary uainoda destitute succoure fled sultan soliman great turke desiryng hym succor recouer hungry gaiue turke glad haue occasion distroy hungry assembled puissan army entred hungry made proclamacion toune citie woulde obey kyng ihon ther kyng put fire sworde proclamacion fearid hugarians al maner yelded self subiectes uainoda citie bude onely except whych last yelden composicion shuld depart bag baggage al safe conduit signed withe great turkes hand thei firste robbed ian zeres shamfully slain turke thus bude possession left uainodacrueltie turkes lewes great bastard sonne duke uenice fiue thousand fotemen two thousand horsmen haste entered austrice wher people committed crueltie tiranny neuer hath hard written thei put eies thei cut nose eares thei cut priuy bers woman thei cut pappes rauished uirgins woman great child thei cut ther belly brent child beside thei passed thei brent corne tree howses al would brent make contry desolate last two twentie day septembre turkes armie came nye uienne riche famous citie austrice fame two hundreth fiftie thousande men armie fiue twentie thousande tentes sighte citie beginnyng siege certein christian men taken turkes turkes cut heddes foure leper lazer cote without citie put vpon pole made christen prisoner preset great turk therof toke great ioy prisoner released certain bad go captaynes tell thei would yeld citie hym thei depart bag bagage thei would kepe force woulde suerly haue put al sword citie captayn duke phillip bauier earle palantine rine nephew palsgraue elector young man noble corage twentie thousand almaynes two thousand horseme nothing feared turkes threatnynges turke perceiuyng ther boldnes bent grete ordinaunce thre hundreth peces gaynst walles commaundyd towne assauted turkes gaue greate assaut christen men valiantly defended turkes compelled fle many slaine fourth day octobre turke bent ordinaunce wal shoke wal al men within supposed walles would haue fallen doune thei litle harme sone amendid sixt day octobre eight thousand christen men issued toune came wher turkes miner wer working slew gret nombre destroyed mine dai turkes gaue great assaute citie christyan men valiantly defended threw downe great loggs barres iron slew many turkes thus turkes assauted citie leuen time somany time wer bete away great terrible assaut twelue day octobre assaut christyan men valiantly defended selfe slewe hurt many turkes day commandement turke could geue woulde nomore geue assaute turke perceiued well bothe strength citie corage capitaines also winter muche colder contreys sore troubled hym people wherfore called counsail concluded breake vp siege departe fouretene day octobre shot greate stone citie day till night boute tenne clok night caused tentes take vp fire strawe stuffe remoued al armie towarde bude sauing fiftie thousande horseman whiche taried next day behynde cariyng hym greate nombre christyan prisoner whiche put mine suche vile seruice siege turke loste murderthe numbre turkes died sicknes cold aboue fourescore thousande men one bassates afterwarde confesse thus citie uienne defended gaynst greate turke power whiche greate displeasure especially n uer beseg citie either yelden taken tyme siege metrician made verse cesar italiam quo venit carolus anno cincta est ripheis nostra vienna getis yere themperour gaue lord master saynt ihones ierusalem bretherne iland malto liyng betwene scicile barbarie employ selfe vpon christes ennemies lorde master place suer enhabite sith put rodes turke beseged uienne haue hard xxii yere begynnyng two twentie yere kyng like politike prudent prince perceiued subiectes person diuers time within foure yeres last past brought realme greate nombre printed bokes new testament translated english tongue tyndall ioy bokes common people vsed dayly red priuely clargie would admit thei punnished suche persones red studied taught thesame greate extremitie bycause multitude greate power redresse grefe wherfore made complaint chauncelor leaned much spirituall mennes part cause vpon imprisoned punished greate nomber cause great rumor controuersie rose daily emongest people wherfore kyng cosideryng good might come readyng new testament reuerence folowyng thesame euell mighte come readyng thesame euil translated folowed came starre chambre fiue twentie day may commoned counsaile prelate cocernyng cause long debatyng alleged translacion tyndall ioy truely translated also prologue preface sounded heresiethe newe testamet orbidden rayled bishopes vncharitably wherefore suhe bokes prohibited commaundemet geuen kyng bishoppes thei callyng best learned men vniuersities cause new translacion made people ignoraunte law god notwithstandyng commaundement bishopes nothing set furth new tra slacio caused people stody tindalles translacion reaso many thinges cam light shall yere maye bishop londo caused al newe testametes bought many bokes brought paules churcheyarde london openly burned ende yere wilde irishman knowyng earle ki dare england entred lande spoyled brent coutrey diuers contreyes earle ossery beyng kynges deputie made litle resistaunce lacke power wherfore kyng sent erle kyldare ireland sir wyllyam skeuyngton knight master kynges ordinaunce diuers gunner whiche pollitickly ordered selfe enemyes glad offre amendes treate turce sir wyllyam skeuyngton nexte yere returned england leuyng erle kyldare kynges deputie wyll returne execucion treatie cambray whiche agreed lady elianor frenche kynges child deliuered raunsome appointed paied haue heard last yere wherfore ye frenche kyng gathered money subiectes wt spede money ready sent great master fraunce called anna de memorancye noble bayon money receiue lady child thither came great constable castle mounsire prat emperor crounes wayed touched fault soeuer spanyardes found thei would receiue great nomber caried child backe fro foutraby spayne thus great master fraunce company lay styll bayon without hauyng purpose performed marche till ende iune lenger lyen kyng england sent sir fraunces bryan bayon warrant payment wherevpon day deliueraunce appointed sainct peter day iune whiche day great master xxxi mulettes laden crounes came one sydethe deliueraunce frenche kynges child riuer auday whiche riuer departeth spayne fraunce taried till first day iuly whiche day lady elianor child put two great boates hauyng onely xii gentleman spayne like maner great master two great boates money xii gentleman boates met brydge made middes riuer constable spayn xii gentleman met great master fraunce xii gentleman bridge litle salutacion frenchemen entered ii boates lady two child spanyardes two boates money eche part hasted land thus frenche kynges wife child deliuered handes whiche deliueraunce great ioy triumph made fraunce also iuly fyers made london diuers place thesame consideracion cause emperor haue heard last yere passed italy germany receiued great honor triumph citie ausborough august iune present elector almoste prince empyre kept great counsail prince germany two seueral opinion seueral name part fauored pope thynges done aucthoritie called catholical part whiche folowed preached onely fospel christ called euangclical thynges concernyng fayth wer many cou sailes cardinal campeius pope legate would suffer euangelical persones called lutheran argue catholical men euagelical person called papystes lest openyng scripture authoritie ye court rome haue bamned therfore emperor put matter till another tyme matter let slyppe mocion men serched law god within yeres many people refused pope head churche forsoke pardon xix day september citie lodon sayd made quene purchased new bull ratificacion mariage sayd made cardinall purchased bull curse kyng would restore old dignity king suffer correct spiritualtie meddle ame inuencion sounded moste trueth shall heare afterward october riuer tyber heigth rome place rome almoste xiim person drouned next moneth zeland holland brabant sore noyed water many people muche cattel drouned haue heard last yere cardinall yorke attainted premunire notwithstanding king geuen b oprickes yorke wynchester great plentie substaunce licesed lye dioces yorke beyng dioces grudgyng fall remembryng kynges kyndnes shewed wrote court rome diuers prince letter reproche kyng muche lay stirred reuenge cause kyng realme insomuche diuers opprobrious wordes kyng spoken doctor edward keerne kynges orator rome sayd cardinal sake kyng haue worse spede suite matrimonythe pryde cardinal cardinal also would speake fayre people wynne heartes declared euer vniustly vntruely ordered whiche fayre speakyng made many beleue sayd true getlemen gaue great giftes allure vnto reputacion among people determined installed inthronised yorke al pompe might caused trone erected cathedral church suche heigth fashio neuer seen sent lordes abbo te prior knightes esquiers gentleman dioces manor cawod vi day nouember bryng yorke maner pompe solempnitie kyng whiche knewe doynges priuye conueyaunce yere dissembled matter see would length till saw proude heart high exalted would triumphantly installed without makyng kyng priuye yea maner disdayne kyng thought mete conuenient suffer lenger continue malicious proude purpose attemptes wherfore directed letter henry vi erle northumberland willyng al diligence arrest cardinal deliuer therle shrewsbury great stewarde kynges housholde erle seen letter couenient nomber came manor cawod iiii day nouember brought cardinal chamber sayd lord pray take paciencethe cardinal arreste arrest arrest sayd ye cardinal yea sayd erle haue commaundement haue suche power sayd cardinal cardinal legate de latere pere college rome oughtnot arrested temporal power subiect power wherfore arrest withstand well sayd erle kynges commission whiche shewed therfore charge obey cardianl somewhat remembred himselfe sayd well lorde content obey although negligence fell punishement premunire lost lawe landes goodes yet person kynges proteccion pardoned offence wherfore meruail nowe arrested specially consideryng mamber sea apostolike temporal man ought lay violent handes wel see kyng lacketh good counsail well sayd erle sworne warden march self tolde might staffe arrest men vnder degree kyng nowe stronger haue comission whiche haue seen cardinal length obeyed kept priuie chamber goodes seazed officer discharged phisician called doctor augustyne lykewise arrested brought tower sir walter welshe one kynges chamber vi day nouember coueyed cawod sheffelde castle deliuered therle shrewsburies kepyng till kynges pleasure knowen attachement muche commonyng amongest common people wherfore many glad surely fauor cominaltie cardinall thus arrested kyng sent sir wyllyam kyngston knight capitaine garde constable tower london certain yomen gard sheffeld fetche cardinal tower cardinal sawe capitaini garde sore astonnyed shortly became sicke perceiued great trouble towarde cause men sayd willyngly toke muche quatitie strong purgacion nature able beare sir wylliam kyngston comforted easy iornayes brought abbay lecester xxvii day nouemberthe cardinal dead buried leycester feblenes nature caused purgacions vomites dyed second night folowyng abbay lyeth buryed cardinal may perceiue story great stomacke compted himselfe egall prince craftie suggestion gatte handes innumerable treasurethe discrip ion cardinal forced litle symony pityful stode affeccionate owne opinion open presence would lye say vntruth double speche meanyng would promise muche performe lytle vicious body gaue clergie euil example hated sore citie london feared told dye way toward london wherfore feared lest comons citie would arise riotous maner sley yet dyed waye towarde london authoritie cardinal set clergie suche pryde thei disdained men wherfore fallen folowed shall heare write life doynges cardinal great worke whatsoeuer god forgeue soule bodyes misdedes cardinal dead kyng remoued fro hampton court grenewiche quene katherine kept solempne christmas twelfe night satte halle estate diuers enterludes riche maskes disportes great banket christmas came manor westminster whiche called yorke place cardinal attainted premunire gone northward made feoffement thesame place kyng chapiter cathedral churche yorke writyng cofirmed thesame feoffement kyng chauged name called kynges manor westminster nomore yorke place whole clergie england euer supported maintayned power legantyne cardinal wherfore kynges counsail learned sayed plainly premunire spiritual lordes called proces kynges benche answere day apperaunce conuocacion concluded humble submission writyng offered kyng c pound good lorde also geue pardon offence touchyng premunire act parliament ye whiche offer muche labor accepted pardon promised submission clergie called kyng supreme head ye churche englandthe kyng first named supreme head whiche thyng neuer confessed wherevpon many thinges folowed shall heare parliament begone vi day ianuary pardon spiritual persones signed kynges hande sent lordes whiche tyme conuenient assented tot bill sent comons lower house red diuers froward persones would wyse assent except menne pardoned saiyng men whiche thyng cardinal wer case wyser sort answered would compell kyng geue pardon beside vncharitably done hurt clergie themselfes good wherfore aduised consent bill sue kyng pardon whiche counsail folowed determined first sende speaker kyng would assent bill whervpon thomas audely spekar common couenient nomber common house came kynges presece eloquently declared kyng common sore lamented bewayled chaunce thynke imagyne selfes gracious fauor graciously geuen pardon premunire spiritual subiectes wherefore moste humbly besought grace accustomed goodnes clemency include thesame pardon kyng wisely answered prince soueraigne lorde ought restraine libertie copel shewe mercy pleasure vse extremitie lawes mitigate pardon thesame wherfore sith thei denied assent pardon spiritual persones whiche pardon sayd might geue without assent great seale would well aduised pardoned would noted compelled answere speaker common departed sorowful pensiue light persones sayd thomas crumwell whiche newly come fauor kyng disclosed secretes common whiche thing caused kyng extreme kyng like good prince considered sorowfull comons answere made thought quiet wherfore owne mocion caused pardon premunire drawen signed hand sent comon house christopher hale atturnay whiche bill sone assented common louyngly thaked kyng muche praised witte denyed vnworthely demaunded bountyfully graunted perceiued sorowed lamented parliamene sat xxx day marche noone came common house lorde chauncelor diuers lordes spiritualtie temporaltie nomber xii lorde chauncelor sayd worshipfull house sure ignorant know well kyng soueraigne lorde hath maried brother wife wedded bedded brother prince arthur therfore may surely say hath maried brother wyfe mariage good many clerkes doubt wherfore kyng like vertuous prince willyng satisfied conscience also suretie realme hath great deliberacion consulted great clerkes hath sent lord london present chiefe vniuersities chirstendome knowe opinion iudgement behalfe although vniuersities cambryge oxforde sufficient discusse cause yet realme auoyde suspicion parcialitie hath sent realme fraunce italy pope dominion uenicians knowe iudgement bahalfe whiche haue cocluded written sealed determinacions accordyng shall heare red sir bryan tuke toke boxe xii writynges sealed red worde worde ensueth translated latin englishe tongue determinacion vniuersitie orliaunce long syns put forth v college doctor regentes vniuersitie orliaunceorleaunce two question folow fyrst whether lawfull lawe god brother take wyfe woman brother hath left second forbidden lawe god whether prohibicion lawe god may remitted pope dispensacion foresayd college doctor regentes accordyng custome vsage came many tymes together sit diuers tymes vpon discussyng foresayd doubtes question examyne way muche might diuers many place old testament newe also interpreter declarer law god canon lawe wayed considered thynges exactly good leysure deliberacio haue determined cocluded foresayd mariages cannot attempted enterprised except man wrong plaine contrary lawe god yea although done pardon sufferaunce pope witnes coclusion determinacion haue caused present publike writyng signed scribe sayd vniuersitie strengthed fortified seale ame enacted chapel lady annunciacion good idynges christes commyng orleaunce yere lorde mdxxix v day april determinacion facultie decree vniuersitie parys name lord itlawers parys put forth v deane college right counsailful facultie decree vniuersitie parys question whither pope might dispence brother might mary wyfe brother hath left mariage betwene brother dead wyfe consummate deane college sayd facultie many disputacions reason made bothe sydes vpon matter great long turnyng serchyug bokes bothe lawe god pope lawe lawe ciuil counsail say pope hath power dispence foresayd case witnes wherof haue caused present writyng strengthed seale facultie signe scribe chiefe bedle yeuen congregacion assemble saint ihon laterenense parys second day may mdxxx determinacion ciuilians canonistes vniuersitie angevv long tyme syns wer purposed vnto v rector doctor regentes lawe canon ciuile vniuersitie angewangew ii question folowyng e whether vnlefull lawe god lawe nature man mary wyfe brother departed without child mariage consummate againe whether lawfull pope dispence suche mariage aforesayd rector doctor haue accordyng custome vsage many tymes communed together sytten dispute question fynde certaintie discussed examined many diuers place aswell lawe god law man whiche semed pertaine purpose brought bothe party examined thinges faythfully good co science considered vpon sufficient deliberacion auisement taken defyne determyne neither lawe god nature permitted christen man euen authoritie sea apostolike dispensacion graunted pope mary wyfe brother hath left although brother departed without child mariage finished consummate witnes aforesayd thynges haue comaunded scribe sayd vniuersitie signe present publike rument fortified great seale vniuersitie ena ted churche saint peter angew yere lorde mdxxx vii day may determinacion facultie diuinitie vniuersitie paris deane facultie holy diuinitie vniuersitie parysparys present writyng shal come wysheth sa etie sauior iesu christ whiche true safetie late risen great controuersie great difficultie vpon mariage betwene moste noble henry viii kyng england defendor fayth lorde ireland c noble lady katherine quene england doughter catholike kyng ferdinand whiche mariage onely contract betwene former husband also consummate finished carnall intermedelyng question also purposed v discusse examine accordyng iustice trueth say whether mary brother dead without child hath left beyng prohibited law god nature made lefull pope dispensacion christen manne mary wyfe brother hath left foresayd deane facultie callyng remembraunce vertuous holy thing agreable profession vnto dutie loue charitie v shewe waye iustice right vertue honestie whiche desire leade passe ouer life law lord sure quiet conscience could ready satisfie honest iust requestes whervpon old wont came together vpo othe churche maturyne thesame cause solepne masse deuout prayer holy ghost also toke othe euery deliuer study vpon foresayd question pleasure god accordyng coscience diuers many session sittynges whiche continued churche saint maturyn also college called sarbo e fro viii day iune second day iuly searched examined muche diligence could suche reuerence religion conscience becommeth suche matter bothe bookes holy scripture also moste approued interpreter finally generall synodal cousailes decree constitucions sacre holy churche whiche long custome hath receiued approbate foresayd deane facultie disputyng vpon foresayd question makyng answere iudgement full co sent moste part sayd facultie haue concluded determined foresayd mariage brother wife departyng without child forbidden law god nature pope hath power dispence wt suche mariages whether contract contract credence beleue witnes assercion determinacion haue caused ale facultie notary signe put vnto present writyng dated generall congregacion kepe othe saint maturynes yere lorde mdxxx second day iuly determinacion vniuersitie burges berry biturs deane facultie diuinitie uniuersitie burgesburges accordyng example paule doctor ye getiles whiche doeth likewise begyn writyng praier vnto beloued god among moste dere reader vnto write called grace peace quietnes conscience come god father lorde iesu christ gathered together one place octaues whitsontide body mynde sittyng house sayd deane question put v againe whiche purposed v often tymes beyng smal question whiche whither brother takyng wife brother dead mariage consummate perfite doeth thyng vnlawfull last sought trueth thing perceiued founde muche labor studye euery one v himselfe muche often turnyng holy bookes euery one v corrupt wherby might lesse obey trueth began holy gost put minde geue euery man one arbitrement sentence haue well perceiued truth wtout regard respect person persones whiche rehersed xviiicha ye leuiti al law forbidden ye law nature co matrimony together lawe wyse released authoritie manne whiche made abhominable discouering brother foulnes signe commen bedyll notarie seale foresayd facultie put vnto present writyng x day iune yere lorde mdxxx foote writyng shall one forme fashion wt head began praier let v ende example paule spake say grace fauor lorde iesu christ charitie loue god communicacion holy ghost amen determinacion diuines pope vniuersitie bonony god best mightiest taught fyrst olde lawe testament owne mouthbonony forme fashion accordyng loue charitie maners life men secondarely god take afterwardes manhod vpon redemer man made new lawe newe testament onely forme fashion accordyng loue charitie life maners men also take away declare doubtes whiche arise many case clerely determined shall helpe greatly perfite vertue goodnes say perfite loue charitie wherfore thought euermore part folowe moste holy doctrine lawes father heauen lightned light god aboue holy ghost geue sentence iudgement high doubtfull matter haue leyserly sufficiently taken aduisement vpon cause haue clerely serched opened thing many reason writynges holy father aswell one part doyng nothyng nere rashly without deliberacion therfore certaine great noble men instantly desire v would al diligence possible loke case ensueth afterwardes geue iudgement vpon thesame accordyng moste equitie right conscience stickyng ouely trueth doctor diuinitie uniuersitie euery one himselfe examined matter home house came together one place treated vpon many dayes asmuche connyng learnyng could anon loked case together examined together compared thyng together handelyng euery thing selfe trye euen would say lyne rule brought forth maner reason whiche thought could brought contrary part afterward solued yea euen reason moste reuerend father cardinall cai taine yea moreouer deu eronomi dispensacion stirryng vp brother sede shortly maner reason opinion ye cotrary part many semed belong purpose question asked v whether forbydden onely ordinaunce churche el law god manne might mary wyfe left brother departed without child commaunded lawes done whether pope may dispence man make suche mariage whiche question nowe haue examined bothe selfe secretely also openly diligently exactly could possible discussed ye best maner wittes would serue determyne geue iudgement say stifly witnes without doubt stedfastly hold mariage horrible accursed cryed vpon vtterly abhominable onely christen infidele vnfaythfull heathen prohibite vnder greuous paynes punishementes lawe god nature man pope though almoste may thinges vnto christ geue keyes kyngdome heauen hath power geue dispensacion man contract suche mariage maner cause consideracion suggestion eady tymes place defende maintaine truth conclusion witnes wherof haue made present writyng haue fortefied thesame bothe seale vniuers tie also seale college doctor diuinitie haue subscribed signed general accustomed subscripcion cathedral churche bonony x day iune yere lord mdxxx determinacion facultie diuinitie vniuersitie padua italy haue written maintenaunce catholike fayth affirme god best mightiest geue preceptes comaundementes olde lawe owne mouthe exampler v wherein might see order life maners god done became manne put vpon manhod become redemer byer mankynde made newe lawe testament mere liberalitie geue v onely cause aforesayd also take away declare maner doubtes question might arise whiche opened declared true meanyng thentent therby might made perfitely good greatly fruitful v holesome seyng mind god making lawes hath entent euermore shalbe becometh christen men folow moste solepne ordinauces ye high workemaster god help light aboue capacitie nature vtter iudgement maner doubtes harde question considered thing best maner sufficient leysure made clere many euident reason party many aucthorities father churche determinyng nothyng nere wer rashely without conuenient deliberacion seyng therfore certain great orator ambassador humbly require pray v would vouchesafe serche al diligence could case folowyng afterwardes geue sentence vpon plainly simply lokyng onely trueth doctor diuinitie uniuersitie came together euery man examined thing particulerly owne house haue beaten learnyng connyng able anon wer together considered examined wayed thinges selfes brought al maner reason whiche thought might meanes made co trary without colour cloke wholy clerely dissolue take away amongest al dispensacion lawe deut ronomi styrryng vp brother sede al maner reason determinacions contrarye semed v pertaine thyng purpose vtterly confuted dispatched question put v whether mary wife brother departed without child forbidden onely lawe churche ye lawe god also forbidden lawes whither pope may dispence wt suche matrimony whiche question haue discussed farre could haue made clere priuately euery man selfe al togethers opely say iudge decree witnes trueth affirme suche mariage mariage yea abhorred cursed euery christen man abhominate greuous sinne clearely forbidden vnder moste cruel penalty lawes nature god man pope vnto keyes kyngdome heauen committed christ sonne god hath power dispence right law cause suggestion excuse suche matrimonye contract thinges whiche forbidden law god vnderneth power aboue uicar god concernyng thinges onely suche thynges god hath determined himselfe lawe hath lefte determinacion ordinaunce man mayntaine trueth sentence conclusion moste certaine vndoubted defence thesame al one mynde accorde shal tall tymes euery place redy witnes wherof haue made writyng haue authorised accustomed seale uniuersitie also college diuines dated padway churche hermites saint austen fyrst day iuly yere lord mdxxx determinacion vniuersitie tholose treated vniuersitie tholose harde question whether lefull brother marye ben wyfe brother departed without chyldren besyde another thyng troubled v sore whether pope hath cure christes flocke would dispensacion men call suffre least wyse might lawfull rector uniuersitie called counsell doctor regetes tyme tholose shew myndes question twyse iudged counsell geuyng ought hasted doone vpon head neede tyme space doo anye thynge conueniently ought bee last came togither one place best learned connyngest doctor holye diuinitie also doctor best learned bothe lawes yea finally many experiece matter able thing either iudgemet discresion eloquence excellent wyttes dyd swere woulde obey sacre holy counsel woulde follow decree father man hath good conscience wyll violate breake euery man sayde mynde matter debated reasoned diffusely large bothe partes conclusion fel fast poynte sentence determinacion oure uniuersitie one voyce dyd determine conclude pure cleare conscience defiled maner leuen corrupcion lawful man neither law god law nature take wyfe brother hath lefte seeyng may doone law god nature answered pope lose man fro lawe dispence thing contrary sentence verdyct brother olde tyme compelled law deuteronomy mary brothes wyfe departed without issue law shadow fygure thinges come vanyshed away assone euer lyght trueth gospell appeared bicause thynges thus haue geuen sentence forme aboue haue comaunded sygned notary secretory fortified aucthorised puttyng autenticall seale uniuersitie aforesayde tholose calendes fyrst day octobre yere lorde thousande vcxxx determinacions read shewed aboue hundreth bookes drawen doctor straunge region agreed kynges mariage vnlefull whiche read day spent chauncellor sayd commen house may reporte countreys haue seene heard al men shall openly perceyue kyng hath attempted matter wyll pleasure straugers reporte discharge coscience suretie successio realme cause repayre hyther wyl departe determinacions publysshed wyse men realme moche abhorred mariage woman wer wylfull wyse learned spake agaynst determinacion sayd uniuersities corrupte entysed doo thought kyng selfe sore lamented chaunce made maner myrth pastyme wont dyned resorted quene accustomed minished nothyng estate moch loued cheryshed doughter lady mary wyse woulde come bed ester began draw nere parliament tyme ended proroged till last day marche nexte yere parliament aforesayde acte madethe acte po onyng whosoeuer dyd poyson persone shoulde boyled hote water death whiche acte made bicause one richard roose parliament tyme poysoned dyuers person bisshop rochester place whiche richard according acte boyled smythfelde teneber wednis ay followyng terrible example wynter season xxvi day ianyuer citie luxborne portingale wonderous earthquake erthquake destroied many house tower slew many people fallynge downe kynges palace shoke quene ladyes fled palace without seruauntes sought succour myght get sodeinly quakyng seassed rockes opened sprange water shippes hauen lyke haue peryshed earth quaked agayne dyd harme nyght ceassed whiche earthquake many men murthered distroyed vniuersitie aforesayd great nombre clerkes well learned men determined kynges mariage vnlawfull detestable agaynst god lawe haue heard kyng willyng quene haue knowledge sent dyuers lordes coucel last dai maie beyng wednisday whitson weke whiche lordes chaumbre grenewyche declared determinacion haue hearde asked whether would quyetnesse kynges conscience put matter iiii prelate iiii temporall lordes realme abyde appele quene answered kyng father concluded mariage sure ignoraunt asked conncell clerkes well learned men maryed second tyme doubte maryage woulde haue disbursed great treasure dyd doctor maner agreed maryage good insomoche pope hym selfe knew best dooen dyd dispence ratified seconde mariage agaynst whose doynge meruayle persone wyll speake wryte determinacion vniuersitie woma lacke wytte learnyng aunswere god commit iudgemet whether thei haue done iustly percially sure neither kynges father father woulde haue condiscended mariage ben declared vnlawfull say shoulde put cause viii persones realme quyetnes kynges conscience praye god sende grace quyet conscience shalbe answere say lawfull wyfe hym lawfully maryed ordre holye churche hym espowsed trew wyfe although worthy poynte wyll abyde tyll cowrte rome preuy begynnyng haue made therof determinacion finall endyng answere lordes departed kyng whiche sorye heare wylfull opinion especiall trusted pope law keping preceptes god kyng lyke politicke prince perceyued merchaunt straungers especiall italian spanyardes portyngales daily brought oade oyle sylke clothes golde ueluet merchaudyse realme therfore receyued ready money money euer deliuered merchauntes exchaunge neuer employed money comodities realme therby kyng hyndered custome outwarde also commodity realme vttered greate hynderaunce subiectes wherefore caused proclamacion bee made mydsomer tearmea proclamacion exchaunge accordynge olde estatute made tyme kyng rycharde seconde persone make exchaunge contrary trew meanyng acte estatute vpon payne taken kynges mortall enemy forfayte myght forfayte proclamacion many clothes commodity realme well solde shortly merchauntes fell exchaunge agayne proclamacion shortly forgotten kyng whytsontyde quene remoued wyndsore continued tyll xiiii daye iulye whiche daye kyng remoued woodstocke lefte wyndsore laye whyle remoued moore afterwarde estamstede day kyng neuer saw together wherfore commen people dailye murmured spake folysh fantasy affayres prince ordered commen people conuenient thynges opened theim kyng sent certayne lordes queene estamstede aduyse confirmable lawe god shewe vnto uniuersities clearely determined pope coulde wyse dispence mariage therefore dispensacion trusted clearely voyde none effecte manye mo cause aduysementes declared whiche nothynge moued styll sayde truly kynges trew wyfe hym maryed doctor dead law learnyng farre mannes mynde tyme maryage yet thinke courte rome whole churche englande woulde consent thing vnlawfull detestable call styll say wyfe wyl pray answer lordes departed came kyng made reporte haue hearde mariage alonly talked england fraunce spayne italy yea thorough christendome maner especially themperourrs courte insomoche great marque spayne sayde syr nicholas heruy knyght beyng kynges ambassader themperours cowrte gaunte lorde ambassador englande meruayle lytell kyng master dalyeth themperours aunte dissended assure noble bloode hye parentage themperours maiestie may wyl suffre iniurye doone bloode lynage shoulde whole xxii yeres serue wyfe bedfelow reiecte princely maner therein neither loue loyaltie poore verlet long serued prince herte coulde haue reiected hym put hym hym sayd kyng well councelled matter moch meruayled amongest christen prince thynke honestly handeled honorably hys wyfe bicause brother wyfe doctor say affirme man excuse kyng saye bnt hath ben euyll handeled kepte lyke concubine paramour bodely appetite great spotte shame rebuke whole lynage spot wayes sponged recompenced shame kynred treasure redemed kyng maister remembre well matter shall fynde transcendeth farre aboue losse erthly possessyons woulde woulde better aduysed englysh ambassador answeredan answere lorde comission extedeth answer matter enforme truth wyl somewhat say besyde commission fyrst say kyng maister neuer ment matter honorably truly vertuously bothe pleasure god profyte surety realme neuer shall anye prince euer better contented pleased woman hath ben neuer prince loued cherished honoured woman king maister hath dooen woulde herte mynde wyll styll keepe wyfe goddes lawe woulde suffre lorde remembre well thyng shall fynde doubt fyrst moued councell spayne emperour kyng englande agreed themperoure shoulde marye ladye marye kynges doughter upon communicacion doubte put themperours councell whether kynges lawfull doughter well knowen maryed brother wyfe matter secrete spred councell bothe fraunce flaunders great defamacion kyng englande great vncertaintye successyon realme whereof aduertysed thynke neuer prince tooke sorrowfully dolently satisfiynge conscience called cleargye felte opinion trustyng owne subiectes onely ensure excellently lerned sent uniuersities fraunce italye
